XML.Hansard-Body: Mr Speaker (Hon. John Mickel, Logan) read prayers and took the chair.

Mr SPEAKER: Honourable members, I have to report that I have received from Her Excellency the Governor a letter in respect of assent to certain bills, the contents of which will be incorporated in the Record of Proceedings . I table the letter for the information of honourable members.

“A Bill for An Act to amend the Alcan Queensland Pty. Limited Agreement Act 1965, the Commonwealth Aluminium Corporation Pty. Limited Agreement Act 1957, the Environmental Protection Act 1994, the Geothermal Energy Act 2010, the Holidays Act 1983, the Mineral Resources Act 1989, the Nature Conservation Act 1992, the Petroleum Act 1923, the Petroleum and Gas (Production and Safety) Act 2004, the South Bank Corporation Act 1989, the Vegetation Management Act 1999 and the Water Act 2000, for particular purposes”

“A Bill for An Act to amend the Energy Ombudsman Act 2006, the Environmental Protection Act 1994, the Fisheries Act 1994, the Land Valuation Act 2010, the Mineral Resources Act 1989, the Petroleum Act 1923, the Petroleum and Gas (Production and Safety) Act 2004, the Queensland Competition Authority Act 1997, the Queensland Institute of Medical Research Act 1945, the South-East Queensland Water (Distribution and Retail Restructuring) Act 2009, the Sustainable Planning Act 2009, the Vegetation Management Act 1999, the Water Act 2000, the Water Supply (Safety and Reliability) Act 2008 and the Wild Rivers Act 2005 for particular purposes, and to make consequential or minor amendments of other Acts as stated in schedule 2 for purposes related to those particular purposes”

XML.Hansard-Body: Mr SPEAKER: Honourable members, I wish to acknowledge the numerous messages of condolence and support from our colleagues and friends from the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association and individual parliaments across Australia and the Commonwealth who contacted the Queensland parliament during our recent floods. On behalf of the parliament of Queensland, I have formally thanked them for their expressions of interest, care and concern at this difficult time for the residents of our state.

Mr SPEAKER: Honourable members, the Queensland parliament yesterday achieved a new milestone in openness and accountability with the launch of the broadcast on demand service, which will allow people to watch parliament on replay online. Broadcast on demand is an archive of the parliament’s live video broadcast that will allow anyone with internet access to watch parliamentary proceedings at a later point in time--at a time of their choosing. From yesterday, the broadcast of the proceedings will be stored and available to view on replay on the parliament’s website.

The online record of proceedings will feature a camera icon at various points throughout the document--for example, in the left margin alongside the start of each member’s speech or statement and at the commencement of question time. By clicking on this icon people will be able to watch online a video replay of the proceedings of the parliament from that point onwards. The on-demand broadcast footage will become available at the time the Record of Proceedings is published throughout a sitting day, which is at 2 pm, 4 pm and within two hours of the House rising.

Broadcast on demand is the third and final stage of the broadcast of parliament initiative that started with the live audio broadcast of proceedings in 2003 and which was followed by the live audiovisual broadcast in 2007. The live broadcasts over the internet will continue, with the new broadcast on demand capability to operate in addition to those. Technical aspects of the new service and user feedback will be monitored during a six-month introductory phase, so I encourage members to provide any feedback.

XML.Hansard-Body: Mr SPEAKER: Honourable members, I wish to advise all of you of the passing of a staff member and a former staff member during the recess. David Groom, who was known to many of you, was a cleaner with QBuild attached to the parliamentary precinct for many years. Regrettably, David passed away in mid-January.

Longer serving members may recall Ted Newton, who was the protocol officer in the 1990s. I regret to inform the House that sadly Ted passed away after an illness on 31 January 2011. I know the thoughts of all honourable members will be with these gentlemen’s families and their friends.

Hansard-Body.A: (South Brisbane--ALP) (Premier and Minister for the Arts) (9.34 am): I move--

XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent1: 1. That this House desires to place on record its appreciation of the services rendered to this state by the late Robert William Scott, a former member of the parliament of Queensland;

2. That Mr Speaker be requested to convey to the family of the deceased gentleman the above resolution, together with an expression of the sympathy and sorrow of the members of the parliament of Queensland, in the loss they have sustained.
XML.Hansard-Body: Robert William Scott--better known to us as Bob--was born in Gordonvale on 28 September 1931. I acknowledge today the presence of his wife, Jenny Scott, son Keith and other family members, who I think are about to join us in the gallery. I also acknowledge the presence of a long-serving colleague of Bob Scott, Manfred Cross, a former member for Brisbane Central, and his wife, Barbara, and another former member for the seat of Cook--the seat held by Bob Scott--the Hon. Steve Bredhauer, who has joined us.

Bob Scott was educated at the Gordonvale state schools to subsenior level before qualifying as an electrician in 1952 and later completing an Associate Diploma of Electrical Engineering at the Queensland Institute of Technology in 1970. Bob worked as an electrical engineer for many years for the North Queensland Electricity Board and was later the assistant district engineer for the Far North Queensland Electricity Board in Cairns.

Bob Scott was a true Labor man and a member of the Electrical Trades Union. He was also a member of the Association of Professional Engineers and the Institute of Engineers. Bob Scott joined the Australian Labor Party in 1960 and went on to hold various positions at the local executive level and was also the foundation president of the Cairns branch of the Young Labor Association.

At the state election of December 1974 Edwin Wallis-Smith retired as the member for Cook and Bob Scott was selected to contest the seat as the ALP candidate. However, Mr Scott was narrowly defeated at the poll by the National Party candidate, Eric Deeral. Not to be deterred, Mr Scott again contested the seat of Cook at the state election of November 1977, this time turning the tables on Mr Deeral in what was another close electoral contest. From that point Bob was to ably represent the vast electorate of Cook until his retirement from this place at the state election of December 1989.

Bob’s highest priority while representing the people of Cook was to advocate and act for the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people of not only his own electorate but for all Indigenous Queenslanders. Bob served as opposition spokesperson on Aboriginal and Islander affairs from January to November 1983 and opposition spokesperson on northern development and Aboriginal and Islander affairs from November 1983 to November 1986. Serving in these positions maximised his opportunity to pursue this heartfelt policy area. Bob was very highly regarded by his Indigenous constituents and this respect was born out of his hard work and strong desire to understand their aspirations, to advocate on their behalf and to improve their lot in life.

Bob Scott was also a very passionate North Queenslander--someone who lived all of his life in that area and who understood many of the issues facing people who lived so far away from the capital city and the issues facing people in the north and the far north of our state and he passionately advocated for them in this chamber. I acknowledged Jenny Scott’s imminent arrival and I am pleased to acknowledge that Jenny Scott has now joined us.

In 1984 Bob was a member of a parliamentary delegation to Japan and Korea. Lawn bowls was among one of his great loves. He was a member of the Queensland Parliamentary Bowls Club and represented Queensland at a number of the annual interstate parliamentary bowling carnivals during the 1980s.

It is perhaps poignant that we are marking the passing of Bob Scott today at the same time that our thoughts are with the people of his beloved Far North Queensland who have suffered so greatly at the hands of Cyclone Yasi. Bob, of course, saw many cyclones in his representative years and he worked tirelessly to assist his communities to recover from their impact. Among Bob’s many qualities he was most of all a caring and compassionate man with a huge amount of energy and a determination to represent his sprawling diverse electorate to the very best of his ability. He was well known as a workaholic with enormous energy. He was also well known to many in this chamber and respected across the political divide as a very decent man with strong values who worked hard for the people he represented.

Since his retirement from this chamber I had the opportunity to run into and meet up with Bob and Jenny on many occasions, and that is because they continued to be so active in their community. I have run into them at community events, at local festivals and at ALP functions. They were people who continued to work and be connected with their community. Whenever I would meet up with Bob he was always cheerful, always enthusiastic about whatever he was doing, always generous with his political advice about what he thought I should be doing, but always delivered with a great deal of care and compassion for the people that he cared so much about.

I know that the people of the electorate of Cook and members of this House will mourn his passing. I know that his passing brings a great loss to his family. He was dearly loved and a great family man. On behalf of the government I take this opportunity to extend my sympathy and that of this House to Mr Scott’s family and to his many friends.

Mr LANGBROEK (Surfers Paradise--LNP) (Leader of the Opposition)
(9.40 am): I rise to speak to the condolence motion on the passing of Robert William Scott, a long serving member of this House, who died on 19 January aged 80. I think it is fair to say that Bob Scott was an old style Labor man. By that I mean he was not a political careerist who knew all of politics but little of life. He had worked, he had got his hands dirty, he had raised a family and he had bettered himself before entering politics. Through ongoing education he rose to the rank of electrical engineer with the North Queensland Electricity Board and at age 46 he won the seat of Cook and represented the electorate for 12 years between November 1977 and December 1989, when he retired.

Bob Scott was born in Gordonvale in 1931. Like Ben Chifley his father was an engine driver. Educated at Gordonvale State School, after subsenior he took up an electrical apprenticeship and qualified as an electrician in 1952. But he did not stop there. He took on further study and qualified as an electrical engineer by first completing an associate diploma in electrical engineering in 1970 aged 39 and then an MIE Australia to become a member of the Association of Professional Engineers and the Institute of Engineers.

Bob Scott was a staunch member of the Electoral Trades Union, the ETU, and it was through this involvement that he joined the Australian Labor Party in 1960. I know that he was a staunch supporter of the ETU. Bob Scott was active in the Labor Party and was nominated to run for the seat of Cook, which he won at the 1977 state election and held for 12 years. His parliamentary career included serving as opposition spokesman on northern development and Aboriginal and Islander affairs and he served on party committees for culture, national parks, mines, energy and police.

As mentioned, Bob Scott was certainly no political careerist. He qualified as an electrician. He married in 1954 and with wife Jenny raised four children. During those years he studied to become an electrical engineer. He knew a fair bit about life and work and raising a family before he came here. He was a member who represented his electorate faithfully for 12 years. I know that all LNP members join me in noting the passing of Bob Scott and in offering our condolences to Mr Scott’s family, his wife Jenny and their friends.

Mr O’BRIEN (Cook--ALP)
(9.43 am): For me, Bob Scott was everything a man should be: hardworking, intellectual, caring and kind. He epitomised not just the way a member of parliament should conduct themselves but all men who wish to gain the respect and acceptance of the communities in which they live. Bob was a passionate advocate for change. He represented the most undeveloped electorate in this parliament for what were amongst the darkest days for the Labor Party and, many would argue--especially Bob--the darkest days for this great state.

When Bob first contested Cook in 1974 Gough Whitlam was PM and Perc Tucker was the leader of the Queensland ALP. In the electoral annihilation of the state ALP that year Bob narrowly lost the seat to Eric Deeral when the National Party ran two candidates only to see their least preferred candidate succeed. I will talk about that on another day. It was ironic that Bob was beaten by Queensland’s only and first Indigenous MP, as few people in the history of this parliament, even to this day, would have done more at a grassroots level to support Indigenous people. He campaigned continuously for a further three years and was elected the member for Cook at his second attempt in 1977.

Bob by his nature was a non-judgmental man. He was inclined to take you at face value and did not mind what race, gender, colour, culture or sexuality you were as long as you were genuine. He did not mind if you were religious, although he was a dedicated and life-long atheist. He did not have a very high regard for those who professed to be devout but who did not live their lives by very Christian principles. He had firsthand experience of the terrible things some people did in the name of religion to Aboriginal people, especially on the missions. Having said this, Bob did not suffer fools. On one occasion when Steve Bredhauer was the member and minister for main roads he happened to mention to Bob that someone had suggested naming a bridge near Cooktown after a former prominent local National Party identity that neither had a very high regard for. Bob said, ‘At least if you name a bridge after him the next I drive to Cooktown I can say I ran over the bugger.’

Although he was generally tolerant of people’s choices, he did not much like tories, probably for good reason. For one, the National Party government of the day refused to spend any money on infrastructure in the vast seat making it incredibly difficult to get around. Members in those days did not have anywhere near the resources we have today, meaning that people like Bob had to use their own car and hitch plane rides with their federal counterparts just to be able to see their constituents and get a handle on the issues. It was made difficult by the then director of native affairs who, after the demise of the missions, virtually controlled every aspect of the lives of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders. Bob alluded to him in his maiden speech without naming him and I will do the same here today. He was essentially the last protector of Aborigines in Australia and with political ambitions of his own he later contested the seat for the National Party. He obstructed and denied Bob at every opportunity. But of course the people are not stupid and they kept putting their faith in Bob in greater numbers at each subsequent election that he contested.

Bob was a Labor man to his boot straps and would proudly fly the Labor flag everywhere he went and in some pretty hostile territory. Around Cook in many rural and remote parts of Queensland he was well-known for his hard work and his integrity. He was a true man of the people, be they farmers, council workers, miners or housewives and there was no doubt he was held in the highest regard by thousands of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders who knew him as a friend and a champion.

He once famously kept this parliament going through an all-night sitting as he railed against the injustices and inadequacies of the then Community Services Act. He did not have much time for factional politics or the machinery of the Labor Party, preferring to work his electorate to working the numbers here in Brisbane, and was perceived as a bit of an oddity by his peers; perhaps a bit of a loner. He was an avid reader and knowledgeable on just about any topic and always wanted to test his knowledge and expand it by discussing just about anything with anybody any time. He read almost constantly, even in the car on long drives across his electorate, if Jenny was driving, or on a charter flight by the dim cabin lights or a special book light he always carried. He taught himself to speak and read Italian at quite a competent level. Dimbulah was part of the Cook electorate in those days. There was a lot of Italian migrants there and Bob used to interpret letters and things like that for people. He did that well into his later years as well. Even in the old Joh days, if the Labor Party wanted to filibuster they would just wind Bob up and he could talk for hours about anything, or pretty much nothing.

Family was everything to Bob. He loved Jenny more than anything in the world even though at times they seemed to have their differences. Bob loved his family: his daughters, Janice, Shirley and Desley, and his son Keith and, in spite of a very strict upbringing, they all loved him. Bob also loved his grandkids and would do anything for them. Many of us here in this chamber have spouses or partners and families to support us in our political lives. Some of our families tolerate it and, frankly, some of our families do not much care for the sacrifices we ask of them. In Jenny, Bob had his political soul mate as well as his life partner. They did just about everything together and spent countless hours driving or flying hundreds or thousands of kilometres across the length and breadth of the Cook electorate. They were at every school sports day, country race meeting, rodeo, fete, ball, camp draft or horse sports, wedding or funeral, and mostly they went together. If Bob had a commitment in parliament or elsewhere, Jenny would go ahead into the electorate and meet Bob there or stand in his place. They were a team and a partnership unlike anything else seen in this parliament by members present or past.

As the member for Cook, Bob increased his margin at successive elections until his retirement in 1989, but sometimes we felt if we could have had both names on the ballot paper we would have scored a few more votes. Bob never surrendered his passion for politics. I remember the day I was sworn into this place, 15 years after Bob retired. He had managed to corner the then Premier, Peter Beattie, on the Speaker’s Green and was giving him the full benefit of his opinion on whatever the issue of the day may have been. Plenty of people were queuing up to see the Premier, but they had to wait until Bob had had his say. Even today, over 20 years since Bob retired, not a week goes by without someone in the electorate asking me how he is going, such was the impact he had on people’s lives.

There are many people who would like to be standing in my place here today, paying their respects to Bob. His successor and my predecessor, Steve Bredhauer, and I both owe much of our political careers to the work put in by Bob. If we were to look around the room and count the number of seats Labor has held continuously since 1977, I doubt we would reach double figures. John Philips is another who would like to pay his respects, as is Senator Jan McLucas, Bob’s longstanding electorate officer Catherine Dunne, John Adams, the Benke family of Cooktown and Daniel Mosby from Masig Island, to name a very few.

Bob spent his entire time in this place in opposition, but he left with a reputation for trying his best and achieving results. Most of all, though, he left with unquestioning integrity. Today we mark the passing of a member of a near extinct breed--one of nature’s true gentlemen. If only more people were like Bob. Goodbye, old friend.

Mr RYAN (Morayfield--ALP) (9.50 am): I rise to support the condolence motion before the House, which honours the service of Robert William Scott to the people of Queensland. Bob Scott was a good and devoted husband to Jenny and father to Janice, Keith, Shirley and Desley. He often spoke with me about his love for and pride in his family. Following his retirement from parliament, Bob and Jenny moved to Upper Caboolture, which is part of the Morayfield state electorate, and joined the mighty Burpengary branch of the Australian Labor Party. There is no question about Bob’s commitment to the Australian Labor Party. He was a proud member. He was a true believer. He was a supportive comrade. He was a mentor to Labor candidates and Labor members of parliament. Most importantly to me, he was my friend--he was my good friend.

Those who knew Bob would know that words were important to Bob. Bob knew words could educate, inspire and motivate. He knew that words could break down cultural barriers and bring people together. Bob made sure every word counted, that every word had meaning and that he meant every word he spoke. He knew that words were powerful. And, as we have heard from previous speakers today, we know that he had lots of words to offer anyone who would listen. Bob made that clear during his maiden speech in this place in 1978. In that speech, he said rather cheekily, but nonetheless insightfully--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: I listened with amazement to the utter and absolute piffle that the honourable member for Caboolture went on with in his speech in the Address-in-Reply motion. These speeches are read by the electors and I cannot imagine what they would think of a person who would waste the time of this House by speaking on such trivial matters.
XML.Hansard-Body: As we have heard, Bob taught himself the Italian language because many of the Italian migrants in his electorate of Cook had very limited English. Interestingly, when Ken Hayward, the former member for Kallangur, joined this parliament in 1986, he sat next to Bob in this chamber. One day, Ken noticed that Bob was reading something that was not written in English. Ken said, ‘Bob, mate, what are you reading? Is that some foreign language or something?’ Bob responded, ‘Yes, Ken, it’s a foreign language. It’s Italian.’ By learning Italian, Bob did more than just open another channel of communication with people living in the electorate of Cook. By learning Italian, Bob showed that he was a true representative of his community and that he was committed to truly engaging his community in our democracy. Even when it came to Italian, words were important to Bob.

I understand that when Bob retired from this parliament at the 1989 election, he did not give a valedictory speech. When asked why he did not give a valedictory speech, Bob simply answered, ‘If I could not say it during my 12 years in this parliament, what good comes from saying it now?’ Words were important to Bob.

Heartbreakingly, for the last few years Bob had the burden of battling the terrible disease of dementia. I would regularly visit Bob at the hospital or at the nursing home, and I was always overwhelmed by Bob’s honesty, and his tireless and continued advocacy for the Australian Labor Party. Even on my last visits to see him at the nursing home, he introduced me to the staff and other residents of the home as their local member. When Jason visited as well, Bob was very excited that two local members were there. Words were important to Bob.

I saw Bob in the Caboolture Hospital a few days before he passed away. We spoke about his life, about his time as the member for Cook, about his love for his wife and his family, and the Australian Labor Party, and that terrible disease dementia. He wanted me to say something on his behalf in this condolence motion. He wanted me to call on this parliament to support greater research into finding a cure for dementia. It is a terrible disease, as many members would know. Bob wanted this parliament to know that more needs to be done to find a cure. Words were important to Bob.

Bob was my friend. He taught me many valuable lessons about modesty, humility, integrity, honesty and hard work. He was a great man, and a good and loyal servant of the Australian Labor Party and the people of Queensland, especially the people of the Cook electorate, the people he loved. I hope my words provide honourable members with a small insight into how important he was to the people of Queensland; how important he was to me.

Hon. RE SCHWARTEN (Rockhampton--ALP) (Minister for Public Works and Information and Communication Technology) (9.56 am): You would be battling to deliver a better speech than the two previous ones. Certainly I do not intend to try to outshine either of those contributions; they were marvellous. I simply want to say that I knew Bob Scott and I knew him to be the great Labor bloke he was. He was prepared to stand up for the battling classes in this state. He was never frightened to put an opinion forward or to have a good argument if the need arose. He devoted his life to the Labor movement and to the Labor Party. Unselfishly, he gave up his seat before we came to government in 1989. He told me once that the reason for that was that he had had his run and he thought it was time for younger blood to come in. He knew that we were going to win government. There is no doubt that he would have been a minister. He had the capacity and the intelligence to be a minister.

Throughout his long life as a scholar, Bob proved that he understood the need to continue to learn, but he also knew about the business of government. He said that after working for 12 years with Jenny--and it is great to see you up there, Jenny, and the rest of the family--he thought that he did not have another three years in him as the member for Cook, because of the tireless and energetic way he went about the business. He was man enough and unselfish enough to recognise that, and hand it on to Steve Bredhauer. I think it is a rare quality in anybody, let alone a politician, to be unselfish enough to know yourself to that extent.

I do not want to add anymore except to say that Bob Scott was one of nature’s great gentlemen. He was a true soldier of the Labor Party and the working classes of this state. He and his other half, Jenny, were inseparable, both in their efforts in the Labor Party and in their duties as family people. It must be a terrible loss to you, Jenny, as it is to the Labor Party. When he retired, one thing that Bob did was to indulge his passion for the environment. I hope that up at Kuranda those butterflies are still flying beautifully on this occasion.

Mrs SULLIVAN (Pumicestone--ALP) (9.59 am): My husband Jon and I first met Bob and Jenny Scott in Cairns in the early 1980s. Of course, Bob was the state member for Cook then and a very prominent man in the ALP. Both he and Jenny often organised fundraisers with guest speakers for the ALP and it was at these functions that Bob introduced us to John Gayler, who later became the Labor federal member for Leichhardt. He introduced us to Keith De Lacy, the then member for Cairns, and Mr Ed Casey, the former member for Mackay.

During the years--I have been a member of the Labor Party since 1980--our paths have crossed many times. I remember Bob’s selfless support for Labor candidates, especially John Gayler. He helped him to victory in the 1983 federal election. It was always good to have someone like Bob who you could rely on in your corner during an election campaign, and Bob was very reliable.

Not only were Jon and I fortunate to know Bob through the ALP but we were also fortunate to live next door to his niece in Edmonton just south of Cairns. Trish always spoke highly of Bob and Jenny and she visited her uncle and aunty twice while he lived in Morayfield. Trish recalls Bob sending her books from his extensive library on topics she was interested in. As we have already heard from other speakers today, he was an avid reader.

Imagine our delight when Bob and Jenny Scott turned up in my electorate of Pumicestone in their retirement and those old acquaintances were renewed and strengthened. Of course, Bob was genuinely interested in helping me in my role as the local state member and he always made himself available to hand out how-to-vote cards on election day. His advice was often sought and it was always practical advice. The only election Bob missed was the federal election last year when he was far too ill to assist.

Bob was an avid birdwatcher. When he and Jenny would feel the need for relief from the pressures of parliamentary life they would hook up their camper trailer and follow their long-term love of birdwatching. With their close friends Barbara and Manfred Cross, they covered most of the well-known bird sites in Queensland. With his other good mate Pat Comben by his side, he would go to great lengths looking for a bird that Pat had heard about in a particular location. He would study birds for hours but rarely photographed them. Bob was the first of his birdwatching group to purchase from Germany a Leica spotting scope so he could study at close quarters the wader birds that visited Australia annually from Alaska and Siberia. He would graciously loan his scope to his friends to try who would, in turn, purchase one for themselves.

Despite the fact that Bob had not been in great health for some time, it was distressing to watch his deterioration over the past couple of years. The last time I visited Bob in the nursing home he said to me, ‘You’re too tall to be Carryn.’ With his passing we have lost a great servant for Queensland, in particular Far North Queensland, and a great servant of the ALP; a thorough gentleman. I offer my sincere condolences to Bob’s wife, Jenny, his children, Janice, Keith, Shirley and Desley, their grandchildren and his friends. My thoughts and prayers are with you all.

Hansard-Body.A: (Murrumba--ALP) (10.02 am): It was an honour and a privilege to serve for a term with Bob Scott in this parliament. As the member for Pumicestone has just said, he was a true gentleman.

XML.Hansard-Body: The period between 1986 and 1989 was a robust time in this House. Bob was more than at home in those robust circumstances. He brought to that robust time and to the robust style of debate that occurred at that time a certain finesse, the mark of a gentleman. In those days, we used to keep the conversation going until the quite early hours of the morning--and sometimes the quite late hours of the morning. I remember on one occasion that it was sometime after one o’clock and Bob was addressing the House on the question of northern development. At that time there was a little bit of heckling, a little bit of interjection and a little bit of a murmur in the House. The Speaker said--and we have all heard Speakers say this often since then--‘There is too much audible conversation in the House.’ I have always wondered what would be exactly the right amount. But at that time Bob had a response. He said, ‘Thank you, Mr Speaker. I do understand, though, that they’re all very interested in the Cook electorate. I just wish that they could express their interest silently.’

Bob was always a gentleman. As the honourable member for Morayfield said, Bob liked words and he used them with delicacy and with panache. Bob had extraordinary energy. I remember those late-night sittings and on one occasion I said to Bob, ‘You’ve got a really big electorate. What are you doing?’ He said, ‘Tomorrow I’m going to be in the Torres Strait islands.’ I think it was three o’clock in the morning or something like that. There were no limits to the extent of Bob’s willingness to represent his constituents. I said, ‘This must really take it out of you.’ He said, ‘No, not at all. It’s just that I have this problem. Sometimes I can’t be in two places at the one time. For example, on Labor Day I cannot be in Weipa and I think it is your destiny to go to Weipa and represent me.’ He was meticulous; he never left a stone unturned. Yes, I went to represent Bob at Weipa. It was a great honour to do so and I discovered that he was as much loved there as he was in other parts of his electorate.

Bob was a gentleman, a great man and a true servant of the people. To Jenny and to his friends and family in the gallery and elsewhere, I wish them strength. I say to them: We are all honoured by the fact that Bob in his life did so much and we have lost in Bob a life that was well lived.
Question put--That the motion be agreed to.
Motion agreed to.

Hansard-Body.A: (South Brisbane--ALP) (Premier and Minister for the Arts) (10.12 am): When severe Tropical Cyclone Yasi ploughed into the Queensland coast, it brought fear, devastation and misery. This destructive cyclone, as we all know, left homes and schools and roads and community halls in ruins, but we will rebuild and emerge from this tragedy stronger.

XML.Hansard-Body: But what we cannot rebuild are those crops--those crucial fields of bananas and sugar cane--that now lie flat and ruined, crippling the livelihoods of our far northern farmers. It is estimated that Yasi has left our northern primary producers with a damage bill in excess of $1 billion, affecting up to 75 per cent of the nation’s banana crop and devastating many sugarcane farmers. And the circumstances of these primary producers, along with other businesses in the north, are unique. This region will face significant economic challenges because of its reliance on a few key industries, such as sugar and bananas, and because it is a long way away from other major centres in terms of competing for recruitment and employment.

That is why this morning, along with the federal Treasurer, Queensland has announced a new package of measures to help local economies rebuild and to help businesses keep their doors open. This package has been developed in consultation with some of the affected communities and some of the major stakeholders and is jointly funded by the Commonwealth and Queensland governments.

The package includes the activation of category C assistance, which entitles small businesses and primary producers to grants of up to $25,000. It also includes the activation of category D natural disaster assistance and other new measures, which will include special concessional loans of up to $650,000 for eligible businesses, primary producers and not-for-profit organisations suffering extreme damage, with a grant component of up to $50,000. It includes wage assistance for employers, including primary producers, equivalent to Newstart for up to 13 weeks to help maintain businesses. This period may be extended to 26 weeks. Finally, it includes a $20 million Rural Resilience Fund, jointly funded--$10 million each--by the federal and Queensland governments, to help fund business and community support activities, such as farm clean-ups, counselling and social support measures.

Many of these assistance measures are modelled on those that were developed for the first time after Cyclone Larry. The member for Hinchinbrook will know that in the case of Cyclone Larry these measures were not activated for some period of time because basically they had to be invented. We have learnt from Cyclone Larry. We are taking that lesson and putting these measures on the ground much, much sooner than happened in the case of Larry. I am very, very pleased that these categories of assistance will be made available to eligible small businesses and primary producers in the local government areas of Burdekin, Cairns, Cassowary Coast, Hinchinbrook, Palm Island, Tablelands, Townsville and Yarrabah.

While it is too early to estimate the cost of rebuilding infrastructure, the measures announced today, together with funds under the Australian government disaster recovery payments, are expected to deliver in the order of $400 million of assistance to cyclone affected communities in our northern areas.

This package is designed to keep business doors open and to keep farm workers in communities. Our government is determined to get all of those who have suffered through the nightmare of Yasi back on their feet and to keep them strong into the future.

Hansard-Body.A: (South Brisbane--ALP) (Premier and Minister for the Arts) (10.16 am): It is not only primary producers in the north of our state who are suffering as a result of our recent disasters. A number of Queensland’s key industries have been severely impacted over the last two months. Our government is doing everything it can to provide the necessary assistance to get Queensland back in business as soon as possible. Every industry has been affected in different ways, faces different challenges and requires different kinds of work with government.

XML.Hansard-Body: The tourism industry has faced a number of challenging years. The global financial crisis brought its own worries, as did the changes to the Australian dollar. But it faces further challenges now in overcoming the incorrect perception that we are closed due to cyclones and floods. The $9.2 billion tourism industry is essential to Queensland’s recovery, as well as the more than 200,000 Queenslanders whose livelihoods rely on it.

Under a joint state and federal government initiative, the tourism industry will receive a $10 million injection to work to overcome some of those perceptions. The tourism industry support package is a vital boost to that recovery effort. The focus of this package will be a major marketing campaign, particularly into New South Wales and Victoria, to inform potential tourists that the best thing they can do to support Queensland right now is to take a holiday where Australia shines. Last week I reinforced this message while addressing national tourism leaders and media representatives in Sydney, assuring them and their clients that Queensland tourism is very much open for business.

It is not just tourism that needs assistance. Small business, primary producers and the mining industry have all been directly impacted. In the midyear review brought down by the Treasurer shortly before Cyclone Yasi hit, the estimated impact on the coal sector from the December-January floods was $2.5 billion and a further $1 billion impact to our rural sector. My ministers have been working with all levels of industry in these areas, and I have personally spoken directly to key stakeholders, such as the Queensland Farmers Federation, AgForce, Canegrowers, banana farmers and the mining companies about the sort of assistance they need to recover.

For stakeholders in the mining sector, we need to do everything in our power to fast-track approval processes that will allow them to get their mines operating again. We have now acted fast to approve a number of temporary environmental permits that allow immediate mine dewatering where it is safe and appropriate to do so. Today, over 90 per cent of coalmines in the Bowen, Surat and Clarence-West Moreton basins are operational and producing more coal every day as they work towards a return to full production. I am advised that seven mines, or 13 per cent of the industry, are already producing coal at or near full capacity, while 44 mines, or 82 per cent, are in recovery mode, with production levels varying from 20 to 80 per cent of normal output. Only three coalmines, or five per cent of the industry, have not yet resumed any production.

Those who had the opportunity to fly over some of these mines during the recent flooding and saw those pits completely full of water would know that that is a remarkable recovery in a short period of time. Obviously, full recovery is some way away for all of them. To see so many of them now operating is important to those local regions and important to the economy of the state.

Many small businesses have seen DEEDI’s mobile small business vans travelling into disaster affected parts of the state to offer advice about the range of tools and assistance available to help small business recover. These include increases to the Jobs Assist program to help firms in trouble and advice about Centrelink’s Disaster Income Recovery Subsidy to assist employees who have had a loss of income as a direct result of the flooding or Cyclone Yasi. All industries in Queensland have been affected in some way by these natural disasters and we are committed to continuing to work with peak organisations to get every one of them back on their feet and making the great contribution that they are capable of for the Queensland and national economy.

Hon. AM BLIGH (South Brisbane--ALP) (Premier and Minister for the Arts) (10.20 am): It was not only industry that felt the impacts of some of our disasters. The arts heart of Queensland, the Cultural Centre at South Bank, has been devastated by these floods. I am very pleased to advise the House that it has reopened today after being closed for a number of weeks.

Since floodwaters inundated the lower-lying facilities of the Queensland Performing Arts Centre, the Queensland Museum South Bank, the Queensland Art Gallery, the State Library of Queensland and the Gallery of Modern Art, a team of contractors and staff have been working round-the-clock to get the centre reopened. I am pleased to advise that the collections were all kept safe. We have not seen any damage to any of the precious collections in any of those institutions.

All of the five buildings sustained damage, particularly to the crucial and complex electrical and mechanical systems. With more than 3.9 million visits recorded across the precinct annually, we wanted to make sure that these buildings and their popular exhibitions were safe and accessible as soon as possible. The centre will be open today so Queenslanders can return to cultural activities and enjoy the exhibitions, the children’s activities, the performances and the services that have made the precinct one of Queensland’s most-loved icons.

This weekend the precinct will celebrate its reopening with two days of free, fun-filled family activities and, of course, that great Queensland cultural phenomenon, the sausage sizzle. Children and their parents should look out for Jurassic Joe at the Queensland Museum South Bank and the new Megawatt exhibition at the Sciencentre. Children will also love the special story-telling and songs in The Corner at the State Library, not to mention all the amazing art activities at the Art Gallery and GoMA.

The reopening of the Cultural Centre is also an important signal to visitors from interstate and overseas that the capital city of our state is open for business. It is a great place to visit, to bring your family and to enjoy some of our world-class attractions.

I can also report to the House that while workers were busy returning Brisbane’s Gallery of Modern Art to order, GoMA’s smallest inhabitants have also been hard at work. Many who have seen the current exhibition will have seen the musical artwork by French artist Céleste Boursier-Mougenot called ‘From here to ear’. Céleste’s entrancing sound installation has been one of the most popular artworks in the major exhibition ‘21st Century: Art in the First Decade’.

Filling an entire gallery on level 3 of GoMA, the sound installation is an unconventional musical instrument made entirely of coathangers that is played by small finches, but it is also a fully functional habitat for the finches. In fact, the finches have been so comfortable that a new generation of birds has hatched. I can advise that 40 finch hatchlings were in their custom made nests while the gallery has been closed for the clean-up. It is great to see new life in these disastrous circumstances. The Australian Finch Society has been monitoring food, water and conditions in the gallery to ensure a happy and healthy environment for the birds and their babies.
I encourage Queenslanders to visit this exhibition. It celebrates the art of the first 10 years of this century. I know that the public will waste no time in visiting our landmark arts facilities.
XML.Hansard-Level-2-Heading: Hansen, Mr R, Visit to Brisbane

Hansard-Body.A: (South Brisbane--ALP) (Premier and Minister for the Arts) (10.23 am): This week Queensland has the pleasure of playing host to an inspirational Canadian visitor. Rick Hansen is a celebrated athlete, a catalyst for change in society’s attitudes and a man dedicated to making a difference. At the age of 15, Rick Hansen sustained a spinal cord injury in a car crash. He was paralysed from the waist down and was forced to slowly come to terms with how to deal with his new life.

XML.Hansard-Body: After months of rehabilitation, he returned to his first passion, sport. Fuelled by his mantra ‘anything is possible’, he went on to win 19 international wheelchair marathons, including six medals as a Paralympian. Some members will remember Rick Hansen from his legendary Man in Motion World Tour which began in 1985. This was a world tour that he undertook in his wheelchair--wheeling more than 40,000 kilometres through 34 countries to raise awareness about the plight of people with a spinal injury, to challenge prejudices and to raise money for research to find a cure. Through that Man in Motion World Tour he raised $26 million which, in the mid-1980s, was a very considerable amount of money.

This is the 25th anniversary of that Man in Motion World Tour. As I noted at the reception I held for him last night, Rick Hansen did not choose the soft options when he visited Queensland. In fact, he took his wheelchair into Birdsville as part of that journey. He has visited parts of our state that many others have yet to visit. He sought and he achieved a collective shift in consciousness in the belief of the potential of people with disabilities when barriers are removed. He is visiting Queensland, as I said, as part of the 25-year celebrations of his remarkable world tour. In the 25 years since his tour, he has established a foundation that has been instrumental in promoting spinal cord research, rehabilitation and accessibility around the world. The foundation has also raised or leveraged a further $200 million for this research.

I had the pleasure of meeting Mr Hansen during a recent trade mission to the Americas and took the opportunity then to invite him back to Queensland. At the reception I hosted in his honour last night we celebrated some local heroes who are making a difference in the field of disability. Mr Hansen announced the Rick Hansen Foundation’s Difference Maker Awards. I would like to pay tribute to the two Queensland winners of those awards: firstly, Mr Ian Chill, who will be well known to people in Cairns. He is a paraplegic and has done remarkable work in this field. The second winner is Dr Vernon Hill of the PA. He is a very long-term researcher and one of the founders of the spinal injuries unit at the PA Hospital.

I would like to take the opportunity to also congratulate the Spinal Injuries Association’s Inclusive Community Champion Award winners. For North Queensland, Decision Easy from Cairns walked away with the award. In Central Queensland the winner was the Hinkler Hall of Aviation and café in Bundaberg. It was well deserved. The south coast Queensland winner was the Mary Cairncross Scenic Reserve. The Queensland winner overall was the Portside Wharf and Cruise Terminal in Brisbane.

The Queensland government has entered into a research alliance with the Rick Hansen Foundation in Canada with a $1 million grant. That is a joint initiative of the Queensland University of Technology, the PA Hospital, the Rick Hansen Institute, the Michael Smith Foundation for Health Research in Canada, the Queensland Clinical Trial Network and Griffith University. The project includes the implementation of the Rick Hansen Spinal Cord Injury Registry in Queensland. This is a leading-edge, one-of-a-kind spinal cord injury observational database that will enable researchers to collect information on people with spinal cord injury, link clinical trials information and ultimately improve treatment. This will be the first Rick Hansen registry outside of Canada. I hope it is the beginning of many around Australia and around the world.

Queensland is lucky to have world-class researchers in this field. It was a great honour for us to have our name associated with a prestigious research institute like the Rick Hansen Foundation. It was also a great honour and a great inspiration to many people who came to the reception last night who are living with a spinal cord injury, who are caring for someone with a spinal cord injury or those who love or have a family member with a spinal cord injury. Those people need inspiration in their lives and Rick Hansen is a burning symbol of what can be achieved.
Mr SPEAKER: Before I call the Deputy Premier, I advise the House that question time will start at 11.05 am.

Hansard-Body.A: (Lytton--ALP) (Deputy Premier and Minister for Health) (10.29 am): One thing that has never ceased to amaze me over recent weeks is the resilience of Queenslanders. So many have experienced unimaginable tragedy, having been subjected to devastating weather events on a scale unlike anything ever seen before. First there were the floods, unprecedented in their spread and reach, and then almost immediately after this we saw the fury of Cyclone Yasi and the destruction it left in its path.

XML.Hansard-Body: It is true to say that in recent weeks Queenslanders have been knocked down time and time again, yet they have continued to pull together, to get up and to rebuild. They have done this with great courage, but we must also remember that, for all of the tough times had already, there are still many tough times to come. A lot of people will have the support of family and friends to help get them through, but many will also try to pick up the pieces and carry the load alone.

For all of our strength and our Queensland spirit, we must remember that no-one is immune to the impacts of the events of recent weeks. In times like this, it is important to look after our mental health and the mental health and wellbeing of our family, friends and neighbours. We must put our pride to one side and ask for help when we need it--whether it is a shoulder to lean on or someone to talk to. Stoicism is admirable but only to a point.

We want everyone to know that if you need extra support it is here for you. That is why Queensland Health has been out on the front line in those areas affected by the events of recent weeks--in neighbourhoods, in evacuation centres, in recovery centres and visiting door to door where it is needed. We have deployed mental health outreach teams to flood affected communities throughout the state--from Toowoomba and the Lockyer Valley to Theodore, Rockhampton and Emerald. This included a deployment of 104 psychological first aid trained emergency, community and mental health staff in some of the hardest hit regions of the Lockyer Valley--lending support as communities attempt to come to terms with the terrible events that have changed their lives forever. These teams have been led by mental health staff from the Ipswich and West Moreton Mental Health Service. The Lockyer Valley region has been further supported by teams of mental health professionals from New South Wales. A Victorian team has also supported communities in Theodore and Emerald. We also welcomed the assistance of world-leading experts in this field--former Australian of the Year, Professor Patrick McGorry, and Professor Beverley Raphael, both of whom I met--who helped to share their experience with our mental health teams in the field.

After Cyclone Yasi, our Queensland Health staff were again out on the front line. In Townsville, an extra eight mental health nurses were on hand to provide additional support and to relieve those staff affected by the cyclone themselves. A team of seven medical staff and mental health nurses accompanied and remained with in-patients transferred from Cairns Base Hospital during the evacuation to Brisbane. A team of six Brisbane based mental health nurses supported the Cairns team in the return of these patients to Cairns. A further team of five psychological first aid trained staff continue to support the Cairns mental health services. These staff include nurses, social workers and Indigenous health workers who are operating from Cairns to provide support to the worst affected areas of Tully and Mission Beach.

These teams, like our teams in the floods, are visiting recovery centres as well as going door to door where it is needed. People can also speak to their GP, phone 13HEALTH or speak to their local community mental health service. We have continued to work closely with organisations, including Lifeline and the Red Cross, in this recovery effort. I want to make the point personally that problems may not manifest immediately for all people, so if they do appear in a little while’s time we would ask that people seek help at that time as well. If honourable members detect this in their constituents, I would implore them to suggest this to their constituents as well.

I also want to take this opportunity to thank our Queensland Health staff who are out there every day doing this important work, and many of them have had their own families or homes directly affected. Their contribution is helping to make a difference for so many, and they will play an integral role in the recovery and rebuilding of these communities, not just in the immediate weeks of the aftermath but for a long time to come.

As Queenslanders, I know we will come through this, but it will be a long and difficult road for many and it is something we cannot do alone. However, it can be made easier when we reach out for help in the times we need it most, and we are making sure our mental health professionals and Queensland Health staff are there every step of the way. On a personal note, I also thank both the Minister for Local Government, who is a clinical psychologist herself, and the member for Gaven, who is a general practitioner. They are both good sounding boards and can be used as a source for their perspectives on these issues throughout this crisis.

Hon. AP FRASER (Mount Coot-tha--ALP) (Treasurer and Minister for Employment and Economic Development) (10.33 am): While the emotional and personal cost of the summer’s natural disasters can probably never be truly measured, the full economic and fiscal impact will emerge over time. Late last month, the government released the midyear fiscal and economic review, which took into account the devastating effects of the floods which hit almost three-quarters of the state. The review revised down economic growth from 3 per cent in last June’s budget to 1 per cent for this financial year. It also estimated a damage bill of around $5 billion--25 per cent, or $1.25 billion, of this to be borne by the state.

It is clear that the January floods took the long handle to our economy and to the Queensland budget. However, as Queensland braced itself for a second natural disaster of an almost unprecedented scale, so too did our economy. I can advise the House that Treasury has completed its preliminary estimates of the fiscal and economic damage bill from Cyclone Yasi. It is expected that the restoration and reconstruction effort following Yasi will total approximately $800 million--our share will be $200 million. This outstrips the combined Cyclones Larry and Monica bill of $480 million.

As we have previously said, the government was very aware in putting together the midyear budget update that the threat of natural disasters had not passed at that stage. Today, the Yasi cost brings our exposure to around $1.45 billion, within the expected $1.5 billion we have set aside from the expected proceeds of the Abbot Point long-term lease transaction.

As with the floods and most natural disasters, it was the road and transport infrastructure that sustained the most damage and which is the largest part of the Yasi bill. There will also be a further hit to our economic growth, with a loss of production that will cut our projected growth rate further for this year down to around one per cent. This will be realised through losses in the tourism industry and additional delays or losses to coal exports but, most significantly, Yasi has hammered the Far North rural sector. Hits to the sugar and banana industries are the most significant, with the losses in sugar likely to be recorded next financial year also. As I said when delivering the midyear review, this is by no means the final bill. These are preliminary estimates--this year’s budget will still be calculating the massive effort required this year, next year and beyond.

With regard to the costs to be borne from disasters, there has been a broader debate about the state’s insurance arrangements. It is important that this debate be conducted from a factual basis. Firstly, the Queensland government does have extensive insurance coverage. In fact, it is a matter of record that the Queensland Government Insurance Fund was instigated under this government. It holds funds of $900 million. Agencies across government pay an annual premium into the fund, determined by the State Actuary. The fund meets the costs for a range of events--damage, theft, vandalism and other incidents that can occur on government property or through government agencies. The state’s insurance fund is not reinsured. In lay terms, this means it is not doubly insured. That is, a premium is not paid to a private reinsurance company to further underwrite claims. The fund is judged to be sufficient of itself. This policy position was considered at length, through a two-year process, which concluded in 2004 to not pay a reinsurance premium for the fund. This was last re-assessed formally by the Insurance Commissioner in 2009, and the original policy decision was affirmed.

The second major aspect to this debate is the nature of natural disaster insurance maintained for the infrastructure assets of the state. I am still unaware of any government in Australia that has natural disaster insurance which would have covered the losses from the event in Queensland. Of those states which do pay a premium to a private insurance company, it is the norm that, firstly, council owned infrastructure is not insured and not included and, secondly, roads are excluded from the policy. This is an important point. The damage bill from the floods had been estimated at $5 billion, as I said. Of this, $2 billion was for local government infrastructure and $2.5 billion was for the road network. That equates to $4.5 billion worth of costs that would not be covered under the insurance coverage some other states hold. This is an important point, and most of those who have entered this debate have set aside that point for their own convenience.

Queensland is a signatory to the Natural Disaster Relief and Recovery Arrangements, as is every other state and territory. These are the same arrangements that have been in place for decades. This includes the cost split of 75-25 for major natural disasters--the same split applies in each state and territory. There is no special arrangement for Queensland. It has been this government’s policy position that the NDRRA mechanism should have the primary role in funding disaster recovery. This position has been shared by previous governments of both political persuasions. It is also the position of the Commonwealth--a policy in fact implemented by the Howard government.

I have noted with interest recent comments from unnamed industry sources that natural disaster insurance for Queensland is readily available. Previous market soundings have indicated that an insurance premium would likely be in the hundreds of millions of dollars. It would also involve a complex, lengthy and costly due diligence process. This is not just a matter of ringing different companies to get a better quote on your home and contents insurance. Acknowledging the facts in this debate makes this easier to digest. Unfortunately, as so many know only too well, Queensland is far more prone to natural disasters than other states. We have a state and local government road network in excess of 170,000 kilometres and we are decentralised, with a broad range of infrastructure assets spread across vast regions.

There are no off-the-shelf products that provide comprehensive coverage for a state like ours. I must point out that the state does maintain insurance arrangements outside the Natural Disaster Relief and Recovery Arrangements. Economic infrastructure like the Gateway and Logan motorways, Suncorp Stadium and other major sport facilities are all covered. Our port, electricity and rail corporations have their own insurance and other infrastructure not covered under the NDRRA, such as the car park at South Bank to use but one example, falls under the Queensland Government Insurance Fund. Queensland will continue to access the longstanding Natural Disaster Relief and Recovery Arrangements; so will every other state and territory, as has been done for generations. The state’s insurance and disaster relief arrangements are long standing. They are neither negligent nor unusual. Of course, the events of the last week invite these issues to be revisited. The government is open to this debate, but we are keen for it to be conducted on the basis of the facts.
XML.Hansard-Level-2-Heading: Natural Disasters, Department of Public Works
XML.Hansard-Body: Hon. RE SCHWARTEN (Rockhampton--ALP) (Minister for Public Works and Information and Communication Technology) (10.40 am): Queenslanders have done an extraordinary job looking after Queenslanders in the last two months when Mother Nature has thrown nearly everything she has got to throw at us. We are not people prepared to abandon our friends and our mates and our neighbours if they are in difficulty. Instead the mud army of volunteers, Emergency Services staff, the Army and organisations such as QBuild were all there in our darkest hours. I will speak at greater length later when I have an opportunity about QBuild, but suffice it to say that QBuild has been able to respond to 600 government buildings throughout the state with the 1,200 day labour people that we have and the army of subcontractors that are tied to them. During the flood crisis the Sales and Distribution Service of the Department of Public Works provided more than 215,000 essential items to flood affected communities. These included water, food packs, air mattresses, bed pumps, high-pressure water cleaners, insect repellent, baby bottles, baby formula, baby wipes, gum boots and disinfectant.

In response to Cyclone Yasi, QFleet made 119 vehicles available for recovery work. The current stock available in Cairns is now 18 vehicles, with this figure likely to increase as additional vehicles are trucked in from Brisbane, Rockhampton and Townsville and with some new purchases in Cairns. In Toowoomba four 4x4 vehicles were needed to get into flood affected areas. Goprint worked around the clock during the flood crisis in close collaboration with the Department of Communities to print daily newsletters providing important information to residents in flood affected areas. Project Services has carried out nearly 500 structural assessments and condition assessments on much of the state’s vital built infrastructure, including Queensland’s iconic buildings. The Shared Service Agency and CorpTech ensured pays were processed on time despite some of the significant challenges, such as the basement of the Neville Bonner Building data centre being flooded. Staff worked tirelessly to shut down the centre, which provides services to CorpTech, SSA, Department of Education and Training, JAG and DEEDI.

Finally, from Christmas eve to 10 February Smart Service Queensland responded to more than 145,000 calls through the SES community recovery and the Premier’s disaster relief lines. Further, it had almost two million hits to the flood website and 41,000 hits to the cyclone website and took more than $39 million in donations to the Premier’s disaster relief fund. The Department of Public Works has a proud history of building Queensland. It has an even prouder one now of supporting Queenslanders.

Hon. S ROBERTSON (Stretton--ALP) (Minister for Natural Resources, Mines and Energy and Minister for Trade) (10.43 am): Since Christmas eve, as we all know, three cyclones--Tasha, Anthony and supercyclone Yasi--have swept into Queensland. Adding to the misery, massive floods devastated Brisbane and central and southern Queensland. This was a disaster on an unprecedented scale, but the response from emergency services workers was outstanding. As Minister for Energy I want to take this opportunity to recognise and thank the dedicated Ergon and Energex crews responsible for restoring power to hundreds of thousands of properties impacted by these natural disasters. More than 2,000 staff have been involved in rebuilding and reconnecting the state’s power networks. It is the largest deployment of electricity field staff in Australia’s history.

Around 200,000 customers from Mackay to Cairns lost power during Tropical Cyclone Yasi as power poles were snapped and wires were whipped away by the wild winds. Despite dreadful conditions, the hard work and expertise of the Ergon crews backed up by their Energex and interstate colleagues saw all but 20,000 of the 200,000 properties blacked out restored within a week--a remarkable effort. To put this into perspective, when Cyclone Larry hit in 2006 approximately 90,000 premises lost power and 15,000 were still without electricity a week later. Unfortunately, problems in areas hardest hit by Cyclone Yasi are not over yet. Safety, however, is the prime concern. Some properties are so extensively damaged it could take weeks, if not months, before electricity can be safely restored.

Ergon is supporting essential infrastructure and facilities in these locations with large mobile generation units while the repair and restoration effort continues. To give members an idea of the scale of the destruction, two high-voltage towers at Cardwell were toppled, more than 22,000 power poles were damaged between Babinda and Cardwell and more than 2,500 kilometres of powerlines were dragged down by the storm. This was an around-the-clock repair job on a massive scale coming only weeks after record floods decimated other parts of the state. I know from meeting many Ergon and Energex staff that they have a deep commitment to restoring power as soon as possible to those impacted by natural disasters, and they perform this work often in the most challenging of circumstances. On behalf of all Queenslanders, I say thankyou to these exceptional Queenslanders. You have yet again proudly served your state.

Hon. GJ WILSON (Ferny Grove--ALP) (Minister for Education and Training) (10.45 am): The Bligh government is reaching out to students and teachers affected by the devastating floods and Cyclone Yasi. We recognise the importance of supporting Queenslanders emotionally and financially in the days, weeks and months after the disasters. For students who lost clothing, the Bligh government is providing them with two free sets of uniforms which are being supplied through school P&Cs. Counselling is available to students who have been traumatised by what they experienced.

Following our request to the federal government, 15 additional chaplains will be sent to schools across the state to provide extra support for students. Child trauma expert Associate Professor Brett McDermott has been engaged to run a series of online forums for teachers to help re-engage students. Experienced and well-respected psychologists Dr Rob Gordon, who works closely with the Australian Red Cross, and Dr Michael Carr-Gregg are also providing advice on how to support affected teachers, students and school staff.

Special leave arrangements are in place for teachers and students adversely affected by the disasters. Teachers who lost personal teaching resources when their schools were flooded or hit by the cyclone can apply for up to $2,000 to replace it. This joint state and federal government scheme has been increased from $500 to ensure teachers have the tools they need to continue teaching our kids. Schools can also access a range of experts, including guidance officers, youth support coordinators, nurses and other health workers.

More than $2 million worth of goods donated by the community has been collected and distributed to disaster-affected schools, students and families by OneSteel Pty Ltd from its Acacia Ridge warehouse, and I want to acknowledge Tony Schreiber and the extraordinary role that he is playing in that regard. These goods, donated by generous individuals, businesses and organisations, include more than $1 million worth of computer software, 60,000 pairs of shoes, tens of thousands of books and 2,000 backpacks. At last count, more than about 10,000 packages of these supplies had been sent out to schools.

Tomorrow is the SchoolAid Floods Relief Appeal to raise funds for affected Queenslanders. I encourage all Queensland schools to get involved--indeed, I encourage all Australian schools to get involved--by observing a minute’s silence, lowering flags to half-mast and making a gold coin donation. While returning to school was a big step in the right direction for students and teachers affected by the disasters, we recognise it will, for many, be a long time before life returns to normal. The Bligh government will continue to support them in every way possible to ensure they can continue their important learning and teaching journey.

Hon. NS ROBERTS (Nudgee--ALP) (Minister for Police, Corrective Services and Emergency Services) (10.50 am): The Queensland Police Service and emergency services agencies, including Emergency Management Queensland, the Queensland Fire and Rescue Service and the Queensland Ambulance Service, have been at the forefront of the flooding and cyclone response, supporting disaster management groups at all levels. Strong leadership was provided across all agencies, and many lives have been saved because of the dedication and hard work of staff and volunteers. In the Courier-Mail
Qweekend magazine, journalist Trent Dalton reflected that--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: The people at EMQ are quite possibly the world’s best at what they do.
XML.Hansard-Body: I have no doubt that they are, and to them and the police, fire and rescue and ambulance officers who worked with them we owe an incredible debt of gratitude. More than 500 police officers were temporarily redeployed across flood and cyclone affected communities and patrols were increased to protect homes and businesses. Police also managed one of the most comprehensive missing persons searches in the state’s history following the tragic flooding events in the Lockyer Valley.

EMQ staff were heavily involved in planning, logistics, regional deployments and intelligence gathering. Officers were also embedded with local disaster management groups to provide support and advice. Around 1,300 State Emergency Service volunteers were deployed during the disasters and EMQ Helicopter Rescue staff winched 61 people to safety and evacuated 104 people.

Queensland Fire and Rescue personnel in the State Operations Coordination Centre at Kedron supported deployments of swift-water rescue crews, rapid damage assessment teams, aerial operations and clean-up operations. Hundreds of rural fire volunteers helped with evacuation centres and the clean-up of homes, businesses and vegetation.

Queensland Ambulance Service officers worked with Queensland Health and the Australian Defence Force on the largest hospital evacuation undertaken in Australia’s history--transferring patients from two Cairns hospitals to Brisbane. The QAS Special Operations Response Team and tactical medical centres were also deployed to disaster zones.

Queensland Corrective Services officers supervised low-risk prisoners, those on probation and parolees, who contributed more than 9,000 hours of community service in flood and cyclone ravaged areas. Staff from the Department of Community Safety’s corporate support and policy divisions also volunteered or were rostered to undertake alternative duties in the support of their colleagues. I also thank the media--particularly the ABC and commercial radio and television--for their role in disseminating important warnings and safety messages.

Our disaster management system and the people who make it work have served our state well at a time of great need. Whilst recognising the enormous damage and loss that has occurred, Queensland is better positioned to recover thanks to their efforts.

Hansard-Body.A: (Greenslopes--ALP) (Attorney-General and Minister for Industrial Relations) (10.52 am): I rise to provide the House with an update regarding the government’s assessment of Queensland’s optional preferential voting system. Before proceeding further, it is worthwhile recapping on the genesis of this review. Soon after the federal election, held on 21 August 2010, a spokesman from the Australian Electoral Commission raised public concerns about the level of unintended informal voting that occurred in Queensland. The concern articulated at the time was that the level of unintended informal voting may be attributed to differences between the voting systems in play at state and federal levels. At the state level, Queensland adopted optional preferential voting in the early 1990s while full preferential voting is used for federal elections.

XML.Hansard-Body: The Queensland government has now had an opportunity to complete its assessment of a number of issues arising out of the 2010 federal election, including informal voting, and this week’s sitting provides the first opportunity to update the House on the government’s deliberations. The government’s view of the assessment is that the evidence is equivocal and insufficient to support a change to the voting system at this time. The evidence is inconclusive in relation to the issue of concern for the government and others in the community--that voters were potentially being disenfranchised because of the different systems in use at state and federal elections. This issue was of significant concern to the government and prompted our action to conduct this assessment following public comments made by the Australian Electoral Commission. This is because the Australian Labor Party is, as it always has been, committed to ensuring that all citizens can participate in the democratic process to the maximum possible extent.

While the assessment shows that the rate of informal voting in Queensland increased slightly at the 2010 federal election to 5.45 per cent, it is not possible to definitively conclude that the differences in electoral systems were responsible. There may be other factors at play, including an increased number of blank ballot papers. The Australian Electoral Commission is conducting its own review of voting patterns in the 2010 election. However, given that our own assessment shows that the reasons behind the rate of informal voting are inconclusive, the government has decided that certainty is required and that it is unnecessary to delay a decision on this matter.

Obviously, this is an area that will be subject to ongoing analysis, scrutiny and review by the Australian Electoral Commission and others to determine whether voting patterns and trends vary. The government has given a considered and measured response to this issue, rather than rushing out into the public arena with a knee-jerk reaction. The end result is that optional preferential voting will be used at the next Queensland election, which is due in March 2012. The review will be available on the website of the Department of Justice and Attorney-General later today.

Hansard-Body.A: (Thuringowa--ALP) (Minister for Main Roads) (10.55 am): Out of the floods, Queensland’s vast road network--33,000 kilometres--took more damage than any other government asset. More than a quarter of our road network was affected. Towns and communities were cut off, motorists were isolated, trucks could not get through--and when those trucks grind to a halt communities and local economies do, too. That is why my first priority was to get those roads fixed to get Queensland moving again.

XML.Hansard-Body: Today, I want to pay tribute to the men and women who did just that: our roadworkers. Their job is not nine to five; they are out there working in difficult conditions. It can be hazardous, and for that we owe them a huge debt of gratitude. Road crews and contractors have been working hard since Christmas to help reconnect communities and get vital supplies into the worst hit areas. Around 1,200 roadworkers swung into immediate action. They are very much a part of each local community that has been deeply affected by the tragedy upon tragedy that marked the start of this year. Many had their own flood and cyclone battles on the home front, but they put their community’s needs ahead of their own. Through their efforts, they have helped save lives and made life just that little bit easier for the rest of us, opening up the highways so that fresh food supplies can once again line the supermarket shelves.

Whilst the full extent of the damage to our state controlled road network will not be known for many months, our people are still out there fixing. We are talking about an unprecedented long-term repair job brought about by one of the worst natural disasters in our state’s history. It is the biggest workforce deployment in our history. And mark my words: Main Roads crews are moving heaven and earth to get those roads fixed as swiftly as they can. We have engineers, geotechnical experts, surveyors, bridge and transport inspectors, road builders and pavement testers working hard to repair those flood damaged roads as swiftly as possible. We are on the road to recovery, due in no small part to the efforts of the men and women who work on our road network.

Hansard-Body.A: (Condamine--LNP) (11.00 am): I give notice of a motion to disallow subordinate legislation pertaining to this government’s closure of the Queensland snapper fishery under the Fisheries Act 1994 and through regulations pertaining to sections 42 and 43 of this act.

XML.Hansard-Body: Mr SPEAKER: Visitors to the House today will be the North Lakes State College. I welcome the students, teachers and any parents. North Lakes State College is in the electorate of Murrumba.
Mr SPEAKER: It is a very special event today for someone in the Parliamentary Service servicing the electorate of Buderim. Laura Hegarty is in the public gallery and she turns 21 today.

Mr LANGBROEK
(11.00 am): My first question without notice is to the Premier. On 18 October 2010 state cabinet received a briefing from the head of the Bureau of Meteorology on the severity of the pending natural disaster season.
