I ask: in relation to this brief will the Premier today release all documents provided to state cabinet, along with the minutes of the meeting, so that Queenslanders can have access to this important information?

Ms BLIGH: I thank the honourable member for his question. If I understand it rightly, he is asking for documents in relation to the briefing provided by the Bureau of Meteorology. The presentation made was a PowerPoint presentation. I do not see any problem with that being made public. It was material that was on the bureau’s website, or some interpretation of that data. The material was then subsequently put into the public arena by myself at a press conference and, if my memory serves me correctly, Jim Davidson from the bureau attended that press conference.

I do think it is a great credit to the bureau that it identified the likelihood of an extreme summer wet season and brought it to the attention of government and the public. What it meant was that councils across the state were then in a position to make appropriate arrangements and that state government agencies were in a position to make arrangements so that we made sure that key personnel were not on leave at the time when this might be a critical issue. Warnings were given to the public, both through local government and through radio ads, that there might be weather that would require them to take certain action and gave advice about what to do in a cyclone et cetera.

Our emergency services were better prepared as a result of the information provided by the bureau not only to the cabinet, but also to the public and to any councils that sought further detail from them. I think that we can be very grateful that modern forecasting gives us the opportunity to have so much warning. Seeing the damage caused by the category 5 cyclone that crossed the coast predominantly in the electorate of the member for Hinchinbrook, one can only begin to imagine what it must have been like on Christmas Eve in 1974 in Darwin when people had little or no warning, where people were asleep when something of that force and that magnitude hit without any preparation. Again I can only imagine what it was like for people in Innisfail and Mackay in 1918 when similar level cyclones crossed the coast. They had no satellites, no radars, no warning, no ability to protect themselves or their families. I am very grateful for the work that gave us an opportunity to be prepared not only in the days leading up to the event but in the months preceding it.

Mr LANGBROEK: My second question without notice is to the Attorney-General. While it is acknowledged that some insurance companies have acted responsibly in relation to the floods and cyclones, others have acted with no compassion whatsoever, and I ask: is the government currently providing legal aid assistance to those victims in need of advice who are battling insurance companies?

Mr DICK: I thank the honourable Leader of the Opposition for the question. The short answer is yes. We have developed an extraordinarily comprehensive legal response package for Queenslanders affected by floods and cyclones called Flood and Cyclone Legal Help. This is a package of initiatives that the government, in partnership with the legal profession, is rolling out throughout Queensland. I particularly want to acknowledge a number of bodies that have assisted Legal Aid Queensland, which is leading the project, in presenting and developing this package for affected Queenslanders. They include the Queensland Law Society, the Bar Association of Queensland, the Queensland Association of Independent Legal Services. In particular I want to acknowledge the leadership of Scott McDougall who is the coordinator of the Caxton Legal Centre and has been a strong voice for volunteer legal community groups in that process. We are working with other agencies of government, in particular the Department of Communities, to deliver that service initially through recovery centres throughout Queensland and now we are holding a number of public meetings to consult with affected Queenslanders and to provide them with advice and assistance.

Just last night there was a public meeting that was held in the suburb of Oxley. Those of us who went to Oxley and helped clean some of those houses on the Saturday after the flood struck Brisbane know how devastating the flood was to that part of Brisbane. It was one small example of the devastation suffered by many other suburbs throughout Brisbane and other places throughout Queensland.

It is a very positive process. As the Leader of the Opposition will know, the federal government has been very strong in advocating for affected communities and taking the fight right up to insurers, as has the state government. The Assistant Treasurer Bill Shorten, the Commonwealth Treasurer Wayne Swan, the state Treasurer Andrew Fraser, and all members of this side of the House in the condolence motion yesterday--particularly the members for Bundamba and Ipswich West--have all been calling on insurers to do the right thing, calling on insurers to put their hands out to help Queenslanders who have been affected and not hide behind strict formal legalism to get away from or around or over or through what is their obligation to Queenslanders in distress. I do acknowledge the advocacy of all members of this House, including the member for Lockyer and others who have been so terribly affected by the floods. As one, we call on insurers to do the right thing, to support Queenslanders in distress and to put their hands in their pockets to help Queenslanders at this difficult time.

Mr SHINE: My question is to the Premier. Could the Premier update the House on how the SMS alert system worked during the cyclone and floods and the performance of the State Disaster Management Group during this unprecedented period in our history?

Ms BLIGH: I thank the member for the question. I think one of the great things about Australia is that we learn from the experiences that we have and we share those learnings across the country. After the Victorian bushfires, through the Council of Australian Governments and the Ministerial Council for Police and Emergency Management, attended by the Hon. Neil Roberts, there was a great deal of work done about how we could use modern technology better to alert people to imminent danger from natural events. Out of that process the state governments of Australia with the federal government agreed to a nationally uniform emergency alert system using SMS and landline telephones. That system had probably its biggest and most significant test anywhere in the country during the recent events experienced here in Queensland.

In total, across both disasters there were 53 separate warning alerts sent out using the state-wide system to 5.6 million mobile and landline phones. This was an extraordinary effort and what it meant was that, for example, during the flood crisis, 37 separate warnings to 1.2 million phones and during Yasi 16 separate warnings to 4.4 million phones. That is through the state disaster management process. In addition, a number of local councils have their own system with their own constituents. I know, for example, the mayor of Emerald used that very effectively during the flooding event in that town.

It is something that we are going to see more of. From talking to people in places like Emerald, I know just how useful it was. Not everybody is at home watching TV and not everybody has the radio on. Early on in some of those events, people lost power and, therefore, were cut off from normal media avenues. Mobile phones, while they continue to work, and landlines are a potential source of getting out information. We will continue to refine the system.

No alert is possible or useful unless we have forecast information to tell people. In that regard, I want to recognise the work done by some of our senior people over the past eight weeks. Jim Davidson, known to many as the face of the Bureau of Meteorology, has four decades of experience. He is someone in whom you can have a lot of confidence. He was backed up by expert hydrologists, Peter Baddeley and Jimmy Stuart, who were assisted by an expert in storm surge, Robert Schwartz. Between those people, in most instances we saw an incredible degree of precision. The peaks of rivers were predicted accurately to within half a metre and, in most cases, to within the hour that they arrived. That allowed for necessary planning. Similarly, in relation to the cyclone, I think they picked the crossing spot almost exactly and the time to within the hour. It was a remarkable team and I pay tribute to them. I accept that there are some questions remaining about events, particularly in Toowoomba. Those will be answered following the commission of inquiry.

Mr SPRINGBORG: My question without notice is to the Premier. I refer to the Premier’s statement on Friday that she supported local government claims for Natural Disaster Relief and Recovery Arrangements funding for water, sewerage and transport services. Has the Premier written to the federal government in accordance with section 3.6.3 of the disaster arrangements claiming special circumstances apply to those services and will the Premier publicly release the letter today for the benefit of all Queenslanders?

Ms BLIGH: I can advise the House that I have done better than write a letter. I have had a personal meeting with the Prime Minister on this issue. As a result of that, there is now a team involving the federal Treasurer, the state Treasurer, Andrew Fraser, and federal and state Treasury officials who will work through some of the complexities in relation to this issue. For the benefit of the House, I point out that the Natural Disaster Relief and Recovery Arrangements do not provide for the payment of funds for certain kinds of infrastructure, particularly those for which a fee for service is charged, particularly where those fees for services provide a profit to the organisation concerned.

The provision of water and sewerage services differs across the councils of Queensland and differs in other councils in other states such as Victoria, parts of which have also been affected by similar disasters. Some councils are asking the federal government to give consideration to extending those financial arrangements to an area that has never been covered and, to my knowledge, has never been paid for. This is a totally unprecedented area of activity for natural disaster relief payments. That is not surprising, because the event we have experienced was an unprecedented event. It was unprecedented in its scale and its scope. As I have noted before, some of the worst impacts have hit our smallest councils. Councils with the least ability to pay, the smallest rate base and that cover a wide area have seen many of their facilities damaged.

I understand the importance of this to local councils. I understand the impatience and urgency that some councils feel. Equally, it is important to understand that this is an unprecedented area of Commonwealth-State financial relations. You cannot make a commitment without having at least some idea of what it will cost and how you will fund it. That work is happening right now. I assure members and the public that Canberra and the federal government are sympathetic, but quite reasonably they need to know what it is that they would be making contributions to, not only in Queensland but also in other parts of the nation. We will work carefully through those issues.

The way we got through this disaster, across all levels of government, was with a degree of patience, goodwill and cooperation. Those three things are going to be needed every single day of the recovery. It is important to put the politics aside as we put the people first. As we work to make it easier for communities, councils and local areas to recover, trying to score political points will not help. Rather than having a public debate about this, we are getting on with the hard yards, we are sitting down and doing the calculations and we are working out what it is that can be paid for.
XML.Hansard-Level-2-Heading: Natural Disasters, Premier’s Disaster Relief Fund
XML.Hansard-Body: Ms NELSON-CARR: My question is also to the Premier. Given the answer that she has just given about goodwill, patience et cetera, could the Premier update the House on further work that the Premier’s Disaster Relief Fund is doing?
Ms BLIGH: I thank the member for the question. She has seen firsthand what disasters have done in the northern part of the state. I know that she is concerned about a number of her constituents.

When we saw the beginnings of the flooding event that we thought would be devastating to Queensland, I established a Premier’s relief fund to take donations from across the state and the nation from people who wanted to lend a helping hand. When I set up that fund, little did we know just how much call would be made on it and how many contributions would be made. As at the close of business yesterday, we had $213,520,780 in the fund. That is the largest relief fund ever raised in Queensland’s history.

As I noted in my contribution yesterday, we have received donations from people from around the world, we have received donations from people from across the country and we have received an extraordinary contribution from New Zealand of about $2.3 million. However, I have been particularly heartened and touched by stories of children donating their pocket money. The Leader of the Opposition talked about our experience on the telethon and I am sure he had a similar experience to myself of taking calls from age pensioners who would apologise that they could not give more than $10, but they wanted to contribute. We know what a big proportion of their pension $10 is and how much it meant to them.

We have done a good job of encouraging those contributions, but I need to be honest and say that we need more. As well as our flood victims, people affected by Cyclone Yasi need help. There are people who are going to need our help simply to get back on their feet. Relief funds such as these help people who fall between all of the other safety nets: those people whose insurance does not cover them, those people who are not eligible for some of the other grants, those people who did not have much to start with, those people who need a helping hand not only from the government but also from the community working through funds like this. This will not be an easy task for the people administering the fund or recommending its distribution. Again I pay tribute to the members for Gregory and Rockhampton and to David Hamill and his team.
Mr Schwarten: They are meeting this morning.

Ms BLIGH: They are meeting regularly and are working through some diabolical questions about how to best get the funds to the people who need them most. I pay tribute to those members who, with their communities, have been fundraising. The member for Bulimba raised $27,000 and the member for Ashgrove raised $10,000 by holding community events such as cake stalls and sausage sizzles. People want to be a part of this and they want to help. I encourage other members to talk to people who have held similar events and, where possible, it would be great to see people continuing to hold such events throughout the year.

Mr SEENEY: My question without notice is to the Minister for Natural Resources. I refer to the comments that the Premier made in the parliament twice this morning, referring to the key climate predictive tools now available. For the benefit of the House, I table a copy of the operational procedures for Wivenhoe Dam with half the pages blacked out. I ask: will the minister indicate where in this document the operators of the Wivenhoe Dam are required to be responsive to the SOI index and the La Nina climate cycle?
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Copy of a Seqwater Manual of Operational Procedures for Flood Mitigation at Wivenhoe Dam and Somerset Dam, November 2009 [ 3935 ].
XML.Hansard-Body: Mr ROBERTSON: I thank the member for the question. Of course, that flood manual was released because it is a document that has been referred to the commission of inquiry, as it should be, for the purposes of detailed analysis. I noted a contribution by the member in this morning’s Courier-Mail , in which he made the allegation that this flood manual had its genesis following the building of the Wivenhoe Dam. To that extent he is correct. What he is not correct in saying, and what he is deliberately misleading about, is that it has not changed since then. In fact, it has changed on at least seven or eight occasions as a result of detailed knowledge and experience.

For example, since 1974 and the subsequent building of the Wivenhoe Dam there have been at least two events of 1974 proportions that the dam managers have dealt with and dealt with very successfully. That is to say, there were flood events in South-East Queensland of 1974 proportions that the new Wivenhoe Dam has coped with on two separate occasions. What they had to deal with on this occasion was a flood event at least twice that of 1974--twice that in terms of the amount of water coming into the catchment. So when we consider the contribution of the member for Callide in this morning’s Courier-Mail , as usual we should take it with a significant grain of salt.

Back in October last year, what were the member for Callide, the member for Southern Downs and the LNP calling for? They were calling on this government to reduce the flood buffer in Wivenhoe Dam. I did note that, because the LNP has form in trying to rewrite history. Despite being caught out two days ago for removing the offending media release about which the Leader of the Opposition says he has no idea, as is the case on so many occasions, nevertheless two days later it is still not there. The member has had two days to contact his webmaster and tell him to put it back. I do have a copy of it here. So that there is a permanent record of what the LNP said--
Mr Seeney: What did I say about the SOI? Read the bit about the SOI.
Mr ROBERTSON: I am happy to quote from the press release. It states--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Mr Seeney said it was time to review management policy so more of the dam could be used for water storage to reduce chances of another water crisis.
XML.Hansard-Body: That is, cut into the flood buffer. The simple fact is this: if the LNP were in charge of our dams, more South-East Queenslanders would have been impacted by the January floods than was the case. They were putting at risk the safety of South-East Queenslanders because of a cheap political stunt. I table that media release.
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Copy of a media release, dated 6 October 2010, titled ‘Labor not interested in Wivenhoe ‘rethink’ [ 3936 ].
XML.Hansard-Body: Mrs MILLER: My question is to the Deputy Premier and Minister for Health. Can the Deputy Premier and Minister for Health please inform the House how Queensland Health is supporting Queenslanders in the aftermath of the recent floods and Cyclone Yasi?

Mr LUCAS: I thank the honourable member for the question. I have had the great pleasure of being out in the electorate of the honourable member twice since the flood events. I have certainly enjoyed her taking me around, showing me issues of interest. I want to make one specific mention--the honourable member mentioned it yesterday--in relation to the churches. It is fashionable in certain quarters to knock churches and their contribution. Like all of us, churches are not perfect. Some of the work they have done, in particular in the member’s electorate, through this flood and cyclone event has been outstanding. I think we should very frankly acknowledge that and the wonderful work they have done.

Ensuring that Queenslanders continue to receive the health care they need was a top priority throughout the recent flood and cyclone disasters. When one looks at cyclone events such as Yasi, which was a category 5 cyclone--and there is no category more serious than a category 5--in which we lost one life, which is one too many, I think it is important to contrast that with what occurred in another developed nation; that is, the United States with Hurricane Katrina. Some 1,860 or more people were lost as a result of that hurricane. In the wash-up and in the examination of these things, that speaks volumes about how we have done.

Of course, in spite of disasters life goes on. Therefore, we need to make sure we are continuing to deal with the necessary issues as part of providing front-line health services. That means we take steps during disasters to make sure we are still providing facilities. For example, when the river split the town of Emerald in two and there was a likelihood of the hospital being flooded, we took the opportunity to evacuate the hospital and set up a temporary facility on the other side. Some people in Emerald asked, ‘Why did you do that? The hospital was not flooded.’ If in the middle of the flood event suddenly the water did come up and inundated the hospital, we would then have had to call on our emergency services workers to divert from their other tasks in order to evacuate the hospital when they should be in a position to actually provide services to other people. Often we do this as a precaution. It is an important thing to do.

In Gracemere, a clinic was established in partnership with local doctors and staffed by local nurses and our staff to provide services when Gracemere was cut off. We had the monumental Cairns evacuation, and I pay great credit and tribute to our staff for the way they did that. Queensland Health takes precautions in relation to these events because it is much better to adopt an overly cautious approach in relation to these matters and evacuate, when in retrospect it was not needed, than to not do it in the first place.

In the aftermath, there are very significant efforts in terms of primary healthcare teams, free tetanus immunisations--a number of us have witnessed that throughout Queensland, particularly in flood areas--and 13HEALTH. I have been around the state visiting our Health staff in all sorts of areas, thanking them for the work they have done. I thanked them in Tully, where the roof of the hospital was lost, amongst very significant devastation. This is what the 80,000 people in Queensland Health do every day of the week, and I thank them for it.

Mr NICHOLLS: My question is addressed to the Treasurer. In light of the floods and the cyclone affecting Queensland, the Treasurer has previously referred to the Queensland Government Insurance Fund and its reserves of $700 million. Today he has said it is in fact $900 million. Given that there is no reference to those reserves in the midyear financial and economic review, there is no separate fund reported for it in the Queensland Treasury financial statements and there is no mention of it in the budget papers at all, can the Treasurer tell Queenslanders where these funds are physically held, where they are publicly accounted for and how much will be spent on disaster recovery?

Mr FRASER: I thank the shadow Treasurer for the question. The existence of the Queensland Government Insurance Fund is so much a secret that, in fact, there is a dedicated page for it on the Treasury website. The important thing about the Queensland Government Insurance Fund is that it was this government that brought it in. Making provision for the future has been a long-term goal during our time in office.

Earlier this decade the Queensland government--this state government--put in place the Queensland Government Insurance Fund. It presently does have funds in the order of $900 million--that is determined by the State Actuary through the premiums charged to agencies--to ensure that at all times the reserves and the assets held by that fund are sufficient to cover the liabilities of the fund. The State Actuary determines the premium and, more to the point, it is reviewed annually by the State Actuary as to its efficiency.

Beyond that, the Auditor-General has full access to all those arrangements and accounts for the holdings of the Queensland Government Insurance Fund in the whole-of-government accounts, which of course were signed off by the Auditor-General this year, as they were in each and every previous year. If there is a matter of substance about which the shadow Treasurer has a concern, he is more than able to raise that with the Auditor-General because it has in fact received the sign-off.

The reality here is that the Queensland Government Insurance Fund is in place primarily to deal with acts of vandalism and damage to property--in circumstances where a school burns down, for instance. A generation ago, when a school burnt down there was no provision made for the ability to recover that property. These days, when a school burns down the recovery cost is not deducted from the education minister’s budget; the Queensland Government Insurance Fund provides the ability to recover that property. That is an important reform.

It is also there to provide for the sorts of liabilities that a state may acquire. For instance, if someone trips over at the Queensland Gallery of Modern Art, stunned by the art there, and it is deemed to be an act of negligence on the part of the state, it is the Queensland Government Insurance Fund which underwrites that. This is a very important arrangement about satisfying the long-term liabilities of the state. It is also a hallmark of the last generation of the Queensland government--on both sides, I do acknowledge--to fully fund our superannuation liabilities. This is a fund in that vein.

It is a very good thing that we have this insurance fund. As I said in my earlier remarks, the primary mechanism for dealing with natural disaster is the longstanding Natural Disaster Relief and Recovery Arrangements, which exist in exactly the same terms for each and every state and territory. Beyond those arrangements, we do have levels of commercial insurance for a range of economic infrastructure. Finally, we ensure that, in the end, the ability to recover is put as the priority. As I have said on a number of occasions, that will be the priority for determining the course of the state’s finances in the state budget I expect both this year and beyond.

Mr WENDT: My question is also to the Treasurer and Minister for Employment and Economic Development. Is the Treasurer aware of any data that outline’s Queensland’s economic momentum leading into this summer’s flood and cyclone disasters?

Mr FRASER: I thank the member for Ipswich West for his question. He is one of the people, of course, who has been dealing so ably with his community and the breadth of his electorate affected by flood and damaged in many particular ways. I know that he has also been working not only with community groups and residents but with his own local businesses to ensure that they have access to support from the state--the arrangements that have been put in place to assist in particular small business, it being vitally important to keep people in jobs at a time like this.

There were many people at the end of 2010 who were firmly in the camp of ‘bring on 2011’. I was one of them. That was because I always had a great deal of optimism about the trajectory of the Queensland economy in 2011. The September state accounts, which are now available, detail and underscore why that optimism was well placed. We saw in the September accounts business investment growing, growing by 3.2 per cent in the first quarter of the financial year and for the second quarter in a row. What that shows is that business investment was returning to the Queensland economy. That was before the two massive LNG projects, which we drove to approval, were sanctioned by those companies and the spend was yet to kick in. So the evidence is clear that business investment was returning as the economic recovery that we were authoring was gaining momentum.

There is probably no better example of the underlying strength of the Queensland economy before the natural disasters hit, the recovery that was building, than last week’s data on employment from the Australian Bureau of Statistics. It was a remarkable result, if probably somewhat an unbelievable result. For the 18th month in a row the Queensland economy generated jobs--4,600 jobs against a record high participation rate, 18 months in a row of jobs generating growth in the Queensland economy. That means that our jobs delivery stands at 83,600, with 16,400 to go. What that means is that we remain on track to deliver on that key election commitment of 100,000 net new jobs.

The ABS were at pains to caution that data and I, for one, agree with them. Anecdotally, I expect that a great deal of the effects of the natural disasters will flow into the next month’s release from the ABS, and I think we should all wait with caution to see what those figures are. But this government remains determined to deliver and drive on with generating jobs growth. What we need right now are people out there promoting the cause of the Queensland economy, not attacking the Queensland economy. Let us understand that a recovery was building. It was being put in place to generate jobs to drive growth this year.

As we reach across the political divide and across the community in order to support individuals, a key part of that is going to be for all sides of this parliament to support growth in the Queensland economy, to talk up the prospects of industries like tourism and agriculture and to support the Queensland economy.

Mr CRIPPS: My question without notice is to the Minister for Public Works. At the 2006 state election the government promised that within 100 days of being elected a construction timetable would be developed for priority areas so that suitable buildings, including schools and TAFE gymnasiums, multipurpose halls, workshops and community entertainment centres, could be constructed to the standards necessary for a cyclone shelter. Will the minister commit to publicly releasing today that timetable for the information of the people of Queensland?

Mr SCHWARTEN: I thank the honourable member for his first question in this parliament. Cyclone shelters are a very relevant issue, but, if the honourable member takes the trouble to examine the history of this, what he will know is that we committed to build these as part of the building program subsequent to that decision being made. We can see evidence of that already occurring, with five of them being rolled out in the north.

Coming out of Cyclone Yasi, and having been in the honourable member’s electorate last week, I think we need to rethink this whole strategy, quite frankly. I have not had a chance to discuss this with the Premier, but my own view is that every single one of those BER buildings that were built in his electorate have managed to withstand this level of cyclonic activity. It would be foolhardy in my view to go out and spend more money when these buildings are already there and have withstood the cyclone. I know from Project Services that those buildings were in fact overdesigned. I was advised last week in Cairns that they were designed to the highest possible standards in that regard. So they have withstood the venom of that cyclone, and one could easily argue, I think, that it would be quite wise at this stage to appraise that set of circumstances.

I was at Silkwood the other day and I observed that the building that had blown away there was one that was funded by the federal government directly to the school. It was not one that was built by the state government and it was not built under our plans. But every other building that I saw had that capacity. Ironically, the Tully State School--the primary school which the honourable member attended--has a brick building that was built in the 1930s and, in my view, would serve very well as an evacuation centre. My personal opinion of the evacuation centre used in Cairns, the Earlville Shopping Centre, is that it was a very informed decision to make, and I think we ought to be concentrating our efforts down that path as well and looking at whether or not there needs to be some subsidy from the public sector to go into that to create an evacuation centre.

My quick is answer is that the policy that was announced was revisited. There was a desire then to have it as part of the built environment, the normal construction, as Education Queensland did, as one example. I think we really need now to revisit this whole question in terms of whether we want to squander money on evacuation centres that will ultimately not be required.

Mrs SMITH: My question is to the Minister for Natural Resources, Mines and Energy and Minister for Trade. Will the minister outline to the House how the Bligh government’s water reforms helped guarantee water security during South-East Queensland’s floods?

Mr ROBERTSON: I thank the member for the question. I have stood in this place now on numerous occasions to explain the benefits of South-East Queensland’s new water grid, not just in terms of ensuring that South-East Queensland is drought proof but also in terms of ensuring that there are additional benefits when it comes to challenging times such as we have seen over the last months with those devastating floods in January. Quite simply, the impact of those floods on particularly the Mount Crosby water treatment works meant that a critical part of South-East Queensland’s water grid--the desalination plant at Tugun on the Gold Coast--came into its own in terms of ensuring quality water supplies to the people of South-East Queensland.

At the height of the floods, some 10 tonnes per second of silt and debris were flowing past the treatment plants at Mount Crosby downstream from Wivenhoe Dam. That meant very challenging times for Seqwater workers at that treatment plant, and I will come back to them in a moment. What it meant was that, at the most critical time, as a result of the desalination plant quality water supplies were able to continue, much to the amazement of interstate water authorities who have since contacted Seqwater to find out how they achieved that. Had we not had that desalination plant, then the whole of Brisbane, Logan, Redcliffe, Redlands, Ipswich, up to the Sunshine Coast and northern parts of the Gold Coast would have been boiling their water for days on end as a result of not being able to maintain water quality. It was as a result of being able to fire up that desalination plant that we were able to maintain water quality and not have the third largest city in Australia having to boil water.

One of the untold stories of this flood is the magnificent work that those workers at Mount Crosby performed in order to maintain some level of throughput. They had lost power. They were working in vertical tunnels of 40 metres, in pitch dark with torches in their mouths, in order to keep switching on and off pumps to maintain some level of treatment coming out of that Mount Crosby plant. They were being flown in by helicopter to change shifts after 12 hours. And I have to say that they were working in the most hazardous of circumstances. It is a story that will be told in far more detail at an appropriate time, but I take this opportunity to place on record my absolute respect and thanks for those workers at Mount Crosby for their bravery and commitment to their posts. They are some of the unsung heroes to date of what happened during those devastating events.

Mr RICKUSS: My question is to the Premier. Many constituents in my electorate who have been badly affected by storm damage do not qualify for state grants because of the current means test levels. Will the Premier put the people first and please urgently reconsider the means test levels so that these victims can access this much needed money and get on with rebuilding their lives?

Ms BLIGH: I thank the honourable member for the question. The member might have heard in my earlier comments about the Premier’s relief fund an acknowledgement that some people, because of their circumstances, do not qualify for other forms of assistance and that is why these sorts of relief funds are so important. The means test that applies to state government assistance is the same means test that applies in every state of Australia and is indexed every year. Therefore, it is the same one that applied to those people in Mackay who had floods in 2008, to those people in Emerald who had floods in 2009 and to those people who experienced the bushfires in Victoria, for example. I appreciate that sometimes these things are very difficult. I know the difficult circumstances being faced by the constituents of the member for Lockyer. I know of his genuine care and compassion for them.

What I can say to the member for Lockyer is that in the design of the allocation of funds from the Premier’s relief fund it will be people like the people in the Lockyer Valley and their circumstances that will be the foundation on which any decisions about the allocation of funds is made. What I would encourage the member to do is to speak to both the member for Gregory and the member for Rockhampton about how to best craft this. The member knows these people’s personal circumstances. I do not think it is in their interests, and nor would he ever seek to, to put their incomes into the public arena. In terms of how that intersects with asset tests et cetera, I think it would be very useful for the member to meet with those members--I am sure they would agree to such a meeting--to make sure that we craft this in such a way that picks up exactly the people it is designed to pick up, and that is those who need it the most and who might otherwise slip through the crack of safety nets that are designed for people who are in absolutely extreme circumstances.

I recognise that there are a number of opportunities for immediate relief through Centrelink that are not means tested. The first round emergency payment out of the fund is not means tested. However, I do have to say that the Australian Taxation Office rules that apply and have applied for, I think, the entire history of the federation requires funds like this to means test second payments to qualify as charitable funds for the purpose of tax deductibility.

This issue was raised with the Commonwealth at COAG the other day by both me and Ted Baillieu. There has been an agreement that the tax office will look at some of those issues. But we do not want people to be able to put funds together outside of natural disasters for the purpose of tax evasion. It is a fine line to walk. As we did with Cyclone Larry, any means test that is struck will be considerably more generous than applies to government welfare payments to capture and to assist the very people that the member for Lockyer refers to.

Mr WETTENHALL: My question is to the Minister for Education and Training. Can the minister please inform the House about the huge effort by the community to get our schools back on their feet after the flooding and Cyclone Yasi?

Mr WILSON: I thank the honourable member for the question. It is somewhat of an untold story what has been done by the community to get two lots of schools--those in South-East Queensland and Central Queensland affected by the floods and then those in the Far North affected by the cyclone--operating again and in a condition where students could return. It has been an extraordinary effort by the larger community, truly making the point, if we did not already know it, that schools are the heart and soul of our community.

If we think about the flood impact not just in Central Queensland but up in Toowoomba, in the Lockyer and down in Brisbane it is worth noting that within one week of those flooding events taking place all but three of 92 schools were able to be reopened for the first day of school this year. Three were not able to be but those school populations were transferred to nearby schools. Some 89 schools out of 92 schools that were flood damaged--this ranged from minor to quite serious flood damage--were able to reopen.

Why was that possible? Because Education Queensland personnel, QBuild personnel, principals, staff, P&Cs, parents, community volunteers and many others chipped in and achieved that result. Why did they do that? Because they well understood that getting children back into their normal school routine was one of the biggest contributions they could make to helping the families who were flood affected get back to normality and stability, which is absolutely what they needed to do.

Likewise, in the Far North and a little further south to Mackay on the day the cyclone hit, some 346 schools--Catholic, state and independent--were closed. That is nearly 25 per cent or nearly a quarter of all of the schools in Queensland. By the Friday, all but around 170 could have reopened. Then over the following week that number was progressively brought down. Only 11 were still shut on Friday and those 11 opened on Monday.

Again, the same broad community involvement is what brought that about. Thousands and thousands of students were able to get back to school as quickly as possible not only so they could resume their learning journey but to help them readjust and get back into normal life along with their families. I take my hat off to everyone involved in that extraordinary effort.
XML.Hansard-Level-2-Heading: Woolooga-Eerwah Vale High-Voltage Electricity Transmission Line
XML.Hansard-Body: Mr WELLINGTON: My question is to the Minister for Natural Resources, Mines and Energy and Minister for Trade. I realise everyone has questions about flooding but my question relates to the Woolooga to West Cooroy powerline which the government has been dealing with for some time. Recently one of my constituents told me how they cannot sell their property because once prospective purchasers find out about the proposed powerline’s proximity to their property all negotiations stop. When does the minister anticipate being able to make a decision on both the need for the proposed powerline and the proposed location either via the National Highway corridor or the current Powerlink proposed location?

Mr ROBERTSON: I thank the member for the question. To meet forecast demand to 2050 joint planning by Powerlink and Energex has identified that a new high-voltage electricity transmission line will be needed by around 2014, connecting Powerlink’s existing Woolooga substation to a proposed new substation site at Eerwah Vale. The reason that this matter is somewhat contentious is that, although 90 per cent of the project is planned to be built on existing easements next to existing infrastructure, there is a section of about 8.6 kilometres of the powerline which will require a new 60-metre wide easement. This is what has attracted some controversy and some criticism from the member’s constituents.

That is why an exhaustive process has been undertaken over the last couple of years in terms of Powerlink’s environmental impact assessment. I think it is fair to say that I would share the member’s concern about the length of time it has taken to finalise this matter. What has occurred is that in the intervening period new planning procedures have been put in place by my colleague the Minister for Climate Change and Sustainability in terms of protecting vegetation for koala habitat. Various assessments have been needed to be undertaken in accordance with those planning policies. That has caused a lengthening of the time for Powerlink’s consideration of these matters.

I am informed that that work is now nearing completion. That designation then has to come to me for approval and, of course, it has to be exhaustively assessed. I am told that that work will soon be with me. We expect to finalise this project by the middle of this year. We are only a couple of months away from receiving that application from Powerlink. I can assure the member’s constituents--the residents along the proposed corridor--that the 55 submissions that they have put forward with regard to this matter will be considered carefully by both my department and me.

Based on the member’s advice this morning, I understand there is a view that the road corridor may be wide enough to accommodate this powerline. If that be the case then that will be taken into consideration to verify it and determine the final route. As I said, member for Nicklin, we are literally now only a couple of months away from finalising that matter so that the uncertainty that he referred to in terms of the impact on the local real estate market can be lifted as soon as possible.

Ms GRACE: My question without notice is to the Minister for Public Works and Information and Communication Technology. Can the minister inform the House about efforts by QBuild to help parts of Queensland affected by flooding and Cyclone Yasi?

Mr SCHWARTEN: I thank the honourable member for the question in relation to the mighty QBuild. As I mentioned this morning, QBuild throughout the state and throughout this disaster period has worked with its contractors on some 600 buildings. There have been 1,200 staff and contractors thrown at this event, and I think the result that the Minister for Education pointed out a short while ago is just one example of their work.

Whether it is in Theodore and coordinating Channel 7’s Bounce Back program and a number of other projects, or whether it is connecting 250 houses in Queensland, or whether it is working with Ergon to coordinate the reconnection of houses in my electorate, or whether it was cleaning up at Cardwell last week and cutting up all the debris with chainsaws--the mighty QBuild have been there. We are the only state which has a day labour workforce of 1,200 people. One of the great benefits of that is you can bring those people in to work at these sorts of times. We would have struggled to get private contractors of that number. I do not know how we would have got 90 of them into Far North Queensland in the last couple of weeks so we could get every single school opened last Monday. Every single school was opened with a genset, coordinated by QBuild in its nerve centre out of the Cairns office. It was a phenomenal activity.

I thank the principal in Tully--and the honourable member might like to pass this on to her--for providing them with a couple of cartons of beer to take on the bus. QBuild was running a bus service down to Cardwell every day. Unfortunately, there was no lavatory on the bus and when I was driving back I noticed that they had to drive into a cane paddock in the member for Mulgrave’s electorate. I did alert the shadow minister to this matter. I guess what it shows is the gratitude that the teachers had for those young workers--and most of them were young people--who got out there and got their schools back in order. Similarly, at the hospital in Tully, they set up my old mate Spanner from Innisfail.
Mr Lucas: They were doing a great job there. I saw them there myself. Thank you.
Mr SCHWARTEN: Great. And the nurses came out. They did not bring them any beer but they brought them a cup of tea. They are far better at looking after teachers than nurses, obviously.

I am proud of every one of the QBuild workers. Whether it was the people who came over and waded through the water at the Neville Bonner Building to make sure the police pays were processed or whether it was the people who went to Cardwell or any other part of this state, each one of those QBuild workers did a magnificent job.

Mr FOLEY: My question without notice is to the Minister for Health. Now that it is compulsory for local governments to fluoridate the public supply of drinking water, will the government provide free fluoride filters for the significant number of Queenslanders who do not wish to drink fluoridated water?

Mr LUCAS: I thank the honourable member for the question. I have got to say that the initiative for fluoridation of our water was not one that occurred during my time as health minister. I regret that because I think it is one of the most important public health initiatives this government has ever had, and I thank the honourable Minister for Natural Resources, Mines and Energy for that wonderful and outstanding initiative that he had that I wholly endorse.
Mr Seeney: He hasn’t done many other things right.

Mr LUCAS: Well, he did not issue a media release on filling the dam up and then get caught out taking it down. In relation to fluoride, Queenslanders had the worst teeth in Australia and now under fluoridation in the course of time we will have the best teeth because we will have the most extensive network. In addition to the fluoridation policy, the government also met the capital costs of providing that equipment into significant communities in Queensland and the operational costs that are a part of supplying water.

The issue of supplying filters has been discussed before. The government does not believe it is appropriate to do that at this time. In fact, the government invested very heavily in a number of different initiatives for people to make different sources of water available to them, but we do not believe it is appropriate that we subsidise the provision of filters. The use of a filter for drinking-water purposes only is a fairly modest thing--and there is certainly no suggestion that it be used in relation to shower water and those sorts of things--and we think it is best undertaken by people individually.

Some people asked at the time why we did not, for example, supply fluoride tablets. The evidence shows that providing fluoride tablets to people in lieu of fluoridation can be far more hazardous because people do not control their doses and people can forget whether they have taken their tablets and then take more of them than they should, so the ability to provide it in a sensible fashion through a fluoridation process is how it goes. Queensland has the most extensive public dental health system in Australia, and that is a good thing. The Commonwealth government is looking at how it might support that even further still, but some things have been tied up in the Senate with the coalition when it comes to further rolling out teeth improvement treatments.

I thank the honourable member for the question. The answer is no, but I do thank again the previous minister for the wonderful public health initiative he made. It is public health initiatives that, frankly, make the biggest difference. You can individually deal with someone or you can deal with a community, and that is why I think this House ought to be justly proud of our initiative.

Mr PITT: My question is to the Minister for Primary Industries, Fisheries and Rural and Regional Queensland. Will the minister inform the House of the levels of assistance to small businesses and primary producers in the wake of recent natural disasters? Can he advise how many applications have been processed to date by the Queensland Rural Adjustment Authority?

Mr MULHERIN: I thank the honourable member for the question and I thank him for his ongoing support for small businesses and primary producers who have been affected in the wake of the recent flooding and cyclone events. We are committed to providing every assistance which is available to small businesses and primary producers to assist them in rebuilding, replanning and recovering from the widespread effects of these natural disasters that have affected various parts of Queensland.

Under the NDRRA--the Natural Disaster Relief and Recovery Arrangements--there are a number of assistance packages that are available to help primary producers and small businesses to get back on their feet. The Queensland Rural Adjustment Authority administers these programs, and I would like to place on record my support and thanks to Colin Holden and his staff at QRAA for the fantastic job they have done. They have been working around the clock since mid-December. They have processed about 1,500 grants under category C since then, with a total value of $2.6 million.

There are different forms of assistance. Under category B, there is assistance for small businesses and primary producers through concessional loans, which is $250,000 at four per cent, plus a freight subsidy for primary producers, with a maximum of $5,000. Under category C, which requires the Premier to write to the Prime Minister seeking approval, there is a $25,000 grant program. Tier 1 is $5,000 to assist with immediate recovery and tier 2 is up to $20,000 to help effect the repairs to the damage. The Premier and the Deputy Prime Minister this morning announced an extension of category C to a number of areas that were affected by Cyclone Yasi--that is, Burdekin, Cairns, the Cassowary Coast, Hinchinbrook, Palm Island, the Tablelands, Townsville and Yarrabah. There is also a package under category D that was announced by the Premier and the Deputy Prime Minister which will provide further assistance to small businesses and primary producers.

Category D special assistance has only been activated once before, and that was following Cyclone Larry. However, we have learnt a lot from Cyclone Larry in terms of what assistance will aid in the recovery. It is really about tailoring a scheme to meet the demands. Assistance under categories B and C of NDRRA should be, in the majority, sufficient to help primary producers recover, but under category D--

Mr HOPPER: My question is to the Minister for Primary Industries. I refer to the previous question, which the minister just answered, and to the federal activation of category D natural disaster assistance for communities and businesses hit by Cyclone Yasi, and I ask: will the minister advise the House what actions he has taken and what progress is being made to have Darling Downs farmers who have suffered total devastation from the floods similarly declared as category D for natural disaster relief payments and loan subsidies?

Mr MULHERIN: I thank the honourable member for the question. Under category D, the package announced today for the Yasi affected area means that there are concessional loans of up to $650,000 with a $50,000 grant program which is based on a 25 per cent component of that. In relation to the area of Central Queensland, South-West Queensland and southern Queensland, the Premier has written to the Prime Minister around category D assistance for places that have been severely impacted. We will continue to negotiate with the Commonwealth government around that assistance, but the general severity of Cyclone Yasi was recognised by the federal government and it made that announcement this morning. I personally have spoken with Joe Ludwig. The protocol is that the Premier must write to the Prime Minister, so we have followed those protocols. I have been involved in discussions with the Treasurer, and the Treasurer is leading the negotiations for the Queensland government in relation to further assistance.
Mr SPEAKER: Order! The time for question time is over.

Hansard-Body.A: (South Brisbane--ALP) (Premier and Minister for the Arts) (12.01 pm): I present a message from Her Excellency the Governor.

XML.Hansard-Body: The Speaker read the following message--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: I, PENELOPE ANNE WENSLEY AC, Governor, recommend to the Legislative Assembly a Bill intituled--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Indent1: A Bill for an Act to establish the Queensland Reconstruction Authority and provide for other measures to assist with the rebuilding and recovery of Queensland communities affected by disaster events, and to amend this Act, the Building Act 1975, the Disaster Management Act 2003, the Integrity Act 2009, the Land Valuation Act 2010, the Public Service Act 2008 and the State Development and Public Works Organisation Act 1971 for particular purposes.
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Message, dated 15 February 2011, from Her Excellency the Governor recommending the Queensland Reconstruction Authority Bill [ 3937 ].
XML.Hansard-Body: Hon. AM BLIGH (South Brisbane--ALP) (Premier and Minister for the Arts) (12.03 pm): I present a bill for an act to establish the Queensland Reconstruction Authority and provide for other measures to assist with the rebuilding and recovery of Queensland communities affected by disaster events, and to amend this act, the Building Act 1975, the Disaster Management Act 2003, the Integrity Act 2009, the Land Valuation Act 2010, the Public Service Act 2008 and the State Development and Public Works Organisation Act 1971 for particular purposes. I present the explanatory notes, and I move--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: That the bill be now read a first time.
XML.Hansard-Body: Question put--That the bill be now read a first time.
Motion agreed to.
Bill read a first time.
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Queensland Reconstruction Authority Bill 2011 [ 3938 ].
Tabled paper: Queensland Reconstruction Authority Bill 2011, explanatory notes [ 3939 ].

Hansard-Body.A: (South Brisbane--ALP) (Premier and Minister for the Arts) (12.03 pm): I move--

XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: That the bill be now read a second time.
XML.Hansard-Body: This truly has been the summer of sorrow as our state and its people have faced unprecedented natural disasters. Just as most of Queensland was recovering from the flooding that swamped Queensland in December and January, Tropical Cyclone Yasi inflicted a path of damage south of Cairns and north of Townsville.

These have been immense events. We suffered substantial loss of life and people saw their homes destroyed, their lives, livelihoods, businesses and farms overturned and their communities shaken to their foundation. But the endurance and resilience of Queenslanders is remarkable. Together our state and our people will undertake the massive recovery and rebuilding process. The task before us is greater than any we have faced. To meet that task, the government will establish the Queensland Reconstruction Authority to spearhead the work.

The Queensland Reconstruction Authority Bill 2011 will establish an authority to scope and coordinate the state-wide rebuilding program and to cut through red tape and any other barriers that would stand in the way of swift recovery and rebuilding. The QRA will work in cyclone affected communities in North Queensland as well as the 60-plus flood affected communities across the state. Major General Mick Slater will chair the authority, with former Coordinator-General Graeme Newton as the CEO. An office of the Queensland Reconstruction Authority will be established in North Queensland and will be dedicated to cyclone recovery. It will be headed by Chief Superintendent Mike Keating, who will be seconded from the Queensland Police Service.

Our message is this: no-one and no part of Queensland will be forgotten. The rebuilding of small rural communities is just as important and just as urgent as the rebuilding of the state’s cities and major regional centres. Under the bill, the authority will prioritise the work needed to rebuild community infrastructure and services in flood and cyclone affected communities; it will coordinate and manage the rebuilding and recovery of affected communities, including the repair and rebuilding of community infrastructure and property; and it will coordinate the distribution of financial assistance for affected communities. The bill vests the QRA with significant powers to ensure proper and expedited planning, preparation, coordination and control of development for rebuilding and recovering affected communities.

Local government will retain primary responsibility for land use and building approvals. The QRA will have powers to be exercised within declared areas or projects to expedite or intervene in regulatory decisions or approval processes or directly undertake planning functions or development. This will include the power to compulsorily acquire property required for reconstruction within reconstruction areas, but only where this is strictly necessary for reconstruction or to manage and mitigate the impacts of natural disasters. We intend that these powers be used only by exception and with the full cooperation of local government where absolutely necessary to facilitate the construction effort.

The QRA will work collaboratively with local government and other regulatory agencies to secure appropriate approvals and expedited reconstruction works in the first instance. But the powers granted by the bill will ensure the QRA is able to cut through and intervene by declaring a reconstruction area or project where necessary to expedite reconstruction, recovery and disaster management efforts.

The powers vested with the authority are adopted from existing powers available under various acts--the State Development and Public Works Organisation Act 1971, the Urban Land Development Authority Act 2007 and the Sustainable Planning Act 2009. This will ensure legislative consistency across our planning and development approval laws while centralising relevant planning, decision-making, acquisition and works powers within the QRA.

Finally, the bill contains a sunset clause to wrap up the QRA after two years, recognising that the focus of the authority will be to fast-track the rebuilding effort and get Queensland back on to a business-as-usual footing as quickly as possible. The work set down for the Queensland Reconstruction Authority cannot be underestimated. The sooner reconstruction commences and is completed, the sooner Queenslanders’ lives can be restored, the sooner our social fabric can be repaired and the sooner our tourism, small businesses, farms, mines and other industries can get back to normal, the sooner we can get our state and national economic growth back on the rails. As Queensland moves from disaster response to disaster recovery, the government will continue to stand alongside our flood and cyclone affected citizens. The Queensland Reconstruction Authority will greatly assist in concentrating the effort to return to normality and beyond as quickly and as effectively as possible, and I commend the bill to the House.
Debate, on motion of Mr Langbroek, adjourned.
Resumed from 15 February (see p. 86), on motion of Ms Bligh--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent1: 1. acknowledges with great sadness the devastation caused in Queensland by the natural disasters that this State has endured since December 2010;
2. extends its condolences and deepest sympathy to the families and loved ones of those killed in the natural disasters;
3. grieves for those who have suffered injury and who have lost their homes, property and personal possessions and extends our support for their recovery;

4. places on record its sincerest gratitude for the leadership and the valued contribution of the police, emergency service and medical teams, defence personnel, federal, state and local government and private sector employees, and community and voluntary service providers, together with the thousands of workers and volunteers from Queensland, other parts of Australia and overseas, who have selflessly contributed so much in difficult and often dangerous circumstances to help affected communities;

5. sincerely acknowledges the many fundraising activities which have been organised and thanks the people and governments in Australia and overseas who have sent messages of support and sympathy and who have generously donated resources and funding to assist our fellow Queenslanders; and
6. pledges to work with affected communities and all levels of government, as Queensland recovers from these natural disasters and is rebuilt.
XML.Hansard-Body: Mr NICHOLLS (Clayfield--LNP) (12.08 pm): I join in the motion of condolence moved by the Premier. I can only talk of the aching sorrow that I feel for the friends and families of those who perished in the events that have occurred in Queensland--from north to south--since December 2010. In no way can I, of course, feel the pain that those friends and family feel, but my heart does ache for them and for their loss. Can I also acknowledge the contribution of members here yesterday and later on today from across the partisan divide and from across the state. I join with many members in extending my sympathy, support and admiration to the members for Lockyer and Hinchinbrook--two men I am proud to count among my friends. I also commend the work of Ann Rickuss in helping Ian and the people who were so tragically affected in their community.

I am sure I was not the only member in this place to get a little glassy eyed while listening to the member for Lockyer relate the tales of the wall of water that fell upon the towns and hamlets of his electorate. We also heard yesterday of the passion that the member for Hinchinbrook feels for his electorate. I must say that I marvel at his resilience, his perseverance and his humour in the toughest of times--a true North Queenslander. I have listened with a sense of awe and wonder to the stories that have been told in this place, including those relayed by the honourable the Premier and the honourable the Leader of the Opposition. I extend my sympathies to all of those who suffered, whether from the Central Queensland floods, the flash flooding in Toowoomba and the Lockyer, the floods in Ipswich and Brisbane and, of course, severe Tropical Cyclone Yasi. I also express my thanks and admiration to the members of the Queensland Police Service, the emergency services, and all of those who were called upon to help and assist our communities. In particular, I mention, as others have done, Deputy Commissioner Ian Stewart, who did such a tremendous job in leading the disaster team. Who but the most heartless could remain unaffected by the natural forces that have been visited on our great state and who but the most empty and hollow could not feel a sense pride in the way Queenslanders of every stripe and shade came together to help each other, to support each other, to comfort each other--in fact, to display what Abraham Lincoln described as the better angels of our nature.

The effects of the Brisbane floods on the electorate of Clayfield have not factored in too many news stories. They have not made the headlines. That is as it should be when one looks at the devastation suffered in other parts of Queensland. But the grasping tentacles of the floodwaters did extend to the businesses and a few--thankfully a few--homes in Clayfield. Of course, the Emergency Services headquarters building is, in fact, located in my electorate of Clayfield. Thankfully, it remained high and dry. With Breakfast Creek on one boundary, the sleeping leviathan of the Brisbane River on another and the bay on another, the people of Clayfield are always aware of the possibility of flooding. Indeed, it happens on a fairly frequent basis when the king tides flow in and the rain falls. But the magnitude of the wall of water coming down the Brisbane River did stir people into extra action. As the suburbs of Pinkenba and Albion started to look like they would be experiencing a very damp evening, locals, emergency services and the council swung into action.

The Pinkenba Community Association, through its president, Ted Slater, started contacting local families to find out who was at home, who was on holidays, who was mobile and who was not--in effect, to start putting together an emergency plan, a disaster plan. Names were taken and lists were compiled and people walked the streets knocking on doors to find out the information that would be necessary in case the floodwaters rose. Alice and David Smith from the Pinkenba Community Association spent hours going around and getting those names. Cars were moved to higher ground at the Airport Link storage facility on Eagle Farm Road. Tinnies were unshackled from trailers and tied up to front stair post rails in preparation for the expected deluge and a couple of motors that had not been turned over in a long time were oiled and fuelled up. Sandbags were deployed and as far as things could be prepared they were. So by Wednesday afternoon it was time to visit the Pinkenba boat ramp and view the spectacle of the Brisbane River--the true Queensland spirit: everything that could be done had been done; it was time to go and see what was coming.

In Albion, local flooding is a regular event. From the Breakfast Creek Hotel to the home of the mighty Brethren at Crosby Park and the Albion fiveways, businesses and homeowners started the sandbagging of premises and homes. I spent hours with Councillor David McLaughlin and my two sons, Jeremy and Duncan, helping with the sandbagging. It was a sight to see my poor old Ford Territory scraping along on its bump stops fully laden with sandbags on more than one occasion. On that note, can I acknowledge the tremendous work done by the volunteers at the depots handing out sandbags. We had one down at Eagle Farm. There was a sense of community as people came together and worked on that equipment that loaded up the sandbags. We had the managers of local businesses driving forklifts to load up the backs of trailers and trucks. We had people from across the suburbs on the northern side coming together to work on those operations. Meanwhile, back at Albion as we unloaded sandbags and as the waters rose up around our legs, we all mucked in to help. I commend all of those who helped in all of those areas. As other members have said, they are largely unnamed and they did not want to go named. They were people who just saw someone doing something and they decided to drop everything and come and help. So we worked as teams all around that area at the back of Albion.

Then the floodwaters came and for the first time in my entire life Kingsford Smith Drive was eerily silent--even at 11 o’clock at night. The road was closed and all you could see under the yellow lights of the pontoons and wharves was this wall of water coming down the river, dragging bits and pieces of everything from further upstream--rubbish bins from Ipswich, lettuces from Rocklea; the whole lot came flying down the river there. That sleeping giant hit at about 4.30 am. As I said, fortunately the suburbs were not badly inundated. The water came up about a metre and a half through Albion and I got a phone call on Thursday morning from the local residents in Pinkenba saying that it was no worse than a king tide, could they have the power back on and they did not know why they wasted all of their time doing it all. But I think they were happy to have had the security that was provided by those sandbags, by those preparations and by the SES who came and helped them.

I acknowledge the tremendous leadership shown in Brisbane by my friend the Lord Mayor Campbell Newman. I think there was no-one who was watching the news or listening to the radio at that time who did not understand the passion he felt and the drive he gave to having in place a disaster management plan that ensured that the people of Brisbane were as well protected as they could be in the circumstances. If ever there was a man for the moment, Campbell was that man. The Brisbane counterdisaster plan flew into action. People were deployed, council officers were sent out and the clean-up was able to start almost immediately.

On the afternoon before the flood there were calls going out to line up extra evacuation centres. As the heights changed--and people might recall the different predictions about how high the water would go--there were concerns that more people would need to be looked after in evacuation centres and that the centre at the RNA would not be big enough. So the call went out. I made some calls in my part of the world as well for people on the northside. Can I acknowledge here the Brisbane Airport Corporation, which on the Wednesday night had people turning up in the belief that the airport was an evacuation centre. So the airport had to look after 350 people whilst continuing to run the airport. Unbeknown to them, people just turned up. The word had got out. Harvey Lister and the team at AEG Ogden--the company that runs the Brisbane Entertainment Centre at Boondall--required one phone call to say that, yes, of course they would make their premises available. In fact, it was unnecessary but it was made available and staff would be rostered on or would volunteer to come in and man that centre to provide services should it be needed. In fact, the entertainment centre served as a basis of providing services to the northside in the clean-up.

So businesses and community came together on the northside to provide what was needed in Brisbane. Together with federal member Teresa Gambaro, Councillor McLaughlin and I started visiting on the Saturday morning after the clean-up had really got underway, helping businesses primarily with information about accessing the various grants and loans and services that were made available by the state government, by the federal government and by local authorities. I also visited the Doomben racetrack, which was one of the marshalling yards for the volunteers--the magnificent mud army that came together in Brisbane. It was unbelievable to stand there at 7.15 am on a Saturday morning and see the hordes of people just wanting to help, turning up with boots, with shovels--with all of their paraphernalia--wanting to now know how they could help. It was a tremendous outpouring of the strength and community spirit that abounds in Brisbane and on the northside. Hundreds of people who I thought would never have picked up a shovel turned up to help and I am sure they got a few blisters for their troubles on the way through.

As I said, fortunately the damage in Clayfield was able to be cleaned up without too much trouble. For those members who know that part of the world around Allan Border Field, it is interesting to note that it flooded. Nailed about halfway up a telegraph post was a ‘Speed limit four knots’ sign and a couple of tinnies made their way from the gates--I think they are the Bill Brown gates at Allan Border Field--down Bogan Street at Albion down to Breakfast Creek. So we were watching the speed limit and also observing the road rules of the river in that part of the world.

The mighty Breakfast Creek Hotel, which has been inundated three times since 1893, was back up and running by Australia Day. In fact, on Australia Day it held a fundraiser for flood victims. I have not brought in the T-shirts that were sold at that fundraising appeal to present to you, Mr Speaker; I am going to auction them off at a local event in the next week or so. There was an enormous amount of money raised at the Breakfast Creek Hotel. I commend Sam Gullo and his team at the Breakfast Creek Hotel for what they have done.

I also acknowledge my friend Father Dimitri Tsakas and the Greek community based at South Brisbane for the magnificent contribution they made to the recovery effort in and around Fairfield. A mate of mine, a fellow called Tony Cassimatis, opened up his house and he and his wife made food and sandwiches and acted as a marshalling point in the Fairfield area. They were only metres away from the flood. Tony, his wife and the Greek community did a fantastic job in that part of the world. We came together at the Greek Orthodox Church on that Saturday night. The help that was extended by that community, as it was by many other communities across Brisbane, was phenomenal. As others have remarked, the assistance provided by the young people in those communities was remarkable, giving us, I think, a greater sense of the value of young people and their willingness to help and assist.

Many others helped rebuild in and around Albion. Energex were responsive to the needs of my community, resuming power and explaining why they could not resume it in places. I congratulate the teams that were put in place to liaise with local members. I think they did everything that could reasonably be expected of them in terms of providing information and making those connections work. I spoke to many Energex workers who were doing the work on the lines. To an extent they were getting a little frustrated at all the calls for power to come back on but they were working assiduously in turning that power back on. Local electrical contractors in my part of the world volunteered to go out and certify each of the premises to make sure the power could be turned on. I think that saved many people a lot of time and money.

There are still issues to be sorted out for the businesses in my part of the world. Thankfully they are few. One of the businesses is Cuttings Wine, run by a fellow called David Bone. It supplies fine wines to restaurants around Brisbane. They are situated at Albion. As the water was coming up they picked up all the mighty expensive wine and stacked it on top of the less expensive wine and we sandbagged. There were no promises of freebies as a result of doing all that work but, nonetheless, it looked like a pretty good haul that was there. Unfortunately, the water seeped through the sandbags and destroyed all of the cartons holding the cheap wine so that all of the wine above toppled in. It is a business that is very substantially limited in what it can sell. Because it has a wholesale licence it can sell only 2 per cent of its product to the public, although I am sure that if it was able to sell to the public its staff would be knocked out in the rush as people sought to buy survivors of the 2011 Brisbane floods. We are liaising with the minister responsible for liquor licensing in relation to that issue to see if we can find some way around those restrictions.

I acknowledge the work of businesses in and around Brisbane supporting the rebuilding. We have talked of the communities and we have talked of the local organisations, but I also acknowledge a couple of other people who have not been mentioned. I first acknowledge the Billy Connolly concert that was held on Sunday night at the entertainment centre. Over 100 staff volunteered their time for that concert. Billy Connolly volunteered his time for the concert. The total value, I am told, will be somewhere north of $450,000 for that one event, all going to the Premier’s Disaster Relief Appeal. Everyone who worked there that night was a volunteer. We had managers directing traffic and acting as ushers. I acknowledge the gift of the city of Kaohsiung in Taiwan. It made a sister-city donation last Saturday to the Lord Mayor’s Disaster Relief Fund of $100,000. I acknowledge the Taiwanese community more generally which had, up to the time that I was there, already raised $30,000.

We have talked about some of the efforts of some of the big companies. I want to acknowledge the efforts of the RACQ and the disaster-funding package it made available and the generosity it provided. Also, the Commonwealth Bank made its funds available. When we talk about community we should include the generosity of the very many businesses that do the right thing.

I acknowledge the people in Nundah Village who are fundraising in two Fridays time, on 25 February. The people of Nundah are coming together to hold a fundraiser to support the Premier’s Disaster Relief Appeal. Even people like my own sister, who lives in Sydney, have organised progressive dinners and they have raised something like $10,000 from expatriates by charging exorbitant prices for rum and coke.
