The community comes together in many different ways and has many different tentacles to support Queenslanders. They show that community spirit is alive in all parts of our society.

These have been testing times for Queensland and Queenslanders. Things have been written about testing times. I think for many people there is some comfort in the wisdom of Solomon as recorded in Ecclesiastes. Many people will know it. It states--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: To everything there is a season, and a time to every purpose under the heaven:
A time to be born, and a time to die; a time to plant, and a time to pluck up that which is planted;
A time to kill, and a time to heal; a time to break down, and a time to build up;
A time to weep, and a time to laugh; a time to mourn, and a time to dance;
A time to cast away stones, and a time to gather stones together; a time to embrace, and a time to refrain from embracing;
A time to get, and a time to lose; a time to keep, and a time to cast away;
A time to rend, and a time to sew; a time to keep silence, and a time to speak;
A time to love, and a time to hate; a time of war; and a time of peace.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: Truly, Mr Deputy Speaker, they have been the times.

Hansard-Body.A: (Mount Isa--ALP) (12.26 pm): I am honoured to speak to the Premier’s condolence motion before the House. On behalf of all of the residents of the Mount Isa electorate I offer our sincere condolences and pay our deep respect to the families who have lost loved ones and the families who have endured massive losses during the devastating natural disasters which have gripped our state since December. We know that their lives will never be the same; indeed, nor will the lives of all Queenslanders who have shared their sorrow and pain.

XML.Hansard-Body: It has been said, and will continue to be said, I am sure, that where Mother Nature has been at her most destructive humankind has responded at its very best. There is little doubt that what has happened has changed our state forever. As disaster after disaster has unfolded, we have witnessed from every point in Queensland the horror of the events, the extraordinary bravery of many and then the incredible response to people in need by family, friends and complete strangers.

To my colleagues in this House whose communities were directly affected: you have shown your strength and you have given us your personal insight into the reality of the horror through your eyes and the eyes of the people who have suffered and lost so much. I feel sure that there would not be a person who has not been amazed by the bravery, courage, resilience and generosity of the people of Queensland. What we have also witnessed is the incredible leadership of our Premier, Anna Bligh, who has shown her incredible strength, compassion and a capacity and ability to give so many people the strength to face these terrible times and, most importantly, believe that we would get through them and end up stronger.

To the Deputy Premier, Paul Lucas: I know that many of the mayors across the state have truly valued the continual support you have given them throughout each event. To Minister Neil Roberts: you have led by example to so many. Your portfolio and people cover all of our front-line workers across the state--servants of the people who went well beyond the call of duty over and over again. Your steady and calm leadership is greatly admired and respected by many. To our Treasurer and government ministers: you have not only been there for our state, but in many cases have worked tirelessly within your own electorates which have been badly affected. I further acknowledge Major Mick Slater and his team, who are leading the recovery effort.

I thank the members of the committee for the Premier’s relief appeal. We could not have selected wiser heads or bigger hearts than those of the Minister for Public Works and member for Rockhampton, Robert Schwarten, and the member for Gregory, my mate Vaughan Johnson. Who would have thought that in just a few short weeks of the new Disaster Management Act coming into effect on 1 November 2010, it would face its first major test. Indeed, it has been tested ever since. Possibly the most significant changes included putting the Queensland Police Service in command and strengthening the role of local government in disaster preparation. From where I stand, both have been resounding successes. I thank the people who assisted me personally, including staff from the Premier’s office and the ministers’ offices, all the incredibly helpful departmental staff, at the local level Mike Glasson from the Bureau of Meteorology in Mount Isa and, of course, our local ABC and North West Star .

From day one the QPS officers involved have performed in an exemplary manner. They stood side by side with the government and local councils as they prepared for disaster and battled to regain control after the events. I acknowledge the leadership of Commissioner Bob Atkinson and Inspector Ian Stewart, our state’s first disaster coordinator. In my part of the world, Ian Stewart has become everyone’s favourite uncle. He worked with Bruce Grady, who was appointed as our first state disaster recovery coordinator. From day one they have shown us how truly lucky we are to have people of the calibre of those three gentlemen working for us all. Over time it has been my great privilege to meet personally many of the mayors and councillors from across the state. Right across the state our councils have been magnificent. As their communities were drowned by unprecedented flood rains and then raging torrents and later the fury of Cyclone Yasi, they stood firm as pillars of their communities, with mayors leading from the front to assure residents that things would be all right.

Who would have thought that in western Queensland we would be looking down the barrel of a category 1 cyclone? By the time Yasi reached Julia Creek it still had a sting in its tail and Mayor Woodhouse can say that they survived Cyclone Yasi. By the time it reached further west, it was a severe rain depression.

There is little doubt that great adversity brings out the best in all of us and is was exemplified by the leadership and contribution of our police, our ambulance and fire officers and, in particular, the swift-water crews who worked tirelessly and with great courage to save so many people. I thank our health and defence personnel, EMQ staff and our helicopter crews. As we heard from the Premier, their work was unprecedented in Australian history. I thank the truly selfless men and women of the SES from right across the state. I thank local, state and federal government staff who served and continue to serve our communities. The partnerships and relationships between councils and EMQ staff have now been well and truly cemented. All of those people stood side by side, shoulder to shoulder, at every level of government across every community.

Many lessons will be learnt from the disasters. We will heed those messages. The government, in close partnership with councils and local communities, will continue to plan for the future. There is little doubt that we will ensure that we are even better prepared for the next natural disaster, and we will continue to build resilience in each and every community.

I thank and acknowledge the wonderful generosity of the people of my electorate who have and I know will continue to contribute financially to the Premier’s fund to help those families in need. In conclusion, one thing we can say for sure is that through these extraordinary times we have united our state, closed the divide between the city and the bush, and shared the pain one and all. I hope that the spirit and strength that has come from this summer of sorrow will remain and strengthen us all as we go forward to rebuild our state, not only with bricks and mortar but with the uniqueness of spirit and soul that makes us Queenslanders. I commend the motion to the House.

Hon. A PALASZCZUK (Inala--ALP) (Minister for Disability Services and Multicultural Affairs) (12.34 pm): I rise to speak in support of the condolence motion. The summer of 2010-11 brought to our state devastating floods and cyclones, a collision of natural disasters unprecedented in modern times. The flooding events took the lives of 35 Queenslanders and left their mark on communities, not just physically but also emotionally. Whole communities have now pulled together to support families, friends and neighbours at a time of unimaginable catastrophe. Volunteer armies also sprung up throughout Queensland.

At the outset, I pay my respects to all those Queenslanders who lost their lives. I pay tribute to Van Toan Giang, who lost his life in stormwaters in Durack while checking on his father-in-law’s property during the floods. I know that the Vietnamese community has been deeply affected by this tragic loss. He was a young man, recently married. I extend my deepest sympathies to the family and the local Vietnamese community at this very difficult time.

I acknowledge the Premier’s outstanding leadership during the recent natural disasters. She has inspired a state and a nation, leading Queensland through one of its toughest times. I thank Ipswich Mayor Paul Pisasale, Councillor Milton Dick and Councillor David Morrison for their efforts locally on the ground. I also thank my own staff for helping me to clear out entire shelves of Gatorade at the Richlands Woolies on more than one occasion. It was all handed out to thirsty volunteers during those hot summer days.

In Gailes, entire families lost a lifetime of possessions and stood powerless as their personal effects were destroyed in the floods. When the water receded I visited those normally quiet streets--Dulin Street, Alma Street, Mirrin Street, Killalan Street--and the damage was immense. Wrecked fridges and air conditioners, spoiled bedding, tennis rackets, Scrabble boards and childrens’ toys were piled sky high on the footpaths. I personally witnessed acts of amazing compassion and kindness in this neighbourhood. I saw volunteers helping residents salvage personal possessions from their homes. I saw people lending families generators, trailers and shovels. I saw mothers and children delivering sandwiches, cakes, pikelets and cold drinks to volunteers who were helping with the clean-up. I saw Army and Emergency Services workers and community recovery staff working around the clock to help get families back on their feet. For many, this period was a time of great sorrow and loss, but it was also a time of great community spirit.

The residents of Gailes Caravan Village lost their homes and possessions, which were swept away in the floods, but they did not lose their spirit. Some found refuge in the community recovery centre that was established at the Shiloh Christian Church at Redbank. With the help of volunteers and staff, they were able to get back on their feet and start rebuilding their lives as alternative accommodation was sought.

During the flood crisis, one of the most inspiring things I witnessed occurred in the low-lying area of Centenary Village in Darra, where a flooded creek swamped up to 70 family homes. The flood level had reached the roof of one woman’s house. Most of her possessions were ruined or swept away and she had no insurance. However, she had spirit, courage and tenacity, and she was determined to fight on and rebuild her life. Her son was leading the working bee at the house, with neighbours also lending a hand. I asked two men who were pitching in with the clean-up how they knew Isabela. ‘Oh, we don’t know her’, one of the men replied. ‘We are just here to help, like everyone else.’ One the men had come from Murrumba Downs and the other had travelled from Strathpine on the north side. They had given up their time and travelled to help a complete stranger. They are among the true community heroes of the floods. That was repeated across the streets of Brisbane and the state.

Also, Cathy Easte established a recovery centre for flood affected residents in the local community hall at Centenary Village. Tireless volunteers made this centre a real community hub for local residents, with state government recovery workers also providing much needed outreach to people who could not travel to the Wacol centre.

There was one especially inspiring volunteer at this recovery centre. Allan Wade from Innisfail in Far North Queensland stayed for six days to help local residents get back on their feet because he was not able to travel home. Allan was a tower of strength for these residents during a difficult period. He wants to revisit Centenary Village to do more recovery work and raise funds for the flood affected residents on his way to the blues festival at Easter. Well done, Allan.

The Camira-Springfield Community Centre also did an outstanding job during the floods. It served as a one-stop recovery shop, with part of the centre transformed into a giant warehouse with essential items for flood affected residents piled metres high. Non-perishable food, clothing, electrical goods and children’s toys were donated in vast quantities--a lifeline to so many people.

The nearby Wolston Park Golf Club at Wacol was also hit hard by the floods, with fairways swamped and the clubhouse submerged by floodwaters. This is a real community club and its membership and green fees are amongst the lowest in Brisbane. This is where the workers of Gailes, Goodna and Camira go to play golf. I know that members of the club want to see the course repaired and the clubhouse refurbished. I am confident that Mary Byrne and her committee will ensure the club bounces back.

Deaf Services Queensland did a great job during the natural disasters keeping deaf and hearing impaired Queenslanders informed. Auslan interpreters featured heavily during the flood and cyclone updates provided by the Premier. I want to pay tribute to their outstanding efforts during this time.

We also kept Queensland’s multicultural communities well informed throughout the floods. Multicultural Affairs Queensland produced disaster relief fact sheets in over 30 languages including Chinese, Filipino, Greek, Japanese, Samoan, Spanish and Vietnamese. Queensland’s multicultural communities are working tirelessly to raise funds for the Premier’s Disaster Relief Appeal. I want to thank them all for their generosity and compassion and for working side by side to help flood affected residents. Our multicultural communities have helped to show above all how much we have in common; that, first and foremost, we are all Queenslanders.

In conclusion, in the aftermath of the floods, there were people standing side by side, shoulder to shoulder. There were no divides, just people bonded by a will to get things done. This was community in action in our streets, in our suburbs, in our cities, cleaning, carrying, baking, delivering, shovelling, hosing and salvaging. There was an army of volunteers--strangers by name, but not in spirit. This was real mateship. It is what Queenslanders and Australians are renowned for throughout the world. This is what our Australian history has recorded throughout the generations. It is a story told time and time again. We will always be there to help one another in good times and in bad, for better or for worse. We will see things through together.

Hansard-Body.A: (Pine Rivers--ALP) (12.43 pm): I rise this afternoon to support the Premier’s motion and to add the voice of the people of the Pine Rivers electorate to the words of sympathy and comfort that have been espoused in this House today and yesterday. In my 44 years I have not seen so many disastrous weather patterns pile one on top of the other for weeks on end. I, along with many others, watched on the television the disastrous events unfolding out west last year and in Toowoomba and the Lockyer Valley in early January. The scenes of devastation were unbelievable.

XML.Hansard-Body: Most of the houses and businesses in my electorate were spared the worst of the problems associated with excessive rain and floods. Unfortunately, about a dozen houses around Strathpine and Lawnton were affected and also Dayboro did not escape the inundation. Indeed, the local Dayboro residents say it is the worst flooding that Dayboro has seen since the early 1930s. According to Councillor Bob Millar, Dayboro had over 600 millimetres of rain in several days. This saturated land could hold no more water and it just had to find a way to escape, which it did, through the lower streets, inundating houses, businesses and the bowls club.

I would like to offer my thanks to Senior Constable Troy Nowitzki and Sergeant Ken Robinson for their magnificent efforts during the floods in Dayboro. Due to logistics, Troy was in town and Ken was on the other side of the creek. Both were working furiously to ensure residents were safe and able to get out of their houses and up to higher ground. Senior Constable Troy particularly should be commended. He was as sick as a dog and had no communication equipment on him but was out there in the pouring rain rallying the people and keeping them safe. From that point on the entire community banded together to work through the floods and to clean up and help. Councillor Millar was telling me that within two days of the flood he was receiving phone calls from local volunteers offering assistance to other people within the region as they had already cleaned up impacted businesses and homes in their own area. Senior Constable Troy organised a community debriefing meeting and over 170 people turned up to share their stories, offer more help and work through what assistance was available to them.

At this point I would like to thank the local, state and federal government public servants who hit the streets of Dayboro in the days after the flood to doorknock businesses and residents to see what assistance they could provide. They also came to our flood debriefing to offer further information. Even though the town and surrounding district looks nice and tidy again, we must remember that some people did suffer significantly as a consequence of what happened in the days before and after the flooding. It will take some of them a long time to recover, both financially and emotionally, and we will be there to support them and help them through their journey. Indeed, this Friday night, Dayboro is running a major fundraiser which is being hosted by Heather Foord. It is the Flood and Fire 2011 Concert and Charity Auction, which will raise funds for local people who have been badly affected by the flooding. That includes the McKavanagh family of Laceys Creek, who lost their home in a fire the week before the floods and whose farm was damaged during the flooding.

I am so proud of the Dayboro community, the police, the volunteer organisations, the local residents who just pitched in and the six blokes who took it upon themselves to mow the soccer fields with their household lawnmowers because it would have been ripped up by the slasher and they did not want the kids turning their ankles. I think that would have made a great photo.

Several sporting venues suffered damage during the floods such as the Dayboro Bowls Club, Dayboro Little Athletics, Dayboro soccer, Dayboro tennis and the Pine Rivers Swans AFL. The sports minister, the Hon. Phil Reeves, personally asked to visit some clubs so he could ascertain the level of loss and damage and to offer his personal support. His visit was very much appreciated and we look forward to the assistance that the state can provide through the increased grants and through the help of the peak sporting bodies.

The Pine Rivers community has gotten behind our fundraising efforts by donating money and goods. Senator Mark Furner, Councillor Mick Gillam and I worked closely with Club Pine Rivers to hold a fundraiser. What started out as an idea for a sausage sizzle on a Sunday afternoon soon turned into a sporting and auction extravaganza with sports celebrities from the Broncos and Lions and Olympians Jessica Schipper, Jodie Bowering and Melanie Schlanger. A special thankyou goes to The Veronicas--Lisa and Jess Origliasso--who were going to turn up for an hour and ended up staying for six hours signing autographs, serving sausages and hosting dinner. The community turned out in force and Club Pine Rivers raised $25,600 on the day for the Premier’s flood relief fund and another $5,000 since then, which will go to local sporting clubs to help out.

Putting aside the devastating weather patterns that caused the disastrous flooding, local residents do have questions about the operation of the North Pine Dam, the issues surrounding early warning systems and problems with insurance companies. There will be submissions from people across the Pine Rivers electorate to the commission of inquiry and I will be working with residents to ensure the right questions are asked and that answers are delivered.

Further to this, our road network suffered quite significantly due to the flooding. The AJ Wyllie Bridge at Petrie was totally cut off for almost a week and only the high bridge was re-opened as the low bridge suffered extensive damage. Compounded with this was the closure of the lower part of Strathpine Road along the flats which meant the only way in and out of Strathpine was on a single-lane road. Just to really make a mess of the traffic, Youngs Crossing Road was cut off repeatedly as water was released from the North Pine Dam. It caused huge delays. I would like to thank my community for their absolute patience during the difficult times that we are experiencing at the moment.

The Moreton Bay Regional Council has indicated that it will pursue the option of a high bridge across Youngs Crossing Road so that this important access road can finally be flood proof and our road network will work at all times. I commend it for moving this council initiative forward and I have indicated that I will support it as it asks for state and federal government support to help make this $100 million bridge a reality. I take this opportunity to let the Premier know about this important flood mitigation project for the future for the people of Pine Rivers. I will be speaking about this more often to her and to other levels of government.

Whilst the events of 2011 will be indelibly etched into the minds of those directly affected, it is up to all of us who were not affected to keep supporting them as they recover and rebuild. Businesses need residents to shop locally and support them. I remind everyone that it is not just those businesses that were flooded that have had a downturn in their business; there are those like the Lawnton businesses who were affected by the closure of the AJ Wyllie Bridge. So it is up to all of us to get behind our businesses and support them and support our sporting clubs and residents.

Our community will recover and our thoughts and best wishes will be with our fellow Queenslanders who have suffered through the floods and the cyclones of this dreadful summer of 2010-11. I support the motion before the House.

Hansard-Body.A: (Mirani--LNP) (12.49 pm): I rise to speak briefly to the motion of condolence before the House today. Firstly, I indicate that there was very little damage across my electorate. Of the two cyclones, Cyclone Yasi and Cyclone Anthony, Cyclone Anthony probably did the most damage, with several houses being unroofed and some trees being brought down across houses and roads et cetera. But it is important to realise that there were people right across my electorate who were affected, particularly in Rockhampton. In actual fact, the small suburb of Depot Hill is in my electorate.

XML.Hansard-Body: I think most people would know--and the member for Rockhampton raised this issue--that the people who live at Depot Hill have a history of putting up with flooding and they find joy in having flooding parties et cetera. They are used to doing that. As Rockhampton is flooded fairly regularly, they take some pride in the way in which they handle the floods. I think it was fairly disappointing that the preparations they made in terms of stockpiling food et cetera were terminated by the switching off of the power. I do not know the full history behind that, but I know that the swampies at Depot Hill were rather disappointed about that.

Overall, we are were all just horrified at the vision that came into our living rooms over two or three weeks in terms of the flooding through Emerald and then further down through Dalby and Condamine. Ultimately, the rain then fell in Toowoomba and we witnessed the absolutely unbelievable force of the water through Toowoomba, then down the escapement into the Lockyer Valley and finally into Brisbane. On top of that, a few days later came the two cyclones in North Queensland. I do not want to be a spoilsport, but I have to point out the old-time theory--it is not theory; it is fact--that the cyclone season does not actually finish until Anzac Day. We have had cyclones in April and we have had quite severe cyclones right up to that time. So our views should be tempered by the fact that there is a real possibility we could get further cyclones on the Queensland coast.

The recent events have affected the incomes of a lot of people in my electorate. The sugar industry, the cane industry and the milling industry will face a tremendous downturn not only because of what happened last year, when up to 25 per cent of the crop was left in the paddock--indeed, if we do get a severe cyclone in that area most of that will be destroyed by winds--but also because of the inability of farmers to plant a crop, get a successful strike and grow a decent crop for this coming season. There will be a real impact because we have had rain right throughout North Queensland from about the end of August last year.

So there is an economic impact right across North Queensland. And now the cyclones in North Queensland and the closure of the Babinda mill will have a real impact on the viability of the sugar industry across Queensland. Of course this is true for the horticultural industry as well. We have pineapple farmers in my electorate at Alligator Creek. The proprietor was complaining that, because the highway was closed at Rockhampton, he had difficulties transporting his pineapples to market, and this was at a time when the price of pineapples had peaked.

I would particularly like to congratulate all the volunteers and the non-government organisations, the police, the SES, the QFRS and the rural fire brigades, and more particularly the people who just rolled up with little notice with mops and buckets and scrubbing materials to help people. It really does make you proud to be part of a community and part of a nation where volunteering is a big aspect of our lives. I think we should pat ourselves on the back. Even though we have in our community people who are not community minded, when the chips are down it is surprising to see the number of people who will actually go out and help other people. On TV I was watching vision of the riots in Egypt. It was really heartening to see that, after they settled down, people volunteered to clean up the square in which they had been protesting. I wonder whether the vision from Queensland had been shown in Egypt and people saw the need to help out in the public interest.

I am very conscious of the fact that the bill to be debated after this condolence motion gives us the opportunity to talk about infrastructure issues, but I think it is important to understand that the Bruce Highway is really the lifeline of Queensland. Even though there were areas in North Queensland closed because of the cyclone and flooding, the closure of the highway at Rockhampton for more than two weeks had a huge impact on Queensland. It had a huge impact on North Queensland in terms of its ability to move goods to the south, as I have just mentioned. We need to look at that piece of infrastructure as a national network of transportation. Many people were inconvenienced by the closure of that road but they could still drive from Rockhampton to Mackay. So there were a lot of people driving to Mackay to catch planes to travel not only to Brisbane but also all over the world. A lot of those travel plans were of high importance--for funerals, weddings or any number of reasons. I have to say that I was really disappointed to hear that the airlines increased the price of a seat out of Mackay by double, triple or more. I think that is very disappointing. People were travelling because they had to, not for some social reason. They were travelling for something that was really important to them. I was really disappointed about that. I think we need to look at that sort of profiteering as we move forward.

The other real concern is the number of people who have lost their homes. For instance, in North Queensland 650 homes are totally destroyed and another 2,500 homes are unlivable. There are a lot of people who had no insurance, who were underinsured or for whom the insurance company will not accept liability. There will be some people who have a mortgage on their home. Even when a house is destroyed, the mortgage still has to be paid. There will be other people who are renting and who lost all of their possessions. They also will have some difficulty re-establishing their accommodation.

As we move forward--and there have been some deeply felt and heartening speeches made in the parliament over the last two days--we need to think about those people who are going to be tremendously disadvantaged. There are going to be quite a lot of people in that situation. Let us hope that all of the support we can give them, through government departments and donations et cetera, will go to the people who need it most and that, in terms of accommodation, we are able to look at ways of getting relocatable housing into areas that really need it.

In debating this motion of condolence, I think it is important that for a moment we think about those people who are going to be severely disadvantaged, not just in the next couple of months but possibly for the rest of their lives. Our hearts go out to all of those people. I really do support the motion of condolence.
Sitting suspended from 12.59 pm to 2.30 pm.
Debate, on motion of Mr Elmes, adjourned.
XML.Hansard-Level-2-Heading: Notice of Disallowance Motion, Out of Order
XML.Hansard-Body: Mr SPEAKER: The member for Condamine this morning gave notice of a motion to disallow ‘subordinate legislation pertaining to this government’s closure of the Queensland snapper fishery’. Section 50 of the Statutory Instruments Act 1992 enables the disallowance of subordinate legislation, including a provision of subordinate legislation. Standing order 59 provides for notices of motion for the disallowance of ‘a statutory instrument or guideline pursuant to an Act’.

Such motions, which have legal consequences, require precision. The member’s motion lacks particularity sufficient to constitute a disallowance motion, as it fails to identify which instrument is to be disallowed. Such motions should specify the name and number of the instrument or instruments to be disallowed. Reference to the empowering provision of the primary act is insufficient as there may be many instruments made pursuant to a power. I therefore rule that the notice of motion is out of order.
Resumed.

Mr ELMES (Noosa--LNP)
(2.31 pm): I rise to extend condolences on my own behalf and on behalf of every single person living in the electorate of Noosa to those Queenslanders who have lost loved ones as a result of the floods and cyclones which have affected Queensland in this terrible past few weeks. All of us in Noosa, indeed all of us on the Sunshine Coast, simply count our blessings as having been largely spared from the effects of these extreme weather events. Yes, there has been some minor flooding and some wind damage, but it is inconsequential in the scheme of things. We have been fortunate and we know how fortunate we have been and we give thanks for that good fortune.

I am, at the same time, proud of the members of my community who have extended even their widely respected great capacity to give of themselves in the service of others. They have raised tens of thousands of dollars and gifted countless items to replace clothing and household items lost to flood and to wind. They have started, albeit in a small way, the long process of recovery for the victims which will be a long, slow, painful process.

Before I came into this place my career was in commercial radio and wholly in Queensland. It is from this perspective that I have seen over the years on a firsthand basis the impact of floods. While Brisbane was suffering the terrible effects of the floods of 1974, I was based in Mount Isa where it and the rest of the great north-west was being flooded. A couple of years later it was Warwick being flooded. In 1981 it was Dalby. A couple of years after that it was Emerald experiencing, by comparison to these recent events, minor flooding.

For many years I was associated with radio stations in Gympie and Noosa and saw a number of floods come and go in Gympie, particularly the dreadful 1999 event where the Mary River reached 21.95 metres. For most of these events I was on-air reporting and bringing the news to the rest of the community. But in Warwick and Dalby I, with many of my colleagues, were on the ground, part of the community force, cleaning up in the aftermath. The smell, the slime, the broken dreams and the destroyed lives I will never forget.

This very personal reflection is a preamble to the conclusion that I had reached. That conclusion was that genuinely I thought I had seen it all before. Nothing could possibly prepare one for what has affected this state since December 2010. Who could have imagined that a flood of any description could occur in Toowoomba--on top of the Great Dividing Range? We have all seen the TV footage of what took place there. But not even Hollywood could have envisaged, could have created with all the digital technology at its disposal, images which we have watched open-mouthed in horror and in tears. We are probably fortunate that footage is not readily available of the worst events--those in the Lockyer Valley; communities where the lives of decent Queenslanders have been so tragically and prematurely lost.

I had the opportunity to travel to flood affected St George with my leader, John-Paul Langbroek, where, with the member for Warrego, Howard Hobbs, we spoke to a great many locals who were hastily preparing for the river to peak, which it did later that night at 13. 2 metres. As is the case in many areas, a flood is not unusual. But the degree of preparedness which this local council and the community achieved was outstanding. The existing levy system and the temporary levies are outstanding examples of local communities under strong leadership moving to protect themselves from the consequences of the will of Mother Nature.

The flooding in Central Queensland, the south-west, the Darling Downs and the Lockyer Valley and then in Ipswich and in Brisbane was breathtaking in its scope, the destruction of infrastructure and the loss of life. But then monster Cyclone Yasi appeared, which in a different way attacked without mercy that part of our state so far spared from the ravages of flood.

In Far North Queensland, again with the Leader of the Opposition, I travelled extensively within the electorate of Hinchinbrook. My colleague Andrew Cripps, as members know, spoke very movingly yesterday during the condolence motion in this House.

Floods normally leave structures relatively intact. That did not occur on this occasion, as we have seen. The evidence of violence visited upon these little communities was everywhere: stumps where a home once stood, banana crops severed uniformly a metre above the ground, cane fields bowed, mutilated and twisted. Who will ever forget the site of the Hinchinbrook marina with millions of dollars worth of water craft stacked higgledy-piggledy?

Queensland has experienced cyclones Tasha, Anthony and Yasi, floods of Noah proportions across 70 per cent of a vast state and reflooding of many local areas--in the case of Dalby, five times--and storm surges. Toowoomba fell victim to an inland tsunami. In the graphic words of Police Commissioner Atkinson, ‘It seems we have experienced a series of one in 100-year events almost simultaneously.’ Certainly the areas around Cardwell have seen Cyclone Larry in 2006 and Cyclone Yasi only a few years later. Those people must be asking themselves why and how.

How do older residents start again? Small businesses have been devastated. My wife’s parents have a business in Emerald which suffered losses in excess of $100,000 but whose pain would have been so much worse without the selfless generosity of strangers who simply came in and helped them prepare and clean up. Can I say to members in the House that if anyone is looking for a sewing machine, the Peter Taylor Sewing Centre is open for business.

From where do young families who have lost everything but the mortgage get the courage to rebuild their lives? From where do they get the courage to get up, dust themselves off and start all over again?

We have been very fortunate to have seen some great leadership on display during this heartbreaking summer to date. It is from strong leadership that those who have been so adversely affected maintain their spirit. We have seen and paid tribute to the Premier and to the Lord Mayor of Brisbane who have been at the forefront. I also want to thank the Leader of the Opposition who has crisscrossed the state, too often unseen, and lent support in a very personal way to so many victims.

It is visits such as his and those by Governor-General Quentin Bryce and Governor Penelope Wensley and other high-profile community leaders which give comfort to those who have suffered loss. For those victims not to feel forgotten and abandoned it is imperative that these visits to comfort and support do not stop any time soon, and certainly not before the job is done.

I take this opportunity to pay a very special tribute to the member for Lockyer, Ian Rickuss, and his wife, Ann, for their leadership and tireless work within their community, arguably the most adversely affected of all. As the shadow minister for police and emergency services, I offer my heartfelt thanks to police, firefighters and Queensland Ambulance Service personnel who have given so much. The Defence Force personnel and the interstate contingents, both professional and volunteers, including those police who became special constables, have my personal gratitude.

Queensland could not function without its volunteers, the SES, the rural firefighters and the other support agencies which have done so much for so many. I particularly recall the lift that the Red Cross gave when they arrived in Tully. They were there under the leadership of Greg Goebel and performed an absolutely vital service, while Volunteering Queensland and of course the Salvation Army rose to the occasion as we expect from such fine organisations.

It would be remiss of me not to acknowledge the contribution of the Minister for Police, Corrective Services and Emergency Services, the Hon. Neil Roberts, who went about his duty in a calm, reassuring and professional manner. I also acknowledge David Smith from the minister’s office who ensured that I, as the shadow minister, and local members from affected areas were kept completely up to date.

We should also acknowledge the preplanning which is not on display in normal times but which becomes so evident in times like we have just witnessed. Clearly, the rapid response by our emergency services indicates that they have been diligent and coordinated in preparing to meet the challenges which this wide brown land of sweeping plains, of drought and flooding rains can present. Members from electorates which have been affected have rightly praised their local heroes. I would just like to add that, for me, Jordan Rice is the epitome of a selfless hero. What a man in a boy’s body.

While the immediate danger has passed for the time being, the effects of these tragedies will continue for a long time. Those people in the Lockyer who struggle to survive day to day have not had time to grieve. Grieving is an essential human emotion. It is essential that those individuals, families and communities which suffered so much do have time--preferably sooner rather than later--to grieve properly and fully. They will need to know that we support them while they meet that raw need.

Many of those children who heard Yasi coming, experienced the calm of the eye and then heard the coming of the other side of the cyclone will be fearful for many years to come at the sound of modest wind or a coming storm. We can rebuild the houses, the offices, the schools, the roads, the railways, the airports and the marinas. We can reconnect the electricity and resupply fresh water. What we cannot replenish easily is the faith and trust that children have in the safety of their own home. Children should be able to go home and feel safe when they can go nowhere else.

In coming days we will be learning the lessons from what we have experienced in Queensland. We will be looking at insurance at the state level and at a personal and domestic level. We will be looking at public infrastructure and what we might do, as an example, to floodproof the Bruce Highway. We will be looking at dam management and what more can be done to simultaneously provide drinking water and mitigate against flooding, balancing both aims. We will be looking at planning decisions to protect homes and businesses from flooding. We will be looking at building standards to protect our built environment from destruction. And we will be looking for synergies in public buildings to act as refuges when all else fails. In short, we in this place will be the front line of ensuring that children feel safe in their own homes in the future and that the lessons of these tragedies and this adversity are not lost. That must be our overriding priority.

Hansard-Body.A: (Pumicestone--ALP) (2.43 pm): On behalf of all the residents in the electorate of Pumicestone whom I represent, I offer my sincere condolences to the families who lost loved ones during what has been described as this country’s worst natural disaster. My heart goes out to everyone who lost everything and have to somehow rebuild their shattered lives. I was deeply distressed by and I will always remember the television footage of entire communities being devastated by the recent floods. I know that everyone will remember this time as a time of extreme sadness. The loss of life, property, infrastructure, businesses, jobs, animals and land will be felt for many, many years to come, and our patience will be tested while this government, with the help of Queenslanders, works to rebuild the 75 per cent of the state that has been affected by floods and more recently by Cyclone Yasi.

XML.Hansard-Body: Some homes in the electorate of Pumicestone were flooded a couple of days before Brisbane was inundated. We sustained minor damage compared to other areas, but these people whose homes were flooded needed assistance to help them recover. I am very proud to say that this help came immediately from the Bligh government’s recovery team and from donations from the community. My sincere thanks go to the volunteers who helped me collect and distribute food, clothing and toiletries. The Seventh-day Adventist Church and the Caboolture and Bribie Island Christian Outreach Centres put in many hours to ensure those who needed goods received them. I appreciated the efforts of Jamie Purcell from the recycling depot for keeping his eye out for items that could help me replace lost property. I thank everyone who helped in any way. I seek leave to table a list of everyone who offered to help.
Leave granted.
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: January 2011 Flood Donors List--Pumicestone [ 3940 ].
XML.Hansard-Body: Mrs SULLIVAN: I thank everyone who offered to help when I asked for assistance to clean and mow. For example, we received the help of three youngsters from Bribie Island: Nick Freney, Ben Hansell and 16-year-old Josh Walker. I thank those who helped with teaching resources for the Brassall State School, which lost everything. I would like to particularly thank Danielle Hartmann, who was transferred to a school in Burketown and who said to me, ‘Here, have my resources. I can buy more.’ As a retired teacher I can say that I would have been proud to call those resources my own; they were brilliant and they were in excellent condition. There were 92 schools affected and we could help only one.

I would also like to thank those who provided toiletries for the evacuation centres in Ipswich West and Bundamba. I still have a good-quality, second-hand queen size bed if anyone knows anybody who needs one. The list of helpers is lengthy and does not include all of those in my electorate who donated money to the Premier’s flood appeal. I could not take cash through the office, but I did suggest that anyone who wanted to give money should go to the bank. I recall one lady who did not have a car so I picked her up and took her to the nearest bank. When we arrived back at her house, she emptied her bathroom cupboards to help with the toiletries drive, and she is an age pensioner who is privately renting.

The Bribie Gleemen, as usual, took it upon themselves to organise a concert, with all the proceeds going to the flood appeal. Their concert, with the assistance of the Bribie Island Big Band and the Uke Dukes, raised $4,000--an incredible individual effort and one that is greatly appreciated. The Gleemen have put on a concert in aid of every natural disaster since 2006, and there have been plenty--seven alone in Queensland.

The bill for the devastation is enormous and it is mounting. To put it into perspective, one rescue helicopter costs $1,000 an hour. How can we pay for the loss of 30 years worth of infrastructure, services and facilities? At the same time we are also losing coal royalties, so we as a government are being hit at both ends: we have less money coming in and we have more money going out. It will take years and everybody’s commitment, and our patience will be tested.

Those areas like mine which suffered very little will feel some pain in the future. Some projects may be delayed while government resources go to those communities which have lost everything. Already we have been told that some existing sport and recreation grant programs will be either cancelled or restarted at a later date to help with the flood and cyclone recovery efforts, which include assisting sport and recreation clubs to re-establish lost facilities. My constituents are very understanding of this unprecedented predicament, and I trust that they will continue to support the measures taken by this government to rebuild Queensland.

I am pleased that I was able to travel to Bundamba after the assistance was given in my own electorate. I find it hard to describe the devastation and the smell, but in one of the streets where all the homes went underwater there was a sign on the very top of a large pile of flood affected belongings which read ‘My life is on my lawn’.
I take this opportunity to congratulate and thank Sinead Burgess, a young talented local artist who wrote a beautiful song at 1 am.
Mr Ryan interjected.

Mrs SULLIVAN: I take that interjection from the member for Morayfield, who has heard Sinead Burgess at many local events in the community. I agree with him: she is one of the most wonderful performers and a very talented girl in the electorate of Pumicestone. She wrote a beautiful song at one o’clock in the morning after seeing the Toowoomba flood footage. Her song is titled Rise Above the Tide . It is an inspirational tribute to all of those who were affected and all of those who came to the aid of flood victims. As Sinead sings, Queensland will rise above the tide.

Hansard-Body.A: (Greenslopes--ALP) (Attorney-General and Minister for Industrial Relations) (2.49 pm): I rise to speak on this condolence motion to pay my respects to those who lost their lives in the floods that devastated so much of Queensland during the summer of 2010 and 2011. The events that have unfolded in the past two months have emphasised, if any was needed, just why we are bred differently north of the New South Wales border. On one hand we enjoy a climate and lifestyle that at times is reflected perfectly by those well-known tourism slogans that have helped us become so popular beyond our borders. But, on the other hand, we all know that life in Queensland cannot be conveniently captured in a postcard. In a very short space of time nature’s wrath can inflict unimaginable devastation upon our communities, and so it was across our great state in late December 2010, January 2011 and February 2011.

XML.Hansard-Body: In a few short weeks the majesty and privilege of living in the best state in the best country in the world was quickly contrasted with the terror brought on by the extreme weather events that affected so many of our fellow Queenslanders. In particular, the scenes that occurred on Monday, 10 January 2011 in Toowoomba and the Lockyer Valley defied belief. Cars were tossed around in floodwaters like toys, houses were swept from their stumps and, worst of all, families were torn apart. None of us will forget the bravery of 13-year-old Jordan Rice, who urged a rescuer to save his brother from rising floodwaters first. Those floodwaters stole Jordan and his mum, Donna, from us and tore a family in two. Unfortunately, these tragic circumstances were repeated throughout the Lockyer Valley as another terrible wave of water, described as an inland tsunami, swept through communities without warning. One minute Queenslanders in these communities were going about their lives and daily routines, as we all were on that fateful day; the next they were grappling with the threat posed by a broiling, surging swell of horror and heartbreak. It is impossible to imagine the terror.

However, in equal measure Queenslanders have borne witness to extraordinary acts of courage and determination in the aftermath of these terrible natural disasters. From the Lockyer Valley to Lakes Creek in Rockhampton, from Condamine to Cardwell, from Karalee and Rosalie to Theodore and Tully, from Bundaberg and Bundamba and Goodna and Ingham to the southside Brisbane suburbs of Rocklea, Fairfield, Norman Park and Oxley, and to communities such as Fernvale and Lowood, we have seen the true Queensland spirit come to the fore in the wake of these disasters. We have also witnessed courage and compassion from friends, neighbours and complete strangers that make all of us proud to be Queenslanders. This spirit has also been evident among staff of the Department of Justice and Attorney-General, some of whom bore the brunt of the recent natural disasters.

In difficult times during the past few weeks departmental staff distinguished themselves by continuing to serve the people of Queensland with a level of dedication beyond the call of duty. I had the privilege to speak to the courthouse registrars in many flood affected areas including Gatton, Pittsworth, Dalby, Chinchilla, Warwick, Goondiwindi, Stanthorpe and Taroom. Those registrars and other court staff stayed at their posts and continued to serve the people of Queensland, even as floodwaters threatened their communities. Among them was Mark Koszan, the registrar at the Gatton courthouse. Mark chose to sleep at the courthouse after the terrible flood that affected the Lockyer Valley because, as Mark told me, he just wanted to be able to help anyone in need and answer any queries from members of the public if required. These acts of dedication and commitment in difficult and sometimes traumatic circumstances, which were repeated right across the Public Service and across our state in so many fields of endeavour and in difficult circumstances, are too numerous to mention. But those countless acts of courage and kindness and bravery and endurance, as articulated by so many members in their support for this condolence motion, will inspire citizens of this state for years to come.

This same spirit was evident in the hordes of volunteers who have put their hands up to help out their fellow Queenslanders in the wake of these disasters. Here in the south-east this spirit was exemplified by the tens of thousands of people who spontaneously reached out to complete strangers and kick-started the flood recovery in so many streets and suburbs. But we should also acknowledge the numerous other volunteers who contributed during these disasters--the orange army of SES teams, the Red Cross volunteers in the evacuation and recovery centres, and the countless community groups that pitched in without question. Volunteering has always been an important part of my life and all Queenslanders can be proud of their achievements in recent weeks. I want to make special mention of the extraordinary response from residents within the electorate of Greenslopes. Fortunately, the electorate of Greenslopes was spared from the worst effects of this extreme weather, but that is not to say the electorate survived the floods unscathed. There were a number of homes in Norman Park in particular that were affected by the rising brown tide of floodwaters. For those people who had to throw out furniture, rip up carpets and get the muddy water out of their homes, the flood had a significant impact. It was depressing to see someone’s life reduced to a pile of rubbish on the footpath, although we all realised that others were much more affected.

I am pleased to advise the House that many residents in the Greenslopes electorate made the effort to help out their neighbours in response to the floods. Numerous volunteers contacted my office to ask how they could help out. As the floodwaters rose, I joined a band of willing workers to help sandbag homes in Riddings Street in Coorparoo. I also doorknocked parts of Temple, Jellicoe and Burke streets in Coorparoo as local creeks started to rise. After the floodwaters peaked, the volunteers and I headed to Adina Street, Norman Park, where we helped residents take the first steps towards recovery. When our assistance was no longer required, the group and I headed off to other southside suburbs such as Fairfield and Oxley, where there was enormous damage to property. Among the people who helped out were Yvette, Ross and Trent Abberfield; Michael Beckett; Katherine Eames; Andrew Elphinstone; Simon Hammer; Michelle and Rod Massy; James Oliver; Jonathon Ring; Matthew Sellers; Zosia Kilmartin; John Denny; and Joe Kelly.

This same spirit of cooperation was evident at the evacuation centre that was established at the Queensland Sports and Athletics Centre, better known as the QEII Stadium to many southsiders like me. I spent an evening helping set up camp stretchers to make the place ready for the hundreds of flood refugees who had to take shelter while the floodwaters rose around their homes. It was both humbling and heart warming to see the best of humanity on display during the floods crisis.

But the generosity of southside residents did not stop there. As the floodwaters receded and the impacts were fully revealed, it became apparent that many schoolchildren were going to start the school year with little in the way of school books and other materials. I put out a call within my electorate for donations of stationery for schoolchildren in flood affected areas, and the response was remarkable. Just four days after issuing the request, my office was like a de facto stationery warehouse. Virtually every available square centimetre of floor space was covered with bags and boxes of books, pens, rulers, rubbers, glue sticks, knapsacks and even lunch boxes and water bottles. In all, the donated stationery was worth about $8,000--a staggering response from residents and community groups from the southside suburbs. One very savvy community group, the MacGregor Lions, whose membership included a former school principal, even went to the trouble of separating its donation in year levels. There was a bag containing materials suitable for year 1 students, a bag of materials for year 2 students, a bag for year 3 students and so on. The principal at the school could not believe the generosity and thoughtfulness of these gifts when we dropped them off. In the end, we needed a convoy of four cars to deliver the stationery to the Bundamba State School in the electorate of Ipswich and Redbank Plains State School in the electorate of Bundamba, and more stationery supplies will be on their way soon to the badly affected electorate of Ipswich West.

I would like to thank everyone who contributed to the great Greenslopes stationery drive. In particular, I would like to mention some of the community groups that responded to my request. These groups included the Greater Mount Gravatt-Mansfield Lions; MacGregor Lions; Father Dimitri Tsakas from the Greek Orthodox Church at South Brisbane as well as the broader Greek community of South Brisbane even though they were struggling from the impact of floodwaters; southside mums from the Brisbane Family Day Care service; Julie Fox and her brother Chris Fox from the Greenslopes newsagency in the Greenslopes Mall where I did my first ‘Walk a day in my shoes’ stint; Australian Merchandisers; AgriFood Skills Australia; Officeworks’s Canberra warehouse; GHD, the engineering and professional services firm; the Community and Public Sector Union; the Workplace Health and Safety Queensland office at Lutwyche; and Queensland South Native Title Services.

Of course, the generosity of the Greenslopes community did not end with the flood clean-up or the stationery drive. I am pleased to report that almost 200 residents attended the Great Greenslopes Australia Day Sausage Sizzle at Easts Junior Rugby League Club in Holland Park on 26 January 2011. This event managed to raise almost $2,000 to contribute to the Premier’s Disaster Relief Appeal. Special mention must go to Easts Junior Rugby League Club, which hosted the event without charge and also donated the day’s bar takings. I also wish to thank the members of the Lions clubs from Holland Park and Greater Mount Gravatt-Mansfield who cooked hundreds of sausages on the day.

Along with numerous individuals who generously donated such as Eva Key and the Wynola Girl Guides group from Coorparoo, other supporters of the great Greenslopes sausage sizzle included Greg Purcell from Meat You Here butchery in the Greenslopes Mall; Shantelle McCudden from Baker’s Delight in the Greenslopes Mall; Tony Merlino and Dot Smith from Coles at the Greenslopes Mall; Andrew Nicolau from JJ’s Fruit Shop in the Greenslopes Mall; Clarence Wong from Brumby’s at Mount Gravatt; Dearne Maxwell at Contours gym in Greenslopes; Dan O’Kane from Dan Murphy’s at Holland Park; Sonya Smith at Video Ezy in Greenslopes; Susan Meehan from Objects d’ at the Greenslopes Mall; Renee Dawson at Andrews Light Up at Mount Gravatt; Peter Weiss from LJ Hooker at Coorparoo; Cass Conwell from All About Health and Body; and Paul Windsor from Vintage Cellars at Stones Corner. This is the sort of community spirit that makes the south side such a great place to live.

As we begin the long journey to recovery from these devastating natural disasters, I am reminded of the words of the disciple Paul to the Christians of Rome--‘Rejoice in hope, be patient in tribulation, persevere in prayer’. We must all be patient and persevere as we recover from these terrible disasters. But I have faith that the Queensland spirit will prevail. On behalf of myself, my family and the residents of the state electorate of Greenslopes, I express my sincere condolences to those who have suffered, and who continue to struggle, at this difficult time.

Hon. S ROBERTSON (Stretton--ALP) (Minister for Natural Resources, Mines and Energy and Minister for Trade) (3.00 pm): Whilst my electorate of Stretton was physically untouched by the January floods, that does not mean that my constituents were untouched by the suffering of their fellow Queenslanders. I have often spoken of how proud I am to represent one of Australia’s most multicultural electorates and time and time again over many years these multicultural communities have been among the first to dig deep into their own pockets to help those who have been impacted by natural disasters. Whether that be raising funds for the victims of the Christchurch earthquake last year, the Victorian bushfires of 2009, the terrible floods in Pakistan, Cyclone Larry in 2006, the earthquakes in Taiwan and southern China and, of course, in 2009 the terrible tsunami that struck Samoa and other Pacific islands as well as the earthquake that hit Indonesia, the various ethnic, cultural and religious groups that make up the Stretton electorate have mobilised quickly and efficiently to dispense comfort and aid to the victims of these terrible natural events.

Today I want to take the opportunity provided by this condolence motion to pay special recognition to these multicultural groups. Over the years I have marvelled at the generosity of spirit and giving of the Taiwanese community. These new Australians first started to migrate to our country in the late 1980s under the Hawke government’s business migration scheme. Entrepreneurial by nature, successful businesspeople in their country of origin, this community has established itself as a vital and visible component of the outer south side of Brisbane. The variety of community groups they have established separately and together have raised hundreds of thousands of dollars in flood aid.

The Taiwan Friendship Association of Queensland, the Taiwan Women’s League of Queensland, the Taiwanese Chamber of Commerce, the Hakka Association of Queensland as well as the Taipei Office of Economic and Cultural Affairs have all gone about the business of fundraising quietly, efficiently and with a compassion that can only be admired. Just as generous have been those constituents from the People’s Republic of China and Chinese communities from other parts of Asia. The fundraising efforts of the Mainland Chinese Society of Queensland, the Cathay Club in combination with the Sunnybank RSL, as well as the work of the Chinese Consulate to support Chinese tourists in Cairns during Cyclone Yasi all deserve mention and our thanks.

Many of my Chinese constituents are practising Buddhists and have established vibrant and popular temples and orders to allow them to practise their faith. The Chung Tian Temple and Buddha’s Light International Association have established a proud tradition of mobilising substantial physical and financial resources whenever a need arises. The Tzu Chi Foundation has worked tirelessly in the Bundamba electorate and in southern Brisbane suburbs ministering aid and assistance to those most vulnerable.

Over the past few years Australia’s business migration program has delivered to my electorate new constituents from other parts of the world--from India, Pakistan, South Africa, Fiji, Zimbabwe, Botswana, Egypt, Lebanon, Bosnia, Saudi Arabia and the Arab Emirates. Predominantly Muslim by religion, this community has also demonstrated a generosity of spirit, a commitment to helping their fellow Queenslanders and a love of their new home. The Islamic Council of Queensland, the Muslim Charitable Foundation, the Islamic College of Brisbane at Karawatha and the various mosques and Crescents of Brisbane have all raised significant funds for the cause and often in cooperation with other non-Muslim organisations such as the Lions Club of Kuraby and I understand that their fundraising efforts have not finished.

I have deliberately not mentioned individuals as there are too many to list and no doubt I will leave some out. But I will mention one: Mohammed Sayed Dawoodjee, a trustee of the Kuraby Mosque, who one week before the floods hit Brisbane made a significant donation on behalf of the Kuraby Mosque to the Premier and me for the victims of the Central Queensland floods. Then one week later Mohammed’s own business, Rocklea Cold Storage and Distribution, was inundated completely and its future is now in question. When I visited Mohammed at his Rocklea business his concern was not so much for his own future but for the 70 small businesses that rely on his cold stores to store and distribute their products. It is this concern for our fellow man in time of distress and hurt that has typified all of the efforts of my wonderful multicultural electorate of Stretton. I recognise and thank them all, including the many other community organisations and individuals, and simply say that it is an absolute honour to represent such a generous electorate.

Earlier today I mentioned the heroic efforts of the South East Queensland Water Mount Crosby treatment plant team. I want to expand on those comments during the course of my contribution. I again would like to pay tribute to the truly heroic work of these 19 Seqwater staffers and contractors who braved horrific conditions to make sure that our drinking water continued to flow--water we take for granted every time we turn on a tap.

Much of Brisbane’s drinking water is treated at the Mount Crosby water treatment plants and pumping stations in Brisbane’s western suburbs. This critical infrastructure is spread over two sites: the east bank and the west bank plants. Following the rains and extreme flooding that inundated the Brisbane River catchment and tributaries, the river was awash with debris, silt and other rubbish, making it extremely turbid. The severe raw water conditions, as the experts call them, were so bad that both treatment plants were shut down. On Wednesday, 12 January, rising floodwaters had completely isolated the east bank plant. The pump station and its raw water wells--one of them to the depth of around eight storeys, or more than 40 metres underground--were flooded.

Up at Mount Crosby Weir the flood level was only about a metre below the 1974 levels and I am sure the House understands the severity of that situation. The next day, Thursday the 13th, maintenance staff were flown by helicopter into the facility in a New South Wales Fire and Rescue chopper at 6 am. Their entry was dramatic and what they found looked like something out of a Hollywood disaster movie. Light circuits were blown and light fittings were filled with water. The dewatering bilge pumps were inundated and all the line shaft and thrust bearings--the machinery fundamental to supplying clean tap-water to the people of Brisbane--were filled completely with mud, silt and water. The plant was in terrible shape and without speedy repairs Brisbane’s access to clean, drinkable water would have been threatened. The maintenance team members toiled in horrendous conditions while filthy water rained down on them. It was pitch black, extremely humid and the floors and ladders were slippery with fetid mud. With torches in their mouths, team members crawled on their chests through mud and filth deep down into the subfloor to access vital dewatering pumps and to overhaul mechanical and electrical equipment.

The east bank plant was built in the 1890s and Seqwater staff were definitely drawing on old school fitter and turner skills to get the plant back up and running. This was a situation that none of the workers had faced before and the textbooks were certainly thrown out the window. Twelve hours later at 6 pm the crew was airlifted out. The wells had been pumped out and that evening provided some crucial drying time for temperature probes and safety sensors. At 6 am the next day, the crews were back at the treatment plants to continue their work. Shortly after 10 am that day they succeeded in bringing two pumps back online to help provide more than 100 megalitres of raw water for treatment and supply to the grid.

But the work did not end there. The workers’ tireless efforts meant that by Saturday nine raw water pumps were back online, capable of delivering more than 450 megalitres for treatment. At the same time a team of 20 Seqwater staff were hard at work at the isolated Mount Crosby Water Treatment Plant. These were staff who were stranded after rising floodwaters cut roads. Rather than bemoaning their lot or sitting around waiting to be airlifted out, they got stuck in and did the hard work to ensure that the plant was able to continue to deliver treated water into the water grid. Staff were also hard at work repairing the Lowood and Kilcoy water treatment plants. At Kilcoy, it was ordinary rank-and-file community members rolling up their sleeves to help staff bring the plant back online.

I recently visited the Mount Crosby Water Treatment Plant and I had the opportunity to experience the cramped, claustrophobic conditions firsthand. However, when I visited the lights were on, the humidity manageable and the facility was not awash with foul mud and water. Heroism knows many forms and what we saw at Mount Crosby was true heroism. It was only through the remarkable grit, ingenuity and selflessness of the Seqwater staff that Brisbane’s drinking water supply was able to be secured. In less than a day and a half these 19 workers were able to take the plant from a situation where it was unable to produce any water to where it was able to supply the entire grid. Their efforts saved authorities from having to issue ‘boil water’ alerts across much of South-East Queensland. The loss of drinking water supply would have significantly compounded the havoc of the extreme flood event as well as hampering the early recovery process. These men at Seqwater are, in one sense, ordinary Queenslanders who, in the hour of the state’s greatest need, were called upon to do something truly extraordinary, something few people would be able to do and even less would be willing to do.

Many Queenslanders can tell similar tales of jobs that needed to be done and people putting their hands up, willing to help out. We are not out of the woods yet. The recovery is still in its very early days and we still face difficult months ahead. Queensland has never faced a challenge quite like this, but I know that the men and women of this great state are undaunted. Life will go on and we will rebuild.

On a somewhat lighter note, this morning the Premier mentioned the generosity coming from overseas. As members will know, I am a great fan of the round-ball game--the true football. It was with somewhat mixed feelings that I learned about an initiative by the Glasgow Celtic Football Club. I have to say that it is not my club of choice. If I were pushed, I would back the Blues rather than the Hoops. Celtic toured Australia back in 2009 and played a very entertaining match against the Brisbane Roar at Suncorp Stadium. Celtic remembered the warmth of their time here in Brisbane and, as a result of that, decided to put up for auction the signed jerseys of a recent match. The mixed feelings I have are because it just happened to be the match in which they played my home team--my place of birth--Aberdeen. On that occasion Celtic, as they have done on four occasions this season, gave us a towelling.

I learned yesterday that, as a result of the auction of those signed jerseys, they have raised £5,000 which will go to the Premier’s Disaster Relief Appeal. Again with mixed feelings I have recently discovered that I will be the recipient of one of those jerseys through the generosity of Professor John Fraser, who is one of Australia’s best heart surgeons. John is a Glasgow Celtic fan of many, many years. I am somewhat pleased to say that his choice was a jersey of a former Aberdeen player, so the hurt and embarrassment are not complete. I place on record my thanks for the generosity of Glasgow Celtic in this initiative. It is greatly appreciated. The many Scots who make up Queensland, many of whom would have been impacted by these floods, would certainly appreciate their generosity as well.

Mr STEVENS (Mermaid Beach--LNP)
(3.12 pm): I rise today with a heavy heart to join with my parliamentary colleagues in supporting this motion of condolence and acknowledging one of the most devastating periods of natural disaster in Queensland’s history. My electorate of Mermaid Beach was not affected directly by the recent natural disasters. For a change, the Gold Coast miraculously escaped water damage of any great magnitude. However, as shadow minister for tourism and racing I have watched in disbelief the devastating effects of the disastrous floods and cyclones all over Queensland. I express my sincere condolences to all of the families who have suffered the greatest tragedy of all, that being the loss of loved ones--in some cases having them ripped from their arms in the most heartbreaking of circumstances.

To all those who have lost their homes and the possessions they have accumulated over a lifetime I give my sincere, heartfelt sympathies. This period in Queensland’s history will be remembered as its annus horribilis and comprises a series of events combined that I cannot fully comprehend as to its total devastation. To have disaster on top of disaster is inconceivable. But as we all know, we should never underestimate the commanding and unknown powers of the forces of Mother Nature.

The Premier, to her great credit, advised Queenslanders last year of the impending La Niña pattern and weather conditions forecast for this summer period. She warned of the possibility of cyclones for the summer season. Little did she know how right she was and what the future would hold for the state of Queensland and for her.

Personally, I would like to acknowledge the dedicated and unwavering support and commitment of our emergency services personnel, including the Queensland Ambulance Service, the SES, the Fire and Rescue Service; our volunteer St John Ambulance officers, who themselves treated 6,500 people across the state; our swift-water rescue teams; the Police Service; our Defence Force personnel; public and private sector employees; the thousands of mud army volunteers; all other volunteer organisations; and the courageous Queensland community, who came out in the time of crisis to help their fellow man. I would also like to make special mention of all of our interstate emergency personnel and volunteers who ventured across borders to help Queenslanders in need when we most needed them. In many cases it was a reciprocation of our emergency services helping other states during bushfires, but it was and is greatly appreciated.

I congratulate the Leader of the Opposition, John-Paul Langbroek, on his steely resolve to remove politics from this devastating misadventure and to concentrate only on making a great personal effort across all affected areas of Queensland with his personal appearance at every catastrophic site. He did not chase the media for self-indulgence at a time when a higher need for empathy with disenfranchised Queenslanders prevailed as his No. 1 priority. The response was overwhelming and exceptional and the generosity of spirit will live with us forever. It has been truly inspiring and has renewed our faith in humanity.

The tourism industry is suffering enormously from the devastating effects of the recent natural disasters. I congratulate the government on the $10 million advertising package promised for the industry to tell the rest of Australia and the world that our tourism industry is open for business. As I looked at the images of a devastated Dunk Island, I reflected on the trip my wife and I took to Dunk to celebrate our wedding anniversary in January just a couple of years ago. We had the most wonderful time any tourist could want from any destination in the world. To see the atomic-bomb flattening of the facilities on Dunk made my heart cry for the poor owner, who has the herculean task of building it up all over again.

Not only will tourism infrastructure and facilities take time to replace; the fractured image of our mighty tourism industry in Australia will take time to repair. Even areas that were unaffected by floodwater damage require immediate investment to restore confidence and their reputation as destinations that are open for business right now. The $10 million is a great start, but I call on the state and federal governments to back industry requests for a $50 million rescue package for the tourism industry. The size of the industry in Queensland and its importance to the Queensland and Australian governments make it imperative to invest in protecting tourism jobs and tourism infrastructure. This financial support will be critical to the rebuilding of the tourism industry, which is worth $9.2 billion to our economy and which directly and indirectly employs 220,000 people.

The tourism areas of Mission Beach and Dunk Island were hardest hit, along with Yeppoon, Airlie Beach and the Whitsundays, with the devastating effects of both cyclones reaching up and down this region of the coast of Queensland. I support the head of the Queensland Tourism Industry Council, Mr Daniel Gschwind, in his comments that the spirit of Queenslanders through these disasters should be the inspiration and centrepiece for the new tourism industry campaign. In his words, ‘it’s not just the never-say-die attitude and the laconic humour but the absolute efficiency in getting stuck in and not just surviving a disaster but building confidence’ that will drive our tourism industry to the forefront of our economic generators when the world realises the cyclone threats have passed. What the tourism industry needs in order to restore businesses is to build confidence. The new slogan ‘Queensland... Ready to welcome you’ says it all. I commend Tourism Queensland for the development of this promotion and for its strict time frame in disseminating this message as soon as possible.

The racing industry was also hit hard and the clean-up effort at Callaghan Park racetrack has been significant and very difficult. With the community banding together, we have seen a light at the end of the tunnel and race days will resume from 19 March 2011. I emphasise my unqualified congratulations to the Racing Queensland board on its immediate response of providing a rescue package to industry participants in the Rockhampton area to tide them over until their jobs and the local industry come back online. The racing industry gathered together for a fundraising event for the floods. I was very humbled to be a part of the bipartisan efforts, given so freely, at this and hundreds of other fundraising events across Queensland. Across the state Queenslanders were magnanimous in their giving, with many not only supporting fundraising events but also volunteering to clean up their local turf clubs. The particular event I went to raised $126,000 and I congratulate all involved in the organisation of that event. Other country tracks, such as at Taroom, were completely obliterated.

I commend Racing Queensland for its support of the racing industry in Queensland following the disasters. I implore it to continue in a benevolent frame of mind to ensure country race clubs can continue to provide social interaction and community fabric for isolated areas, long after the flood damaged racecourses have been repaired.
