We need to continue to band together as the next stage in our recovery is our healing. When our communities have finished the physicality of rebuilding homes and community infrastructure, which we know is going to take a very long time, we need to take positive steps to learn from nature’s cruel and frightening lessons.

The psychological effects of such devastating events need to be addressed as a community. If it is just phoning a friend or relative who has been affected by the recent events to see how they are going, then please do so. That ongoing support is just as important as the physical clean-up work. You might think it is small, but it gives people the opportunity to talk to someone about the pain that they may be going through. This will help Queenslanders so much in their recovery. Through this, as a state we will become stronger and more resilient than ever before. I wholeheartedly support the condolence motion before the House. I reiterate my deepest sympathies to all those who lost loved ones in this very cruel fashion.

Mr DOWLING (Redlands--LNP) (3.22 pm): I rise to speak to the motion of condolence to Queensland’s natural disaster victims moved by the Premier and offer my wholehearted sympathies to families suffering loss. Queensland has witnessed flood and cyclone events that are hard to imagine. Those events had the ability to bend us to their will but not to break us, nor will they break the Queensland spirit. We have heard many examples of courage, bravery, dedication, commitment and generosity unequalled in our history. The events of late 2010 and early 2011 will continue to reshape Queensland. Queenslanders will not be daunted or put off their resolve to rebuild their part of Queensland stronger and better than it was. The strength of Queenslanders is drawn from our common love of our state and of our fellow Queenslander and a belief in our own ability and our own capability. Strength comes in many forms. However, it begins when people stand up to be counted.

As the events unfolded around the state, people from my electorate began calling and asking, ‘How can I help?’ Just like the rain, the calls kept coming from more and more volunteers. Redlanders were not affected by the floods, but we were very affected by the images on our TVs of the events of December and January. I want to pay special tribute to a few volunteers who worked tirelessly to help affected communities: Suzie Masters, Stephanie Pearce and Terri Davidson. Suzie Masters is a resident of Victoria Point. She called me one afternoon with a plan. She was most insistent that I make time to see her and I did. We met that night and she said that she needed my help to make her plan a reality. She needed me to open doors for her. On the evening we met, she explained her plan and within 12 hours we had a distribution centre, we had a Facebook page, we had 20 to 30 volunteers all ready to go and God knows how much aid ready to be distributed. I will come back to that detail later in my address. Suzie had a catchphrase. Whenever and wherever we needed people or supplies, she would say, ‘Ask and they will come; ask and it will come.’ How right she was. Suzie was shadowed by her two young adult children, Katie and Nicholas, who are both students at Victoria Point State High School. A little later I will talk more about the youth of the Redlands.

Stephanie Pearce is involved in the school communities of Victoria Point State High School and Redland Bay State School. She joined our team pretty much from day one. She worked with a team of volunteers, working on logistics, communication and administration. If anything needed doing and you gave it to Stephanie, you could guarantee that it would be done. She worked tirelessly with hundreds of perfect strangers--a new batch of strangers every day. And all I can say is, ‘Thank you, Stephanie, for your contribution.’ Terri Davidson is a nurse. The prerequisites for nursing are caring and responsibility. Terri stepped up to the plate and was largely responsible for managing the receiving and sorting of goods, repacking, loading. You name it, if had to do with logistics Terri would be there to ensure it happened and happened safely. Those three ladies brought professionalism, good humour and energy to this vibrant team.

Suzie had not only an idea or the seed of an idea. She had seen an empty warehouse with a ‘For lease’ sign in the window. By 10 pm, after that first evening meeting, we had the keys to a warehouse provided by local businessman Brian Oldfield, dealer principal from Oldfield Holden in Capalaba. I take this opportunity to thank him for his generosity. Not only did he provide the warehouse but he also ensured that the power was turned on, he organised for litter to be picked up and the rubbish bins to be emptied through J.J.Richards on an almost daily basis, and he made a generous personal donation.

I acknowledge the support of my neighbouring electorates of Capalaba and Cleveland. Both honourable members, Michael Choi and Mark Robinson, put their shoulders to the wheel. We worked as a team. Alone we could have been effective and we were effective. I know we each did our own individual things. However, together, with the help of thousands of Redlanders and thousands of volunteers, we were able to make a most amazing contribution. Redland City was unscathed, but we were not untouched and we were not unmoved. A network of volunteers came together through service communities, scouts, guides, Lions, Apex, Rotary, life saving clubs; charities such as St Vinnies, Lifeline, Global Care and so many others; businesses such as Oldfield Holden, RSVP Party Hire, Bunnings, Officeworks and many other businesses. They were all there from day one to help us out. Their generosity made the entire thing possible.

By far the most indelible image of the Queensland community flood relief was seeing hundreds of young people come forward. So often young people are criticised, as outlined by the Leader of the Opposition, John-Paul Langbroek, in his contribution to the condolence motion. The young people, who are so often criticised, were amazing. Through sites such as Facebook, young people have a network that you would not believe. They showed leadership, they showed commitment and they showed maturity beyond their years. I mention three in particular: Rocky, Michael and Claire. Last year they were school leaders at Victoria Point State High School and Sheldon College in my community.

There were also students from pretty much every school in the Redlands as well as students from schools in the Capalaba and Cleveland electorates. There were teachers from schools in my electorate and those adjoining it. The Facebook page--the social networking--was updated hourly. This actually demonstrated what a powerful tool social media is and it was used in a very positive way. That network brought in those young people in their droves and for that I am eternally grateful. The Facebook page being updated so often brought us not only the volunteers we needed but also the much needed goods.

I also acknowledge the efforts of our federal member Andrew Laming, the member for Bowman, and his support and involvement in the process. The community of Redlands dispatched goods to affected communities across the state including suburbs in and around Brisbane. I remember going out with the member for Moggill and having a look through the areas of Kenmore and some of those suburbs in his electorate. We pulled up to talk to a group of volunteers with shovels, wheelbarrows and what have you. You could tell they had done a hard day’s work. I wound down the window and I said, ‘G’day.’ One of them said, ‘You’re Peter.’ I said, ‘Yeah, how do you know that?’ He said, ‘We’re all from Redlands.’ There was one from Capalaba, a couple from Thornlands, one from Mount Cotton, one from Redland Bay and one from Victoria Point. That demonstrates the depth of support that came from not only the Redlands but also those other communities that were not affected.

The member for Capalaba, Michael Choi, and I led a convoy of vehicles out to Ipswich. Again, that was so well received and so well appreciated by Councillor Paul Pisasale, Mayor of Ipswich. I acknowledge his contribution on behalf of his people. We helped townships in the Lockyer Valley, Maryborough, across the range into the Darling Downs and beyond. We dispatched food, clothing, furniture, medicines, cleaning goods, utensils, insecticides, batteries, shoes, personal hygiene products, et cetera--you name it. The generosity shown was touching and it touched the hearts of recipients. They realised that they were not alone.

The Rotary Club in our area got together and held a monster garage sale to raise much needed money. Help from Redlands and our community came in many forms. The warehouse we used was filled and emptied many, many times and I thank not only those who volunteered to pack and distribute its contents but also those who contributed items.

I have travelled to numerous communities and heard firsthand their stories--stories that tell of hurt, suffering and loss. It brought home to me the importance of counselling. I acknowledge the work done so far and the work that lies ahead for the church and welfare organisations to counsel Queensland families, to help them come to terms with their loss and to rebuild the Queensland spirit. The power of conversation and an embrace cannot be underestimated.

I applaud the many formal and informal supporters working on the ground in those affected communities. If there is one word that springs to mind when wanting to describe Queenslanders, it is resolve. I also add my thanks to the many community leaders who stepped up for their communities: members of this House, federal members, councillors, police, emergency services, Emergency Management Queensland, SES, church leaders and our military. Their dedication is to be commended.

The Queensland spirit--the ‘don’t let a mate down’, the ‘help your neighbour’--is typified by the man on the land. Farms have been decimated and yet they provide our food and our clothing. I met with a number of people in the community out at Cecil Plains and I would like to acknowledge Jan and Meagan who hosted a meeting on their farm, which was quite badly damaged. They invited transport operators from their community, grain growers, suppliers and businesspeople. They were all affected but they wanted to talk about the issues they were facing. I was pleased to be there. I thank the member for Condamine for facilitating that.

On my travels I met an American couple who had never seen anything like this--this human army willing to help out. They tell me that traditionally Americans are spectators and critics, but guess what? They, too, became volunteers. They, too, had caught the Queensland spirit. It is infectious. I met rail workers from Gladstone who pretty much adopted Theodore. I acknowledge that the member for Callide mentioned them in his address. I joined them at a town barbecue with EMQ, the police, SES, councillors and residents. It was a giant thankyou barbecue in the town.

I also acknowledge the office staff--the EOs and the AEOs--of the state members who, in large measure, carried some of the day-to-day routine in the office. I thank them for their backing on our behalf. Travelling primarily by road you see the magnitude of the destruction and the magnitude of the job that is waiting for us to step up to. Road, rail, infrastructure, irrigation, mining--they are all industries and assets that have been decimated.

We have heard much about leadership and we tested our authorities. We tested our police, we tested our emergency services, we tested the SES, we tested the local and regional disaster management groups and they all passed their tests with flying colours. For that our communities will be eternally grateful. The test for us, however, will be ongoing. The tragic circumstances will not be forgotten. The loss of lives will not be forgotten, nor should they. The generosity of Queenslanders will not be forgotten. The Queensland spirit will not be forgotten, nor will it be extinguished. We weep for those gone. We pray for those missing. We help those suffering and we hope for the future.

Mr CHOI (Capalaba--ALP) (3.36 pm): In the last few weeks it would be fair to say that Queenslanders have relived the images vividly depicted in Dorothea Mackellar’s poem My Country . Her words in describing this country of droughts and flooding plains as well as her beauty and her terror echoed through our land, our farms, our neighbourhoods, our streets and our homes.

Widespread flooding and the most severe cyclone in living history struck terror in our hearts from the far north to South-East Queensland. When the Premier delivered the bad news at 10.30 pm on Wednesday night just a fortnight ago telling us Cyclone Yasi showed no signs of weakening, those in the safety of our homes in Brisbane felt terror for the people in the far north. Overnight we waited with bated breath. A category 5 cyclone was bad and to make things worse we were already exhausted before Yasi hit our shores. Raging floods across Queensland had already caused the Premier to declare three-quarters of this great state a disaster zone.

We saw how quickly and how intense rain can fall. In Brisbane we were slightly relieved when the Brisbane River peaked just below the 1974 flood level, but we watched in agony as the death toll continued to rise from the flash flood in the Lockyer Valley. These few weeks tested our determination, our resolve and our faith. From these dark clouds we look for that ever elusive silver lining, and on this occasion we did not have to look too far.

I went to the evacuation centre at Bowen Hills and spent some time there working with the honourable member for Brisbane Central, Grace Grace. A well-mannered young girl came to the counter asking for water while holding firmly to her mother’s hand. ‘Sure. Would you like some food, too?’ I asked. I glanced at her exhausted mother, who held my eyes with a desperate but determined gaze. ‘Only if you have enough for other people,’ her mother said in a quiet and uncompromising tone.

What makes a person, despite their own circumstances, think not of themselves but of others? What went through a young boy’s mind in a raging flood when he asked a rescuer to save his brother first and, in doing so, gave his life as a consequence? What motivates a mother who has lost everything to find the energy, the fortitude and the strength to counsel others in an evacuation centre? Maybe it is the human spirit. Maybe it is what the Premier said: ‘We are the people they breed tough north of the border.’ Maybe it is just that we are Queenslanders.

People naturally thanked me as I gave them water and food at the evacuation centre. However, it is I who must give thanks for many humbling and inspiring experiences in the last few weeks. Our community, in a sea of consumerism just after Christmas and New Year, has found its roots and its soul.

My electorate was spared any major natural disaster this summer, but the good people of the Redlands know instinctively that they have to do something to help their fellow Queenslanders--and help they did. In Capalaba, the Queensland community flood relief collection centre was established by Redlanders Suzie Masters and Stephanie Pearce. The centre worked in conjunction with the local disaster management group coordinators to deliver much needed goods to where they were required. People turned up in droves to volunteer their time and to give donations, with many locals offering trailers and even horse floats to help with transportation.

Capalaba and Redland businesses gave generously to help set up the collection centre. Local businesses donated essential stationery and fans to keep volunteers cool, and strangers brought plates of food to keep volunteers going as they formed human chains to pack trucks with donated goods. Just to give this House an idea of the breadth of generosity, within one hour, the combined efforts of businesses in Redland City saw a helicopter filled with donated essential items, some of them medical items, bound for the most isolated flood stricken areas in the Lockyer Valley. In fact, over a two- to three-week period the collection centre has collected, packed and delivered two loads to the RNA Showgrounds, four loads to Maryborough, 24 loads to Ipswich, 10 loads to Bundamba and many loads to the totally devastated areas of Grantham, Murphys Creek and Gatton. Donations from the Redlands were some of the first they received.

I take this opportunity to thank a few people. First I thank our Premier for her leadership and for her informative and calm persona and determined attitude in the darkest hour of our state. I also thank the whole cabinet for stepping up and spending extra hours and days to comfort our fellow Queenslanders; all the emergency services personnel, who are just wonderful; and, of course, Suzie Masters, Stephanie Pearce and Terri Davidson for starting the community collection centre.

I also pay tribute to my two parliamentary colleagues the member for Redlands and the member for Cleveland, Peter Dowling and Mark Robinson respectively, for being able to work together in a totally bipartisan way to help our community. I also thank the Rotary Club of the Redlands for organising one of the biggest donations and warehouse sales in the history of our city. Over two weekends they have raised something like $90,000 to help victims of the cyclone and the flood. I would also like to thank Brian Oldfield--who was mentioned earlier by the member for Redlands--from Oldfield Holden for offering his warehouse for us to use. I also thank Mick Corboy from the Golden Circle factory outlet at Capalaba for donating 5,000 mops and 5,000 brooms for the clean-up process.

Flood and cyclones do not discriminate. Whether you are white or black or Hindu or whether you are Muslim, Christian or Buddhist, we all suffered the same way. I think the response from the multicultural community has been amazing. I was in the evacuation centre with the member for Brisbane Central when the multicultural community came in with food and drink. We had Italian food, Greek food and Chinese food. It was like a multicultural banquet. It was actually better food in the evacuation centre than in my home! The Chinese community brought in their normal food, like beef in black-bean sauce and sweet-and-sour pork, which was a treat to a lot of people staying at the centre. But it took me quite some time to explain some of the delicacies that they sent in. One of the delicacies was gluten rice with chicken inside, wrapped in a lotus leaf. I was hoping they did not send in any other delicacies such as chicken feet to the evacuation centre!

Over the last three weeks and with Chinese New Year, the Chinese community took the opportunity to raise funds for flood and cyclone victims. Whether they were Chinese from China, Hong Kong, Taiwan or South-East Asia, they took the time and the opportunity to raise a lot of money for the state. I have been taking note of the money they have donated to the Premier’s appeal and other funds, and I am quietly confident that the total amount donated by the Chinese community would have exceeded $1 million. That is not bad for a group of people who not too long ago were referred to by a red-headed politician of distant past as living in ghettoes and not assimilating.
In closing, I seek leave to incorporate a poem written by one of my constituents.
Leave granted.
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: We Aussies love our country--be we citified or countrified, miner, nurse or grower
We love our freedoms--speech and worship--to vote or stand for office ... and freedom to be strong and bold!
Our nation’s vagrant weather has a democratic soul
and treats us all the same when it comes to flood and toil:
But trouble nurtures spirit and spirit conquers all
‘specially when it’s Aussies who set out to lend a hand
We tackle fire and flood, and storm and pests--and strive to ease the grief of those who’ve lost their blooming lot ...
Their sons--their wives--their loved ones all--their land and now their home ... but their Aussie mates will share the load
To comfort, feed, clean, rebuild--whatever they need to do--
and more than that, it’s the trouble and tears they’ll share.
XML.Hansard-Body: Mr CHOI: Lastly, I wish to share a story with members in the House. One day a couple in a battered car turned up on the driveway of the collection centre. I knew them from having provided some assistance to them in the past. They are a truly classic Aussie battler family with three kids under five years of age. Between them--and I know this for a fact--they would have less than a few hundred dollars in the bank, if that. They opened the boot of their 20-plus-year-old car and it was full of fresh produce and tinned food they had bought from the supermarket for flood victims. The docket was still inside one of the bags and my attention was drawn to the amount printed on the bottom--$324.24. Not often do I find myself speechless. I felt so small in the presence of giants. As a state, as Queenslanders, together we weep, together we hug, but together we will rebuild our great state.

Hansard-Body.A: (Mansfield--ALP) (Minister for Child Safety and Minister for Sport) (3.46 pm): We will never forget those harrowing days when floodwater invaded parts of Queensland. The torrent of water was as cruel as it was unprecedented, making its way through homes, streets, suburbs and towns without mercy. Mother Nature flexed her considerable muscle, tossing cars around like toys, devastating family homes. It left in its wake a path of destruction on both a physical and an emotional level. We will never forget it.

XML.Hansard-Body: Queenslanders have lost so much. I would like to extend my heartfelt condolences to the Queensland people who have suffered significantly in recent weeks. The lives of loved ones, relatives, friends and neighbours have been lost. We have seen the heartbreaking images of families returning to discover what was left of their homes, treasured possessions scattered or lost in the torrent. I do not think any of us will forget Monday, 10 January.

I had come home from the Sunshine Coast that day and had left friends of mine who were on their way home to Chinchilla with their five children. I got a text at about 3.30 that afternoon saying that they were stuck on the road just outside Withcott. The road had become a car park and it looked like they were in for a long stay--not that they or I knew what had occurred. Like everyone else, I turned on the TV news at six o’clock that night and I do not think I believed what I was seeing in Toowoomba. Little did we know that it was to have an impact further down the Toowoomba range in the Lockyer region. That family finally got up the range at about midnight and then stayed in Toowoomba until the Thursday, when they eventually got home to Chinchilla. It just goes to show their timing. Thankfully they stopped at DFO on the way home to buy some school clothes.

To me, those pictures were something you would expect to see overseas, not something you would expect to see in Queensland. I think those pictures actually contributed to people making sure they listened to the messages from the emergency services and the Premier about being prepared for the flood that would follow in the next few days in Brisbane and Ipswich and when Cyclone Yasi hit a couple of weeks later. After we saw those pictures of Toowoomba we knew that we could never know what to expect. I think it opened everyone’s eyes and ears. It must be tragic for those who experienced this and those who witnessed this.

The tears, the anguish, the desperation over that time was raw and palpable. You could see the fear in people’s eyes as they made the decision to evacuate and spend the night at evacuation centres. During the time I spent at the Queensland Sport and Athletics Centre, the old QEII stadium, which was being used as one of the major evacuation centres, I witnessed the suffering firsthand. In the makeshift bedding, they could only imagine the waters engulfing their family homes and snatching their treasured belongings. You could see the tears in their eyes as they imagined what tomorrow and the weeks to follow would bring. But they were safe.

Thanks to the amazing number of volunteers, stranded families had a safe haven, a warm place to sleep and something to eat. It was a small blessing during those tough times. The humanity and true spirit of being a Queenslander was on display with an overwhelming response.

The volunteers arrived, as did the donations. It was an avalanche of generosity. There were tables overflowing with the essentials--clothes and shoes. I remember a driver of a truck that was full of fruit that pulled up at QSAC. He said that he could not get up the mountain and the fruit was only going to perish so he left the fresh fruit for those at the evacuation centre. The kitchen was fully stocked. The volunteer chefs were going full steam ahead--24/7. We will never forget it. It was great that we had a facility that could be used for that purpose.

We saw the heartbreaking effects of the floods but we also saw, once again, what Queenslanders are made of. We rallied round our mates and together formed what has been called the mud army. With the member for Yeerongpilly, I saw the aftermath of the floods in Rocklea. Rocklea is only 10 minutes from my home. The electorate of Mansfield was not impacted at all but 10 minutes down the road we saw destruction that was indescribable.

Some people had just finished renovating their dream home, only to find a mud wasteland had replaced their pride and joy. The mud did not discriminate. The foul-smelling brown sludge encased front yards and backyards. We grabbed whatever we could to help--in my case, a shovel and a broom. I did not use them. It was our hands that were needed.

I got to help an elderly couple from Rocklea who had experienced this before. My wife, friends of mine and I assisted as well as people we did not know. The beautiful home they had been living in since 1958 was ruined. The water had reached their roof, soaking the insulation batts and warping the foundations and the floors. At this house we saw a plastic table stuck on the aerial on top of the house.

It was too much for the mum to bear. She could not come to the clean-up. She had seen it all before and could not bear to see her beloved home once again swamped by mud. The clean-up was an overwhelming process for the dad. He had to find a quiet place to sit down as 53 years worth of belongings were carried out of his home and placed on the footpath for collection. It has to be hard to see your home of 53 years gutted. We had to rip up the carpets and the floorboards and tear down the plasterboard. We did not do this alone. The mud army rallied. That day renewed everyone’s admiration for generation Y. Often they get criticised for wanting it all for little effort, but their spirit and gung-ho attitude was commendable. We will never forget that.

It was terrific that friends of mine, my family and staff members assisted me in helping these people. They also helped at the evacuation centre. A prime example of this is that my wife, who is a teacher, and a teaching colleague of hers came with me on both days that we spent helping over that weekend. The deputy principal of a local school came along as well. My neighbour saw me arrive home after getting my tetanus shot on the first day. It is a pity my sister had to give it to me; she was working for the council. He said, ‘I had to work all day today, but I really want to come and help. What time are you leaving in the morning?’ I said that I was going to leave at 6.30. I opened my garage door at 6.30 on Sunday morning and not only was one neighbour there but also three of his mates. That just typified what this was all about--helping people who needed our help more than ever before.

For many Queenslanders, once they had secured their homes and businesses their next thought went to their local sporting club. This is the place where community comes together, where mates socialise over a game of sport, where people come to relax. In many cases, these clubs are the glue which binds communities together. The devastation I have seen over the past few weeks cuts you to the core. It is as hard to see your local sports club affected by the floods as it is to see your home or business impacted.

We think that about 500 clubs across the state were flooded. The waters inundated ovals and courts, canteens and equipment sheds. I have been out and about visiting families and clubs asking what they need to do to get their sport back on track. I have had the pleasure and honour of meeting a lot of these people, from Bundaberg to Ipswich. Just recently I was in Maryborough and Gympie. I intend to visit more places. We will rebuild, but we will never forget the experience.

No sooner had most of Queensland mopped up then Mother Nature revisited our state with another natural disaster in the form of Cyclone Yasi. We could only watch in terror as Yasi bore down on Far North Queensland packing a category 5 punch. I have no doubt that North Queenslanders did not sleep very well that night. I am sure I speak for many members in this House when I say that southern Queenslanders did not sleep very much that night. I had the TV on and the radio close by. I prayed that the north would not be impacted as we feared it would be. As we know, parts of the north were impacted.

We have never seen anything like it--the wind, the rain, the force of that cyclone. It must have been a terrifying experience. Debris was strewn across backyards and streets, with people’s belongings buried underneath broken timber and sheet metal. Once again, the people of Queensland have been battered. But we are a strong bunch. Once again, we will get through this. I would like to pass on my deepest thanks to the emergency services crews and police. Their planning and preventive measures were nothing short of fantastic. I do not think anyone will forget that.

I also take this opportunity to thank the hundreds of sporting clubs that have rallied behind all those affected. At the evacuation centre we had visits from the Broncos. They were not just fleeting visits. I will not forget the sight of big burly Ben Hannant playing playdough with the Samoan children who were there or seeing Ivan Henjak and a few other Broncos lifting large electric beds into QSAC. The men’s and women’s Roar teams came along. The Reds were involved in sandbagging.

We saw players from rugby league and the AFL help with the clean-up, and we even had an AFL side come all the way from Western Australia to help. We have all heard about the great fundraising efforts by many of the high-profile sporting clubs. Many people are very quick to knock these clubs, but when the chips were down they were there to help and we appreciated it. We will continue to need their help and the local sporting clubs will particularly need their assistance. It was terrific to be at Moorooka State School and Goodna State School when the entire Australian cricket side gave those communities the lift that they deserve. I thank those players for that.

We now look to the future. We have to continue with our efforts to put Queensland back together. Like the people who lost their lives, we are strong, we are tough and, yes, we are Queenslanders. We will never forget. As a person who is a proud Queenslander, a person who from the age of 14 has never missed a State of Origin game in Brisbane and who has never been so proud of Queenslanders--particularly as we have won five--I have got to say that I have never been as proud to be a Queenslander as I was on that Saturday after the floods when I was standing with hundreds and thousands of people ready to help. In fact, there were so many people that trucks could not get into areas of Rocklea to clean up. It was amazing.

At one of the houses I was at, we still heard the cheekiness in the people. The daughter of the couple who owned the house we were cleaning found some dentures that day. Her father was out the front looking at everything and she yelled out, ‘Dad, are these yours or mum’s, and do you want to keep them?’ There was that sort of laughter going on. When we shifted the bed and saw lots of chocolate wrappings, they said, ‘That mum has a sweet tooth, hasn’t she?’ They kept their sense of humour and that just shows what type of people we are.

It was a harrowing experience. We have always regarded Brisbane as a big country town. We thought we had lost it, but I think over the last few weeks we have proven that we have not lost it. I hope we continue in that vein because it will be many weeks, months and years before people recover from this. They will need all of our assistance for years to come.

Hansard-Body.A: (Mulgrave--ALP) (4.02 pm): On behalf of the people I have been elected to represent in Mulgrave and on behalf of my own family, I extend my heartfelt sympathy and deepest condolences to the families and friends of those loved ones who have lost their lives or who have had their lives changed forever. Like many other members of this parliament, I felt for the people of Central and Western Queensland as the rain began to fall in December. In January, I watched on with shock and amazement as events unfolded in Toowoomba and the Lockyer Valley. Later, I felt helpless as I heard reports of floodwaters heading to Ipswich and later Brisbane. I remember remarking at the time that I felt somewhat guilty that for once it was not the northern part of the state that was on the receiving end of nature’s fury. Little did I know how wrong I would be.

XML.Hansard-Body: Last weekend, I attended a multifaith church service in Tully to honour those who have suffered. It offered a chance to reflect and to offer prayers for those who have suffered. The congregation was reminded by Commissioner Bob Atkinson that in Queensland our seasons are not as clearly defined as in some other parts of the world, but there is one season we know plenty about and that is the wet season, which gets larger and longer the further north you go. And then there is the cyclone season on top of that.

Like most people from North Queensland, I have been through cyclone seasons many times before. I remember when Cyclone Winifred struck Far North Queensland in 1986. It came across the coast on 1 February--my birthday. I was meant to be having my first ever birthday party, with a cake and all of my friends from school. Needless to say, my party was cancelled and instead of a cake I had a milk arrowroot biscuit smeared with butter and topped with hundreds and thousands.

Almost 25 years later to the day, it was a case of deja vu, only this time I spent my birthday preparing for Cyclone Yasi--cleaning up my yard, securing loose items and, most importantly, making sure my family, particularly my wife and son, were safe. I also found myself travelling between Cairns and Innisfail to try to be involved in local disaster management group meetings for two regional councils and I was on the phone with a third at Yarrabah. We were well prepared for this event. The Cairns Regional Council had undertaken comprehensive flood mapping to guard against the threat of storm surge. We saw the unprecedented airlift of more than 320 patients from the Cairns Base Hospital and the Cairns Private Hospital, and an additional 500 people from the SES had been sent into the area. The lessons learnt from the Cyclone Larry experience would be invaluable and any complacency that may have crept in over the years disappeared once we all got a look at the monster weather system that was headed our way.

On the night of 2 February and early the following morning, our region was struck by the fiercest cyclone recorded since 1918. As anybody who has been through a few will tell you, with cyclones it is not what you see, it is what you hear. Besides the sound of the ABC Radio coverage, it is the relentless howling. It is also what you feel, like the vibration of your house. The seeing is what you do the next day.

Daybreak revealed plenty of vegetation loss and minor structural damage around my immediate area of Gordonvale. I visited local evacuation centres and for a moment I thought perhaps we had got off lightly. It was only when I heard from my brother-in-law in Kurrimine Beach that the extent of the impact started to become clear. He and his wife and three children were safe, as were their horses--which spent the night inside the house with the family--but their house had been severely flooded and they had lost their shed, their roof and every window in the house. Just today, they found out that their house is not structurally sound and is no longer habitable. Their story has become typical for areas south of Innisfail.

From everything I have seen, Babinda and the greater Innisfail area have been affected less dramatically than with Cyclone Larry but it has been affected nonetheless. Certainly, the restoration of power has been an ongoing issue, but I know just how flat out Ergon workers have been. I also know that the thoughts of people in these communities have been with their southern cousins, because the people of Babinda and Innisfail have been through this before and want to repay some of the kindness shown to them in the past.

By Friday, 4 February--just one day after the cyclone--a relief squad of 2,600 people was converging on towns from Townsville to Cairns. Our first priorities were to ensure our people were safe. Food and medical supplies also ranked among those first priorities. We then set about to begin the restoration of essential services like transport, power and water supply. The longer task is rebuilding the houses and the infrastructure that has been damaged or destroyed, and that will run into billions of dollars--148 houses were destroyed, a further 649 are uninhabitable and 2,335 have suffered moderate damage, and that is before we look at the damage to infrastructure.

The Far North has long been a tight-knit community that looks after its own and willingly lends a hand to others in need. This has been demonstrated time and time again in the aftermath of Cyclone Yasi--from residents in affected areas helping friends and neighbours who had been hardest hit, to the tireless workers from emergency services and the police, workers from Telstra and Ergon, Defence Force personnel, workers from government agencies and NGOs and, of course, the hundreds of volunteers. Never have I been more proud to be a Queenslander.

Locally, there are some who I believe deserve special mention, like district disaster coordinator Inspector David Tucker, who kept cool under pressure in the planning and preparation, and Mayor Bill Shannon--indeed all the councillors and staff at the Cassowary Coast Regional Council--for the way they have rallied the community during this difficult time. Thank you also to the unsung heroes from outside our area, including staff from the Department of Community Safety and the Department of Communities, who were on the ground as quickly as possible after the danger had passed to coordinate the state government’s response.

I thank the Minister for Emergency Services, Neil Roberts, and staff across all the ministerial offices. Much has been said in the media--indeed in this House--about the leadership of Premier Anna Bligh during this time of crisis, but I contend there is nothing out of the ordinary about her leadership. I say this because over the past month or so I have seen the same determined, strong, decisive, compassionate and articulate leader I have seen many times before. No, the leadership of Anna Bligh has not been extraordinary, but Anna Bligh the person has been. She has been a beacon of hope for all Australians at this time. We have all been lucky enough to have seen her in full flight and have benefited from her guidance.

We were well prepared for Cyclone Yasi, and now the recovery is under way. The Premier has announced she will establish a Queensland Reconstruction Authority to coordinate and oversee recovery, including cyclone reconstruction. Local leaders on the ground were vital in the immediate aftermath of Cyclone Yasi. Having a local chain of command led by the LDMG allowed the people who best know the local areas impacted by Cyclone Yasi to steer the disaster response. The same approach will apply in the long-term reconstruction, with the decision to establish a dedicated North Queensland Office of the Queensland Reconstruction Authority. This will be based in Innisfail and will be led by Queensland Police Chief Superintendent Michael Keating. North Queenslanders do need their own voice in the reconstruction effort and Chief Superintendent Keating will be that voice. Over the past two decades, he has served in Cairns, Townsville, Tully and Innisfail and also has experience of the reconstruction effort post Cyclone Larry.

It will be his exclusive job to lead the reconstruction for the people of North Queensland and we will seek, wherever possible, not just to replace infrastructure and facilities but to improve upon what was there. While we recognise the need for recovery to be expedient and prioritised to those areas which need it the most, just as critical are the local economies that have been devastated. In Tully the Building Services Authority has opened an office to provide affected homeowners and contractors with information and advice about rebuilding. I believe that government at all levels, wherever possible, should require local work to be done by locals--the community helping their community. Moral pressure must also be applied to insurance companies to use local contractors, and I urge policyholders to make a point of telling their insurance provider that their preference is that a local contractor be used.

While I am not the local member for the areas hardest hit, my office has already been fielding and responding to requests. I offer my continued assistance and that of my staff to all of the people in the communities of El Arish, Silkwood, Tully, Tully Heads and Cardwell who have lost their homes and possessions, some their jobs and their sense of security. Their awe-inspiring resilience and stoicism in the face of disaster proves that they will regroup, rebuild and recover.

I also offer my personal support to the member for Hinchinbrook, Andrew Cripps. I know that he, like me, genuinely cares about the welfare of his constituents. I also know that we share a love of rugby league. We may play for different clubs during the regular season, but when it comes to stepping up to representative football I am only too happy to pack into the scrum with him. I commend him on his speech to the House yesterday and for the statesmanlike manner in which he has approached the clean-up and recovery effort.

Since Cyclone Yasi struck I have been on the ground many times meeting people in those communities I referred to earlier, including visiting with the Prime Minister and the Premier and other state government ministers to ensure they see firsthand the devastation being experienced. What brought it home for me was a meeting with an 85-year-old woman from Tully Heads named Patricia Butler, a local artist of some renown and, quite frankly, a real character. As members have already heard, her house was completely destroyed by storm surge and all that remained were the concrete stumps. Cruelly, this was the second time that that house on that block had been destroyed. Upon meeting her it was immediately obvious that Mrs Butler is fiercely independent but is now faced with the prospect of moving in with her daughter. She has decided that she will not rebuild on that site. Mrs Butler’s story is but one story of the many people deeply affected, and if one needs any further motivation to support these residents they need not look any further than her example.

I have been working closely with the local disaster management coordinator and others at the Cassowary Coast Regional Council on a variety of issues, including improving coordination around volunteers, community recovery centres, accommodation issues--both for residents and workers--and reducing red tape for those people with heavy vehicles and earthmoving equipment who wish to contribute to the clean-up and recovery effort. Anybody who is involved in the response post event will admit that it has not been perfect, but I can say, hand on heart, that authorities are doing the best they can. I believe that because I have seen it for myself.

The damage that has been caused by Cyclone Yasi is not just material; it is also spiritual and emotional. We have to recover from all aspects of the damage inflicted. Just like we were asked to talk to our neighbours before the cyclone to ensure they were prepared and aware of warnings, we need to continue to check on our neighbours to ensure they are doing okay. Not all will be overtly asking for help. And it is not just the immediate damage and disruption that occurred during the tense few hours when the storm hit; it is also the long-term economic and social consequences--the damage to infrastructure and the slow death being experienced by some tourism operators. Not only will the loss of crops such as bananas and sugar have an impact on residents; we have to remember that some farmers have only just got back on track after Cyclone Larry struck five years ago. For some, asking them to start again will be too much.

At the same time that Queensland was being subjected to arguably the worst natural disasters Australia had ever seen, across the Pacific in South America the people of Brazil were dealing with deadly mudslides. Flooding and mudslides are common in Brazil when the summer rains come but, like our recent extreme weather events, this was among the worst in recent memory. The last I heard, the death toll had reached 500 but with many hundreds more missing. Media reports talked about many of the same things we were experiencing--limited access due to road closures, confusion and enormous anxiety by people searching for their loved ones. But there was almost no talk about the damage bill. In many other countries, particularly developing nations, the focus is on building cheaper infrastructure and housing, which, of course, is easier and less costly to rebuild, but almost always there is a significantly higher loss of life if a natural disaster strikes.

I am thankful that we have legislation that ensures stringent building and construction. I am also thankful for the approach we take to disaster management, both proactively and in the response post event. It is no exaggeration to say that we have perhaps the best community safety and disaster management reputation in the world, and it is a reputation that is richly deserved. We can do all of this because we are a wealthy country--in terms of both dollars and our sense of community--but the reason we do all of this is that we place such a strong emphasis on human life. I am sure there will be more we can learn, and we must remember that, while it is many years since a cyclone of Yasi’s force has hit Queensland, there is no guarantee that it will not happen again. So we must reconstruct with that in mind, especially since climate change experts warn that we can expect more violent weather events in the future.

Recovery will be a slow process right across the state but, to borrow from Major General Peter Cosgrove following Cyclone Larry, ‘the sight of the sun glinting off the shiny new roofs will be a telltale symbol of progress’. Thankfully, the one thing that does not need rebuilding is community spirit. It is that spirit that stood resolute and undamaged in the face of the worst that nature could throw at us. I know that all of us in Far North Queensland--indeed, all Queenslanders--have the strength, the determination and the will to go forward following these disasters.

The events of this summer reminded us all that the force of nature does not discriminate between rich and poor. They reminded us that the things we have in common far outweigh any differences that we may have, and they reminded us that we are part of a community and that, even during times of great disaster, something magical can happen when people come together. I wish all of us well in the weeks, the months and the years ahead.

Hansard-Body.A: (Nicklin--Ind) (4.15 pm): I rise to participate in the debate of the condolence motion moved yesterday by the Premier in this chamber. When I read the wording of the motion I thought, ‘What wonderful words the Premier chose.’ I want to take a few moments to go over those again. The motion reads--

XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent1: 1. acknowledges with great sadness the devastation caused in Queensland by the natural disasters that this state has endured since December 2010;
2. extends its condolences and deepest sympathy to the families and loved ones of those killed in the natural disasters;
3. grieves for those who have suffered injury and who have lost their homes, property and personal possessions and extends our support for their recovery;

4. places on record its sincerest gratitude for the leadership and the valued contribution of the police, emergency service and medical teams, defence personnel, federal, state and local government and private sector employees, and community and voluntary service providers, together with the thousands of workers and volunteers from Queensland, other parts of Australia and overseas, who have selflessly contributed so much in difficult and often dangerous circumstances to help affected communities;

5. sincerely acknowledges the many fundraising activities which have been organised and thanks the people and governments in Australia and overseas who have sent messages of support and sympathy and who have generously donated resources and funding to assist our fellow Queenslanders; and
6. pledges to work with affected communities and all levels of government, as Queensland recovers from these natural disasters and is rebuilt.
XML.Hansard-Body: I think the words the Premier used are very accurate and certainly capture the thoughts that we in this chamber and in our respective communities throughout this great state of Queensland have at this very difficult time. On behalf of my wife and my constituents on the Sunshine Coast, I convey our heartfelt sorrow and condolences and put on the record my total support for the motion the Premier moved yesterday.

We have seen extreme weather events around the world. As we heard the warnings from the Premier, little did we know what was about to be unleashed in Queensland, be it the cyclones in North Queensland or the floods in Ipswich and Brisbane. We on the Sunshine Coast have been spared. We certainly have not seen the devastation. But it was hard to believe as we looked at the news--we have 24-hour news today--that this was our state, our Australia, and not somewhere overseas.

As I watched our Premier hour after hour give those many, many interviews, I felt very proud of the way the Premier and our ministers led our great state--our police minister, our Police Service, our volunteers. I think we can all be very proud of our government. I hope that Queensland is able to see this unity and this strength of leadership, because that is what we are certainly looking for at the moment.

When the floodwaters went down and the call for help went out, people from the Maroochy Surf Club were travelling to Brisbane and beyond. When the call went out I thought, ‘I’ve got nothing on. I will rock up.’ As I rocked up with my gumboots and my shovel and bits and pieces Fiona Simpson, my colleague from Maroochydore, was there. Quite frankly, you would not have believed that we were politicians; we were just ordinary Queenslanders lending a hand to help. We went down on the bus and we were originally requested to go to the Goodna Caravan Park. As we were going through to Brisbane and on to Goodna we saw the caravan park and we thought, ‘By crikey, we need heavy lifting equipment, not just people.’ Fortunately, we got the call, ‘Sorry, that’s a job for the Army and the cranes,’ and we were reassigned to a low-lying area in Goodna.

While we were there a Bunnings team came from the Gold Coast. We left home with our lunch bags and we were thinking that we were going to look after ourselves, but lo and behold we had Bunnings from the Gold Coast helping in downtown Goodna. We were daunted by the task, but what was important was that, as those convoys of Army trucks rolled in, as soon as we could fill them they were off to the dump and they were back again. During that day we saw people of all ages, as other members have indicated, come together to help. One thing that really struck me was one house that was devastated. It was like a war zone, but here was the Australian flag. Quite frankly, all it had on it was ‘Thank you’. On our return that evening back to the surf club we were talking in the bus about how it struck us that there were so many Australian flags and that we felt so proud to be Queenslanders and Australians. I think one thing this disaster has certainly done is that it has brought us together as a state and as a nation.

We have all helped in many different ways. On another occasion I joined the staff from the Sunshine Coast Regional Council and we travelled to Brisbane. This time we were designated to go to Graceville. As we drove down to that area I reflected back on 1974 when I was a young police cadet in the Police Academy at Oxley. In looking at some of that country--the houses, the flooding--I could still recall Oxley, Chelmer and Graceville and here I was in 2011 going back to that very area. On this day in Graceville we were helping clean out a block of units--I think there were over 100 units--and there was no insurance. They were just pulling the gyprock out of the units--the ceiling was falling in--trying to wait for the buildings to dry out. On that day Councillor Vivien Griffin from the Sunshine Coast Regional Council had, like me, just joined the mud army. We all were very concerned about disease and infections. Unfortunately, she fell over and her whole mouth was split. She was rushed off to hospital. She, like all of us, was there just simply trying to play her part and help. I am very proud of the many groups on the Sunshine Coast who have helped and who are still helping--I will only reflect on my electorate because other members will reflect on theirs--be they service clubs, sporting groups, or simply individuals who tried to help in so many different ways.

There is one group that I would like to mention specifically, though, and it is a group of young teenagers. Sometimes they are very prone to getting into strife. They are teenagers who visit our Shack, which is a drop-in centre in downtown Nambour just near the railway station. Believe it or not, we own it freehold. It used to be a squash court. The previous committee was not able to continue and they came to see me and asked, ‘Peter, what do we do?’ I said, ‘If you fold up it will be sold.’ We were able to restructure and reorganise and, to cut a long story short, that site is now owned by our community freehold and it is now where The Shack operates from as a drop-in centre for some of our young folk who seem to get themselves into lots of mischief.

But what did we see from these young people who are often doing the wrong thing? These young people are aged from 10 to 17. They went to help with the clean-up in Brisbane. I would like to recognise those young people here on the official parliamentary record. I think they went over and above what was ever expected of them. We as a community feel so proud of these young people because they went out of their way to say, ‘What can we do to help?’ Those people included Imogene Dowler, 10 years of age; Ross McMaster, who is an adult and came along to help; Peter McMaster, 14 years of age; Sam Dudley, 14 years of age; Joel Dowler, 14 years of age; Tanya-Maria Evans, 15 years of age; Jeff Evans, who is an adult and came along as well; Ashleigh McLachlan, 11 years of age; Nigel McLachlan, who is an adult and came along to help supervise; Maryanne McLachlan, who is an adult and came along to help supervise; Dale Dowler, our manager, who is an adult and was there supervising; and Darcy Collier, who is 17 years of age. I just want to put that on the record so that these young people know that we appreciate their efforts.

The member for Lockyer spoke about the devastation in his electorate. I simply say that various groups in my community are doing fundraising to help some of those very families that he mentioned. I will not mention their names during my contribution but simply say that we are all able to play a part, no matter what shape or form that might take.

I am very pleased that after we finish debating this condolence motion we will then debate a very important bill that the Premier has introduced, the Queensland Reconstruction Authority Bill. The Queensland Reconstruction Authority will have the task for two years--I think as it is set out in the bill--to manage the reconstruction effort, to try to streamline bureaucracy and to get results. So often we hear complaints that we are bogged down in bureaucracy. I am certainly looking forward to the debate on that bill commencing at the appropriate time. We have also had the launch of the commission of inquiry, which will have the specific role of examining matters, including the preparation and the planning. I am certainly looking forward to the recommendations from that inquiry, which I understand will come back to this House later this year, perhaps around August.

A number of members have spoken about their views on the insurance companies. When I was at Goodna, at the last house that we worked on before we hopped on the buses an elderly couple were there. They said, ‘We were told not to do anything until the insurance company assessors came round so that they could see that we did not damage it ourselves.’ So while other houses had been cleaned, they were told to leave it so that there could be no challenge. They stayed and they informed us that they were offered $15,000--‘Take it or leave it. That is all anyone in this area will be getting.’ I will not name the company. I believe that it will cost in excess of $50,000 to repair the damage. There is no way in the world they will be able to manage that without a fair and just insurance payment. They have paid their insurance premium every year--on time, the full amount. I certainly hope and I am looking forward to some strong recommendations about how we can improve the laws not just in Queensland but also throughout Australia to really make our insurance companies do the right thing and not hide behind strict legal interpretations.

Earlier I spoke about the extreme weather conditions we witnessed on the news last year and over recent years. I conclude my contribution by urging our government to seriously look at saying that in some areas we are full; there is no room for new communities on flood plain locations which developers want to see developed. Yes, we certainly will rebuild where our existing communities are, but I believe the government and we all as elected members of this parliament need to seriously look at where we are proposing new communities to be built, because often we see councils approving future communities and saying, ‘Yes, we will build on a flood plain.’ The water has to jolly well go somewhere.

I am looking forward to the debate on the other bills I have touched on. I resume my seat and conclude by saying that it is great to be a member of this parliament and to see all members, be they government, opposition or members of the crossbenches, speaking as one, as all Queenslanders certainly want us to.

Mrs STUCKEY (Currumbin--LNP)
(4.30 pm): I rise to speak to this condolence motion to acknowledge the efforts of the Queensland people and others during the recent devastating floods and cyclones and to convey my deepest sympathy to those who lost loved ones, those who lost their home, property, pets, possessions and businesses. In doing so may I also communicate the thoughts and prayers of the people in the Currumbin electorate on the Gold Coast, an electorate spared by this sequence of cruel and bizarre natural events.

I feel blessed that I have never experienced a serious flood or a cyclone. Despite watching hour upon hour of graphic television coverage, I doubt I can say that I truly understand the magnitude of this series of natural disasters. However, I have witnessed the grief and despair experienced by my colleagues on both sides of the chamber. I particularly want to mention the anguish and the heartache being felt by the honourable members for Lockyer and Hinchinbrook on behalf of their cherished communities. Mother Nature does not discriminate, but these two gentlemen must be questioning why their regions copped such merciless hard hits. Very few, if any, honourable members of this House have been left untouched by the devastating effects of Mother Nature as she wreaked havoc across our great state during what should have been a joyous celebration over the Christmas-New Year period. It tested the strength, bravery and spirit of countless Queenslanders who are first and foremost Australians.

As this horror movie rolled into our living rooms around the clock, day after day and week after week, I was initially overwhelmed with a sense of helplessness which grew into a sense of guilt, a sense of guilt that the Gold Coast was spared while so many other areas suffered. The guilt thankfully gave way to a deep sense of pride in my fellow Queenslanders and fellow Australians. From those who gritted their teeth and soldiered on under immensely tragic circumstances to those who pitched in with hampers, money and physical help to clean up the awful mess. A veritable army of goodwill volunteers appeared from across the state. What struck me and many others was the genuine display of indomitable courage, attachment to local communities and determination displayed by people when faced with such adversity, some of them having lost everything. This, coupled with a community spirit that lifted the heaviest of hearts of people right across Queensland, showed the rest of the world what we are made of--pride and resilience.

May I add my heartfelt praise and admiration to the appreciation expressed by other honourable members for the outstanding efforts of the SES workers, police, our defence force, local council mayors, volunteers, not-for-profit organisations and charities such as Red Cross and Lifeline and the hardworking meteorologists who tracked our weather patterns so concisely. I commend the Premier and the opposition leader John-Paul Langbroek for the leadership and empathy they both displayed.

Currumbin is a close-knit community and, whilst I was moved by the flurry of fundraising activity and offers of help the people in my electorate undertook, like so many others in unaffected areas it did not surprise me greatly. I would like to place on record my sincere thanks to the people of the Currumbin electorate for the numerous acts of kindness and activities they organised and participated in. Many lined up to get a seat on buses that would take them to Ipswich to help clean up as part of the countless mud armies of volunteers. Others headed to Brisbane or regional areas to pitch in. I wish to make mention of a few of them and I apologise to those I have omitted.

Bilinga woman Amy Tessmann started a collection drive out of her own home and has been inundated with goods that have since gone to good needy homes--and I use the word ‘homes’ very, very carefully. LNP women conducted a hamper drive of personal care products which were distributed to Central Queensland communities. On Sunday, 23 January the Tugun Community Flood Relief Fundraiser was held in the park adjacent to the Tugun Surf Club with bands, parades, silent auctions and raffles. Organised in less than a fortnight by Serene Beauty owner Megan Waters, this event raised almost $20,000 including $5,000 from our local Tugun Community Bank. The Heartwave Beach Walk was organised by young Heidi Bartholomew and took place at Elephant Rock, Currumbin last Saturday in support of the flood ravaged community of Grantham in the Lockyer Valley. Several hundred people attended the walk and afterwards they formed the shape of a heart on the sand to be captured from an aerial view and sent as a message of warmth and love to Queenslanders in the Lockyer Valley ravaged by cruel acts of nature. At last count over $5,500 was raised from that event.

Both of those previously mentioned events were keenly supported by many of our local surfing and football icons. Cooly Rocks On, the newly branded Wintersun Festival, held a mini dance party and collected more than $5,000. The Elanora Uniting Church held a theatre night on Friday, 11 February organised by the church’s Adult Fellowship president, Mary Flynn, raising $2,000. And, of course, our Rotary and Lions clubs were as usual busy helping. Charities that have stretched themselves to the limit must not be forgotten.

Small businesses are also deserving of assistance from the government. These devastating floods and cyclones across Queensland have belted thousands of small and medium businesses hard. For some it has been a double whammy: their homes and their businesses. For others their home-operated businesses were severely impacted. Sadly, some will not recover and will have to close, leaving sorrow, debt and loss of jobs. When watching endless television footage these past weeks it really hit home how many regional towns rely on small businesses for so many items and services--literally for their daily bread. Tourism and crop production provide lifelines to so many areas.

In the aftermath there is a chance for those wanting to restart to apply for loans, but still there are mountains of red tape to negotiate as they try to rebuild their ravaged businesses and uprooted lives. The struggle even to survive in business is more evident now in businesses that many townsfolk have run for decades. The Chamber of Commerce and Industry Queensland has worked intimately with the business sector throughout this devastating period, not only offering exceptional assistance and advice to businesses but also working tirelessly to provide valuable statistics that reveal the severe impact these floods have had on Queensland small- and medium-sized businesses. It found that one in five businesses in Queensland has had to close as a result of the floods due to full or partial water inundation, loss of power or being cut off from their businesses.

The average number of days that businesses were forced to close was eight. The average number of days before their business returns to normal operation is 31. The loss to property, including plant and equipment, stock, buildings and motor vehicles to those businesses directly affected by the floods was, on average, $589,000. Businesses directly affected by the floods on average expect to lose in total $908,000 or approximately 11 per cent of their annual turnover. Unfortunately most businesses are currently unsure what their insurance covers them for. Many businesses have also been indirectly impacted by the floods through affected customers, affected suppliers, through employee inability to attend work or through the loss of appeal of Queensland as a tourism destination. It is clear that small business urgently needs help to restart and service local communities.

The summer of 2010-11 will be etched in people’s minds for years to come. It will stand as a reminder to those of us who have been spared that we have a lot to be thankful for. The floods claimed 36 lives, with three more people missing, and destroyed not only personal property but also much loved pets, treasured mementos and livelihoods. May we also remember the incredible outpouring of kindness and mateship from not only Queenslanders but also strangers across Australia and tourists holidaying here, too. We must continue to support our fellow Queenslanders through these difficult phases as they embark on the path to recovery and, ultimately, healing. After all, it is the Queensland way, the Australian way.

Mr WATT (Everton--ALP) (4.39 pm): At the outset, on behalf of the residents of the Everton electorate, I would like to join with every other speaker on this motion to express my sincere condolences to the families of those who lost their lives in the recent floods and cyclones. I also offer my condolences to those who have experienced a very sorrowful loss of property and those who, although they may not have lost their lives or property, have still suffered from this and have lost the certainty and security of what they thought was normal life in Queensland.

I will keep my remarks short in recognition that my electorate largely escaped the physical effects of this recent wild weather. However, I should say that a small number of houses in my electorate suffered from landslides and a number of people did experience some flash flooding. So I do not want to ignore the effects that did fall upon some residents of my electorate.

Like all Queenslanders, I think the residents of Everton have been touched by recent events. We have experienced the impact of wild weather before. The wild storms that hit parts of Brisbane in late 2008, widely remembered as ‘The Gap storms’, also impacted a number of suburbs in my electorate. So a number of people in my area have been talking about how they felt at that time and have expressed sympathy for the people facing this most recent situation.

Of course many locals in my electorate either work or run businesses in areas that have been affected by the floods and there is now some risk to their employment or the future success of their business as a result. They are deeply hurting over that. If nothing else, everyone in my electorate--just like everyone in Queensland--has been deeply touched by the impact upon either friends or family members who do live in the areas that have been affected. Not a day goes by when I do not talk to someone in my area who knows someone who has suffered deeply.

For someone like me who comes from an area that was not physically affected by the floods--and from here on I will confine my remarks to the floods given that they occurred nearer to home--it was a very surreal feeling. The day before the floods peaked in Brisbane I remember driving over the hill at Newmarket on my way to one of the SES depots to help fill sandbags. I was able to look down and see the CBD and I knew that the waters were rising and would reach a frightening level in only a few hours time. The roads, the parks and the streets that I was driving through were completely untouched and were basically not under threat. It was a very strange feeling to know that you were only a few kilometres from areas that were going to be transformed forever and yet there was going to be no impact on yourself or your own area.

Almost every member who has spoken here today has talked about the work that they did either in preparation for the floods or the cyclones or in the after-effects. I myself did get involved and did some sandbagging work with my friend the member for Stafford. I also got very involved in some of the clean-up, particularly in Fairfield, a suburb where I have previously lived and continue to have a number of friends who suffered serious flooding and major property damage. I also had the great privilege of spending a day in Goodna, one of the most badly affected areas from these floods, assisting a Vietnamese couple tear paint off their walls, which had been completely destroyed. That couple had lived in this particular house for about 14 years. A couple of years ago they moved in with the woman’s parents in order to save money so that they could have a baby. They were now facing the fact that all of the money that they had saved to have a baby was going to have to be spent on restoring their house. That is just one small example of the terrible effects that these floods have had on people.

A number of people here have spoken already about the great community spirit that has been on display throughout these events. If there is a silver lining to be seen it is the community spirit that we have witnessed come through. That has been displayed at a local level within the electorate of Everton. A number of community groups were very directly involved in the flood recovery work. I particularly want to single out the Apex Club of Albany Creek, which went out on a number of occasions to perform clean-up work. I know it has done some work at the Milpera school and in other areas as well. The Nexus Church in Everton Park went out on a number of occasions all around South-East Queensland and I know that it is intending to continue to do that as well. I want to pay tribute to those two particular community groups. There are no doubt a number of others which have really assisted with this work as well.

The other thing that has happened locally following the floods is that a number of schools and businesses got behind the stationery appeal which was conducted to support children who had lost everything when it was time to go back to school. Albany Creek State School, Albany Hills State School, Eatons Hill State School and St Williams Catholic School at Grovely all collected stationery from their families. The Albany Creek Centro shopping centre and the Nextra newsagency within that shopping centre also went out of their way to put out buckets and they collected a very large amount of stationery. We were able to drop a very full car load of stationery--it was probably packed to a dangerous level--to OneSteel so they could distribute it amongst the kids who needed it. Again, I want to take the opportunity to thank those people in my area who have really come forward and helped out people whom they had never met and probably will never meet.

In the long term it is going to be interesting to see the attitude of people in areas like mine who were not directly affected by these floods and the degree to which these people remain generous and are prepared to make sacrifices for the greater good and for those people who have lost everything. So far, as I have been talking to local residents and community groups, I have been incredibly pleased that people do understand that it is one of those times when people in our area have been very fortunate and we have to tighten our belts to assist people who have lost everything. I really plead with people in my area to maintain that attitude as we go forward and continue to contribute to the flood and cyclone recovery effort.

The last thing I want to reflect on again is the incredible community sentiment which has been displayed. Previously I have said that one of the things that I have enjoyed most since I entered this House only a couple of years ago is seeing how alive community spirit is in Queensland. It has been very fashionable to talk about the loss of community and the fact that people do not know their neighbours anymore and that kind of thing. Ever since I was elected I have been really surprised by the number of people who have been prepared to reach out and get involved in their community. Again, these floods have really demonstrated that. I have talked about some of the local community groups and local residents who have been prepared to get up and put their community first. I think that is something that we really need to hang on to into the future. We need to take every chance to offer people opportunities to contribute to their community in the years ahead. With those few words, I commend the motion to the House and again express my deep condolences to all of those who have been affected by these terrible events.

Mr FINN (Yeerongpilly--ALP) (4.47 pm): Today we pause and reflect on the tragedies of the past two months across our state. Three cyclones since December and extensive flooding throughout Queensland have left thousands of people without their homes and belongings but, most tragically, 36 people without their lives.

Today I join with my colleagues in feeling great sadness--a sadness arising from the horror of the stories of tragedy and a sadness felt as fellow Queenslanders. The loss of these lives brings with it hundreds of Queenslanders in pain. As we recover from disaster, the pain felt by those who have lost a family member, a friend, a workmate or a neighbour will remain long after the last creek is cleaned up, the last house is rebuilt and the last piece of damaged infrastructure is repaired.

As I speak in the House today I do so with the great honour of representing a community that is both resilient and lucky. The electorate of Yeerongpilly, with its riverside suburbs of Fairfield, Yeronga and Yeerongpilly along with the low-lying suburbs of Rocklea and Salisbury, was hit hard as the wall of water from Toowoomba and the massive rainfall in the Bremer and Wivenhoe catchments barrelled down the Brisbane River. More than 150 streets were flooded and some 1,600 houses were inundated, and yet we are lucky. Many of our houses went underwater, many of our belongings were lost and our parks, playgrounds, sporting facilities and clubhouses were devastated. We lost our cars, our TVs, our computers, our phones and our PlayStations. We suffered great anguish and our recovery will be long, yet we were lucky. We lost our livelihoods, but not our lives; our belongings, but not our breath. On behalf of the muddy and flooded homeless folk of Yeerongpilly, I express our sadness and wishes of peace to those communities that have suffered great loss and to those families who have lost loved ones. Our prayers and thoughts are with you.

I was on holidays when the news of the flooding threat to houses in my community filtered through. I did not know the gravity of the event or what was coming, but making my way home required an early-morning flight, and I woke at 4 am on Wednesday to phone messages from Melinda, the P&C manager at Yeronga State School, frantically seeking bedding for 20 people who were spending the night at the school hall.

Arriving in Brisbane that morning was surreal. Driving home from the airport, I could see that the river was high but the streets were clear. It was a bit rainy but there was not a gale and the sun was breaking through. There was, however, an impending sense of fear and doom. Something was up. The shops were closed and there were not many people around. People who were moving around seemed to do so with a special purpose. When I reached Melinda at the Yeronga school, the disaster began to unfold. Fairfield Road was already underwater and the river peak was still many hours away. As the day wore on, the news reports came of people being rescued from their roofs in Rocklea.

I spent that Wednesday in the school hall as people escaping the floods arrived in shock, carrying plastic bags with all the belongings they could save, often with a cat in a shoe box or a dog on a lead and wearing the muddy signs of wading through the floodwaters.
