There was shock at the speed and the reach of the rising water. The rest of the day has become a bit of a blur, really. The hall was rapidly filling up with donated bedding. People started turning up with food, including baking that they had been doing all day because they could not get to work, and the barbecue was firing up. People were sleeping on the hall floor, while others played chess or watched the unfolding drama on TV--but most were just sitting down, hoping to wait it out.

By afternoon, word had spread of this evacuation centre at Yeronga, and helpers arrived and donations came fast. A couple of fantastic workers from the Multicultural Development Association arrived and found safe and dry housing for some of the families sheltering in the hall. Non-flooded locals began turning up and taking people to their homes to provide them with showers and in several cases to stay with them. The school hall became a haven of safety for the rapidly rising water, as government efforts focused on rescue and evacuation.

Later that day the evacuation centre opened at QEII stadium. When we lost power at dusk, it was clear that we needed to get people to QEII, where they could be better looked after. I will never forget that experience of driving families, with all their worldly belongings in the back of a 24-year-old LandCruiser Troop Carrier, in the dark, with all of the traffic lights out, and using the backstreets, hoping I could get through, with the major roads of Fairfield, Beaudesert, Riawena and Ipswich roads all impassable. The next 48 hours saw the river level peak and the continued devastation of local homes and businesses before the water started to recede on Friday.

The first indication I had of the extraordinary volunteer effort about to happen was in Rocklea on Friday morning. It was about 7 am and only a few homes were accessible and a few locals were around surveying the damage. A couple of men stopped in a truck to ask me who they could help. They had driven down from Maleny that morning, because they had lived in Rocklea in 1974 and they knew that people would need help.

There have been many descriptive accounts of our suburbs looking like war zones. On the weekend of 15 and 16 January, the local area felt like another world. The Army controlled the major roads and limited access to local streets, which had become mud tracks. The streets were teeming with muddy strangers and four-wheel drives, and the piles of belongings and livelihoods were building up on nature strips. Early on the Saturday morning, Phil Reeves and I set up a gathering point and barbecue area on a street corner in Rocklea. Phil had gathered volunteers from his area, and his wife, Megan, had spent the night baking, and we set out to support people who were cleaning up.

We set up outside a house on Leeds Street, where there was no-one home when we arrived. But, shortly after, the owners Neil and Karen Smith arrived home. They immediately embraced us, opened up their house for people to use their bathroom, and thus began a two-week occupation of Neil and Karen’s driveway, garage, nature strip and front yard. The Moorooka Lions came along to run the barbecue, and the house on the corner became a place of replenishment and refreshment and a place of solace from the awful task of dragging your belongings onto the nature strip and tearing the walls and ceilings out of your house. Neil and Karen are true local heroes who supported their community at their time of greatest need, and I thank them sincerely.

Over in Fairfield, Nicki and Anthony Cassimatis set up a similar barbecue and refreshment centre on their footpath to feed the volunteers and provide support to Fairfield residents. There was always a crowd there, and Nicki and Anthony kept it going for two weeks as the clean-up continued. This was incredibly valuable as it provided a great location for information dissemination, and the Queensland Health vaccination van could provide service where people were gathering. Nicki and Anthony and the volunteers who supported them are similarly true local heroes, and I thank them sincerely, too.

I am fortunate to live in Moorooka, in a house that was not flood affected. I cannot imagine the feeling of the loss of all my belongings in a flood or a cyclone. What I did experience, however, was being the first person to see inside a number of houses after the floodwaters receded. It is an eerie sensation to look at a house untouched and unopened while those around them are in the midst of clean-up. The only thought you can have is, ‘I hope those people are okay,’ and the normal reaction is to knock on the door, to walk around the back and to call out. In a few cases the floodwater left doors open or windows broken out, and peering inside was frightening. No sense can be made of the shambles the water left behind. Nothing can prepare you for the mud, the smell, the chaos and the devastation. In each of the cases of houses eerily untouched, the residents were able to be found and the clean-up was able to begin. I thank the police for their attention to my request for welfare checks and their prompt reporting back to me. It was always a relief to learn that people had been found safe and well.

In Rocklea, the state school is yet to open for 2011, with the school buildings inundated and very little of the teaching resources salvageable. It is a small but proud school community at Rocklea, and I am pleased that we have kept the school community together on the site of Moorooka State School. I hope that the time at Moorooka is more of an adventure than an inconvenience for the children of Rocklea. The suburb of Rocklea was one of the hardest hit in Brisbane, with the low-lying houses surrounded by industrial zones and waterways that flood often. They are a tough lot in Rocklea, though, and the stoicism and determination of the local community is shining through as people rebuild their lives and their homes.

In Yeronga, the state school hall was established as a Department of Communities recovery centre, and the school P&C established a drop-in service to collect donations and provide meals and drinks for people, many of whom are still without power as they gather the resources they need to rebuild. Like the homes of Neil and Karen and Nicki and Anthony, the drop-in service at the Yeronga recovery centre became a place of solace and protection and the heart and soul of our community in recovery. The drop-in centre continues today, with services provided at the school’s preschool building, and I thank the Yeronga State School community for managing with the disruption to the start of the school year and for ensuring the service can continue as school returns to normal.

The team of volunteers at the Yeronga school has been directly responsible for many flooded families being able to cope with their losses and the rebuilding task in front of them. Led by Melinda McInturff--an indefatigable and resilient, never-give-up community champion--the team of Jan Potts, Fiona McLeod, Yvonne Ward, Meg Clarke, Sue Baker, Sue Sinnamon, Catherine Goth, Kath Farley, Midge Dowd, Michelle Henkell, Marion Emery, along with Jill and a host of others, including their children and partners, contributed a tower of work to support our community and people in most need, and they continue to do so.

There are so many people to thank and so many businesses and organisations to acknowledge for their support. The Electrical Trades Union provided fantastic assistance and worked directly with me to identify people most in need of help to have their power restored. This work supported many people with little capacity to undertake the work themselves and helped provide their first steps in recovery. To the team of teachers from the Gregory Terrace school and the gang from the Australian Services Union: I say a special thankyou. These people assisted me by doorknocking every affected house in 150 streets in two days following the big clean-up weekend. They gathered direct information on continuing needs, enabling my volunteer efforts to be targeted.

I thank the team from the Yeronga Neighbourhood Watch--Laurie Jensen, Carolyn Ross, Catherine Goth, Pauline Rose, Jaqueline Steffan, Paul Ivory and Andrew and Yvonne Ward--along with local ALP branch members, who repeated this doorknocking effort last weekend to gather details of ongoing needs. I thank Jason from the Chalk Hotel who donated refreshments for Australia Day events, and I also thank Michelle Francis for organising a great Australia Day street party in Yeronga. I also acknowledge Farmcraft at Acacia Ridge who helped with my call for donations for the RSPCA.

There were countless local businesses that supported the Yeronga recovery centre’s needs for meals and sustenance. These include Woolworths Moorooka, Coles at Greenslopes, Liz’s Deli, JJ’s Fruit Market, the Red Lion Hotel, Dollar Dazzlers at Moorooka, the Oriental Taste, Mu’ooz and Ho Choi restaurants, Made in Africa Cafe, Brumby’s Moorooka, Mallan Bulk Meats and Pauls Parmalat in South Brisbane. Yeronga State High School, Wellers Hill State School, Mansfield State High School and Whites Hill State College also provided recovery support.

Along with the mud army volunteers, all of this support has been part of the biggest community action any of us have experienced in Brisbane’s history. This is a story of mateship, of compassion, of mucking in and helping out. It is a story we can all be proud of. It gives us a remarkable base on which to rebuild not only our houses but also the ongoing bonds central to our neighbourhoods, society and culture.

I also received great support from my parliamentary colleagues with the members for Mansfield, Albert, Chatsworth, Lytton, Stretton, Waterford, Stafford, Woodridge, Everton and Greenslopes providing support to the local clean-up efforts. The Premier, the Deputy Premier and Ministers Wilson, Reeves and Struthers all visited the local area to provide support and determine government assistance relevant to their portfolios. Councillors Steve Griffiths and Nicole Johnston worked tirelessly to help people in need and to organise the local flood response and ongoing recovery. Federal member for Moreton, Graham Perrett, also worked across the local area with passion and commitment.

The sports minister made an early visit to my sporting clubs and assessed firsthand the damage at St Brendans Rugby League Club, Yeronga AFL, Souths Cricket Club and Olympic Soccer Club fields and facilities. Already equipment assistance grants have been approved for some of these clubs and local sport will be up and running rapidly. Thanks to some great assistance from the AFL, the junior teams at Brothers St Brendans are back training on their fields and the season will start as normal.

Last weekend I assessed the damage at the Croatian Community Centre which is located very close to the Oxley Queensland Urban Utilities water repatriation plant that contaminated Oxley Creek and surrounding areas. A massive effort is needed to return the club’s soccer fields back to a playable state.

There is significant concern in my local community about the practices of insurance companies. Tricky definitions of flood, storm and water inundation, the lack of transparency in decisions to reject claims, secrecy about who they engage to prepare hydrology reports, discouragement of policy holders to submit claims by a simple dismissal, delays in arranging assessors, not meeting their committed time frames to get back to people and not being able to estimate when rebuilding work may commence are all hindering recovery in my community.

Insurance companies must work out new ways to cover people for tragic events or they must face a new regulatory regime. There has been 37 years between flood events for many of the houses in Yeerongpilly and many people have paid 37 years of premiums. It is time for insurance companies to reassess their risk profiles.

I recognise the commitments of Suncorp, RACQ and the Commonwealth Bank to provide some support to people without cover. I call on them to ensure their subsidiary companies do likewise. I was particularly concerned with media reports last Friday of the experience of a Fig Tree Pocket resident with CGU and the many anecdotal reports I am receiving about companies summarily dismissing enquiries, discouraging claims and rejecting claims without detailed reasoning.

On the whole, insurance companies, despite the way they advertise, do not trade in compassion or trust. You pay them in good faith, rely on their advice and expect them to be there for you in times of tragedy. Instead, their first response is to question how they can avoid paying out.

Tonight I will be launching a local campaign calling on non-affected people to pressure their insurance companies by considering the compassionate response of their insurers when renewing their own policies and requesting a written outline of the company’s actions. This campaign will also include development of a local photo bank to assist policyholders to question decisions to reject their claims.

The road to full recovery will be a long one for the flooded people and families in my local area. We know that the post-traumatic profile of disaster affected areas means tough times ahead. The volunteering efforts in Fairfield, Yeronga, Yeerongpilly, Salisbury and Rocklea are now focusing on the events, activities and social opportunities we can organise to keep our community together.

We are dislocated right now with people living with friends and families in other suburbs. We need to keep bringing people back to their neighbourhoods to share their experiences and to support each other. Our current ghost town like streets need to become vibrant, friendly neighbourhoods again and we need to harness our collective strength to reacquaint, rebuild and recover.

We are a resilient, stoic and lucky community in the Yeerongpilly electorate. We have strong local support networks and a great capacity to help each other. We will rebuild and recover and we will do it together. In true Queensland spirt, we have been knocked down but we are straight back up again.

Hansard-Body.A: (Chatsworth--ALP) (5.04 pm): I rise to add my support to the condolence motion that has been so well supported by all members of the parliament both yesterday and today and on behalf of the Chatsworth electorate pass on our condolences to those who have lost family members or loved ones during the recent disasters that have befallen our great state.

XML.Hansard-Body: The Chatsworth electorate was thankfully not directly impacted by the floodwaters. However, many people have friends and families who have been directly impacted by the floods or more recently by the ferocious assault delivered by Cyclone Yasi on the people in Mission Beach, Tully and the surrounding areas in North Queensland. I have family members living in Cairns, Mission Beach and Feluga. My wife and I had a restless night, as did many Queenslanders, waiting to see the fate of our families the night Cyclone Yasi bore down.

Many Chatsworth residents own or work in businesses that have been impacted by the floods. I know that many people have suffered significant loss, personally and financially. However, Chatsworth residents, like those from all other areas across the state, rose to the challenge and got involved in assisting their fellow Queenslanders by joining in the relief effort. They volunteered as members of the mud army, donated money, organised fundraisers and generally did whatever they could to ease the pain of their neighbours. I know this because I met them. I met them at Norman Park when I was working with the member for Bulimba. I met them in the streets of Milton as they were helping to clean up the mud stained houses in and around that area.

One story I would like to mention is that of Michael James, the butcher at Carina North Meats. He allowed his shop to be used during the night by a flood affected butcher from the Sherwood area. Michael would do his day’s work, clean up his shop, clean his utensils and the other butcher would come in and do the night shift. He would use Michael’s equipment so that he could keep filling his orders and paying his workers. This type of selflessness was on display throughout Queensland. I commend all of the residents of Queensland and, in particular, the Chatsworth residents for their contribution to the relief effort.

I know there were a number of people who wanted to volunteer but who felt that they could not get access. I turned up at one of the council volunteer centres to be told that they were fully booked in the morning. Some 25,000 people had already enrolled. I think it is a good time to suggest to people that if they want to be sure that they can help next time there is an event--and there will be a next time--that they have some training. When a cyclone is approaching the coast or when the waters are rising is not necessarily the best time to volunteer. The best time is now. They should go down to their local SES and join the local SES or the local volunteer rural fire brigade and get the training they need so that when something like this happens they have the skills and knowledge needed to be an effective volunteer and to help out a bit more professionally. I am not taking away from the mud army and those who turned up on the day. The SES and the rural fire brigades can always do with more people. An event like this might be a good time for people to take that opportunity to go down and get their orange uniform, get some training and get involved in volunteering across Queensland.

I would also like to pass on my thanks to the emergency services workers, the police and the volunteers who performed so magnificently during the floods and the cyclone. However, I would specifically like to acknowledge the great work done by firefighters across this state and, in particular, the professionalism and bravery of the firefighters involved in the Toowoomba flash flood rescues on 10 January.

The bravery of these firefighters can only be fully understood by people who have the knowledge and experience of the dangers of fast-moving water. It is an incredibly dangerous environment to work in. I watched on TV, as we all did, my ex-colleagues standing up to their chests in that flowing water. I know the stress that they must have been under. I know that on that day they saved lives. There is no doubt about it.

The events that we have suffered over the last month could shake our confidence and make us feel a little less safe in our day-to-day lives. But I think we can all be reassured by the magnificent work done by our police, firefighters, ambulance workers, SES personnel, EMQ staff and everyone else who has moved in and taken on the task of keeping the people of Queensland safe and rebuilding it after the events we have had.

Natural disasters tend to bring out the best and the worst in people. It makes some people stronger and it can cause others to falter. It is incumbent upon all of us here to make sure we assist those who falter and keep a close eye on our fellow Queenslanders as the days and weeks pass because sometimes they need assistance weeks later. I know from my experience living in Mission Beach during Cyclone Larry that you can hear the tiredness in people’s voices sometimes two or three weeks later. We need to make sure that we maintain vigilance and look after the people in those areas.

I am very privileged to represent the people of the Chatsworth electorate. However, events such as those we have experienced over the past couple of months remind us that we have an obligation to work together in the best interests of this entire state. To that end, it is important that all members of this House--privileged as we are to represent the people of Queensland--ensure for those people who have lost their lives, homes and livelihoods, for those who have contributed so much and for those who are still to make their contribution that we continue to work together to ensure that Queensland emerges from this stronger, better prepared and more resilient.

Mr POWELL (Glass House--LNP) (5.10 pm): I too begin by publicly extending my condolences and those of my constituents to my colleagues and their communities. In particular, I extend my heartfelt sympathies to the members for Lockyer, Toowoomba South and Hinchinbrook. Please know that you are in my prayers and those of many from Glass House.

The events of December and January and subsequently February of this year have left us all speechless and dismayed but ultimately inspired. The electorate of Glass House was left relatively unscathed from these events. I say ‘relatively’ because, whilst we have been left damaged and scarred, we did not suffer loss of life and we did not witness the extraordinary inundation of property and businesses that places like Condamine, Theodore, Rockhampton, Bundaberg, Gympie, Toowoomba, the Lockyer Valley, Ipswich, Brisbane and now the area around Hinchinbrook experienced.

It is with a heavy heart that I realise the topography of my electorate has indeed contributed to this loss in many other communities. Not for many, many years have Glass House locals witnessed the deluges of December and January. Maleny, in the Sunshine Coast hinterland, the home of my electorate office, has an average monthly rainfall of 190 millimetres in December and 270 millimetres in January. In the months just past, Maleny received 685 millimetres in December and an extraordinary 890 millimetres in January, including an astonishing 700 millimetres from 9 to 12 January. Down the hill in Peachester, with average monthly falls of 175 and 300 millimetres respectively, we had 530 millimetres and 930 millimetres in December and January--with, again, a shocking 740 millimetres over those disastrous four days in January.

Even as waterlogged as the Glass House electorate has become, the water runs off very quickly, such is the nature of the topography in the area. But it is where it ran off to that is hardest to accept. Half of that rainfall pounded down the Mary River, swamping Gympie and Maryborough and isolating many communities in its path. The other half stormed down the Stanley River and the Mary Smokes Creek, backed up behind the already swollen Somerset Dam, resulting in excess water being held in the Wivenhoe system and leading to the releases that inundated Ipswich and Brisbane. Whilst we can do a lot as MPs, we have no control over geography or the weather but that does not lessen my frustration that the rain that fell in Glass House contributed to the misery of so many individuals.

Whilst the water passed quickly through the electorate, it did leave destruction in its path. That same topography that I just spoke of means that in Glass House we have a propensity to landslides, and we do them well. Not a single one of my main roads that includes the name ‘Maleny’ in it has not got at least one if not two or three major landslides shutting at least one lane. The Maleny-Kenilworth, the Maleny-Stanley River, the Maleny-Montville and the Landsborough-Maleny have all been affected in some way. Many properties also have been affected by landslides, like some in the neighbouring electorate of Buderim. In fact, one house in Stony Creek has had to be evacuated as a landslide moves progressively closer and closer to that property. There is concern in places such as Buderim that, again, insurance will not cover these instances.

There was other devastation in Glass House as well. I visited the owner of the Sweethearts Cafe in the sleepy little railway community Eudlo on Wednesday, 12 January. She and her husband and neighbours were mucking out the business for the second time in three days. It went under on the Sunday, they cleaned it out on the Monday, only to see it go under again on the Tuesday. She was heartbroken and discouraged, but she is open for business again and serving her wonderful community.

I spent a lot of time in the Mary River community of Conondale. Locals relate stories of debris backing up on the already damaged Grigor Bridge, causing a bow wave of some five to eight metres to spurt up and over the swamped Maleny-Kenilworth Road. That kind of pressure again damaged the bridge closing it for more than a week, splitting Conondale in two and isolating communities further downstream such as Kenilworth. That same water cut off families and the community of Crystal Waters upstream as well, and it took out vital services such as electricity and telephones, some of which still have not been restored. We are talking about a community, despite being only some 20 kilometres from the coast, that does not have mobile phone coverage. Yet these people too battled on. The operator of the Conondale General Store, Ash, despite watching his business suffer because of no through traffic, ferried people and supplies down to the bridge so they could walk across, collecting vehicles on the other side. The Grigor Bridge needs to be replaced, not repaired. It has served the community of Conondale well but it is time to install a new non-timber, flood-proof structure so this vital route to the communities of the Upper Mary Valley can remain open in all weather events.

Turning to the community of Woodford on the Stanley River, it is not widely known but it too housed an evacuation centre for the days after 10 January. Several houses were damaged in Woodford and Delaneys Creek, but the majority of those seeking refuge at the Woodford community centre were travellers from communities further west, from Kilcoy, Stony Creek, Villeneuve and further afield who were trapped because of the rising floodwater. My thanks go to Michael Wallis and Michelle Knight for their caring stewardship of the centre and its occupants. Thanks also go to the community recovery teams that were on hand to lend support, to the countless volunteers and to the many who contributed supplies of food and clothing.

At this point, I would also like to acknowledge the work of Sergeant Jason Renwick of the Woodford police. I do not know whether the Minister for Main Roads is aware, but Jason played a pivotal role in ensuring that the D’Aguilar Highway over Mary Smokes Creek could reopen when it did and that it was not further damaged by truckies who were exuberant in their desire to get their rigs on the move sooner than the highway realistically could handle.

It was while in Woodford that I got to spend some time with the Woodford auxiliary fire service. The crew were ferrying supplies down Neurum Road to the ‘temporary sea’ that was the backed-up Somerset Dam. Where the road slipped below this inland sea, they were loading up a flotilla of volunteer boats to restock the isolated communities of Villeneuve and Glenfern. So to Laura, Tony and the rest of the team--thank you, job well done. I must also highlight the efforts of the federal member for Longman, Wyatt Roy, and division 12 councillor, Adrian Raedel, from the Moreton Bay Regional Council. Both of these guys stepped up to the mark and delivered for their communities. It is a real pleasure to work alongside them both.

Then there is Bellthorpe--the small, meandering community nestled on top of the Bellthorpe Range west of Maleny and north of Woodford. There are only three ways into Bellthorpe--up the notorious Bellthorpe Range Road, via Gap Road from Maleny and, when desperate, the four-wheel drive forestry track up from Stony Creek. After the rain in January, two of these routes were destroyed. The council is only now getting in to start the clean-up on Bellthorpe Range Road. Repairs will happen but not for some time. Gap Road is also still closed, but Councillor Raedel and his team are moving mountains, quite literately, to open a side track. So, for now, residents must resort to the dangerous and circuitous four-wheel drive forestry track. In essence, the community of Bellthorpe remains isolated some five weeks after the events of January. So while the recovery and rebuilding commences, I ask members to spare a thought for the people of Bellthorpe. I know they are not alone, but they are frustrated, angry and desperate.

I, too, would like to place on the record my sincerest gratitude for the leadership and the valued contribution of our police and emergency services crews. To do that I must relate a personal story from that fateful Tuesday in January. As 355 millimetres fell in the catchment, my home town of Palmwoods also became cut off, albeit for less than 24 hours. The only way in and out was for our vehicles to be escorted onto a footpath and guided through the floodwaters by the local Palmwoods rural fire brigade. Guys like Malcolm Brown and ‘Digger’ Diggines and the rest of the team stood in torrential rain for the whole day and into the evening directing traffic through the water and into the town.

In one of those quirky and Australian--no, Queensland--traits, the boys received their thanks and reward from the local business community. The manager of the local Eagle Boys dropped down a tonne of pizzas and the newsagent gave them a carton of beer--to be consumed when off duty of course! The selflessness of the rural fire brigade team and the gratefulness of the local business owners epitomise for me the events of January, and all I can do is say thankyou to them all.

Thanks also go to the many groups, individuals and communities as a whole that have banded together to raise funds for the flood and cyclone affected communities. I am very pleased to report to the member for Lockyer that last Saturday the Maleny community, led by Sharon from Easton Lawyers, raised $5,500 through a cent auction, with all proceeds going directly to Grantham Flood Support. That is just one example of fundraising by the communities in Glass House.

This is my first opportunity to speak since my appointment as shadow parliamentary secretary for mental health, drug strategy and health personnel, and it is rather apt. Increasingly we are aware, through research and experience, that the effects of natural disasters of this magnitude remain with individuals--adults and children alike--for not only the couple of weeks that the member for Chatsworth referred to but for many years to come. I refer to an article in Family Matters by Catherine Caruana titled ‘Picking up the pieces: family functioning in the aftermath of natural disaster’ which states--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Loss is central to the experience of disaster--loss of home, loved ones, independence, identity and a sense of the world as a safe place--and it is the way in which this loss is accommodated that will determine how individuals, families and communities rebound. While a certain percentage emerge from adversity with greater personal resources, most will suffer a degree of distress in the short term, and a minority will suffer chronic, enduring psychological impairment. Adolescents and children in the middle primary grades are particularly vulnerable to the effects of trauma and social upheaval, especially if parents or caregivers are similarly affected.
XML.Hansard-Body: We can look to our southern cousins for direction when it comes to addressing this matter. The Victorian Department of Human Services has prepared a comprehensive document, the Victorian psychosocial recovery framework, to map out the key steps involved in helping individuals and communities recover mentally. It outlines the actions taken in the immediate aftermath of the bushfires as well as the support planned in the medium and longer term. The same department has recently released an update in which it has identified that successful service responses to date and into the future need to have four factors. First, they need to be outreach oriented. Many people are reluctant to use formal services. They are more likely to talk to people whom they have met and grown to trust or who have an established profile in the community. Second, services need to be informal and flexible. Models of service work best if they can be adapted to the situation and people whose lives and communities are often still in a state of disruption and overload. People with mild to moderate psychosocial problems are often able to benefit from shorter, less frequent and more immediate consultations with professionals, especially if they are local or in the form of visits. Third, services need to be integrated with local community activities. Many people will use professional advice during a conversation after a meeting, over a coffee or at a community gathering. Fourth, they need to include social and group opportunities. Sometimes problems arise from a lack of understanding of what are normal responses. There is a need to talk and share information and problem solving among the affected community.

In conclusion, I encourage the Reconstruction Authority to consider these learnings as it continues to rebuild communities physically and individuals and families mentally. If it does not and if we as leaders do not address the psychosocial after-effects of these natural disasters, then we are leaving the rebuilding job only half done and are potentially condemning many Queenslanders to a life of trauma and illness.

Hansard-Body.A: (Caloundra--LNP) (5.24 pm): I rise to make a contribution to the debate of the condolence motion before the House. I start by passing on my sincere condolences and those of all residents of Caloundra to all those who lost loved ones in the flood and other disasters. The will and resolve of a people is truly tested when forces that cannot be controlled are hurled against them and they not only withstand the onslaught but, by their will and resolve, show that they will not be beaten. In such a battle, however, some will endure events and witness sights that will be forever close to the surface of their minds. Yesterday and today we have heard many members speak passionately about the violence of the floods and the cyclone in their electorates and in this state--violence that took lives and destroyed property, businesses, crops, roads and many other things.

XML.Hansard-Body: I want to briefly mention another form of violence: violence to the mind--to the minds of the children, adolescents and adults who lived through the terror and the minds of the men and women who have been involved and will be involved in the recovery. We know that natural disasters have a psychological impact on people, but what that impact will be will vary considerably depending upon the nature of the event, the communities themselves and the individual characteristics of the people involved. A psychological impact can include depression, anxiety, sleep disorders, complicated grief and nightmares. Children can suffer depression, separation anxiety--they can re-experience the event in nightmares and re-enact in play--as well as guilt, avoidance behaviour, fear of recurrence and worry for the safety of others.

There have been a number of disasters looked at in this context. During the floods of 1974 people suffered health issues including headaches, irritability, nervous tension, depression, worrying, fatigue and sleeplessness. These people were dealing with financial difficulties, emotional strain and family problems. My friend the member for Glass House quoted from an article by Catherine Caruana. I also quote from that article as follows--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: The more a victim’s family can turn to its own members or to extended kin for comfort, a sense of safety and material aid, the more likely it will be that they will rebound from disaster psychologically.
XML.Hansard-Body: Queensland has suffered two natural disasters. Both were devastating events. Both have left a trail of destruction--firstly and overtly physical and secondly and perhaps covertly mental stress. The reconstruction of Queensland is underway. Importantly, the mental wellbeing of the victims must be part of this process.

Hansard-Body.A: (Broadwater--ALP) (5.28 pm): On behalf of the people of my electorate of Broadwater on the Gold Coast, I extend to the people of Queensland who have lost loved ones, friends and colleagues in the natural disasters that battered our state since December 2010 my sincere condolences. Like many people, I watched the daily news reports as the days of rain and storms delivered to many communities in our state such unprecedented damage, devastation, fear and terror. Images flashed upon the television--raging waters swamping houses, sheds, businesses and covering our vast land for miles and miles. It was not long before the waters, moving with such speed and volume, could be considered to be a living, breathing thing--a monstrous being that had a mind of its own that no-one could stop or tame. As I sat in my lounge room feeding my newborn son and staring at the images on TV, I was overcome with disbelief that such a disaster was bearing down on Queensland, its communities and its people.

XML.Hansard-Body: As flooding hit the communities of Queensland, inundating an area greater than that of France and Germany combined, stories of how people had lost their homes, businesses and livestock began to emerge. Watching the footage of raging waters in James Street, Toowoomba left me and my family breathless. I could not believe my eyes nor fathom how this could happen in a city located on a mountain range, nor could we comprehend the news that we all woke up to once the waters had invaded the Lockyer Valley. People going about their daily business suddenly were in the firing line of this monster torrent. The news of the floods’ greatest cost, that being the lives of people in these communities, saddened all Queenslanders. I will never forget watching breaking news reports as the Premier gave two-hourly press conferences informing the public of the rising number of people missing in the aftermath.

We pay tribute to the Rice family of Toowoomba and acknowledge the unbelievably selfless act by 13-year-old Jordan Rice who offered his little brother to rescuers only to be taken with his mother by the strong current. As a mum for the second time, I felt the deepest of sadness for the young mother whose daughter was snatched from her arms by the waters. Hearing this family’s story on 60 Minutes last Sunday gave people an insight into how quickly people had to make decisions to protect themselves and their families. Yesterday, each member in this House stood for one minute’s silence to pay tribute to the lives lost and as a way of conveying to the communities and families who lost friends and family members that we as Queenslanders are thinking of them as they grieve.

Yesterday, this House was united in acknowledging that this heartache is being felt by many of the communities represented by members on both sides of this House. I acknowledge the efforts of my parliamentary colleagues who have worked so hard in their communities facilitating efforts to help people find accommodation, to help people clean out their homes and to help people deal with the tragedy and the devastation. My thoughts are with the member for Lockyer, whose electorate includes the townships of Grantham, Laidley, Murphys Creek and Helidon, and the member for Bundamba, whose electorate includes Riverview, Redbank and Goodna and the great many areas along the river.

Following one of the worst floods in Queensland’s history, our state prepared for Cyclone Yasi to hit North Queensland. The member for Hinchinbrook stood to pay tribute to the people of his electorate who endured a night of terror as Cyclone Yasi hurtled through the towns of Tully and Cardwell. The member for Hinchinbrook spoke so passionately about the towns he represents. I have seen his pride glow when I visited Tully last year to open a new ambulance station and I remember the member telling me about how tight knit the community was and how he had grown up in this area. I say to him that I look forward to returning to Tully and seeing all of those wonderful people again. I am sure they will rebuild and develop that great community spirit again. For many of us, we have been to these towns and it is hard to believe that such pretty, quaint towns with buildings and memorials that tourists and visitors love to see have been torn and ripped apart by Cyclone Yasi or the floods.

I was born in Mount Isa and I am a true Queenslander. I have lived in only one other place in my life and that was overseas. Queensland is my home and I have always been proud. However, after watching the efforts of ordinary Queenslanders helping each other to safety, helping each other to prepare for what the night was going to bring, helping each other with the clean-up after the flood and Cyclone Yasi, I remain in awe of the Queensland spirit, the strength and the generosity of fellow Queenslanders and the bravery of so many people.

On behalf of my constituency, I would like to pay tribute to those volunteers--the mud army volunteers who came to support and help in whatever way they could, from sweeping out mud to cleaning out their local cafe or small business, people offering practical assistance to get people back on their feet. I know that many people felt disappointed that for whatever reason they could not contribute to the recovery efforts of this nature and they sought to make appropriate donations of clothing, food and toiletries and they even baked for the workers and put on sausage sizzles. All over Queensland community groups and Queenslanders did their bit and continue to do so. The Premier’s disaster appeal currently totals $215 million and many of my local community groups have raised money in some way to contribute to this fund. Last week I was at a handover of an $8,000 cheque from the Paradise Point Bowls Club and attended the closing workshop of the Internet Secrets conference, where I acknowledged the $52,000 contribution from its members. There are many stories like this and many people and many businesses have contributed, and I say simply thankyou.

The flooding occurred right before schoolchildren were due to return to their school for the school year and my thoughts are of those communities where children had lost all their back-to-school supplies and gear. Together with the members for Albert and Burleigh, our offices were collection points for people wanting to donate new stationery items to support the kids of the Lockyer Valley and to help them return to school. People on the Gold Coast were extremely generous and many commented that by buying the water bottles or the backpacks or the pens and exercise books for this reason had helped them cope with the frustration of not being able to contribute in any other physical way. It also helped them find strength after seeing such devastating images on the television.

I acknowledge the great team of SES volunteers from the Gold Coast who volunteered for deployment to the Lockyer Valley, many of whom I know left behind their own young families to help out for not just days but in some cases weeks. The two catastrophic events of this past summer have etched in our memories images that we will never forget. These events have also been experiences from which community spirit, bravery and kindness have been witnessed by all, but in particular by younger generations and people who have never heard of these towns.

I would like to commend Assistant Commissioner Ian Stewart for his outstanding efforts in his role as the State Disaster Coordinator and Bruce Grady and all of his team at the State Disaster Coordination Centre. I acknowledge the bravery, the unbelievable heroism and the efforts of extraordinary strength and skill by the EMQ helicopter pilots and crewmen. I would also like to acknowledge the many fire officers who were involved in some 43 swift-water rescues that were undertaken in the Toowoomba area alone. In very dangerous conditions, these people worked to save so many others from raging floodwaters and I know the experience of this summer will affect them in many ways. I would like to acknowledge the many public servants from all departments for their work, their dedication and in many cases their expertise in helping the affected communities prepare and recover. Many of these people have, through their actions and commitment, inspired a nation and can I simply say thankyou.

I thank the Premier for her leadership. The Premier kept us all informed and represented all Queenslanders with genuine compassion and concern as she toured our devastated state from region to region. The Premier worked around the clock with a team of great people. Can I say to the Premier that she did us all proud. On behalf of the people of the Broadwater electorate, I support the motion.

Hon. DM WELLS (Murrumba--ALP) (5.37 pm): The people of my electorate of Murrumba have not always been seen as the most fortunate in the land, but in January they were. A few houses were deluged but we were spared the loss of life and the widespread devastation of which honourable members on both sides of the House have spoken so movingly.

So what does one say on behalf of those who did not suffer to those who did? My constituents would not want me to hold the floor for very long. They would want the available time to go to the representatives of those who suffered the most. But they would like me to express their support for their fellow citizens.

This perhaps is what my constituents would want me to say to the constituents of other honourable members in this chamber. We did not experience your agony, but we share your grief. We were not beside you when you faced the elements, but we have been and will be with you in the aftermath. We will support the measures necessary to help you overcome adversity--knowing, of course, that it will cost us, because we are not strangers. We are the people who rang members of our extended family who happened to live in your suburb to wish them well before the storms. We are the people who filled sandbags and sent them to you. We are the people who drove across town or across country to anonymously clean up your houses. We are the people who supported events such as the fundraising function organised by the Deception Bay Bowls Club, who donated to disaster relief funds and whose taxes will be applied to the reconstruction.

Whoever you are, wherever you live, whatever you believe, in this context we are not your regional rivals, your economic competitors or your political opponents. In this context we are your brothers and sisters and we are proud to help.

Mr RYAN (Morayfield--ALP)
(5.40 pm): I rise to support the condolence motion moved by the Premier and in doing so I extend my deepest sympathy and thoughts to the people who have been touched by the recent and heartbreaking rain, flood and cyclone tragedies.

Some people have lost everything. Some people have lost loved ones. Some people feel as though they have even lost hope. Everyone joins those people in saying we are here to help you through these troubling times. We are here to say we will not forget you. As we have heard from other honourable members, the recent rain, flood and cyclone events are the worst natural disasters in a generation and they have affected a lot of people in a lot of communities. Like all Queenslanders, I have been overwhelmed by the enormity of these events. I find it hard to understand how they happened and how people were affected by them. Watching the events unfold around me on the television earlier this year I felt a sense of helplessness, I felt a sense of powerlessness. My heart goes out to all honourable members and the people they represent who have been affected by these disaster events.

Sadly the people of the Morayfield electorate were not spared from the recent rain and flooding events. Local people will forever remember 11 January 2011 as the day that heartbreak struck our community. I understand that hydrologists monitoring the Caboolture River, Burpengary Creek and Sheep Station Creek catchments were concerned that water levels in these watercourses were rising too quickly and posed a threat to people in low-lying areas. Evacuations and some water rescues were required. Emergency Service workers showed great innovation and courage as they went about their work of saving lives.

A lot of people do not realise how serious the situation could have been in the Morayfield state electorate. At Narangba in the neighbourhood that I live in and just around the corner from my house we had torrents of water flowing down suburban streets. We had rapids. We had water currents so strong that people would have been swept away if they were not careful. We had Emergency Service workers using boats on suburban streets to rescue people from their homes. We had police in canoes. We had cars stranded on the Bruce Highway as a result of the rising floodwaters. We had many people dealing with the horror of having dirty, muddy and putrid floodwaters through their homes.

This horror was also experienced by people in the Burpengary, Morayfield, Caboolture, Moorina and Rocksberg areas. People in every part of the Morayfield state electorate were affected in some way by this natural disaster. But through this tragedy one of humanity’s most inspiring qualities shone through: courage. I admire courage. It inspires, it motivates, it reassures; yet it is also so human. It is so human in how it can touch individuals, how it allows individuals to reach out to others. There was much courage on display on 11 January 2011 in the Morayfield electorate. I saw it; I felt it. The strength of the human spirit, the strength of the Queensland spirit, was felt in every corner of the Morayfield state electorate on that day and in the days and weeks following that tragic day. We see it in our neighbourhoods where neighbours continue to help neighbours recover from this event; we see it in our streets where complete strangers continue to help complete strangers recover from this event; we see it in our communities where people continue to open their hearts, their wallets and their homes to people in need; we see it right across our great state where Queenslanders continue to provide a helping hand to those who need it; we see it around our nation, where Australians continue to say, ‘We are here. We are here to help’.

Interestingly, I heard from my cousins who live in the Indooroopilly area about a recent chance meeting with a young Texan man. This man said he was amazed by the overwhelming community response to the flooding event in South-East Queensland. The young man said that back home in Texas one of three things would happen following a natural disaster: either people would be waiting in their homes for the government to come and help, people would be looting or people would be working out who to sue. The young Texan said that what he was witnessing in Queensland could only be described as humanity heaven. Humanity heaven indeed. Something special happened in our communities and our state in the wake of those heartbreaking tragedies. We proved to each other who we are. We are Queenslanders. We are the ones who look after our mates. We are the ones who pick each other up when we get knocked down. Nonetheless, people have still lost their lives, things have been lost, houses have been lost. These things are people’s things, these houses are people’s homes. We must continually remind ourselves that these people must not be forgotten. It was and continues to be important to me to remind those people in the Morayfield state electorate affected by the recent flooding event that as a community we will not forget them, as a government we will not forget them and as their state member I will not forget them. I will do my best to help them. I will do my best to be with them through these troubling times.

In the days and weeks following that tragic day I went door to door visiting people affected by flooding. I sat with them and I cried with them. I cleaned out flood affected sheds and even got attacked by a water rat. I cleaned out blocked gutters. I attended street meetings and community barbecues. However, I was most moved by a visit to a street in Morayfield. The people who live in this street are poor. I have never seen people so poor. They are poor. But what they lacked in financial capacity they made up for in courage, resilience and inspiration. I cannot imagine how I would respond to seeing everything I own being discarded on my footpath. But the people of this street, these courageous people, told me that they would be alright. ‘It’s the other people’ or ‘It’s my neighbour you need to worry about’, they would say. My faith in the strength of the human spirit was renewed that day in that street.

I would like to thank Councillor Chris Whiting, Councillor Adrian Raedel and Senator Mark Furner for taking time to join me in doorknocking affected people in the Morayfield state electorate. Thank you also to sports minister Phil Reeves for visiting affected sporting clubs with me and to community services minister Karen Struthers for calling me and checking on the people of the Morayfield state electorate. I would also like to put on the record my appreciation to Telstra, in particular Kris Carver from Telstra Country Wide, all Telstra workers in the Morayfield state electorate and the members of the Community and Public Sector Union for helping to get affected people reconnected to the telecommunications network so that they could call their friends and family to tell them that they were alright.
I also thank the members of the miscellaneous workers union who contacted me offering support and assistance. Whenever and wherever help is needed, the Missos are never too far away.

It is also important to note the valuable, tireless and selfless work of local groups and local people throughout the Caboolture region. I say thankyou to the Morayfield and District Lions Club, the Apex Club of Caboolture, the Forest Ridge North Neighbourhood Watch group and all Neighbourhood Watch groups in the Morayfield state electorate, the Rotary Clubs of North Lakes and Caboolture, the Seventh-day Adventist Church on Caboolture River Road, the Queensland Police Service and other emergency services workers, the local newspapers and radio stations and all the local people who helped other local people in one way or another. Thank you. I would like to specifically note the outstanding work of the community recovery team from the Department of Communities. This team was of unbelievable support to affected people throughout the Caboolture region. Everywhere I go I hear people praise this team. They say well done and thank you.

Finally, I say thankyou to our Premier, Anna Bligh. Thank you for your strong, compassionate and dedicated leadership. Your commitment to us, your commitment to Queensland, is truly inspirational. Our community’s response to these heartbreaking tragedies has emphasised that great Queensland spirit of getting involved, helping your mates and working hard for those in most need. Despite our sadness for what has been lost, we should use this opportunity to build on that spirit. Let us challenge each other to be more involved in our communities. Let us get to know our neighbours just a little better. Let us spend more time with those we love. Let us always remember that we live in a great place with great people. Let us never forget that we are Queenslanders.

Hansard-Body.A: (Aspley--LNP) (5.51 pm): On behalf of the residents in the Aspley electorate I wish to offer my sincerest, most heartfelt condolences to those families who have lost so much in these recent natural disaster events. The natural disasters in Queensland have left many communities throughout our state in a position of desperation. The stories shared in this House by my colleagues whose communities were directly impacted by the disasters captured the horrifying extent of the devastation that the floods and Cyclone Yasi inflicted state-wide.

XML.Hansard-Body: For the many Queenslanders directly affected, the colossal and heart-wrenching task of rebuilding lies immediately ahead. The unwavering spirit that has been the driving force behind clean-up efforts across Queensland has been evident to us not only on our television screens and in the newspapers but also in the simple acts of goodwill that have been demonstrated by our local communities. We have heard countless examples in the House this week of how individual willpower and community strength can prove uplifting even in the most tragic of circumstances.

The electorate of Aspley was spared the destruction that has devastated our state, but the community’s willingness to extend an arm of friendship and to help those who need it most has been manifest. It seems that everyone has a family member or friend who has been affected. I think this is the reason we have seamlessly come together as one with the will to restore our state. Queenslanders everywhere, either directly or indirectly, have felt the impacts.

We received many calls at my office from constituents wanting to know how they could help by donating money, clothes, furniture and sundry items to those who were evacuated from their homes. Others wanted to know where to sign up for the next volunteer clean-up day or where to help fill sandbags. We also received extensive feedback from community groups who had organised fundraiser events that received tremendous support from local residents. Everyone just wanted to help.

There was the team at Subway, Carseldine, for example, who donated food for the SES workers and established a drop-off point for locals to donate cans of soft drink and bottled water to be distributed to those hardworking volunteers. Members of the Kedron-Wavell RSL sub-branch loaded five Army trucks from the Gallipoli Barracks with donations, including children’s bikes, clothes, linen and kitchenware, and took them to the flood ravaged town of Theodore. It was these sorts of contributions that ultimately made a big difference to those communities who lost everything.

The Aspley Lions Club held a sausage sizzle fundraiser at Bunnings, Carseldine on Saturday, 15 January. Over $3,500 was raised for the appeal. It was heartening to see people buying up shovels, gumboots and brooms ready to join the ranks of the mud army and assist in any capacity. The following day I joined Councillor Norm Wyndham from the McDowall ward and the Brisbane City Council registration team at Doomben, where around 1,800 volunteers turned up to offer their help. Some came from as far away as the Gold Coast, the Sunshine Coast and interstate. Many of the people I had met the previous day at the sausage sizzle arrived with their shiny, new gear in hand and a positive spirit, ready to provide hands-on assistance to those in need. The selflessness and enthusiasm to help their fellow Queenslanders was truly inspiring and I thank every one of them.

The member for Lockyer offered a moving account of the heroism of local residents in the face of unimaginable adversity. Family members and neighbours helped each other onto rooftops as floodwaters swallowed their homes. Many of us could only watch television footage in sheer disbelief. Thirty-five people perished in the floods and 20 of these were in the Lockyer.

The member for Hinchinbrook spoke of the stoicism and resolve of communities in his electorate and their commitment to rebuilding in the aftermath of Cyclone Yasi. This dogged determination comes as no surprise as they are a pretty tough breed up north.

The leadership and statesmanship demonstrated by my parliamentary colleagues across the political divide at a time when their electorates have been faced with almost total devastation is inspiring. Their constituents have lost their homes, they have lost their possessions and some may have lost family members or friends. This leadership will be needed for a long time to come as people face the enormous challenges ahead. I am confident that Queenslanders will continue to help each other get back on their feet, support affected businesses and see that the state is restored to its former glory.

There have been comparisons made to the 1974 floods and Cyclone Tracy as weather extremities, but the events of the past months have set a new precedent for the 21st century that will demand that we plan accordingly for future infrastructure. Population density is increasing throughout the state and the impacts of natural disasters will only intensify without effective planning. The road ahead is indeed a long and rocky one, and now more than ever the people will demand transparency and compassion from their elected representatives.

This has been a chaotic and harrowing time in Queensland’s history, but we have been served a poignant reminder that sympathy, camaraderie and courage are not in short supply in Queensland. To the police and emergency services workers, the SES, on-call public servants, our Defence Force and the army of volunteers who fought tirelessly to ensure the safety of, and give support to, those affected, I extend a heartfelt thankyou. On behalf of the Aspley constituency I offer my thoughts to those people and undertake that they will remain with them until such time as their areas are back to normal. Our people are here in Aspley whenever or wherever they are needed. You will not be forgotten.

Hansard-Body.A: (Maroochydore--LNP) (5.57 pm): I rise to offer my heartfelt condolences to the families suffering the loss of loved ones and all the impacts flowing from recent tragic events of the floods and cyclone in this summer of 2010-11. While my own area of the Sunshine Coast has been left relatively unscathed, we stand together with other Queenslanders who hurt for those who have lost so much, offering our support, our prayers and commitment not to forget the victims throughout this vast state.

XML.Hansard-Body: In the days and weeks following the different stages of the impact of these disasters there was a clear sentiment from people I met who were saying, ‘Don’t forget us.’ They implored that they would be feeling for some time the impact of the events which had taken them to their knees. The devastating natural forces and the subsequent devastation in many other areas meant that media attention shifted from one crisis to the next unfolding crisis. So we saw a situation where those who had suffered so much did worry that perhaps their particular circumstances, which had been so incredibly difficult, might be cast aside. As we remember in this vast state that there have been so many impacted with such incredible forces of nature, we have a responsibility to remember them all and to work to support them all.

As members of parliament well know, as do the thousands of volunteers and front-line public servants, the hardest work is not done in the media spotlight but in the ongoing slog to repair, restore and rebuild homes, hearts, communities and businesses. I pay tribute to those countless thousands who answered the call for help, to the heroes who risked their lives to save others and to all who slogged in the heat and humidity in the clean-up and rebuild of shattered homes and businesses--and this is ongoing. Our police, the firies, SES, electricity linesmen, other emergency service personnel, council leaders, workers and all involved in front-line services have risen to the task in an outstanding way.

I pay particular tribute to my colleagues Ian Rickuss, the member for Lockyer, and his wife, Ann, whose community was so brutally savaged by flash flooding which took many lives; also to the member for Hinchinbrook, Andrew Cripps, whose beautiful North Queensland electorate was shredded by Cyclone Yasi; to the member for Toowoomba South, Mike Horan; and to so many MPs from across this parliament, across the political divide, who have had a real impact in their local areas but who have also been hands-on in supporting their affected communities. We stand alongside of you.

If there is a silver lining in these terrible events, it has been to see the best of people coming forward, thousands of volunteers, at personal cost to themselves, armed with shovels, brooms, mops; tradies volunteering their labour; and unskilled labour volunteering their elbow grease. I will never forget the sight. It was inspirational. Among the tragedy of lost homes and precious possessions turned to garbage on the kerbside was this wave of people of all ages but particularly young people, giving of themselves.

I was proud to work alongside other workers of the mud army in Brisbane and also volunteers from the Maroochydore Surf Life Saving Club in the clean-up in Ipswich. As the member for Nicklin said, we worked together with this great surf club, and it was wonderful to see these young people in action. Sunshine Coast surf-lifesaving clubs also sent their highly trained volunteers with rubber duckies from the seaside to the front line of inundated streets of Brisbane, working alongside SES personnel to check houses for stranded homeowners. There are many, many other stories of volunteer organisations and of volunteers individually answering the call. There has been something of the Anzac spirit, mates helping mates and strangers providing solace through practical service.

After the immediate crisis, the need for help does not go away. In fact, it can become so much more critical as despair can replace courage when the recovery is prolonged and wearing as people count their losses and bear the daily strain of getting back on their feet and getting their businesses, their farms and their lives back in order. This is a mental burden which can be hard to fathom. In meeting with farmers at Cecil Plains with my colleague the member for Condamine, Ray Hopper, I heard how some of these farmers went under floodwaters not once but twice in a very short period of time. Many lost their third crop in a row. They are hardworking, proud people who do not ask for handouts, but now they have been dealt a devastating blow of losing their homes and their livelihoods, and this is a story that is told in so many areas. They survived the drought--10 years of drought in parts of Queensland--only then to invest in the crop they hoped would be their turning point. And they have lost it. They cannot get back on their feet without help.

Governments have a responsibility to recognise these diverse needs throughout this state and, for us in our personal giving, to equip the front-line services--both professionals and volunteer services--to go where we cannot all go and to give practical help and mental health support. Too many lives have already been lost. We do not want to lose anymore as people struggle to deal with the fallout of their losses. Tragically, we are already hearing stories where this impact is becoming a reality.

There are lessons to be learnt from what went wrong in these events and what went right and how to ensure the rebuilding is done with integrity, efficiency and cost-effectiveness. I will say more on these issues when the Queensland Reconstruction Authority Bill debate is before the House. However, at this time I will note that the Bruce Highway, a National Highway, needs national priority in improving its flood immunity as well as other critical transport links which have been ripped apart.

A few weeks ago I drove from Bundaberg to Rockhampton where I met with affected communities, council leaders and road workers when the Rockhampton Airport was still underwater and the Rockhampton section of the highway had been reopened. Queensland was divided for 12 days when the highway was cut at this critical juncture. But the impact goes long past the recession of the water. There are huge impacts upon people’s livelihoods, on the transport sector and on the businesses that rely upon those transport links. The member for Hinchinbrook, Andrew Cripps, has also raised other transport industry impacts, and I applaud his advocacy, as the repercussions from Cyclone Yasi require special attention for people in the transport and trucking and related industries if they are to survive and to be able to go on serving these local economies on the road to recovery.

There is a long road ahead. But we have seen a magnificent response from Queenslanders. We have seen a generation responding to a cause. In some ways it is almost a rediscovery that our neighbours really are our fellow members of Queensland. But there is a lot of work to be done, a lot of questions to be asked about how to approach these needs and, most importantly, a great need that we do not forget in this vast state the vast areas that have been impacted and the diverse needs that need to be met not only with compassion but also with extremely practical help.

Hon. SJ HINCHLIFFE (Stafford--ALP) (Minister for Infrastructure and Planning) (6.05 pm): Throughout our state’s history our character has been forged by what can be devastating natural forces. The events of this summer of sorrow have further formed Queensland and Queenslanders. Thirty-six lives lost in the wake of these terrible natural forces are an indelible reminder to us all of the frailty of humans. But our humanity means that those 36 lives are not lost to their families, to their friends, to their communities--those 36 lives will continue to touch many, indeed, as evidenced by the poignant contributions by honourable members in heartfelt support of this condolence motion. On behalf of the people of the Stafford electorate, I express our deepest condolences to those who have lost friends or family in the floods and the many others who lost property or suffered hardship as a result of the rising waters and of Tropical Cyclone Yasi.

It has been a terrible time for Queensland and few, even if only through the emotional impact of the tragedy, have gone unaffected. While those directly impacted have struggled with the elements, loss and grief, those around them have rallied to help. This debate has highlighted the breadth of ways in which the true character of Queenslanders has shone through--be it the resilience of those whose homes and businesses have been inundated, be it the courage of our emergency services and utilities workers, or the demonstrations of mateship through the volunteering effort or generous support for appeals for assistance.

In the Stafford electorate our community was spared any direct impact of the great flood of 2011, but our community was there in the response. When my honourable friend the member for Everton joined me at the Newmarket State Emergency Services depot and at the Brisbane City Council’s Stafford depot, both in my electorate, our efforts to fill sandbags saw us as part of teams of many hundreds of volunteers from an array of backgrounds.

For many northsiders, the only way they could contribute was via the fundraising efforts, which began when the floodwaters peaked in Rockhampton and they continue today. I could not mention every effort in this regard, but I will note the efforts of some of those Queenslanders whose character is truly still being moulded. Local schools directly unaffected, such as St Anthony’s in Kedron and St Columba’s in Wilston, have adopted sister parish schools in Ipswich and Rosewood respectively. Students as young as six have written messages of support to pupils they have never met. Last Friday alone, one school raised more than $1,100 for much needed books, uniforms and sporting equipment.

But the contributions do not have to be on that scale. They do not have to be on the scale of the significant contributions from our friends overseas and across Australia that we have heard of during this debate. At Somerset Hills State School at Stafford Heights, one year 3 student and one year 4 student took it upon themselves, and with the assistance of one of their parents, to doorknock their street, and they raised $53.40, which was promptly sent to the Premier’s Flood Relief Appeal.

In addition, students at Wilston State School have filled 80 shoeboxes with small gifts and toys and individually addressed them to the 80 students of the Alpha State School. It is just to let them know people are thinking of them. They went so far as to add extra presents for the young siblings of those students to ensure that no-one was left out.

After having extended the sincere condolences on behalf of my constituents, I would now like to in turn thank northsiders and Queenslanders in general for their generous and ongoing goodwill. The events of this summer of sorrow have formed Queensland and Queenslanders.

Ms STONE (Springwood--ALP)
(6.10 pm): On behalf of the people of Springwood, I would like to express sincere condolences to those families who lost loved ones during this tragic time. The scale of devastation has touched us all. So many people have lost so much--homes, personal memoirs and items that represent their family history. Memories of their lives and businesses have been taken away. We grieve with them, all of them, in their sadness.

We can all remember the scenes before the end of last year of the water rising around Rocky and Central Queensland. I was in contact with a friend living near Theodore. I will always remember her saying to me, ‘When I hear the chopper I always go out and wave because I know it will be someone I know having to evacuate their home. I feel so sad for them and I want them to know that we will be here for them when they return.’ She also told me about the Friends of Theodore group that was set up to assist those in need. I know they raised much needed money to help. I was happy to donate to this organisation and to advertise this charity on my Facebook page. The Friends of Theodore did wonderful work out there.

Then in 2011 we saw more death and destruction from Mother Nature’s force. First the floods and then Cyclone Anthony and Cyclone Yasi impacted on communities from one end of this state to the other. I particularly want to thank the Springwood people who went out and helped with the clean-up and who organised food and drinks and took them into our suburbs of need.

I cannot attend a function or do my shopping without being stopped by people who have stories to tell of either families who have been impacted by the floods or the cyclones or stories of how they helped with the clean-up or stories of the devastation that they saw. They all want to keep assisting because they know how fortunate we have been in Logan. I thank each and every person who donated their time, hard work, money and goods to all those in need.

I know the churches and schools in my area are assisting in communities like Goodna that have lost everything. I visited Goodna with the member for Bundamba. I, along with the people of Springwood, will continue to work with her and Pastor Allan Morris from the Shiloh Christian Church to assist as needs change through the recovery and rebuilding stages. The number of people from my electorate offering their assistance has been outstanding. I look forward to continuing to work with them to assist our fellow Queenslanders.

I know that state government and other workers were put into evacuation centres to assist before these events or assist in setting up services after the devastation. It is not very often we thank our public servants, but today I want to recognise their hard work during this time. I know some of them are still away from their families.

I spoke to someone who told me that at their workplace there were two people who had lost everything. They know that these people will need to be cared for and assisted during the months ahead. Imagine going to work and how you would feel when it is time to go home. People are going home to their home, to their furniture, to their kitchen, to their kitchen utensils, to make their dinner, to hop into their bed, to hop into their clothes and their life has not changed. You work every day alongside them and yet you return to a caravan that a family or friend may have given you or a rental home or a room at someone’s house, to clothes that have been donated and to bed linen that has been donated. You have a place that is shelter but it is not your home. Imagine how that must feel and how hard that must be. We must remain sensitive to those around us and we must remain committed to rebuilding those people’s lives. This must be our No. 1 priority.

I do not think there were too many people who slept the night that Cyclone Yasi hit. While we can never imagine the fear North Queenslanders faced that night, we wanted to be awake and ready to assist as soon as we could. Distance was not going to be a barrier for our spirit had made north and south one. Once again, that true Aussie spirit came out.

I cannot stand in this place today without thanking our wonderful emergency service officers all over our state. The Queensland Police Service used every communication media available to get out information to the community. I, along with many others, watched briefings on YouTube and read many messages on Facebook and Twitter. These messages not only conveyed important information but also showed the variety of jobs our police officers took on during the preparation period and after the devastation.

Anyone from around the world can tune in and watch people like Chief Superintendent Paul Taylor speaking with people in communities flattened by Cyclone Yasi. I hope they will get on to the Premier’s Disaster Relief Appeal site and donate. The briefings from Chief Superintendent Alistair Dawson or Assistant Commission Brett Pointing kept us updated regularly either on TV or through live streaming. They had our attention. I have had the pleasure of working with these three officers so I knew that our state was in great hands.

I know police officers from Logan were sent to various parts of the state to assist those in need and to give some respite to local officers who had worked frantically with their communities. I know they appreciate being sent away for only seven days at a time because it allows them to be with their families and do any necessary work they may have to do if the weather impacted their homes. I thank those officers for assisting their fellow Queenslanders.

Firies and ambos were there to help. Our emergency helicopter officers, rapid water rescue teams and our courageous SES officers from all over our state and other states were there to help. Australia is so fortunate to have them. There is no doubt we have the best emergency services in the world.

An image I will never forget is of the Army working in our communities--moving trees, moving debris off our rail tracks and our roads. I know the Navy also played a very important part in clearing the river and making it safe for water activities to start again. For a country that does not have compulsory national service I say we have a very great country because we know that those men and women of the services are there because they want to be. They want to be there helping us and protecting us. To them I say thankyou.

The electricity workers throughout the state have one mighty job to do and a lot ahead of them. I want to say thankyou to them because I know during times of frustration often our Energex and Ergon workers cop a bit of abuse. They do a mighty job and this will be one of the mightiest they have to do.

To the state disaster management team I say a very big thankyou. Deputy Commissioner Ian Stewart did one almighty job and even had time to Twitter his encouragement and support to all workers on the ground.
