I want to acknowledge every MP in this House who has been impacted by the floods or the cyclones. You have made your communities proud. We can see how much you care for them. We will be here alongside you and assisting you with the rebuilding of your communities.

I said before that I was stopped at functions, at schools, at shopping centres, everywhere by people who said to me--and I want to quote them--‘Please pass on our thanks to Anna. She did one mighty job.’ People from interstate who were staying here at the time of the floods have also told me how impressed they were with the leadership of our Premier. Those who stop me want to tell me what great work she did during this tragic time. Today, I take this opportunity to pass on their thanks. I also want to pass on my thanks to our Premier for her leadership, stamina and compassion during this time.

I finish with an image that all of us will remember. The good chaos that was created by all of those who wanted to help--the thousands who came out with mops, shovels, brooms. Whatever it took to clean up they brought it with them. That image was beamed around the world. I had many people from overseas say to me that it is an image they will remember of Australia because it is an image that would be impossible to find anywhere else in this world. It defined the true Aussie spirit--proud to be Australian, proud to be a Queenslander.

Hansard-Body.A: (Waterford--ALP) (6.19 pm): I, too, rise to add my condolences to those condolences expressed by members who have already spoken to this motion. I also add the condolences of everyone who lives in my electorate. The loss of life from these natural disasters has affected every Queenslander and is something we all feel personally.

XML.Hansard-Body: In Logan, the recent natural disasters were a surreal experience. While we sat there high and largely dry, people living only 10 minutes drive away were hurting from the effects of flooding and other natural disasters. That being said, the people of Logan have done everything they can to assist their neighbours in Brisbane and Ipswich and all over Queensland. There has been some creative fundraising to provide financial support, as well as people who have done their best to provide practical support. There are so many examples.

Dave and Deb from Stockmans Tucker Butchery at Meadowbrook have been holding a sausage sizzle fundraiser every Saturday and have raised thousands of dollars for the Premier’s Disaster Relief Appeal. The Islamic community of Queensland had a massive fundraiser on the weekend after Australia Day, raising tens of thousands of dollars for the relief fund. One of the ones that is most touching to me involved Jeta Gardens, a retirement village in my electorate. The Brisbane-Chinese Lions Club, the Australian United Hospitality Association and the residents of this nursing home came together to provide $6,000 worth of donations to the Premier’s Disaster Relief Appeal.

Also, in terms of practical assistance, I had the pleasure of accompanying radiographers from the Logan Hospital along with volunteers from the Centre Against Sexual Violence to help the member for Yeerongpilly to assist his residents in Rocklea and the Rocklea State School in their clean-up. The Waterford Demons, the local rugby league club, trekked over to Goodna on many days to help out their rugby league rivals at Goodna. The Beenleigh PCYC has also raised tens of thousands of dollars to support the flood recovery effort.

Locally, we were quite fortunate. We had some localised flooding, but we were very fortunate that the Wyaralong Dam was completed in December 2010. It was predicted that it would take five years to fill that dam, but it filled in a matter of weeks.
Mr Hinchliffe: In 25 days.

Mr MOORHEAD: The Minister for Infrastructure and Planning is here to inform the House that it took 25 days to fill when it should have taken five years. As well, Logan is home to many emergency services personnel--firies, ambulance officers and police officers--who have been put on the front line of the rescue and recovery efforts, and that is a contribution that Logan is happy to make.

In conclusion, I would like to briefly mention two other things. The first is the importance of social media in the flood effort. Twitter was a forum where people came together to match those people who were prepared to help with those people who needed help. The QPSmedia Twitter feed gave fantastic advice for residents, particularly with their mythbusters, which put many people at ease. Even Meshel Laurie from Nova 106.9 was able to house many hundreds of pets who might have found themselves homeless during the flood event.

Finally, I would like to pass on the thanks of many of my constituents to the Premier. Even as late as Saturday, the Kingston South Neighbourhood Watch asked me to pass on to the Premier their thanks for her leadership during this time and also for the great supply of information about Cyclone Yasi which meant that the loss of life that could have happened did not happen. That is a great saving for Queensland. I look forward to doing everything that I can and that Logan can to help the rebuild effort in the months to come.

Hansard-Body.A: (Beaudesert--TQP) (6.24 pm): I rise to support the motion of condolence to the Queensland natural disaster victims moved by the Premier of this great state in both sadness and hope. Our sympathy and prayers are with those who have lost their loved ones, whose lives were taken in such tragic events. May their souls rest in peace and one day unite again with us all in the fullness of time. Each and every one of us who have been placed in this parliament as leaders to our respective communities has experienced or been touched in one way or another by the pain and suffering that was inflicted on so many Queenslanders and which made many of us weak during the events that took place but has since made us all that bit stronger as a result of these ordeals.

XML.Hansard-Body: Fortunately there was no loss of life in the Beaudesert region, but it must be noted that the natural disaster has impacted greatly on the livelihoods of many farmers and small businesses in the region. Some residents were evacuated to the Kalbar community centre from Kalbar and the caravan park on the Boonah showgrounds as localised flooding increased and numerous roads were being cut off.

Like those in the rest of Queensland, the communities within the electorate of Beaudesert went above and beyond the call of duty in assisting their neighbours in the stricken Lockyer Valley, Toowoomba, Ipswich and Brisbane regions. I want to acknowledge the numerous fundraisers held throughout the region, including the bush dance at Kerry organised by the Opperman family. There was a ‘Don’t Rock the Boat’ fundraiser held at the Woodhill community centre organised by Ray Fleming and the BobKats as well as our local radio station, BeauFM, which is headed by Michael Bassett, which raised more than $5,500 towards the Premier’s relief fund. The Kooralbyn community held a dance and fundraiser, which was put on by the chamber of commerce. The Tamborine community hosted a fundraiser at the Bearded Dragon Boutique Hotel; this was organised by the Neighbourhood Watch group which was led by Geoff McConnell and Kym ‘Tornado’.

Elina Juusola-Halonen and her team at Caddies Community Care Centre in Jimboomba held a fundraising day with car washes, sausage sizzles and activities for the kids. Numerous community organisations such as Rotary, Lions, Quota and Zonta throughout Boonah, Kalbar, Aratula, Rathdowney, Beechmont, Tamborine Mountain and Canungra held events. Next Friday, the P&Cs from Warrill View, Harrisville, Mutdapilly and Peak Crossing will be holding a bush dance and barbecue fundraiser to assist their neighbouring schools that were affected by the floods in Ipswich.

Special thanks go to Andy McCann from Peak Crossing for organising a team of us to assist in the dismantling of a castaway shed donated to the Boonah community by the owner. This will be salvaged and used as a men’s shed for a support group.

Thanks go to the Jimboomba RSL--to John Lilley, Karen Opperman and many others for approaching me to assist in organising a convoy and transit to Grantham to deliver supplies and provide barbecues to the locals and emergency services personnel. President Jim Short walked into the electorate office with a trolley full of water and bread which he purchased first thing in the morning after resolving the motion put forward at the RSL the night before. As pensioners, Jim and his wife, Edna, went above and beyond with their generous contribution.

Another special contribution which I will never forget was from an elderly gentleman who proudly brought in a plastic bag with one kilogram of sausages. You could read in his face that it meant the world to him to know that he was contributing to the cause within his financial limitations. When he requested that he did not wish to be named or recognised for his contribution, it struck me that his contribution was literally more than he could afford.

All the rural firies, the SES and general emergency services personnel from right across the Beaudesert electorate have done and are still doing their region proud. There are too many to name but, boy, was I proud when our rural firies drove into Harris Street, Grantham and I saw a bunch of familiar faces--tired and worn out but ready to do it all over again. To Senior Sergeant Bill Sheehan from Jimboomba Police Station who was transferred to Rockhampton: well done on your efforts. In particular, thanks go to the Scenic Rim disaster management committee--Mayor John Brent and the six Scenic Rim councillors--who were in constant contact with my office and kept me up to date. Appreciation also goes to Father Columba Macbeth-Green of Marian Valley, Canungra. As chaplain to the Queensland police he spent a week in Grantham during the search for the missing and provided comfort to the heartstricken and overcome.

On a lighter note, a group of us delivered sandwiches, chips and water to households in Bannerman Street, which runs parallel to Oxley Creek just down the road from my brother’s house. We decided to lighten the spirits of those struggling to clean up in the heat and to return in the afternoon with an esky full of XXXX Gold. We loaded up the car with a few cartons and then began dropping off the refreshments. By the time we got to the third house, we approached a group of people all sitting down. After we offered them a beer, one of the ladies stared in disbelief and began cross-examining us and eventually accused us quite loudly of all being looters, to which my mate Bernie replied, ‘If we were looters, the beer would be warm and we’d be charging you guys.’ She quickly decided that we probably were legit and reluctantly dug her hand into the ice and thanked us with a grin and a mixture of embarrassment and appreciation.

The community spirit was alive and well in Goodna. The tenacity of the member for Bundamba ought to be admired as she provided a people’s service, operating her electorate office from a tent. She lost everything in her office, much of the contents of which were her own personal belongings. It was amazing to see the amount of people who were pitching in, as her daughter Stephanie tried to salvage the odd photo and organise a team of people to tear down the bits of ceiling that remained and to mop the floors. It was truly incredible to see the whole office completely gutted.

After dropping off a few basic items at her tent, the locals insisted I take a box of bananas from the local fruit shop. Given the cost of bananas right now, I felt pretty guilty dropping off about $30 worth of goods to them and loading up about $60 worth of goods from them. Such was the generosity of these good people.

To my colleague and neighbour the member for Lockyer and his wife, thankyou. Thankyou for rising to the challenge in what must have been one of the most difficult times to help and console a community grieving and in disbelief whilst casting your own concerns to one side. Whilst on a mercy run to Grantham, words, even pictures, could not describe the reality and extent of what had happened. Crops were replaced with bathtubs and household items were scattered all over the place like a disorganised tip. Cars were crumpled like alfoil and homes reduced to vacant blocks. Amongst the ruins an obvious boost of encouragement was the fresh colours of our nation’s flag waving boldly above the ruins, and as the Deputy Leader of the Opposition and also the member for Toowoomba South rightly noted, the spirit of the Anzacs still lives on.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 pm to 7.30 pm.

Mr McLINDON: Amongst the ruins an obvious boost of encouragement was the fresh colours of our nation’s flag waving boldly above the ruins, and as the Deputy Leader of the Opposition and also the member for Toowoomba South rightly noted, the spirit of the Anzacs still lives on, stronger than ever. One farmer I met and spent some time with on his property was Derek Schultz, who had lost everything. With 60 employees and tens of thousands of dollars in repayments every month, his attitude was reduced to those three common words--‘she’ll be right’. To my friend and federal member for Wright, Scott Buchholz, you are a true champion. Few knew that Scott had his own tragedy to deal with following the death of his father only weeks before the natural disasters, yet he was determined to execute his duties to the people he represented and stuck alongside them all the way together with the member for Lockyer. Despite his own personal turmoil, he carried on in the face of extreme adversity and selflessly served others before himself.

This morning Mr Speaker mentioned the passing of Ted Newton, and I think it would be appropriate to mention the passing of Ted Newton coupled with this condolence motion. Ted started in the parliament in 1973 and I did work experience with him in 1995 and have kept in close contact with him ever since. He passed on 31 January. He had a deep appreciation for our parliamentary system and a very entertaining sense of humour. Paul Reynolds, his close friend, said that when he saw him in the Wesley Hospital his last words to him were that he was not scared but just sad, and that very much epitomises Ted. He enjoyed every living moment on earth and I thank him for the mentorship that he gave me through my work experience.

I was fortunate enough to attend Ted’s funeral at Holy Trinity in Fortitude Valley last Saturday. On the Monday night before his death I called the Wesley Hospital and read a text from my father to him, because it was my father’s idea to do work experience here. He said to thank Ted for putting me on the straight and narrow--I do not know how accurate that part is--and to let him know that dad was storming heaven for him. In true Ted Newton style he said, ‘Whatever you do, don’t storm heaven. We have enough of those down here!’ That was his sense of humour. I am grateful to Ted for everything that he taught me about politics. If it was not for his humour and many stories, I probably would not be standing here today. We shared many a red wine on his deck in Bardon and discussed all the problems of the world and how we could best solve them. I wanted to put that on record on behalf of a lot of parliamentary staff who worked with Ted. May he rest in peace.

Amongst all of the tragedies, I want to mention the success of the Wyaralong Dam which is located in the Beaudesert electorate. I want to thank the Minister for Infrastructure, who is present in the chamber tonight, for the communications with my office and for the success of that project, which was just finished a few weeks before it was filled. Prior to the floods some locals were saying that it would never be filled, but it was filled within 25 days. That also prevented a lot of floodwaters flowing into Logan. So that is certainly one of the success stories that came out of this disaster. I think it would be appropriate if I could indulge in tabling Queensland Water Infrastructure’s 12 pictures that went out to the community about the Wyaralong Dam project and the success of the operations there.
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Queensland Water Infrastructure Pty Ltd newsletter titled ‘Wyaralong Dam Project’, Construction Update 9 [ 3941 ].
XML.Hansard-Body: There has been a clear message from this parliament to the insurance companies from all members of the parliament: please be compassionate. I am aware that tonight the member for Yeerongpilly will be launching a consumer based ‘Support a Compassionate Insurance Company’ campaign. I certainly welcome that and congratulate him on instigating that, because those insurance companies that will lend a helping hand above and beyond the call of duty of the written word will be remembered in time to come. I ask them to assist Queenslanders in their moment of need. Special thanks also to my wife, Christy, and her friend Ellen, who spent many nights into the wee hours of the morning preparing hundreds of sandwiches for all of the volunteers in the Ipswich and Oxley areas.

Cyclone Yasi added more pain to an already suffering state, and our northern brothers and sisters were not forgotten even though the pressures on resources and supplies were stretching thin. To all our colleagues in those regions, in particular to the member for Hinchinbrook, well done for the support that you provided to your communities. It was the fear of the unknown that left many of us down here feeling frustratingly helpless to assist in your defence. Distance will not divide us. If you are a Queenslander, you are a Queenslander and the rebuild and recovery will no doubt take place without fear or favour.

Our Premier undoubtedly did an admirable job throughout these tragedies and none of us will ever fully understand the silent pressures that she would have been constantly encountering given the demands on her in that position. I think it is entirely appropriate therefore to also acknowledge and thank her family for the sacrifices that would have had to have been made in order for her to undertake the huge task that lay ahead of her. To the Leader of the Opposition, the huge effort and sacrifices that you and your family would also have had to make throughout these disasters is much appreciated.

One story which will be branded on all of our hearts was that of Jordan Rice. None of us know when our time is up or how we will leave this life. But when that moment is upon us and one has to make a decision between our life or somebody else’s, there is no greater love than sacrificing your own. May God look after this little man and may he rest in peace with his mother.

As collective representatives we must be aware that there are many amongst our communities who may never properly recover from these disasters and we must ensure they are supported financially, physically, spiritually and mentally well beyond the visual repairs and rebuilding which will eventually take place. Sometimes an overdose of our Aussie spirit can get the better of us, and there will be many amongst us who bury the hurt behind a tough face as they try to move on. These people will need our support for a long time yet to come. The industry of politics can often be seen as a very sanitised and robotic process in the public eye when we meet here in what the Speaker often reminds us is the people’s house. But there is a very strong underlying human element that exists in each of us, and that has began to transform amongst us and it is my hope that we can maintain this into the future.

Of course there will always be argy-bargy and hot air flowing to and fro. That is the nature of democratic debate, but we must always safeguard the separation of the person and the profession. Let us battle it out against each other in these chambers with good intent to push the betterment of Queensland whilst being able to leave our boxing gloves in the ring. These natural disasters have inevitably brought communities together, and even though as neighbours we separate our property lines with fences we must always make sure that these fences are never too high that we cannot shake a hand or lend a shovel. Like all members in this House, I have never been more proud to live in Queensland and call myself a Queenslander.

Mr SORENSEN (Hervey Bay--LNP) (7.37 pm): On behalf of the residents of Hervey Bay, I offer my sincere condolences to the families who have lost loved ones throughout the floods. I also offer condolences to the families who have lost property and, in some cases, families who have had to leave pets behind when they went into evacuation centres. Having been the mayor of Hervey Bay and the chair of the counterdisaster committee, you realise just how many people you rely on in times of emergency. I want to thank all of the people who have developed the management plans--the state emergency department, the volunteers and the council staff--because it is not the most exciting thing to develop. We all hope that when developing those plans we never have to use them, but those plans saved a lot of lives during the floods and cyclone. Being prepared is the one thing that saves lives.

Earlier I heard the member for Chatsworth talking about firies being prepared and trained for these emergencies. In times of disaster you always rely on many people like police and other rescue personnel. Those people risk their lives for others, as do the SES, the volunteers, state emergency departments, the ambulance and the fire services. Whether they are rural or urban, the fire services are always there to help, as are VMR and the Coast Guard. They are always there and are well trained to deal with floods and other such events.

Thanks also have to go to the council staff in the control rooms of the emergency management departments. I have been in council chambers with a number of council staff making sure that the generator is going so that when the power goes out you have electricity in those buildings so that the computers can keep going. A lot goes on behind the scenes that a lot of people do not realise. My thanks go to the girls who bring you the coffee to keep you awake, but you cannot sleep anyway.

All of those council workers who work in the sewage treatment plants and the water treatment plants are so important as they make sure that those plants are working as soon as possible after any disaster. I would like to thank all of those people for the time and effort that they put in. The Ergon Energy workers who connect the electricity after storms, floods and cyclones have to work in some horrible conditions. They are working in the rain, in storms and things like that to try to get the electricity back on. The people from Telstra try their best to keep the communications open. We always have to think of them.

My thanks also go to the media, especially the radio. It is a way of getting your message out when all the power goes out. The ABC, the commercial radio stations and the community radio stations all need to be thanked for all the help that they give in times of crisis. My thanks go also to our hospital staff--the doctors and the nurses. It should not be forgotten that most of these people have families at home who have to fend for themselves while their partners are out in the disaster areas.

I would like to thank all the organisations in Hervey Bay that have raised money for the disaster appeal: the Z-PAC Theatre, the artists who put on a show and raised money, the Baptist Church, the RSL, the boat clubs, the hotels in Hervey Bay, the bowls club, the sporting clubs, the social clubs, especially our service clubs--Lions, Rotary and Apex--and so many more who have given to help their fellow Queenslanders. All I have to say to all of my colleagues here and to all Queenslanders is a big thankyou for their efforts.

Hansard-Body.A: (Redcliffe--ALP) (7.41 pm): I rise to convey my sincerest condolences and those of the people of Redcliffe to the victims of the natural disasters that have occurred over the past few weeks. The tragic effects of the recent floods and Cyclone Yasi devastated a large part of Queensland, shattering the lives of so many people. Those natural disasters have left many Queenslanders homeless and with huge bills to make their homes livable again. My heart goes out to everyone who has been affected by these natural disasters that hit one after the other in a very short period, banking up so that they caused unprecedented destruction right across the state. I am proud that Queenslanders have pulled together so heroically to clean up right across the state, particularly our mud army.

XML.Hansard-Body: My electorate of Redcliffe was not hugely impacted by these disasters, but many Redcliffe people who are not new to adversity were among those who hurried to join the mud army and assisted in cleaning up affected homes. Many people also spent evenings baking and delivering the goods to evacuation centres. Others collected furniture to take to people who have been left with nothing. Community groups organised fundraisers and I believe that there are more to come.

The immediate disaster is over, but for those affected there is still a long way to go as they wait for news from insurance companies and begin to pull their lives together again. The rebuilding will also take some time. The emotional toll has also yet to fully surface, as reactions set in after the adrenaline rush of the initial clean-up. So many people will continue to need support.

It is vital that each community is supported in order to kick-start their economies, repair their road infrastructure and transport systems and rebuild their social and recreational facilities. That is the challenge we are meeting currently. This is new ground and the Bligh government is moving as swiftly as possible, in conjunction with the federal government, to deliver the relief that people and communities most need.

I would like to commend the Premier for the swift and effective way in which she brought all levels of government, state emergency services and the military together in the quickest time possible to ensure that the preparation for these events was sufficient and effective and that people had the support they needed as soon as humanly possible after the event. This was the result of the learning from many other natural disasters and very good organisation. Roads were opened and power was restored in the earliest possible time. The Premier tirelessly traversed devastated areas, assessing the damage and the needs of people and communities and putting the necessary support in place immediately.

I would also like to thank Minister Roberts for his tireless work right throughout the disasters, all the SES workers--ambulance, police and military--utility organisations such as the power and the water organisations, all the members of this House for their work to assist the people in crisis and also, of course, the volunteers who gave of themselves to support fellow Queenslanders in crisis. This pulling together is an Australian and Queensland trait--part of our pioneering spirit. We know that together we will stand, survive disasters and prosper to create a better Queensland and a better lifestyle for all Queenslanders.

Mr HOOLIHAN (Keppel--ALP) (7.46 pm): We have before this House a motion of condolence in relation to natural disasters. It rather surprised me to see in today’s Australian an article by Jon Faine titled ‘Frankly I’m sick of hearing about great Aussie spirit’. The article starts by saying--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: If I hear one more politician prattle on about ‘Aussie spirit’ after the latest flood/cyclone/bushfire I might just burst a valve.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: I hope that he streamed today’s speeches and that by the time the Australian comes out tomorrow his valve may well have burst.
XML.Hansard-Body: One of the things that has always concerned me is the claim that ‘this is a one-in-100-year flood’ or ‘this is a one-in-100-year bushfire’, because we do not know when that 100 years starts. Some areas of Queensland have had the highest flood peak on record. Is that the one-in-100-year flood or is that the one for the past 100 years and it starts again from now? We really need to acknowledge that we have suffered grave devastation. We cannot let that devastation occur and not take very strong steps to ensure that it does not happen again.

I have a concern about the reference to people as victims. Certainly, it is always a sadness to lose a loved one, but to lose a loved one in the circumstances of these disasters is really deeply disturbing. They are the real victims. Those people who have lost all of their property or have lost personal possessions or who have suffered injury are in fact survivors, and it is the survivors we have to support. It is the survivors who can look forward with hope. I will deal with the aspect of hope later in my speech.

We have heard from all members about the gratitude that we owe to our leadership. I place on record my appreciation for the manner in which the Premier provided details Queensland-wide, as did the Hon. Neil Roberts, the Minister for Police, Corrective Services and Emergency Services, and his staff, particularly David Smith, who went to great lengths to let everyone know what was occurring.

I take into account the contribution of our police officers. In most cases the local coordinator was a senior police officer. All in all I believe it worked well. In relation to the emergency services and medical teams, I had the honour of representing the minister at the Australia Day Awards for Emergency Management Queensland. At that ceremony I used a comment which I think is something which we have all tried to say in this House: these were not people who did anything out of the ordinary; they were ordinary people but they did extraordinary things and continued to do extraordinary things because it was necessary to protect our citizens. I acknowledge the contribution by defence service personnel; the helicopter pilots of both Emergency Services and the defence services; federal, state and local government and private sector employees; and voluntary workers.

In the Rockhampton area, which was probably the second place to really feel the brunt of flooding, members may have heard of Hastings Deering. Hastings Deering in Rockhampton went right under water. It has about 140 employees. That company kept all of those employees on. They were, in fact, asked to go out and assist community groups and to assist with manning barricades. In fact, they were being paid fully by Hastings Deering during the whole of the flood. They had great fun when they went back to work because a lot of their machinery which had been under water seemed to be a collection point for snakes. In the first day of clean up they managed to collect 99 venomous snakes, about 80 per cent of which were browns and taipans. They knew where to go. These people worked right through and then had to go back and clean up their own workplace.

We have heard about the many fundraising activities. That fundraising continues. We have heard the instances of children donating their pocket money. We have heard of people coming forward to provide assistance. The evacuation centre at Rockhampton was at the university which is in the seat of Keppel. For 10 days to a fortnight the people in that evacuation centre were cared for by Red Cross people. They were not just people from Central Queensland, we had people from as far afield as Tasmania. They were fed by the Salvation Army. Those Salvation Army people provided breakfast, lunch and dinner for up to 180 people for a fortnight. I went to the evacuation centre to have a talk to Ross Dobbs who was in charge. I was going to do a sausage sizzle and he asked if we could do the sausage sizzle on a Sunday that he already had pencilled in because it would give his people an opportunity to go to church and have the Sunday with their family, which they had not done for over 14 days. A lot of the food that was used was actually donated. The Emu Park Bakery sent up two trays of bread just out of the blue. The butcher where I got the sausages, Wayne Spresser of Emu Park, does open Sunday morning but he also provides music and entertainment and he said that he and his friend would come to the centre and sing. It was well received. He, in fact, paid someone to run his business while he came up to the evacuation centre for the benefit of the people who were there.

These are the sorts of generous people who live in our communities. Many people do not want to be recognised. Many people say they do not want a lot of assistance because there is somebody else worse off than them. I mentioned earlier about hope. About a fortnight after the major flood had passed Brisbane there was an article in the Courier-Mail . The writer, whose name escapes me, used the words that I used: that those who survived were, in fact, not victims, they were survivors. He referred to a Latin maxim in relation to hope. The Latin maxim is dum spiro spero.
Mr Johnson: What does that mean?

Mr HOOLIHAN: I will tell you in a minute. It grabbed me slightly because that is the motto of my family. The English translation of it is ‘while I breathe, I hope.’ All of those people who have survived hope for a better future. That hope for a better future will be provided by the people of Queensland. It will be provided by neighbours. It will be provided by friends. It will be provided by people from overseas. I do not think that anyone who questions whether or not there is an Aussie spirit should lose sight of the fact that the Premier hit the nail on the head when she said we are from north of the border; when we get knocked down we get up again. Billy Moore epitomised that when he ran through the tunnel at Lang Park yelling ‘Queenslander’. Despite the fact that we have got a lot of assistance from overseas and other states, we have looked after ourselves, we will look after ourselves, and I think the bipartisanship and support of this motion of condolence shows that every one of us is a Queenslander who cares for our fellow Queenslanders. I would like to thank everybody for their input in assisting people.

Emerald was the first and Rockhampton was the second to receive some fairly substantial flooding, but it seemed to percolate almost as if Queensland ran downhill because then it went to Bundaberg and further down to Toowoomba and the Mary Valley, and thereby hangs the tale. We have mentioned Cyclone Yasi but we forget that three days before Yasi we had Cyclone Anthony, which went right through Queensland to the south-west of the state. Large quantities of rain fell over the channel country from Cyclone Anthony. It ended up in Victoria as a rain depression. I am not really sure, as I am sure most of the people sitting in this House could not be sure, that there will not be more cyclones during this season.

The hope that we can rebuild, that Queensland can get up off its knees and become the prosperous and secure state that it has always been, will occur by dint of a lot of hard work by a lot of very dedicated people.

Ms JOHNSTONE (Townsville--ALP) (7.57 pm): The past two months have been what can only be described as the most incredibly tragic in our state’s history. On behalf of the people of Townsville I extend my sympathy to the family, friends and communities of the 35 people who have died during these extreme weather events. My sympathies also go to those who have lost homes, farms, properties, businesses and personal effects collected over a lifetime. None of us has remained unaffected by the images and stories we saw flashed up on television screens day after day of heartbreak and destruction, of death and of survival. Words hardly seem to do justice to the depth of feeling that I have for what has occurred in Queensland this year. Like millions of people across the country, and indeed around the world, we in the north watched in horror as reports came in on the events in Toowoomba and the Lockyer Valley. I extend my most heartfelt sympathies to all members of this House whose communities have been affected, including the members for Lockyer, Toowoomba North and Toowoomba South who have lost so many good and decent people from their local towns and communities, whether adults or little children who had only just begun their lives.

Images of the past weeks had turned people’s reactions from shock and sympathy into action to assist flood affected Queenslanders. Townsville people were doing whatever they could do to help, whether it was amassing collections of practical, personal and household goods or volunteering and assisting in flood affected communities. Some of our emergency service workers had completed three or four deployments to central and southern Queensland between Christmas and Cyclone Yasi hitting our coast. They were exhausted after the floods and then they had to come back and prepare our own local communities for what was coming.

People had been donating and raising money. I will give just a couple of examples because, as we have heard over the last two days, there have literally been thousands of different fundraising efforts conducted. In just a couple of days 16-year-old Katie Brenton organised a concert in Townsville with local young musicians and teenagers. She raised over $700 at that concert. The Northreach Baptist Church held an appeal day, which raised many thousands of dollars. Mark Brine from A Touch of Salt restaurant raised over $32,000 in a single lunch sitting on Sunday, 30 January.

After the floods and raging torrents receded and the massive clean-up and rebuilding began, along came cyclones Anthony and Yasi. Many people from North Queensland believed they had seen it all before, but we were wrong. On Sunday, 30 January I was attending the A Touch of Salt fundraiser. Local 4TO radio announcer Glenn Mintern and I were urging people to give and to assist our fellow Queenslanders from central, western and southern Queensland in their recovery from floods.

Cyclone Anthony was moving towards the coast and whilst we were somewhat concerned, we were much more nervous about the monster system following it. Based on hydrology information available to us, we estimated some 70,000 Townsville residents could have been affected by a storm surge that had the potential to be six metres above HAT. When we started talking about figures like that in the local disaster management meetings that I sat in on, the look of horror on the emergency workers’ faces was palpable.

History now tells us that Townsville did cop a bit of a hiding from Yasi. There would not be a street in the city that has not sustained tree damage. Eighty-five per cent of our city lost power and many properties suffered minor and not so minor structural damage. Our recovery is well underway and I have to thank Ergon Energy in particular. I will talk more about the recovery in the bill that will follow this debate. I say thankyou to Ergon for the amazing work that they have done.

Townsville’s recovery is well underway, but the recovery for our northern neighbours will take much longer. The people of the Hinchinbrook and Cassowary Coast regions, including the member for Hinchinbrook, have my most sincere sympathy, admiration and support in rebuilding. We have watched the wounds heal after Larry ripped these communities apart only five years ago and now, inconceivably, they have to do this all again.

I love the coastline between Townsville and Cairns. I have been travelling it all my life. I look forward to revisiting some of those communities again very soon. Mission Beach is a particularly special place for me. It is a place we used to go to as children on holidays. It is the place we now take our kids to at least three or four times a year, just for a weekend getaway. I can assure the people of Mission Beach that we are going to be back again soon. We also love the giant gumboot at Tully and the bikini tree that is on the road into Mission Beach. I hope they both made it through Yasi. I am not sure if they did. The member for Hinchinbrook is nodding, so I am hoping that they both did.
A government member: He knows it well obviously!

Ms JOHNSTONE: It is pretty iconic. My sympathy and that of my husband, Carl, and the sympathy of the people of Townsville goes to everyone who has been affected by these disasters. I have proudly put up my ‘You can kiss my Yasi’ sticker on my office wall here in the Annexe. Everyone can come in and be reminded that we will rebuild from this and we will recover. As the sticker says, Queenslanders certainly will not be beaten.

Mr BLEIJIE (Kawana--LNP) (8.04 pm): I rise to speak in support of the condolence motion before the House today. In recent weeks Queensland has been battered by rains, floods and cyclones. She has been tested to the extreme, so much so that statistically 70 per cent of her was covered in waters. The terrible human cost of this disaster is something that we will all live with for quite some time. Sadly, 35 of our fellow Queenslanders lost their lives to the torrent of water that swept across this state with three people still missing. My thoughts and prayers are with those families who have not only been impacted in some way but who have also lost loved ones.

On Sunday, 9 January my family and I were travelling home after a few days at Jimna. We were heading down the Jimna to Kilcoy road and soon realised that something was not quite right. Half the range had completely fallen and blocked the road. We turned back and waited till Monday. Overnight more of the range slipped. We were stuck. The local ranger drew us a mud map to get us down the Kilcoy Murgon Road.

When we arrived in Kilcoy it became apparent that many towns in Queensland were in severe trouble. Kilcoy was cut off to the outside world. We spent some five days in Kilcoy. At the same time we watched in agony as fellow Queenslanders, particularly those in Toowoomba and the Lockyer Valley, were devastated by the torrents of waters and floods that traversed the area.

I recall being in the Kilcoy pub with my family and some 150 other stranded travellers who were stuck in Kilcoy with no way out north, east, west or south. The Kilcoy folk really came to the party. There were hundreds of people stranded in Kilcoy. The local Kilcoy Lions Club set up the emergency evacuation centre where they fed and made 300 meals a day. There was such a diverse range of people stuck in these floodwaters in Kilcoy. But it was great to watch the community spirit unfold in a town that was cut off from the outside world. After three to four days the milk ran out, so the milk was coming over by boat from the dairy. The abattoir workers were being choppered out of Kilcoy across the river into the abattoir to butcher the cattle.

On the 10th and the 11th we watched the unfolding events in Toowoomba and the Lockyer Valley. As I said, the town folk of this area of Kilcoy really stood by the people who were stranded, some of whom had a couple of days of clothes and others who had no money and no access to bank accounts because the ATMs were empty.

I want to thank the people of Kilcoy, particularly Lorna Sherwood from the Kilcoy Lions Club, who did a lot of the coordinating at the emergency evacuation centre. I want to thank Sandy Adams who, with her team, provided over 300 meals a day to the flood stranded guests. I also want to thank the special events group which is a not-for-profit association that helped; the SES and, of course, all the emergency service workers; Sergeant Marty Tanwan, who was one of the area coordinators and the local sergeant in the town of Kilcoy; and the IGA. On the Monday the IGA was fully stocked. By the Friday it had run out of bread, milk and personal hygiene supplies but it kept donating to the local Lions Club and the butchers in the area to feed the hundreds of people who were stuck in Kilcoy until the roads were clear.

There are a couple of events in people’s lives that they can recall. They can remember exactly where they were at that point in their life. For me, I can remember exactly where I was when the world found out about Princess Diana’s death and also September 11. I will never forget being stuck in Kilcoy as Queensland flooded and we watched on the news as the Lockyer Valley and Toowoomba were ravaged by this flood from hell.

While flooding is something that we have seen at various times in our past, flooding of this magnitude has been widely reported in the media in comparison to the devastating floods of 1974. For those of us who were not here in 1974 it is hard to imagine flooding of such magnitude sweeping down the Bremer River, into Ipswich and the Brisbane River and into many suburbs. Thankfully, many communities were able to prepare themselves for the inundation of floodwater, in some cases on more than one occasion.

Whilst statistically 70 per cent of the state was covered in floodwater, many communities did have time to prepare themselves for the rising waters. But let us spare a thought for those in the Lockyer Valley and directly east of the Toowoomba range who had no warning of the wall of water that was heading towards their small but close-knit communities. Sadly, there was also loss of life suffered in Ipswich as the floods swept through the Bremer River and on to Brisbane.

We were greatly underprepared for the events of 10 January 2011 in Toowoomba, Murphys Creek, Postmans Ridge, Withcott, Grantham and throughout the Lockyer Valley. The human cost of the Queensland floods in the summer of 2010-11 is immeasurable. We as legislators and leaders in our respective communities are charged with the task of rebuilding Queensland and ensuring that we are more prepared to respond to natural disasters across this great state.

As the floodwaters subsided and the clean-up task began, our state faced another natural disaster of epic proportions. Tropical Cyclone Yasi was a massive storm set for landfall somewhere between Townsville and Cairns. Many of the residents who live in and around the city of Innisfail in North Queensland and who were still rebuilding and getting their lives together after enduring Tropical Cyclone Larry on 20 March 2006 were preparing for an event that had the potential to be even more devastating.

The spirit of North Queensland should never be underestimated. While the region is often prepared for the annual cyclone season, the circumstance of two massive cyclones--Larry and Yasi--in the space of just five years has the potential to paralyse many communities for decades. Wind speeds of between 250 and 300 kilometres an hour are a frightening prospect, but the tenacity that the people of North Queensland displayed in the face of tremendous adversity in enduring these massive cyclones is truly inspirational. In comparison, Hurricane Katrina had recorded wind gusts of 280 kilometres per hour.

We have heard much about what it means to be a Queenslander. More than being Queenslanders, we are Australians. Throughout the years, in the most terrible of situations, Australians have banded together. We are a family, and nothing brings a family closer than times of immeasurable trouble. I take this opportunity to pay tribute to the emergency services personnel across Queensland who have worked so tirelessly in very dangerous situations to protect and assist their fellow Queenslanders in their time of great need.

The Queenslander spirit has never been more evident than during the recent natural disasters across the state. In the aftermath of the floods, it was great to see so many volunteers out to help their fellow Queenslanders with the difficult task of cleaning out their homes and businesses and in many cases having to count the cost of the damage and start all over again. This tremendous gesture of mateship embodies the true spirit of our state. When times get tough, the first question many people ask is, ‘How can we help?’

In my own electorate I was happy to support the fundraising efforts of the Kawana Waters Uniting Church and the Uniting Churches of the southern Sunshine Coast region in assisting with the Help the Flood Victims concert, which was held at the Events Centre on 29 January. With the assistance of those who attended, the variety concert event had some very generous donations from business--Ian McDowell from Sunshine Toyota and Bob and Natasa Shelley from australianeedsyou.com, who helped in raising the funds--totalling some $20,000 in one night. These funds will be split evenly between the Lockyer Valley and the Burnett regions to help rebuild communities. So I say to my friend and colleague the member for Lockyer: as you and your community were facing your darkest hours, the people of Kawana were thinking of you, were praying for your community and will gladly hand over the split cheque of $10,000 to help in and around your community.

There have also been significant other fundraising events in my electorate which I have been pleased to assist and support. On Sunday, 23 January, Dave Holmes and his team from Honky’s Events arranged the Flood Festival 2011, a variety of local music acts and activities for families in the Kawana electorate. Our local businesses were called upon and, boy, did they deliver and come to the party! Thousands of dollars worth of auction items were donated. Flood Festival 2011, on top of the $20,000 raised by the Uniting Church, raised another $13,000.

On Sunday, 6 February, the Sunshine Coast Unite for Queensland Flood Appeal was held by a local organisation with the assistance of the Kawana Waters Surf Life Saving Club and the Lions Club of Lake Currimundi-Kawana. Another $5,000 was raised from that afternoon which included performances from Uncle Bob’s Jug Band, the Sunshine Coast Ukulele Masters and a surprise performance from their local member--me--as an Elvis Presley impersonator. I was either that good or that bad that they requested a second song. Of course I obliged.
Mr Langbroek: Do one now.

Mr BLEIJIE: No, no. Residents from Living Choice Retirement Village in my electorate also organised a local donation pledge of food and clothing which was sent to the Ipswich community in the aftermath of the devastating floodwaters. I would like to publicly thank Mr Eric Brusewitz and Dawn Chalkley for their efforts in organising this donation of much needed supplies to residents in some of the hardest hit areas in Queensland. I want to say thankyou to the Kawana electorate for sending volunteers and thanks to the surf-lifesaving club for sending their RPVs and their lifesavers and for donating money. Individually these fundraising efforts and donation pledges may seem insignificant in size, but collectively they will provide a great deal of assistance to residents who will struggle to recover from these disasters for a very long time.

So although my electorate did not face the battle from hell with the floods and cyclones, we were thinking of our fellow Queenslanders and were doing what we could without fully understanding or appreciating the severity of the situation. But what we did do is come together in all forms of community groups, some of which I have mentioned today, to fundraise, to raise awareness and to pack boxes to send throughout Queensland.

In one of Australia’s unofficial anthems, I am Australian , the writer, Bruce Woodley, penned two new paragraphs following the devastating bushfires in Victoria. One new paragraph is particularly relevant to our recent disaster events in Queensland. He added the words some 22 years after the original song was penned. The paragraph reads--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: There are no words of comfort that can hope to ease the pain
Of losing homes and loved ones the memories will remain
Within the silent tears you’ll find the strength to carry on
You’re not alone, we are with you. We are Australian!
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: Then he added a further paragraph, which of course dealt with the Victorian bushfires but is so true and embodies our Queensland spirit. It reads--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: There are so many heroes whose stories must be told
They fought the raging fires of hell and saved so many souls
From the ashes of despair our towns will rise again!
We mourn your loss, we will rebuild. We are Australian!
XML.Hansard-Body: I would like to offer my personal condolences to the families of the people who have been lost to these disasters. On behalf of the people of the Kawana electorate, I say: may those who were lost rest in peace.

Hansard-Body.A: (Gladstone--Ind) (8.16 pm): I rise to support the Premier’s condolence motion for Queensland’s natural disaster victims. Since Boxing Day 2010 we have been privileged to see compassion, strength, resilience, generosity and love in the face of intense devastation. We will never forget the dramatic events which have occurred in our state over the past six weeks or so. We cannot begin to believe that the things we have seen will drift from memory; however, except for those directly affected by the floods, those directly in the path of what is called the inland tsunami or those directly in the impact zone of the cyclone, we will forget. It will pass into our memory.

XML.Hansard-Body: Many people in Brisbane do not remember the devastation of the 1974 floods because they were not directly affected or they did not live here. I do because I was here. I remember the stench of the mud, as would anyone who has been through flooding. But the memory fades, thankfully, and it is therefore critical that, at this time when experience and recollections remain raw, we say thankyou, we recognise the communities so deeply affected and we make decisions which will, as much as possible, reduce the risk in any future incidents.

From each person in my electorate I pass on my deepest sympathies to the families who have lost parents, partners or children. Such losses are immeasurable. The grief will remain, and please know that our thoughts and prayers are with you. To those who face periods of deprivation, those who have lost their jobs, farmers who have lost crops or stock: we are thinking of you. Thinking does not put food on families’ plates, and that is where funds from the state and federal government programs are critical. The measure of a community is how it cares for those in need. The Premier this morning said that the Premier’s appeal currently stands at $213,520,780. This has been collected from individuals, companies, governments and other nations.

I know the SES in townships in the middle of Tassie were standing on the side of the Midlands Highway swinging buckets and collecting for the Queensland flood. That was prior to Yasi. As a measure of care, that is astonishing. We add to that the millions of dollars worth of food, clothing, toys and household goods which have been given. Then we add to that the millions of dollars worth of clean-up work that has been done voluntarily.

Central Queensland after the floods, the Lockyer-Toowoomba area after the devastating wall of water and later the areas of Hinchinbrook and other places in North Queensland after Yasi have all been the focus of community concern and sympathy. The list of individuals, families and organisations mentioned here in this place over the last couple of days has been significant. Aside from those mentioned, there is an army of unnamed community members who have selflessly provided physical, emotional, psychological and financial support to people they knew and many they did not. We will remain indebted to this anonymous army for decades to come.

My electorate was spared the brunt of the flooding and the cyclonic conditions. We had localised flooding, including a small community isolated on the inland side of Pikes Crossing. One lady was a week or two away from having her baby. I contacted the SES and they took her contact details. I was able to assure her that with the contacts provided she was in good hands for a medivac should it be required. We were all encouraged by the news that in several places across Queensland, in the face of significant trauma, the safe birth of a little one worked to bring balance back to our lives once more, particularly when the news of some of the losses of young children--children torn from their parents’ arms--reached us. I find it impossible to imagine how those parents would have felt and indeed how those who have survived will manage the grief and despair that they will feel.

Isolation occurred in the Boyne Valley. Even though the Boyne Valley Road near Nellie Simpson Road was flooded as well as the low single bridges, we were greatly spared. Individuals in my electorate are to be praised for the roles they filled. They include the local disaster coordinating committee, including police Inspector Graham Coleman, representatives of the emergency services council and community members, the bands of volunteer workers from Queensland Rail, the Gladstone Ports Corporation, Lions, Rotary, and other service organisations and groups and individuals packed up tools and went to where they were needed. Initially in our area it was Theodore, but I know that others went north and south as the need arose.

Terry Hill, the regional director for Main Roads, was a sentinel in terms of keeping the community informed about road conditions and safety for motorists. For a period of time, he remained available to ABC Radio for local information and for state road conditions. I commend him for his availability, his accuracy and his compassion. He is certainly a great man.

I also commend the RoadTek workers. From early December roads in my electorate were deteriorating significantly with the prolonged rain. In great measure, the start of this deterioration was much earlier with insufficient funds being spent on the Bruce Highway for a number of years. Having said that, RoadTek workers were constantly out patching roads. For weeks when rain was incessant it was a thankless job with patches popping out due to the amount of water in the subsurface of the pavement. But they remained undaunted. Most large, dangerous potholes were patched within 24 hours. They were amazing and I can only commend them for their work. I believe that, where it was possible, they would have done the same amount of work throughout the state--that is, until the floods made it impossible to do the patching.

Similarly, Gladstone Regional Council workers have continued with their tireless efforts to patch roads which, in some instances, were completely undermined. In early discussions with the council, I could understand their frustration that the direction had been given from government that, to get the national flood funding, any flood rehabilitation had to be done by contractors and not by council day labour. That will result in delays in work being done as the contracting process will take more time. Additionally, in smaller councils the majority of their work needed to be done to ensure cattle and crops could either be taken off properties or stock fed. I commend each council worker for their dedication.

The staff of the Gladstone Area Water Board also worked with the residents isolated on the western side of Pikes Crossing to ensure access from their isolated properties could be achieved by using a service road for the dam. I commend Jim Grayson and his team for their effort.

During critical weather events workers from the primary service areas are asked to be available to carry out their work in dangerous and difficult circumstances. I commend the police, SES, hospital, ambulance and fire staff, the Red Cross, St Vincent de Paul, Salvation Army and other charities, Energex and Ergon and all the other service providers that turned out during incredibly difficult times.

The Australian Defence Force has also been present during the hard yakka doing the grunt work, if you like, of cleaning out and stockpiling rubbish. It was not uncommon to see them in Brisbane streets outside somebody’s home where they had pulled out the material that had to be removed and stockpiled it on the footpath. They would be having a smoko or waiting for a truck to pick them up. Whilst it is easy to dismiss and say that they were just doing their job, they did it with enthusiasm and they did it because they cared as well. Individuals in all these organisations make a conscious decision that, after ensuring to the best of their ability the safety of their own family and homes, they will leave and commit their energy to others. This is the strength of our nation and of our state.

While the Gladstone electorate fared well during these storm events, the majority were conscious of the needs of others. We did have isolated incidents of public frustration or dissatisfaction. My office received a number of contacts from residents who were concerned that staple items had disappeared off the shelves--items such as milk, bread, eggs, formula and nappies. I put on the record my appreciation for the work of my electorate office staff. We did have a lot of calls on the office and they worked tirelessly in order to respond to concerns. They checked and found that baby supplies and like products remained on shelves in chemists. They were available when people desperately needed them.

I rang the disaster management group and kept in touch with police and emergency services. Replenishments were arranged within a day and major stores had also commenced restocking. Within days, things began to return to normal in Gladstone. Replenishment was organised, people just needed to be patient, and overwhelmingly they were. They also needed to keep in context that we had a shortage of food where other townships, like those in the areas in the Lockyer and in Hinchinbrook, did not have shelves to put food on. It was important to keep our situation in perspective.

As an indicator of the ingenuity of our locals, the store owners at Ubobo, isolated and with supplies significantly dwindling, organised restocking through cooperation with QR and the use of a road-rail vehicle. Their tenacity paid off.

As soon as the flooding started at Theodore, a Gladstone group started a collection. They set up in the NRG car park. NRG is a power generation plant and they were incredibly generous with their facilities. My contact was Ros and this team worked tirelessly to pack containers with food, clothing and other items to go over to that decimated community. I know they received so much from the community to put into those containers. They went not only to Theodore but also to other parts of the state as the tragedy unfolded.

My community has also joined so many across this nation to help those devastated. After the flooding my office--and I know other members have mentioned this and I believe it is the same group--was contacted by Hannah’s Foundation and asked to be a receiving venue for school items. People responded and it was my privilege to take those donations to Rockhampton. There were school supplies for children in that area who had lost all of their back-to-school items. I thank all those who donated and Hannah’s Foundation for swiftly taking action.

There have been fundraising events, small and large, across the electorate. On 5 March we will have the mayor’s ball. Each fundraising event is greatly appreciated. I put out a call for toys and items to go up north for children under 12. After the first few days, we had to contact a local storage firm. I commend Kitty from Storage Choice who offered a shed free of charge. It is filling up fast and those toys will go to Cardwell, Tully and other areas north in the next fortnight. I thank all of those who have donated. I believe that if you can give the little kids something that they can hug and cuddle or some toys that they can play with it gives mum and dad a bit of a free hand to be able to do the jobs that are very difficult with a little one around your feet. There is nothing like having a doll to hug or a teddy to cuddle or pull its ears off or whatever.

I am sure some members here, like me, received emails from a resident at Dalby outlining actions taken against a number of residents in that area who were endeavouring to assist in the emergency they faced. I forwarded the email to government to have the allegations investigated. If only one allegation has substance, it is bitterly disappointing. We have all stood in this chamber rightly outlining the ingenuity of individuals and communities in coming together and lending each other a helping hand. The information in the email is in direct contrast to that ethos we so rightly are commending in this debate.

When the time came to close the Hannah’s Foundation appeal and I drove through to Rocky, I took the opportunity to visit Depot Hill and the Port Curtis area, which are two localities amongst others which were inundated for a long period of time. The member for Rockhampton represents a diverse community and the people in these particular areas are doing it tough. While they face regular inundation, they do bounce back. It is unfortunate that some comments were made about their motives for not evacuating. These people are experienced in floods; sadly, they are also experienced in human nature and know that their properties, wet but not submerged, are attractive to looting and wanted to stay in their homes.

Each speaker to date has spoken of the magnificent generosity of spirit of all who put their shoulder to the wheel during and after these floods and cyclone events. Overwhelmingly, Queenslanders and indeed Australians have worked to build and not tear down. The exception to that rule is the looters. They truly are the scum of the earth. There is no justification for their actions. In the ’74 floods, members of my family lived at Gailes. Les got up during the night and went outside and the water was around his ankles. He went back and woke up his wife, who is my sister, and said that they had to go. The water was then up to the door of their caravan, which was their home. By the time they waded out, the water was up to their thighs and it was only a matter of minutes. As the flood subsided, looters were diving into the creek and stealing anything of worth from the vans that had washed down the creek. The looters then were moral bankrupts and so are those who do it today.

My grandma was a kindly soul. I remember that the only thing she did not accept well was her grandsons walking around without their shirts on. She commented on that occasionally. However, it was seldom I heard her speak negatively, until an incident after she had made the decision to move into a nursing home--she would not come and live with us. One day, a pair of her stockings went missing after she had washed them. Her comment was this: ‘I hope when they’--that is the alleged thief--‘wear them they fall down right in front of everybody.’ That was as nasty as she got. In the same vein, I hope that those who have preyed on the misfortunes of others suffer a similar fate. May the TV they stole fail; may the furniture or items they felt they had a right to above the rights of those who were flooded be a constant reminder of their lack of personal morality.

While speaking of moral vacuums, I must bring to the condolence motion the feelings of many in relation to insurance companies. To those companies which in the very fine print define, deceive and split hairs over what constitutes a flood, you are putting your trusting clients through hell. Many sit and wait for hydrological reports which could take months. That is not what clients signed up for. The message I bring to you is this: ‘Say what you mean, mean what you say. If you cover flood, cover it and be done with it.’ People take out insurance and pay premiums year in and year out with the expectation that at their time of greatest need they will not be required to argue, justify and defend their expectations. To those companies which are acting true to their word, thankyou.

There are several other matters my community wishes me to raise--issues of infrastructure for the community in light of our strategic importance, but it is more appropriate to raise them during debate on the Reconstruction Authority Bill. However, it was significant that both the Premier and the Prime Minister landed in Gladstone as a base to inspect damaged areas around us. I support the community’s view.

I commend the Premier for her role in disseminating information to Queenslanders. Her calm, informed and compassionate leadership was both essential and appreciated. Those in the team also providing briefings and directions to discrete communities are commended too. ABC Radio must also be commended for their continuous coverage of events across the state as they unfolded. I cannot recall that they had anyone standing up to their knees in floodwaters for effect, but the information they provided was critical for families and communities who were otherwise isolated.

There is so much more which could be said. People’s homes will be rebuilt, roads will be patched and bridges will be repaired. Fridges and lounges will be replaced and life will return to some form of normality. Healing, however, takes much longer. Some scars will remain, with the loss of children, loss of partners and loss of parents. Those experiences will be indelibly etched in the minds and hearts of those affected.

As the rebuilding continues, we must remember those so deeply affected and continue for some time to provide support, counsel and care to them. We are a unique people. We are a blessed nation. We are facing adversity, but with continued strength we will rebuild. For those most affected, we must remain sensitive, aware and available. I support this motion.

Dr DOUGLAS (Gaven--LNP) (8.36 pm): Queensland in the last month faced one of its greatest challenges in its relatively short 200-year history and 150 years as a state. We are a big country with a big heart, but for too many Queenslanders there were not enough tears that could be shed to share their pain when nature rose up and threw itself upon our quiet contentment.

We on the Gold Coast were spared much of this terrible suffering endured by so many other Queenslanders. I know that all Gold Coasters want to express their collective grief. The majority actively wanted to help and many actively did so all over the state. They have raised millions of dollars at a variety of events, including a massive event at Tedder Avenue on Main Beach. I congratulate Ms Katie Page and her family and Ian Vasileski for their initiative in doing so. Katie is a St George girl with her sisters and she has never forgotten that. To all the others who ran many other events, I thank you all. All of that money went to the Premier’s fund and we all dearly hope those funds are spent wisely and promptly and no-one is discriminated against. I share a commonly held view that the means test is set far too low and it denies many fairness in accessing funds.

I would also like to thank all Gold Coasters who gave generously to the care baskets that were distributed widely across the state. My wife Susie is the councillor for Surfers Paradise. With Councillor Margaret Grummitt, Councillor Jan Grew and Mayor Ron Clarke, they shipped nearly 180 tonnes to all communities, including Brisbane, Ipswich and its surrounds, the Lockyer, Toowoomba, Oakey, Dalby, Miles, Condamine and Theodore. The Gold Coast has adopted Theodore--it is somewhat similar to those people from Gladstone--as their town for ongoing assistance.

To Don Kirker of Allspan Constructions and his driver, Barry Hallam, who supplied the B-double that carried all these goods to the west, I thank you very dearly. To the Gold Coast Muslim community and Goss transport, I thank you for your great efforts in transporting a lot of these new donated goods. To Bruce Chater, who is the doctor in Theodore, and all the families of Theodore and the surrounding district, I dearly hope that my family’s gift to you gives you many years of comfort and care when your health is compromised. It will be an enduring legacy from us all.

To all those in regional Queensland, we particularly want to say that we do not forget you and we appreciate your resilience and perseverance. Our state’s fortunes are partially dependent on you and in times of crisis we will never abandon you. I hope this was the message conveyed to all. I especially want to thank Peter Woodhouse, his wife Kim and all their staff from their business at Woodhouse Removals for their packing, storing and transporting of a whole integrated surgery to make this happen in Theodore.

To Gary Kershaw and Ken of Caloundra Removals: I dearly thank you as well. To Parkwood Rotary and Hot Tomato radio station on the Gold Coast for assisting my wife, Susie, in the mattress campaign, trying to get new mattresses for all of these communities: I thank you. The business of Making Mattresses from my electorate in Nerang has supplied new mattresses to many of those in Goodna, Redbank and parts of Ipswich. I want to thank it very sincerely.

I, like all members, am a very proud Queenslander and feel blessed to have been born in Australia. The great challenges that this country imposes on us all as citizens are nothing compared to that which the country gives back. I am sure that this is the true message that Dorothea Mackellar wanted to send with her ‘sunburnt country’ poem. I had the great privilege of being able to give back during the most recent floods in Queensland. By great virtue of opportunity, training, friendship, family and good fortune, I was able to make a small personal contribution as well as a financial one from my wife and family. I could only do this because everyday people in Australia are able to do so. This is the great privilege of being born in this country.

This was a one-in-100-year event--whatever that 100 years is--and every one of the 4.5 million Queenslanders really needed to do something for their fellow Queenslanders immediately and to keep doing it. I think many really did so. I offered my services to those in Central Queensland communities, in whatever role they wished me to play. I thank the health minister, Paul Lucas; the member for Bundamba, Jo-Ann Miller, who is here with us tonight; the Premier; Stephen Beckett, her deputy chief of staff; Director-General Mick Reid; Steven Waller, the regional health director in Rockhampton; the member for Gregory, my great friend Vaughan Johnson, who was here earlier; Inspector Mick Keys, who is in charge of the regional area; and the communities of Longreach, Blackall, Jericho and Alpha for helping me to assist those families in the Central Highlands region who at the time of the floods needed medical care at a very crucial time. Many others certainly volunteered their services as well. I acknowledge all of them and I congratulate them all for helping Queenslanders in what was a very dark period.

In conclusion I would ask you all to consider the plight of the twice flooded town of Jericho in the Central Highlands region. It is a town of 130 very needy people for whom everyday life is a great challenge. They have absolutely nothing and have been somewhat forgotten. They got flooded twice. With the second flood they lost absolutely everything of what little they had when they returned to their homes. Amidst all of the chaos and confusion of those who attract greater attention, we are often judged more by what we do for those who can least help themselves. Appropriately, Jericho, with its biblical historical links, might be one place to judge whether we have truly mastered the task of rebuilding and recovery in Queensland.

Hansard-Body.A: (Sunnybank--ALP) (8.42 pm): Most of my electorate of Sunnybank was fortunately unaffected by the flood inundation experienced by many of our neighbouring electorates. However, I do have residents in areas of Archerfield and Acacia Ridge, where people experienced inundation throughout their homes. There is a mix of residences in Granard Road, Gladstone Street, Rocklea Street, Beatty Street and Gregory Street. Some of these homes are owned and occupied by pensioners and the aged. These people have found themselves living in a shell of a house with very little furniture and clothing. The main thing I am finding as I go around to visit them is the very stoic resilience of these people. They do not feel sorry for themselves; they believe that they are lucky. It has been my experience that the poorest people believe that there are others who are worse off than they are. I find that I almost have to pry to get them to let me know what they need us as a community to do for them.

XML.Hansard-Body: Prior to the floods these people were the self-sufficient in our society, having paid off their homes when they were younger when this area comprised market gardens and the like and it was not the busy commercial area it is today. These people do not have the money to relocate and, as they live on a pension, they do not have funds to go to the shops and replace their lost furniture, clothing and personal belongings, not to mention food items and other grocery items such as washing powder, cleaning products, insect spray and the list goes on. They are most grateful for the emergency money that they have received, but this money has long been spent on cleaning products and other necessities such as the purchase of a new fridge or stove.

Other residents--we cannot forget these, either--are those who live in rental properties. These people have also lost all of their belongings. As this is an area where it is reasonably cheap to rent, most of these residents did not have any kind of insurance and they have lost all of their personal belongings and furniture. They have nowhere else to go. They rely on the property owners to carry out repairs, and I have to say that, from speaking to these people, some of the owners of these properties have been absolutely marvellous and done the right thing. They have forgone rent and got in there and cleaned up the properties very quickly and installed new kitchens, walls et cetera. However, other rental property owners have not been so forthcoming and have caused their tenants much grief.

However, the majority of these people are also very humble. They have told me that the best thing I could do for them is to look out for their elderly neighbours who are not able to look after themselves. I want these people to know that, even though their numbers are not big, I will not forget them. I, along with my electorate office staff, will continue to do whatever I can to lobby for a fair deal for them. In fact, most of these people do want to stay in their homes, whether it is a rental property or their own personal home. However, there are a few residents who are homeowners who would like to have a buyback by the council or some other body because they have been through the 1974 floods and now they have been through this one and they really cannot tolerate it anymore.

One really poignant couple who I have spent some time with are the Walczuks. The daughter lives at 39 Granard Road and her mum, who is in her 80s, lives at 58 Granard Road.
