Both of them have had their houses dreadfully inundated by the flood and they are looking for buybacks, the daughter by Main Roads--and I am going to make representations on her behalf to see if we can have that happen--and the mother by the council if that is possible. We will make representations on their behalf. Clearly, there are so many people who have been entirely traumatised by this flood that they simply cannot return to these properties, and I find that more significantly in aged people who are beyond 80 years of age.

Another group of people who deserve mention--and there are a lot of them in my electorate at Acacia Ridge--are the businesspeople who lost power for over two weeks and simply could not undertake any business activities because they did not have sufficient generators or, if they did have generators, they were not enough to power their computers or the other things they needed to conduct their business. There are a lot of large businesses in Acacia Ridge that are head offices for a lot of smaller businesses throughout Queensland. When you take out head office, you take out the small business wherever it is throughout the state. There are also a lot of small businesses in Acacia Ridge that simply could not operate for the two weeks that they lost power. While we have spent a lot of time in this House talking about individuals--and certainly we should do that because they are so powerfully affected--we should also acknowledge that the businesses of Queensland have done it tough this year by losing their income for two weeks and they are trying to get back on their feet now.

I am very fortunate to proudly declare that the electorate of Sunnybank is a multicultural electorate of Queensland. Our multicultural groups have been incredibly proactive in fundraising. The Taiwanese community has already given a cheque for over $100,000, and I am advised that it is going to double that. There is significantly more to come from it. For example, the Sunnybank RSL and the Queensland Chinese Forum held a fundraising dinner at short notice and it ended up raising more than $40,000. The Islamic community has also been actively fundraising. It tells me that it has so far raised over $100,000. But it is not stopping there, and I am sure we are going to see a lot more from that very generous community. The Islamic community is also very organised in terms of having its own thrift and charity shops and has collected a lot of household items to distribute to people.

The community from the Spanish Centre at Acacia Ridge has also raised over $3,000. No-one asked these people to contribute; they did this because they wanted to help out their fellow Queenslanders. Besides the multicultural community, though, the rest of my electorate has been very active in its fundraising. For example, the people at Iceworld at Acacia Ridge have raised over $6,000. Yesterday I visited Pro Honda at Rocklea, which itself experienced inundation and was out of business for two weeks during the blackouts, and director Paul Peterson handed me a cheque for over $6,000 from a fundraising event it has held. The wonderful community at the Southside Sport and Community Club has handed in more than $30,000 to the Premier’s welfare appeal.

Another group, Appliances Online--one of Australia’s largest online appliance and whitegoods retailers--started fundraising via their Facebook fans and donated more than $80,000 to the appeal. I know many residents have personally given to the flood relief effort. Just yesterday, one of my staff was at the local bank waiting to be served and the people in front just walked up to the counter and handed over $500 to the fund to assist the disaster victims. I am sure that over the past two days members have reflected on what a great country we live in when there is so much generosity from everyone we meet.

We all have tales of wonderful community stalwart volunteer efforts. The people in my electorate who were inundated are very grateful to the volunteers who came to them in the days after the flood and without asking just made their lives so much easier by bringing in their gernis and their backhoes and their trucks and cleaning up their house for them. I know that it is always dangerous to nominate individuals, but I will nominate one tonight and that is Myrna Stevens. She is a wonderful stalwart in the Sunnybank Hills community. As soon as the problems that people would experience were apparent, Myrna and her band of helpers, mostly from the Neighbourhood Watch, set about baking fruitcakes. After first experiencing much frustration on being told that these cakes would not be used at the evacuation centres because of health regulations, they decided to offer these cakes to volunteers in the clean-up effort. Along with the people of the Acacia Ridge neighbourhood centre, they drove around the clean-up areas and offered the hardworking volunteers a piece of fruitcake, a piece of fruit and a drink and they could not keep up with their supplies. Myrna also set up her home as a collection centre for donations and then personally delivered those donations to people in need.

The need does not stop. In the past two days I have been visiting all of the people in my electorate who had been inundated. They still need assistance. Some of them need assistance with insurance companies. Some of them need assistance with their landlords. Some of them still need basic furniture items for their homes--things like wardrobes, lounges, bedside tables and mirrors; simply things that they do not have. But still no-one complains and still I have many generous organisations in my electorate who will continue to work on fulfilling those needs for the people in my area.

Last but not least, I wish to thank the local volunteers who presented themselves at the Macgregor State High School and other centres to assist people who they had never even met clean up their property. Many others gave their services to relatives and friends in need. As I said yesterday, I have two sisters in Yeronga--one at The Corso and another one close to it who were both affected and inundated by the floods. I have relatives in Grantham who were also affected. I think in these times we help our own. We look after our family and we look after our friends and that is what Queenslanders have done for the past few months. I think we have come out of this disaster as a wonderful, caring community. I think we have harnessed the great tank of goodwill in our society. Hopefully, in the months ahead, as some people experience frustration and some people want to change their lives and some people want to rebuild their lives just the way they were, we can deliver good outcomes for each and every one of those people.

Mr WETTENHALL (Barron River--ALP) (8.52 pm): I am very grateful to have the opportunity to place on the record on behalf of the people of my electorate their sympathy and condolences to the family and friends of those who have perished in the floods and cyclones in what has been described as Queensland’s summer of sorrow. For those of us throughout Queensland and the nation who have never lost family or friends or homes or personal possessions to the forces of nature, we cannot really know the loss and the grief, but we share it and understand it. In this place we have only words at our disposal to express our thoughts. As well as adding my personal condolences to those on whose behalf I speak tonight, I particularly want to express my sympathy to the families and friends of those who are to this day still missing.

Like most people outside the areas directly affected, I watched the disaster of the floods unfold on television and as the days passed our summer of sorrow cast its pall across vast swathes of our vast state. I join with all of those honourable members who have already spoken to this motion in thanking all of those people who have supported and who are continuing to support flood and now cyclone ravaged communities. Many of them travelled from all parts of the state and indeed from around the nation and even from overseas.

I specifically want to thank my constituents and all of those people from Far North Queensland who left their families and joined the preparation, rescue, relief and reconstruction effort. I also wish to thank everyone who has raised funds and donated to the Premier’s Disaster Relief Appeal and take this opportunity to remind everyone that the need for donations is not over and that we must continue to see the total climb well beyond its latest tally, which today reached $215,925,456. This appeal fund is all the more important now that it will also help the victims of Cyclone Yasi as well as the floods.

Just as the floodwaters began to recede and the recovery and reconstruction effort began to gear up, along came Cyclone Anthony, closely followed by Cyclone Yasi. In speaking about the impacts of the cyclones in my community, I hope that these words will be understood in the context of the great personal losses that have been sustained throughout Queensland. Most people will say that their losses are insignificant compared to those of others, yet it is important to acknowledge that these events have affected people across the state directly and indirectly in a wide variety of ways.

Cyclone Yasi was the largest and most powerful cyclone in living memory. It menaced communities between Cooktown and Mackay before crossing the coast in the very early hours of Wednesday, 3 February 2011. As the cyclone approached the Queensland coast, by Tuesday the impact zone was looking more likely to include the city of Cairns. By Wednesday morning, Cyclone Yasi had been upgraded to a category 5 storm and the warnings of very destructive winds were coupled with warnings of a powerful and destructive storm surge. A storm surge has particular significance for thousands of people who live in low-lying coastal suburbs, towns and villages that are vulnerable to inundation. In that category in my electorate are the communities of Machans Beach, Holloways Beach, Yorkeys Knob, Trinity Park, Trinity Beach, Kewarra Beach, Clifton Beach and Palm Cove. Thousands of people heeded the advice of authorities and applied precautionary common sense and evacuated to the homes of family and friends on higher ground. Many, including newcomers without established connections and large numbers of tourists, sought refuge in the three designated shelters in my electorate.

One such shelter is located at Redlynch State School and it is a new sports hall and gymnasium that incorporates additional design features that enables its use as a cyclone shelter. This dual-purpose facility demonstrates well how new public infrastructure can, and in appropriate circumstances should, be adapted for use as cyclone shelters. But these measures are expensive. Upgrading the facility for this dual purpose added some $2 million to the cost. Among the many amazing stories to emerge from these events was one at this very shelter where, as the cyclone was wreaking havoc outside, a baby was born.

I visited these shelters shortly after they opened on Wednesday morning and again after the cyclone had passed on Thursday morning. Although Cairns was spared the destruction that was visited upon our friends to the south, the anxiety and fear was very evident on the faces and in the voices of the people as Cyclone Yasi approached, just as the relief was equally evident once the danger had passed. I would like to thank everyone who supervised the evacuation centres and shelters and commend those who took shelter for their good humour and cooperation in trying and stressful circumstances.

Cyclone Yasi’s destructive winds and associated storm surge has devastated Tully, Mission Beach and Cardwell and many other towns and villages in surrounding areas. Its destructive power has caused damage from Cairns to Townsville and for hundreds of kilometres inland as well. Homes, farms, businesses and public infrastructure have all been damaged or destroyed. The damage bill is huge and rising and the task of community recovery and rebuilding is massive. Some 200,000 households lost power yet, as we have heard today, within a week 180,000 had been reconnected. Today, nearly two weeks later, 7,421 people are still without power. Power at my home was out for just a few days and in that short time you become very conscious of how much we rely on electricity for our basic needs, let alone comfort and convenience.

I would especially like to thank the workers in Energex and Ergon who have worked so hard and so effectively to restore power to our flood and cyclone affected communities. I think it is also important to acknowledge that the timely and forceful warnings of the threat posed by Yasi, the evacuation of people from their homes in the impact zone and the thorough and effective preparation carried out by people explains why there were no fatalities as a direct result of wind or storm surge. There is no doubt that these measures saved lives.

I want to conclude my remarks by just making some comments about the Cairns Base Hospital. The Cairns Base Hospital and the Cairns Private Hospital were both evacuated prior to Cyclone Yasi. This was a sensible and wise precaution made for many valid reasons and a decision I fully support. However, with the winds barely passed some people, including the Leader of the Opposition, say we should put the brakes on the redevelopment of the Cairns Base Hospital. He is wrong. The redevelopment of the Cairns Base Hospital is critical to the delivery of more health services for our community. Stopping work on that redevelopment would mean delaying vital services for Cairns. It would mean not opening the final stage of the emergency department expansion, which we will open before the middle of this year. It would mean not delivering the vital cancer services that we as a community have fought so hard for. Cairns needs the hospital redevelopment to proceed full steam ahead. I am determined to deliver on what we promised: more services sooner for Cairns.

The current redevelopment means that we are delivering real services for people in Cairns now. Already the redevelopment has delivered a cardiac catheterisation laboratory, a brand-new car park, a brand-new community health facility, additional chemotherapy chairs, a paediatric chair and a new MRI suite. This means that right now more than 200 patients a year requiring treatment for heart conditions such as interventional cardiology are receiving it locally. By the middle of this year most of those requiring cancer care treatment will get it in Cairns, not Townsville or Brisbane. There will be 340 patients a year who will be able to obtain this treatment locally.

But I know there are genuine concerns in the community about what will happen if another Yasi comes and hits Cairns square on. There are worries that a storm surge worse than that we experienced with Yasi might render the emergency department inaccessible for days. I have spoken with the health minister about these matters and about the evacuation of the Cairns Base Hospital. I have emphasised to him that the people need certainty that good solid contingency plans are in place in case the worst happens next time. The health minister has assured me that the lessons of Yasi will be learned, Queensland Health will ensure that future service planning has regard to the lessons of Yasi and that hospital design in the future continues to have regard to the best way to house all the most essential services having regard to the vagaries of our climate in Tropical North Queensland. I will continue those discussions with the Deputy Premier and the Minister for Health and with the Cairns and hinterland health team.

These dual disasters are an immense challenge for the people in the affected communities and indeed for all Queenslanders and the nation. We will rise to that challenge and, despite the damage and devastation, Queensland will be an even better place to live and an even better place to visit.

Ms DARLING (Sandgate--ALP)
(9.03 pm): I rise to support the motion of condolence for Queensland natural disaster victims and to pass on the sympathies of the people of the Sandgate electorate. I also pass on a message from so many of my constituents who wanted to thank the Premier for her calm and dedicated leadership throughout what seemed a never-ending stream of natural disasters. I acknowledge all the hardworking Bureau of Meteorology and Emergency Service workers who worked tirelessly to keep us safe and the members of the Queensland parliament who worked night and day for their constituents. I spent some time helping the member for Mount Ommaney and visiting many of her residents. I was amazed at the member’s energy, dedication and passion for her constituents. I heard some dreadful stories. I met folk in Oxley who had water over their roof gutters. I met folk who stood in houses like skeletons but said to me, ‘I’m okay. You’d better go and check on my neighbour.’

Like most people I had family and friends in flood zones and in Cyclone Yasi’s hit zones and spent sleepless nights following the news and reports from my Twitter and Facebook friends, but nothing can compare to living through the terrifying floods and howling cyclonic winds. Last year my community lived through the trauma of losing a child. Just yesterday I attended the anniversary mass for St Patrick’s student, Elliot Fletcher, whose young life ended tragically on 15 February 2010. I can only encourage Queensland communities who have experienced the trauma of losing loved ones to stick together, talk to each other and let others help you.

In October last year residents in the suburb of Deagon in my electorate experienced flooding as a result of the combined forces of heavy rains and a king tide so we took the flood warnings very seriously and people in flood prone areas prepared for the worst. Luckily, we were mostly spared, with some minor flooding at Pine Rivers our main impact. However, we watched in amazement as evidence of the devastation further inland washed out into Moreton Bay. Water tanks, outdoor furniture, pontoons, trees, wildlife and bits and pieces of people’s lives found their way onto the beaches of Shorncliffe, Sandgate and Brighton. It was quite a sad sight.

I thank and congratulate the hundreds of volunteers who cleaned up the bay and the beaches and joined the mud army of volunteers in the suburbs of Brisbane. Our local councillors, Victoria Newton and Amanda Cooper, did a great job coordinating volunteers.

Finally, I would like to thank and congratulate the many local community organisations and individuals who contributed to the many charity drives for toiletries, school stationery and cash for those whose lives had been turned upside down. We have had some very innovative fundraisers in my electorate: yoga on the Shorncliffe Pier; a tattoo day that I went to but I didn’t get a tattoo; and a netball competition just to name a few. I am particularly proud of the work of many of my service clubs, businesses, sports clubs, schools and churches who answered my call for help to put on the Flood Relief Fair at the Sandgate PCYC last Sunday. The Bracken Ridge Central Lions Club, with the very energetic Sharon O’Sullivan at the helm, jumped at the chance to help raise funds for the Premier’s Disaster Relief Fund and put in hours of hard work to make the fair a huge success. We raised just under $10,000. I trust that that cash in the hands of people who live in the towns destroyed by Yasi or submerged by floodwaters can be spent locally to rebuild lives and help businesses get back on their feet. I know that all levels of government will pull out all stops to get services and facilities back in order and I have faith in the people of Queensland to help others and help themselves through the stormy days and back into the sunshine.
Question put--That the motion be agreed to.
Motion agreed to.
Resumed from p. 128, on motion of Ms Bligh--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: That the bill be now read a second time.
XML.Hansard-Body:
Mr LANGBROEK (Surfers Paradise--LNP) (Leader of the Opposition)
(9.07 pm): It is with both gravity and urgency that the Queensland Reconstruction Authority Bill has come before this House. It establishes the Reconstruction Authority through the Queensland Reconstruction Authority Act 2011. It amends a number of acts: the Building Act 1975, the Disaster Management Act 2003, the Integrity Act 2009, the Land Valuation Act 2010, the Public Service Act 2008 and the State Development and Public Works Organisation Act 1971.

The LNP will be supporting this bill. We need to rebuild our state as quickly and effectively as possible. The official process starts here with this bill. I have reservations about the bill and the bureaucracy contained within it, but as a parliament we need to show Queenslanders that the recovery from disasters is underway. Soon the LNP shadow minister for flood recovery, the honourable member for Redlands, will make his contribution to the bill. I am proud to have appointed the member for Redlands to this important task. In my opinion it is lamentable that the Premier did not think it appropriate to dedicate a minister to the cause.

As leader I want to rise today and give hope to all Queenslanders that we will support the rebuilding of our communities, the reconstruction of our infrastructure and the rebooting of our industries and economies. I want to tell Queenslanders that their parliament recognises the problems and the trauma they have endured but we are also committed to building a stronger, safer state. We recognise the urgency in getting the reconstruction and recovery of Queensland underway. In offering our bipartisan support for this bill we acknowledge that there will be improvements or refinements that could be suggested to the process.

The magnitude of the recent flooding across our state was immense. As we have heard over the last couple of days, it is estimated that over 70 per cent of our state was impacted by flooding. Tragically, 35 people died and three people remain missing as a result. As our great state was still cleaning up after being inundated by floodwater, North Queensland was battered by Cyclone Yasi. This massive category 5 cyclone unfortunately claimed another life.

Over the last two days members have recounted harrowing tales of tragedy and survival experienced in their electorates. We have heard tales of hope, tales of heroism, tales of luck and tales of humour. More tragically, there have also been tales of loss and tales of heartbreak. Now is the time for Queensland to join together to rebuild--to rebuild the houses, the businesses, the infrastructure and, most importantly, the lives of people who lost so much at the hands of flooding and cyclones in recent months.

Many words have been used to describe the floods that have damaged and distressed our state in the last few months. There are, however, too few words that can capture the tragedy adequately. The hurt and horror caused by these disasters will linger for a long time to come. There were cases of unbelievable and incomprehensible devastation, with lives lost and communities torn apart. There were people who saw their lifetime’s belongings and mementos destroyed and lost. There were people who lost livelihoods--businesses they had put years of effort and toil into. The stories of heartache go on and on--economic pain caused by damage or isolation, material and property loss and, above all, trauma and psychological pain.

As I said yesterday, no Queenslander could be unmoved by the footage of the tragedy as it unfolded in Toowoomba and the Lockyer Valley. No-one could comprehend the scale of the flooding as, one by one, our major centres and our small towns succumbed to the water. Across the state there are people hurt by floods and cyclones, people who have lost everything to the water and the wind.

The trauma will be borne acutely by those who lived through the disaster, but it is shared by all Queenslanders. We have heard that over the last couple of days, with almost every member speaking on behalf of their electorates, showing that this experience has been shared by all Queenslanders. There are people who rely on stalled or stuttering industries for employment and food on their tables. There are businesses sustaining losses and community organisations rebuilding their own premises at the same time as helping others. There are people who helped their neighbours and those who helped strangers.

We cannot forget the impact that the events of December, January and early this month have had on anyone. These are exemplary, everyday Queenslanders. Now the responsibility is to ensure that the damage from the disasters is limited and that the support, assistance and recovery processes are started as quickly and as effectively as they can be.

I want to turn now to industry impacts. The damage to industry and business is massive and not limited to those who had water through their doors or experienced floods. The impact of this summer will be felt for some time by our small businesses, major industries and taxpayers as our economy recovers. Queensland’s three major industries--tourism, mining and agriculture--as well as our small businesses were all hard hit. Many small businesses which closed because of damage or staff shortages have had to bear the loss and some continue to do so as they await rebuilding or the return of customers. Some are unexpectedly casualties of the flooding. A simple example, the Nindigully Pub, illustrates the impact on a business which is miles away from the floodwaters but which is still bearing the cost as a result of road closures and blocked access. However, it is not eligible for government assistance. Other businesses that were not flooded lost their stock in transit--a write-off for the business.

As I travel the state I see many communities who rely on tourism. They have been hard hit in recent months. Priority needs to be given to ensuring that these tourism enterprises receive urgent assistance and rebuilding. However, most of the tourism industry is still operating. They will receive no assistance or handouts, but their income over this peak season has been decimated as visitors either defer their visit or change their itinerary in the mistaken belief that Queensland is closed. We must get the message out that most of Queensland’s celebrated tourism industry is open for business. Much of this industry is small business and is hurting badly. Red tape is a recurring theme for businesses and a very real threat to their viability. The Reconstruction Authority will have a real role to play in clearing the hurdles bureaucracy puts in the path of reconstruction.

Our major export industry, mining, has been badly hit. As we heard reported today, about 13 per cent of our mines are now operative. Mines have been flooded and road and rail connections to export markets have also been cut. The loss of export income and royalties will hurt our economy and state budget for some time to come. In addition, this industry is a major employer of Queenslanders, both directly and indirectly. As well as that, our farming industry has been hard hit, with crop and livestock losses. Furthermore, the loss of infrastructure such as fencing will take substantial time to recover.

Let us have a look at infrastructure. It can be argued that the biggest challenge of the Queensland Reconstruction Authority will be rebuilding our infrastructure. Our road and rail networks are so critical for our economy and our lifestyles. Over a quarter of our road network has been impacted and will need repair or rebuilding. Key sections of our rail lines have been cut. The most prominent example is the rail line to Toowoomba along which so much material is transported to the port of Brisbane. This is expected to be closed until April as a result of the flash flooding which claimed so many lives. Our water, sewerage, electricity and other public utility infrastructure has in many cases been swept away. The Queensland Reconstruction Authority will have a huge task in overseeing the rebuilding of this state. The LNP will support the rebuilding task.

The main aim of this recovery must not be just to return Queensland to normal operation but also to prepare our state for future extreme events. Queensland is a state of droughts and flooding rains. Unfortunately, for too long this government has failed to prepare. In the last budget we saw that the state was facing an $84 billion debt. This is the government that sent Queensland bust in a boom. But despite this spending spree, this government did little, if anything, to prepare our state for flooding. The government emptied our coffers but did not invest in the future.

After Cyclone Larry, then Premier Beattie promised to prepare for the future. There were grand promises about cyclone shelters, summits and other practical steps to cyclone proof our state. The question is: what have we seen since then? The answer is: little, if anything. Once the priority had passed, the media had moved on and memories were forgotten, we saw the government quietly walk away from real action to prepare for the next event. I implore the government: let us not waste this chance. The Reconstruction Authority has a real chance.

I turn to the nature of the Queensland Reconstruction Authority. This Reconstruction Authority was originally set up in response to the devastating floods that Queensland experienced during December 2010 and January this year. The LNP supports the expansion of the responsibilities of this authority to encompass the devastation wrought by Cyclone Yasi. The authority is being established to manage and coordinate the government’s program of infrastructure reconstruction and recovery within disaster affected communities. Under this bill, the authority is granted substantial powers to carry out this role. These powers are modelled on the powers of the Coordinator-General and the ULDA.

Many questions remain regarding the nature, role and responsibilities of the Queensland Reconstruction Authority. The role of the authority is broad ranging and has a lot of parameters as yet undefined. The authority will be responsible for deciding priorities for community infrastructure and services required in the recovery of communities. The process that the authority will use to communicate with communities and other decision makers to establish these priorities is a question mark at this stage.

There is a general function, without definition, to work with the communities to ensure communities’ needs are recognised. In a broad sense, the authority is responsible for flood mitigation, community protection and rebuilding, expedition of regulatory approvals and setting the priorities for community infrastructure and services.

The manner in which it will undertake these functions is not yet fully evident. Information must be collected and collated about infrastructure and other property damaged or otherwise affected in the disaster event, and data sharing which facilities flood mitigation, protection, rebuilding and recovery of communities must be implemented across all levels of government. Yet, at the same time, the authority has overriding powers which allow it to make decisions, extract information and establish processes without the agreement or assent of other entities such as local government. Penalties accompany noncompliance with many of these powers, which strengthens the need for the powers to be used with restraint and transparency.

The authority will also have responsibility for ensuring the recovery facilitates flood mitigation, taking responsibility for the longstanding neglect under this government. The board will have power over the authority in that its strategic priorities will be enacted through the authority. The minister--the Premier--will also have a lot of oversight and intervention powers over the authority. The authority will, as asked, advise the minister about putting into effect the recommendations of the commission of inquiry. These recommendations are only accorded the status of ‘possible implementation’ which, in itself, potentially diminishes the standing of the commission.

The minister may give the authority a written direction about the performance of its functions or exercise of its powers. The minister can declare a project for proposed development to be a declared project if it is to be undertaken in a disaster affected area of the state or it is necessary for flood mitigation or rebuilding purposes. The minister can prepare a regulation to declare a reconstruction area. For projects the minister deems critical or essential for state economic, environmental or social reasons, the minister can declare a critical infrastructure project. The authority may, with the minister’s approval, give a step-in notice to a decision maker and applicant to state that the authority is making an assessment and a decision.

I want to turn now to the matter of the responsible minister. The rebuilding of Queensland will be an enormous task. It is not one to be taken lightly but fast-tracked with action taking community needs and views into account. Under this legislation, the responsible minister has a substantial workload that is highly time critical, including directions, declarations, regulations, submissions, approvals and amendments. The lack of a unique minister dedicated to this portfolio is alarming. Rather than devoting a minister to the sole task of rebuilding our state, the Premier has chosen to swallow up this responsibility to sit alongside numerous other duties. To manage the recovery properly there needs to be a minister who is the driving force behind the reconstruction without concentration being diverted elsewhere. There needs to be a focus purely and simply on getting the job done, with as little bureaucracy as possible and without diversions.

Flood recovery and reconstruction after Cyclone Yasi will not be a task for a couple of months but for many years to come. It is a full-time requirement that needs to balance many factors to ensure the best possible outcomes for our communities and state. The Premier is already juggling her role as federal president of the ALP while undertaking a range of tasks as Premier. Where in that scheme of things will flood and cyclone victims come? What about ensuring Queensland is properly prepared for the next event, particularly once the media scrutiny has moved on, as it inevitably will? Too many times we have seen that this government is only interested as long as there is a hard hat involved, only to lose interest when the cameras are no longer focusing on them.

The LNP has recognised the need for long-term and real commitment to this recovery. To that end, we have moved swiftly to appoint the member for Redlands as the shadow minister for flood recovery. He will be assisted by Lawrence Springborg, the shadow minister for major projects, infrastructure, planning and trade; Mark McArdle, the shadow minister for health; Tim Nicholls, the shadow Treasurer and the member for Clayfield; and the honourable member for Maroochydore--in all those areas of health infrastructure, social infrastructure, economic infrastructure and transport infrastructure. This is to accord the flood victims and the reconstruction of affected areas the importance and attention they need and deserve into the future.

I want to turn now to the matters of transparency and accountability. The authority will have substantial funds passing through its hands, will make decisions impacting on people’s lives and livelihoods, as well as determining what the government’s priorities will be. It is vital the Queensland Reconstruction Authority be open and transparent in its processes and reporting. It must be asked: what relationship will the authority have with departments? What role will cabinet have in overseeing the authority and its determinations on priorities?

As the Natural Disaster Relief and Recovery Arrangements funds are both Commonwealth and Queensland government moneys, what controls will each government retain? What powers will the authority have to make decisions that impact on prior approvals and what compensation will be made available? What promise do we have that the funds from the Queensland government projects being rolled back for the recovery will actually be spent on flood recovery projects and not on just more Labor waste?

The government has already claimed that the Abbot Point terminal proceeds and the 15 per cent public transport fare increase will go to fund the restoration of public infrastructure. As both of these were already scheduled, what acquittal will be provided so Queenslanders can be sure the funds will actually be spent on flood reconstruction? What about infrastructure not covered by NDRRA funding? Will the government give priority to this infrastructure? Will the authority be reporting publicly or to parliament on the numbers and types of progression notices and notices to decide?

What if the state or local government agency fails to comply with a progression notice or a notice to decide? Will that be publicly reported? If the government issues a decision on a step-in notice against the written recommendation of a local government, will this be publicly disclosed? What guarantee will landholders subject to a deferred acquisition land order have that this order will not reduce their land valuation into the future as they can only sell to the government?

The authority has stated that it would prefer to operate on the invitation of local government but has the power to override them. So the question is: what appeal rights will the local authority have? The authority’s jurisdiction only extends to areas impacted by the recent floods and/or Cyclone Yasi. Therefore, flood prone areas that were not affected will be unable to access the powers of the authority to pre-emptively act to improve their flood immunity. Instead, they will have to continue to fight their way through bureaucracy. What options to streamline this process will they have? These questions and many others need to be answered.

I want to turn now to flood mitigation and water management. The authority will also advise on the possible implementation of recommendations made by the commission of inquiry. The LNP has supported the establishment of this inquiry but believes it should be a comprehensive investigation of all matters related to the recent flooding in Queensland. The commission of inquiry needs to reflect on the impact these events have had on our communities and the state of the preparation and deliver answers to every Queenslander.

To do the right thing by Queenslanders who were impacted, we need to make sure we do the best thing for our community and work to ensure that we get the answers and we make the difference. These are questions that need answering, and I fervently hope the commission of inquiry will deliver a report that shows us what went wrong and gives us a foundation to build on.

Every town affected by flooding has its own set of circumstances. Some, as we have heard over the last couple of days, have been flooded regularly. For others, it was the twice repeated inundations and evacuations that exacerbated the heartache.

There has been speculation that there were water management issues which increased the impact of flooding in Brisbane. This, of course, will need to be a focus of the inquiry. It appears that the operating procedures at Wivenhoe Dam failed to keep pace with new technologies and wider developments, effectively reducing the capacity of the facility to react to major flooding events. There were warnings that Wivenhoe and Somerset did not meet the national guidelines for flood mitigation. It seems that this was gauged to be of little importance or urgency as the compliance deadline was set 25 years down the track.

At a time when we have seen an unprecedented $9 billion spent on our water infrastructure, including many white elephants, it is impossible to understand why improving flood mitigation at these dams was ignored. It would seem that capital works, which would increase the capacity of the dam for a comparatively low cost, were dismissed without further investigation, while the second stage of an upgrade at Wivenhoe was postponed for 15 to 20 years because of cost. Similarly, low-cost associated works to affected bridges could have improved regular release procedures. The spaghetti jumble of administration imposed by this government on water seems to have led to communication breakdowns and overly onerous bureaucracy, all at the expense of those in flood paths.

Manuals are of little use if they fail to be practical or relevant. Chains of command are only effective if those at the top are contactable. Delivering forecasts of bad times ahead to the public is not the only job of governments in inclement weather. It appears that there was a long lead-in time to the very wet summer we experienced. It also appears that there was very little planning. An important lesson for the government if it chooses to learn is that panic reactions to crises are no match for planning.

Spending ever-increasing amounts of taxpayers’ dollars on ill-advised or unworkable projects does not protect the taxpayers from foreseeable events. Planning is the best weapon governments have. Constructive criticism is a good foundation for planning. It is to be hoped that the criticisms that will be aired over coming months will be noted and acted upon. Our side of the House will take the information seriously. Planning can also include placing flood emergency response rooms out of the path of flooding.

Release data from Wivenhoe Dam is very difficult to obtain in consistent and complete forms under this administration. Yet it would appear to be likely that this data will show a pattern of low releases from the dam at just the time when one would expect more urgency. Allowing a dam to fill from just over 100 per cent to nearly 150 per cent in the course of one weekend preceding a forecast that there will be a lot of rain over the catchment is sure to be an issue examined by the commission of inquiry. Similarly, releasing one-quarter of the dam’s capacity shortly before the Brisbane River began to break its banks is also a matter for consideration.

My hope is that the hardworking staff who operate our infrastructure are given better conditions in which to work--conditions in which they can act quickly and without impediment in the public interest, without the layers of bureaucracy and tiers of entities which at the moment confuse the processes and responsibilities.

I note that the government has taken the opportunity to roll back the recent swimming pool fencing laws for rentals not just in flooded areas but across our state. The LNP strongly supports the safety of our children around water. We were always concerned when this legislation was brought in that the implementation of the recent changes had been bungled and that landlords may be unable to comply in the short amount of time available before the laws took effect. I know that other members will have comments on that in their contributions.

The government is delaying land valuations by three months, from 31 March to 30 June, on the grounds of the impacts of the recent flooding. Whilst this may be the case, I cannot help but suspect that this is just an excuse as the recent introduction of a new land valuation process required the application of new valuation processes across Queensland.

This bill represents the beginning of the official reconstruction but, more than that, it represents a promise to the people of Queensland--to the people who have lived through these disasters and the people who have lost so much. What they cannot afford to lose now is their trust in our parliament to rebuild their communities. We owe it to the community and these people to ensure the rebuilding is undertaken with practicality, efficiency and compassion. We owe it to Queensland to act quickly and well. Our communities deserve a response that will give them back the communities, facilities and infrastructure they lost, but also a response that provides them with optimism, provides them with hope and provides them with greater expectations for the future. I put on record my intention to pursue this bill’s implementation to ensure it best serves the community.
Debate, on motion of Mr Nicholls, adjourned.
Hon. JC SPENCE (Sunnybank--ALP) (Leader of the House) (9.34 pm): I move--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: That the House do now adjourn.
XML.Hansard-Level-2-Heading: Department of Environment and Resource Management, Traffic Tickets

Hansard-Body.A: (Hervey Bay--LNP) (9.34 pm): I rise to highlight for the House a very un-Australian act carried out by DERM on Australia Day this year. Constituents have strongly voiced their objections to receiving infringement notices on 26 January on the Burrum Coast in the Kinkuna National Park. The nature of the alleged traffic offence was ‘Failure to comply with official traffic sign--road closed no entry’. I table a photo of a poor excuse for a ‘road closed’ sign that was put at the side of the road and really would not have stopped any traffic going down the road.

XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Photograph showing ‘Road Closed’ signs, Kinkuna camping area road [ 3942 ].
XML.Hansard-Body: Anyone who sees the picture can see why motorists are fed up and are ready to fight hard against the fines. The ‘road closed’ traffic sign was not erected in the correct manner and in accordance with the Department of Main Roads’s Manual of uniform traffic control devices , which states--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: The road closed sign shall be used where a roadway is closed to traffic. Barrier boards shall be erected across the roadway in conjunction with the sign and the bars should be aligned to point to the sign.
XML.Hansard-Body: This did not happen, so my constituents need to be let off from paying these infringements. It leads me to believe that this is just a money grab by the government.

The constituents charged discovered from the police that if the sign does not comply with the MUTCD then the sign does not exist. The people who have complained to me agree and are fighting these fines today. The DERM rangers who were on the day handing out the tickets admitted and confirmed that other motorists were as confused as they were as to the road closure signs. That begs the question: why did they not reassess the situation? They had confused motorists. Instead of reassessing the situation they just kept writing out tickets and acknowledging the confusion. When motorists asked why the road was open and had no barricades they said, ‘We didn’t want to put the signs across the road as hoons would just drive over them and we didn’t want them destroyed.’ So they have admitted with that statement that the road closure signs were done incorrectly.
As per the DERM’s website on 26 January 2011, only the Burrum Point camping area was closed. That is why motorists entered at the Kinkuna entrance. The road was not closed after all.

Mrs ATTWOOD (Mount Ommaney--ALP)
(9.37 pm): At the last sitting of parliament in 2010 it came to my attention that Canossa Aged Care Complex at Oxley would lose public palliative care beds. I immediately asked the Parliamentary Secretary for Health to investigate the matter with Queensland Health. After many telephone calls between me, the minister’s office and Queensland Health, I was advised that the Commonwealth funded QEII palliative beds would come online at the end of 2011. So it was decided that after Canossa’s contract expired palliative care services would be taken back by Queensland Health.

Before I became the elected member for Mount Ommaney I was involved in a number of community organisations as a volunteer, one of which was Canossa Aged Care Complex. I have continued to volunteer as a Friend of Canossa over many years. I regularly attend weekly services at the Canossa chapel and participate in volunteer and fundraising events when they occur. My attachment to this place and its people runs deep. There is nothing that I would not do to support this wonderful organisation.

Understandably, I was horrified when this information came to my attention. When I asked the reason this decision was made I was advised that Canossa had suggested to Queensland Health that it wanted to reduce its palliative service anyway. Canossa management and the Canossian Daughters of Charity categorically denied that this would ever be the case.

I have known many people who spent their last days peacefully receiving the greatest of care from staff at the palliative care unit there. It is more than just pain management; it is emotional support and it is spiritual support as you are among the angels, the sisters of Canossa. It is the hope of most residents of Canossa that they would have the choice of being cared for in this very special unit if they needed to be. There are many families of palliative care patients who want to know that Canossa will also be there for them.

The network of friends and devoted followers of Canossa is enormous. After weeks of talking to people from Canossa, local residents, Palliative Care Queensland, the Queensland Health director-general, the acting director-general, the CEO, the Minister for Health and his staff, I finally had a breakthrough. Queensland Health had agreed to extend the contract until mid June 2011, with further negotiation with Canossa after that. Local residents asked me to attend a rally the next day organised by Palliative Care Queensland. When I arrived there, I found that Mark McArdle MP, with two former unsuccessful LNP candidates, were leading the charge against the government. I felt it was appropriate for me to address residents that day. I assured them that although we had a breakthrough there was a lot of work to do to ensure that the quality palliative care services continued at Canossa in the future.

After a meeting held on 10 January--the day before the floods--with Father Jerry, Sister Concetta, CEO Robynne Kent and the minister, it was confirmed that Queensland Health would extend Canossa’s palliative care contract until QEII came online. The minister is also requesting an assessment of Canossa Hospital in relation to the provision of palliative care services for the western suburbs into the future. He will tour Canossa later this week with me.

Hansard-Body.A: (Hinchinbrook--LNP) (9.40 pm): Earlier today, the federal Treasurer, the federal Minister for Agriculture and the Premier of Queensland announced the assistance package available to businesses and primary producers devastated by Cyclone Yasi. I acknowledge the package has been developed in consultation with industry groups. I welcome the fact that category C and category D NDRRA have been activated, as they were after Cyclone Larry. These measures will provide much needed support to communities in my electorate affected by Cyclone Yasi.

XML.Hansard-Body: I am grateful the federal and state governments have recognised the significant needs of industries devastated by Cyclone Yasi. I must, however, continue to press for two additional important measures--that being a fuel excise relief payment for households, businesses and primary producers left without electricity for extended periods and a support package for the transport industry to avoid a crippling cost of living increase in North Queensland.

As of 10 am today, there were still 7,421 customer connections without power between Ingham and Innisfail in my electorate, despite the best efforts of Ergon Energy crews working around the clock. The damage to the electricity distribution system in many communities throughout my electorate ranges from serious to catastrophic. In some rural areas, people will be without power for several weeks. Many households, businesses and farmers are relying on generators and this is very costly. Following Cyclone Larry in 2006, the Howard government provided assistance to businesses, farmers and households that needed to generate their own power by refunding the excise paid on diesel and petrol until supply was restored. I urge the federal and state governments to include this fuel excise relief payment to households, farmers and businesses in their support package. Recent increases in the retail price of fuel have exacerbated the problem faced by households, businesses and farmers affected by Cyclone Yasi, many of whom are also catering for extended family, friends and neighbours without generators.

Many transport operators that normally carry North Queensland products to southern markets have been left without loads and face the prospect of huge increases in costs to bring goods back to North Queensland. For example, road transport operators that normally carry bananas out of areas of North Queensland that have been devastated by Cyclone Yasi will have no loads to carry south. The cost of hauling loads back into North Queensland will be astronomical and freight costs have already increased. Backloading does not exist in the transport industry anymore. Both legs of the journey need to be economically viable. If transport operators are short of loads to carry south, I am concerned the cost of carrying loads back into North Queensland will skyrocket.

I am worried about the possibility of a double or triple whammy for cyclone affected communities. A blowout in the cost of living on top of a shortage of housing and the loss of employment would be diabolical. I urge the federal and state government’s to amend their support package to provide assistance to the transport industry.

Hansard-Body.A: (Whitsunday--ALP) (9.43 pm): Airlie Beach began its life as a weekend retreat for local cane farmers and fishermen. In 1970, Cyclone Ada descended on the area and practically wiped Airlie Beach off the map. As it re-emerged, enterprising locals and blow-ins from the south began to construct accommodation and watering holes and the town slowly gained a reputation as a great place to have a holiday. Today, the town of Airlie Beach has extended up the hill and around the bay, but the one thing that has not changed is the view from the top of the street down to Muddy Bay at the other end. The shop facades are the same as they were 30 years ago, only now they are looking tired and out of place, and the street still floods at the point where Shute Harbour Road intersects Airlie Creek. It is a gun-barrel-straight, bitumen vista that does little to say welcome to our visitors who come from around the world to see the magnificent Whitsundays.

XML.Hansard-Body: A year ago, the Whitsunday Regional Council set out to find and collate all the studies that have been done over the years about how we can improve the amenity of Airlie Beach. They came up with some 40 studies and papers which all basically said the same thing--upgrade the appearance of the town’s central heart. Over the next 12 months, plans were draw up and everyone from the Premier to the Prime Minister was lobbied for assistance to help with a much needed heart transplant for Airlie Beach.

I do place on record my apologies for becoming something of a nag on this issue, as every minister in turn was briefed on the project and taken for a long walk along the offending street. However, as the Australian dollar kept rising and the wet season kept coming and our tourists did not, I was acutely aware that the town needed a shot in the arm to revive flagging spirits and give the business owners a fighting chance of survival. Good news arrived earlier this year with the Commonwealth government confirming that it would honour a $5 million election commitment to the project. It was a start but not enough to make a real impact.

So, Mr Speaker, you can imagine my delight--indeed the delight of my whole community--when just last week the Queensland Treasurer announced that our government would also support the project with a $7 million funding injection. In even better news, he revealed that a deal had been done with the council that would see it put an additional $5 million in the kitty to ensure that the first stage of the revitalisation operation could be delivered.

The $17 million package will deliver one upgraded and one new roundabout, flood mitigation work, a realignment of the street to allow for a central park and general beautification of the streetscape. The finished product will be a cooler, greener, friendlier experience that allows for sidewalk dining and relaxed shopping. My hope is that property owners along the strip will now have the confidence to commence their own plans for revitalisation because it is not just the street that needs a facelift. In the meantime, I know a lot of business operators would really appreciate some consideration of rent relief so that they can keep their doors open until the upgrades are complete.

Hansard-Body.A: (Glass House--LNP) (9.46 pm): In November last year, TransLink released a new draft timetable for the north coast rail service. Within minutes, my office was inundated with phone calls from disbelieving and devastated commuters. Everyone, me included, will acknowledge there are a few positives in the proposed timetable. The new early morning services out of Nambour at 5.10 and 5.38, which replace the current 5.26 am service, are welcomed by those who need to arrive in the CBD early, by 7.02 and 7.36 am respectively. The extension of the weekday Cooroy service to Gympie North also means that there are now two daily return services to Gympie North Monday to Friday. But the flow-on repercussions for the vast majority of the peak hour coast commuters have them begging that these new services be removed and the previous timetable restored, such is the disastrous nature of the proposed timetable. Let me detail their concerns.

XML.Hansard-Body: By moving the morning inbound service that currently arrives in Central at 8.16 to an 8.26 arrival, it means an 8.30 am starter cannot get to work in time. By moving the morning inbound service that currently arrives in Central at 7.42 to an 8.02 arrival, it means an eight o’clock starter cannot get to work in time. By moving the 5.16 pm outbound Nambour service back to 5.04 pm, it means no 5 pm office worker can catch it. By moving the current outbound 5.43 service to 5.47, it means that there is now a three-quarters of an hour gap between this and the previous service.

Reducing the express pattern from 20 stations bypassed down to 13 on most services means longer commutes for those who travel furthest and by far the longest, with two peak services in each direction now only bypassing nine stations. Failing to schedule a Nambour service from Central each weeknight between 7.34 pm and 9.34 pm means there is a two-hour gap each and every night. And there is an ongoing failure to guarantee trains with toilets on all services north of Caboolture. Mr Speaker, a 10-minute movement in arrival or departure time may not seem much to you or to the minister, but to those commuters who have set starting and finishing hours of employment it can mean an additional hour on their day.

These individuals are already doing 12- or 13-hour days; under this draft timetable, it is 13 or 14. That is a crushing blow for the commuter and their family. As someone who, up until my election as the member for Glass House, did this four-hour commute from Palmwoods to the CBD nearly every day of every week, I know that hour can mean the difference between seeing your kids each day and not seeing them at all. Today an e-petition signed by 253 north coast commuters was tabled in this House calling on the Minister for Transport to preserve the existing timetable. Please, Minister, hear the devastated cries of those commuters. Revise the timetable so it does not disadvantage these people, your longest commuters.

Hansard-Body.A: (Capalaba--ALP) (9.49 pm): Towards the end of last year I spoke in this House about a new project to tackle youth violence. Youth violence is a serious issue for the Queensland community and, as a government, we recognise the need to educate our young people about the dangers and consequences of engaging in this type of antisocial behaviour. We have invested over $1 million, which included embarking on a major communication strategy in the One Punch Can Kill campaign. However, governments cannot act alone and there is no doubt the strongest community advocate group on this issue is the Matthew Stanley Foundation. The foundation was formed in 2006 by Paul Stanley after the tragic death of his son Matthew, a young man from Redland City who died after being punched at a teenage party.

XML.Hansard-Body: Paul works really hard in the community to reduce youth violence and I joined him recently to see the foundation in action at the Alexandra Hills Tavern. I am sure some of my colleagues will shake their heads in disbelief at the thought of me in a nightclub at midnight surrounded by hundreds of teens, but duty called and I did my best not to look too out of place! After all, we had important work to do spreading the message of Paul’s most recent campaign. The campaign aims to get the message to our teens that it is cool to ‘walk away and chill out’. What we want to see is the sequence that leads to youth violence being interrupted. We want to find that point where a dangerous situation gets out of hand and stop it. Paul and I spent the evening checking out the ID system implemented by the hotel as well as security measures adopted to ensure that as much as possible the patrons and the staff are protected.

The range of security measures that have been introduced by the tavern includes patron identification using their driver’s licence or 18 plus cards at the door and top of the range security camera equipment. I am pleased to note that quite a few potential patrons were turned away because of past incidents. The tavern also employs police officers onsite and is committed to improving patron behaviour. Hotel owner Tom McGuire welcomed the campaign and is committed to open up his tavern to more ‘walk away and chill out’ campaigns in the future. With thousands of locals turning 18 each year in my electorate and visiting clubs, it is important that young people are educated about safety, and that is an ongoing task.

While this government will continue to work to develop strategies to combat the issue of youth violence now and well into the future, a community campaign is one that I believe drives change, and the Matthew Stanley Foundation is working hard to tackle youth violence. I want to especially mention the Courier-Mail for its donation to the campaign by not sending out Christmas cards last year but giving $15,000 instead to the Matthew Stanley Foundation.

Hansard-Body.A: (Mudgeeraba--LNP) (9.52 pm): Tonight I rise to acknowledge the often unsung heroes of the Queensland Ambulance Service. Last Saturday I had the privilege of spending six hours with paramedics on the Gold Coast witnessing firsthand the amazing work that they undertake. As a registered nurse and a former emergency department nurse, I have been on the receiving end of many patients delivered to the ED by these dedicated ambulance officers and paramedics. As a member of the Gold Coast Local Area Committee for the past five years, it was an opportunity that was not to be missed and gave me an even greater respect for the efforts of our front-line workers. I want to thank Col Nash, acting area director for the Gold Coast, who organised the process for allowing me to spend time with our ambos.

XML.Hansard-Body: I had the pleasure of spending the day with Chris Draper, the regional operations supervisor, who went out of his way to ensure that my experience with the QAS was a memorable one. My thanks also goes to clinical deployment supervisor Peter Caffery, who explained how units are deployed and how he juggles the organisation of which crews, which ambulances and what other types of intervention is required such as the use of the CareFlight helicopter. Young Nick King spent time talking to me about his university paramedic training he had undergone. He spoke of the need for more clinical placements and hands-on patient time in the training of young paramedics. He noted the incredible depth of knowledge and contribution of the older officers whose wisdom and experience added to his experience.

I also visited the Gold Coast Hospital and met with Daniel Schulz, the hospital liaison officer working the ramp at the hospital. Thank you also to the CareFlight crew, the Burleigh paramedics and the Southport intensive care paramedics who attended the incident in Reedy Creek where a motorcyclist dirt biking in the bush came over the top of his handlebars and sustained a suspected fractured pelvis and was subsequently winched to safety by the paramedics and doctor from CareFlight. Thanks also to the Helensvale paramedics who attended an incident at Main Beach where a young father was treated for a suspected spinal injury. The paramedics talked about the improvements that had occurred in their field over the years, including the introduction of 24-hour counsellors to care for the mental health of our emergency services workers. The advent of HLOs at Robina, Gold Coast and Logan hospitals has made a difference in the time taken getting patients on and off QAS stretchers so that officers can get back out on the road quickly.

One issue that needs attention, however, is the concern for the lack of respect our ambos receive from the general public and the number of assaults on officers in the course of their duties. I mentioned that the Liberal National Party had put forward a private member’s bill demanding mandatory minimum sentencing for assaults on our emergency services workers and that we would continue the fight on their behalf. The comment was also made that legislation introduced to stop vexatious calls to the 000 service had had very little effect on the call-out for non-urgent codes.

All in all it was a tremendous experience and only served to ensure that the respect I already have for our ambulance officers and paramedics was heightened, and I wish them all the very best in the course of their duties.

Hansard-Body.A: (Redcliffe--ALP) (9.55 pm): It was the realisation of a dream for Des Webb and the board from the Redcliffe Leagues Club, CEO Tony Murphy and managers Trent Dickson and Kerry Sharpe as the Minister for Sport, Phil Reeves, officially opened the Dolphins Health Precinct. The official opening was followed by an open day with sausage sizzles, free massages and tours around the new facilities. This precinct was the culmination of five years of construction and a total of $3 million in major facilities funding from the Queensland government. Initially the heated and hydrotherapy pools were built as stage 1 and the state government contributed $1.5 million to their development. Construction began last year on the gymnasium with its allied health hub above and the creche and coffee shop to complete the health precinct with the help of a $1.5 million state government grant.

XML.Hansard-Body: This precinct will give Redcliffe people the opportunity to get active in convivial surroundings and to work on focused programs with fitness and health professionals if they have specific needs. Young children, babies, seniors, people with disabilities, those with injuries needing medical treatment or hydrotherapy and people with chronic diseases all have fun options to be active in groups, learn new skills and change their lives. The Dolphins Health Precinct has become a hub for people to meet and form social connections as they do their exercise programs and meet for coffee and healthy eats. Social contact is an important part of leading a balanced life and staying active and healthy into maturity.

This facility epitomises the vision of the Bligh government’s Toward Q2 initiative to make Queenslanders the healthiest people in the nation. Queenslanders are amongst the longest lived in the world. This health precinct will ensure that the people of Redcliffe can have quality lives, enhancing our current bayside lifestyles. The Bligh government sees a quality lifestyle as a priority for all Queenslanders, so funding facilities that give people the opportunities to get active and improve their long-term health outcomes is important. Facilities like the Dolphins Health Precinct will empower Queenslanders to take control of their own health outcomes and to improve their own lives, and that is what this proactive state government is all about--ensuring communities right across the state have the recreation facilities to achieve healthy lifestyles that will ensure continued, long and connected lives.

Dr DOUGLAS (Gaven--LNP) (9.58 pm): In their haste to sell and redevelop the Gold Coast showground facility at Parklands and the existing facility, has anyone in the present Bligh Labor government considered that we might just need these facilities as a major evacuation centre in the event of a big cyclone on the Gold Coast? Do the words ‘well above sea level’, ‘all-weather transport access’, ‘immediately co-located adjoining the new Gold Coast University Hospital’, ‘ample space for helicopter transfers’, ‘highest point closest to high-density areas’ mean anything at all? Yet here we have the infrastructure minister, who is in the chamber this evening, telling 1,500 petitioners one thing and the local Gold Coast Bulletin another about the future of Parklands. The response to the petitioners states--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: The annual Gold Coast show is the most significant of these activities and a suitable alternative venue for this event is currently being planned at Carrara.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: That was on 20 December. On 28 December in an article in the Gold Coast Bulletin the following is stated--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Mr Hinchliffe also denied the Government was in negotiation to relocate the showgrounds to a Carrara flood-plain. A source close to Parklands told the Bulletin the Government was ‘eyeing off’ a 42ha block once earmarked for an over 50s resort.
XML.Hansard-Body: Both of these statements cannot be true. At a proposed meeting on 28 February of this month the minister might tell the Gold Coast Show Society which statement is true. I am one of many who remain confused by the conflicting statements made by Minister Hinchliffe.

Interestingly, Parklands is a very valuable block of land that seems to attract more than a healthy dose of government interest. Why? Because the site could unlock $400 million to $500 million of cash for no real outlay and $200 million of existing infrastructure will be trashed as a result. Why? We need the site for the proposed 2018 Commonwealth Games and no other site is apparently suitable--as we have been told. Not even the current site of the existing Gold Coast Hospital at Southport is deemed to be suitable.

Do natural disasters ever teach us anything? Certainly, if the choice is either the money or the security of a safe, very large, perfectly designed evacuation centre, Labor under Bligh will go for the money--or so it seems. It is often said that he who hesitates is lost. There is no other real reason, apart from an indecent rush for the filthy lucre here. Build the games village at the master planned 42-hectare site, at the existing Gold Coast Griffith University site or on the existing Gold Coast Hospital site, which is to be vacated in 2013, and leave Parklands as it is. Heaven knows we will need it.
XML.Hansard-Level-2-Heading: Waterford Electorate, Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders

Hansard-Body.A: (Waterford--ALP) (10.01 pm): I rise to bring to the attention of the House an issue that is important to the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people whom I represent in the Waterford electorate. I represent an electorate that is home to a diverse range of families as well as to many people who are struggling in life. Many of these families rely on Queensland government services each and every day, whether it be to provide them with secure social housing, health services at the Logan Hospital or, unfortunately in the case of some children, care arrangements put in place by Child Safety.

XML.Hansard-Body: Like my electorate generally, Indigenous people who live in Logan include some families who have great success stories and some families who are struggling and need a hand from governments. Unfortunately, our Indigenous friends and neighbours are overrepresented in this latter category. On top of the challenges that are faced by other families, our Indigenous families often face cultural barriers, barriers of communication and discrimination.

But these barriers to providing high-quality services to the people who need them the most are often compounded by the reluctance of many Indigenous people to complain about government services. Although I often assist members of my local Indigenous community who contact me, too often I meet locals who raise matters after the proverbial horse has bolted or who simply do not think they can have someone investigate and resolve their concerns at all.

That is why I have lobbied Premier Anna Bligh and Attorney-General Cameron Dick to consider the establishment of a unit within the Ombudsman’s office specifically to assist Indigenous people, to ensure they are provided with the services that can start to bridge the gap in life expectancy, health and wellbeing and socioeconomic status that exists between Indigenous and non-Indigenous Queenslanders. A similar unit exists within the New South Wales Ombudsman service and has delivered some good outcomes.

This proposal is definitely something worth exploring here in Queensland. Assistance that could be provided includes help to prepare complaints, taking oral complaints, advice about appeal mechanisms and information about the criteria used for decision making. I know that often this is what members of parliament do every day. I know I do. It is part of the responsibility of being elected to represent people in an area who need every bit of assistance they can get. I am always available to make representations on behalf of constituents. However, sometimes politicians are not the best people to solve problems. I often end up writing letters for constituents or helping people navigate their way through complaints processes. This process is often more empowering and of more assistance than me trying to fix problems for others.

But there is always a limit to what can be expected of members of parliament. There needs to be support for awareness of appeal rights, practical assistance in having concerns investigated and an oversight to ensure that government agencies are treating people fairly. More than any other, our Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander community needs this support.

I am glad to inform the House that the Attorney-General has asked for this proposal to be a matter considered in the strategic review of the Ombudsman that is required to be undertaken this year. I hope that this proposal can be given careful consideration. A properly resourced program of this nature can go a long way to ensuring that the government can respond to the needs of Indigenous Queenslanders and can begin to close the gap.
Question put--That the House do now adjourn.
Motion agreed to.
The House adjourned at 10.04 pm.
